HEADLINE: TURF; 
Quandary: To Hold, Haggle Or Sell?

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS who watched the gyrations of the stock market over the last few weeks and hoped apartment prices would plummet have been disappointed. The Manhattan real estate market has stubbornly defied expectations.
 Kate Tentler, who runs the Web site at Simon & Schuster, went loft hunting in the East Village last Sunday, partly out of curiosity and partly to help friends look for a place to live. 
 "I was surprised," she said. "I looked at a 1,500-square-foot loft that was $800,000." What had she thought the price would be? "I figured, with the economy, it would be half that." She paused. "I mean, it was just a regular East Village loft. Regular. I thought that for $800,000 you'd get dancing cherubs -- you know, something really special." 
Buoyed by low interest rates and a cadre of stock-burned investors hoping to diversify their portfolios, Manhattan's real estate market is chugging into August. Real estate analysts report no sign of a dip.
Brokers say some of their buyers are expressing anxiety about whether the co-ops and condominiums will hold their value; Robert Bland of Brown Harris, for one, described many of his prospective buyers as "on edge." Nonetheless, statistics show that New Yorkers are still reaching for their wallets; there were more contracts signed last month than in July, 2001. Since May, the average price has remained stable, according to Jonathan Miller, who gathers and analyzes statistics for Douglas Elliman, the city's largest real estate agency. 
Despite the stock market's 390-point slide on July 19, Mr. Miller said, the real estate market has continued apace. This does not surprise the experts, who say real estate rarely runs parallel to the stock market. It took two years after the 1987 stock market crash for Manhattan property values to fall, and the market then was overloaded with poorly built cookie-cutter co-ops and condominiums. 
The current Manhattan real estate market's surge has come from the sale of low- and midpriced apartments. Young people, aided by low interest rates, are flocking to buy: prices of studio apartments rose 22 percent from a year ago, and prices of one-bedroom apartments are up 19 percent, Mr. Miller said.
Pamela Liebman, chief executive of the Corcoran Group, said the numbers represented "these kids who normally would have rented." In many cases, she said, parents are buying small apartments for their children because "even if the real estate market softens, they see it as a safe investment." 
Increasingly, apartment shoppers say they are seeking a refuge for at least some of what is left in their portfolios. "The word we hear most often is diversification," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate in Manhattan. Some are liquidating stocks to upgrade their real estate, even if they have to take a mortgage.
Brokers say they are seeing hordes of bedraggled investors, many having watched their more fortunate friends pull out of technology stocks in time to buy their dream duplex on Park Avenue. They hung on over the last year as Nasdaq, where the high-tech stocks traded, nose-dived. They now find themselves trying to sink what's left of their portfolios into real estate.
"But they're finding they can no longer get what their friends did," said Diane Ramirez, president of the Halstead Property Company. "Their friends got into the fancy buildings that require all cash. They don't have that much cash, so they're having to look for apartments in buildings that allow mortgages."
Their solace may be low interest rates: the average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage is 6.375 percent.
Yet some financial planners say that New York real estate may be a precarious investment solution to dwindling stock portfolios. "We're close to a speculative bubble in New York real estate," said Lewis Altfest, president of L. J. Altfest & Company. 
Mr. Altfest warned his clients who are buying strictly for investment, not because they want to make a home, that the real estate market is vulnerable to a reversal.
"Not that stocks are dramatically cheap," he said, "but they may be a better deal than real estate right now." Co-op prices are so high, he added, "that people are getting motion sickness looking down." 
But to Maureen Barry, a 58-year-old investor who is looking for a Greenwich Village building to buy, it doesn't matter that the price of Manhattan real estate may drop a bit. "That's always a possibility," she said. "But it comes back."
She and her husband, James, 60, live in Florida during the winter and in Vermont in the summer. "I'm looking with a dual purpose," she said. "I've got a daughter in New York, and I want to find suitable housing for her and diversify as well." The couple have not cashed out of the stock market yet, but Ms. Barry, a retired management consultant, said they probably would liquidate some of their holdings as soon as they find a property in the city. 
"Our need is driving the timing," she said, "but we both grew up in the New York area, and I've always felt that real estate was a good investment. It's tangible, solid."
Thomas Marrazza has just found a similar property, a building he will live in while leasing the rest. Mr. Marrazza, who runs a business renting out darkrooms, was looking for an apartment; he found a five-story building in TriBeCa and will keep the top floor for himself. "If you find a bargain out there," he said, "you got to go for it. Even if the price would have gone a little lower in the next year, the interest rates are so low now it all evens up."
That is not to say this year's midsummer market is roaring upward like the spring market. "The market is a good summer market, but it's not as frenetic as in the spring," Ms. Ramirez, the president of Halstead, said. 
The open-house crowds of April have thinned out. Instead of Sundays over the classifieds and cappuccino, renters and buyers now prefer to look at apartments on Monday and Tuesday nights, once they are back in town. Attendance has dropped, too, from highs of 80 down to 20, agents say. Brokers contend that that is the normal summer attendance, and may even be somewhat higher than in past years. 
"There is definitely a summer slowdown," Mr. Peters of Ashforth Warburg said, "but it's difficult to tell how much has to do with the swooning summer weather." Still, he said, prices remain stable.
At the Corcoran Group, Ms. Liebman, the chief executive, agreed that sales volume was down from the spring. Nevertheless, she said, the total value of apartments her company sold during July was 29.6 percent higher than in July, 2001.
Brokers complain that the supply of good apartments is still tight, and they say there are still more buyers than there are apartments to sell them. Although inventory is higher than at the end of May, it is still a lot lower than last December, when buyers were still suffering from post-Sept. 11 fear to commit.
Mr. Bland, the agent for Brown Harris, said people of all income levels are stretching to buy something they believe is a better real estate investment.
"I see guys who may have started looking for a $500,000 one-bedroom suddenly saying, 'I think I'll push it up to $750,000 and get a two-bedroom,' " he said. 
Prices remain high, Mr. Bland added, because there are plenty of customers filling in from the bottom. 
Without these low-end buyers, Manhattan's real estate market might be in worse shape, the analysts agree.
Mr. Miller, the statistician and real estate appraiser, said the growing importance of the lower-rung buyer could be seen in the figures for July.
Last month, studio buyers made up 21 percent of the market, up from 15 percent last spring. One-bedroom buyers rose from 33 percent of the market to 37 percent. The biggest shift in the other direction came from two-bedroom buyers, whose numbers shrank from 45 percent in the spring to 27 percent in July. 
"Those two-bedroom buyers were the guys on Wall Street who just lost their jobs," Mr. Miller said.

A Timetable for Buying or Cashing Out
ALTHOUGH sales of Manhattan condominiums and co-ops remain strong -- and prices are high -- many prospective buyers and sellers are seeking advice in what they fear is an uncertain real estate marketplace.
Should they buy now or wait for a market downturn? Should they bid low, or offer full price to avoid a bidding war? Should they sell now, cashing out while they can?
Here's the bad news: there's no clear answer. It depends on one's circumstances. But statistics do not indicate any need to dump a co-op out of fear the real estate market is about to crash, just as there's no reason to think you will get a steal anytime soon. Nevertheless, if you're thinking of selling anyway, analysts say it might be smart to take advantage of your co-op or condo's appreciation. (Married people get $500,000 profit tax-free; singles get $250,000.) Call a broker to see how much your property is worth. If you're serious about selling, appraisals are free.
Pamela Liebman, chief executive at the Corcoran Group, a large Manhattan broker, said that some sellers have become more ready to negotiate over the last month, but that may be because they priced their apartments too high after this spring's booming market. 
Some experts counsel prudence, buying only blue chip real estate: apartments in well-run buildings in established locations, with sunny views and, if possible, one of those extras that always attracts buyers, even in a down market. Look for a wood-burning fireplace, a terrace, a high floor, white-glove doormen and original features like wood paneling and French doors. And don't buy a wreck, especially an expensive one.
"Condition and location are incredibly important in the current marketplace, and premier amenities never hurt," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate.
Yet Mr. Peters worries that today's shoppers are too focused on investment value. "You have to want to live there," he said. "You can't forget you're buying a home." TRACIE ROZHON
Next week, how stock market volatility is affecting sales of second homes.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
A Shift Registers in Willingness to Pay for Internet Content

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL

 BODY:
More Internet users are showing a willingness to pay for content online -- subscribing to news sites, for example, or paying fees to send e-greeting cards -- suggesting a shift in consumers' expectations that online services should be free, according to a survey of cyberspending patterns released yesterday.
 But the survey, put out by the Online Publishers Association, an industry trade group, also shows that a relative handful of businesses benefit from these purchases and that advertising remains the overwhelming source of income for supporting digital content. 
 Extrapolating the online transactions of 1.1 million consumers, the survey found that consumers spent $675 million for digital goods and services in 2001, nearly double the $350 million they spent the year earlier. The survey found that 12.4 million Americans paid for some type of content in the first quarter of this year, compared with 7 million in the first quarter of 2001. The survey did not include payments made to pornography sites. 
A big chunk of the spending accrued to business and financial news sites, which in 2001 racked up $214.3 million in revenue from selling content, mainly through monthly and annual subscriptions.
"It's where people need information the fastest that influences their livelihood," said Michael A. Zimbalist, executive director of the Online Publishers Association, which is based in New York. The association includes about 20 major online publishers, including New York Times Digital, The Wall Street Journal Online, Washingtonpost.Newsweek Interactive, MSNBC.com, ESPN.com and CBS Marketwatch.
The strength of business and financial news sites comes as little surprise given that financial sites started selling content relatively early in the history of the Web; the category has been anchored by the success of The Wall Street Journal Online, which, with roughly 650,000 subscribers, accrued the second-most revenue, after Real Networks, a distributor of audio and video material.
Several other prominent media companies have recently introduced for-pay packages on their Web sites. ABC.com said yesterday that it would begin charging $4.95 a month for "ABC News On Demand," which includes news clips and day-after replays of "World News Tonight" and "Nightline," as well as 30 days of the programs' archives. CNN.com began charging for access to video on its site earlier this year.
Mr. Zimbalist said the industry had also been heartened by a very recent surge of content sales in several emerging categories, notably personals and dating sites, one of the fastest-growing categories, with $72 million in sales in 2001. In just the first quarter of 2002, it had sales of $53.1 million.
In addition, there has been a sudden growth of revenue among sports sites, which are selling subscriptions to fantasy sports leagues and access to sports news and statistics, and among online greeting card companies, some of which now charge people to send virtual cards. American Greetings.com has accrued 1.5 million subscribers, who pay $11.95 a year, since it started selling subscriptions in December, according to the company's chief executive, Josef Mandelbaum.
Mr. Zimbalist said the growth in these categories suggested that businesses are beginning to figure out how to package their services in ways that appeal to consumers, and that consumers are overcoming the idea that content on the Internet should be free.
Mr. Mandelbaum, whose company also owns Blue Mountain Arts, eGreetings and Beatgreets, said: "In the past five years, we trained consumers that content was free -- that was our fault." He added that there had been a "general reluctance, but slowly but surely, people are paying for content."
The story behind the growth in sales of e-greeting cards, however, underscores that in some regards the spending patterns are quite narrow. Mr. Mandelbuam said AmericanGreetings and its subsidiaries controlled some 75 percent of the free e-greeting market; it and Hallmark.com, a competitor, now command much of the subscriber-based market, meaning that the growth in the category is accruing to just a few businesses.
Similarly, just as The Wall Street Journal dominates subscription revenue in the online financial category, Real Networks draws more than half of the revenue in the entertainment-lifestyle category. Real Networks, which has 750,000 subscribers to its premium services, had the most revenue from content sales in 2001. 
Generally, the survey found that of the 1,700 sites charging for content, the 100 with the most revenue drew 97 percent of all revenue and the top 50 sites drew 85 percent of the revenue.
Neil Budde, publisher of The Wall Street Journal Online, said that one common theme he has seen among sites that are successfully charging for content is that they have created an audience eager to return for information or services on a frequent basis. "If most of your traffic is once a month, or once every couple of months," he said, "you've got less of a chance than if you've got regular repeat visitors."
According to the survey, revenue from sales of online content in 2001 constituted about one-eleventh of the $7.2 billion in advertising-based online revenue. But Mr. Zimbalist, noting that content sales hit $300 million in the first quarter of this year -- nearly half the total for all of last year -- said he believed that fees paid for content could become an increasingly large piece of the pie, perhaps as much as one-fifth of the revenue. "It is becoming a leg on the stool that supports online publishing," he said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 2, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the increased willingness of consumers to pay for online content misidentified the Web site that has begun charging for ABC video news clips and news programs. It is ABCNews.com, not ABC.com.

HEADLINE: After Bitter Dispute, Newspaper Changes Hands 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
The Salt Lake Tribune is noting the final phase of its bitterly disputed ownership transition with an editorial in today's editions that promises that "the newspaper will serve all of Utah and be beholden to no one." 
 A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected an effort by the newspaper's former owners to retain control of the publication. 
 The final transition, by which MediaNews group is taking control of The Tribune 19 months after it paid $200 million for the paper's parent company, comes after two years of contentious legal struggles. 
The bitterness of the fight was aggravated by the suspicions of Salt Lake City's non-Mormon community -- including the newspaper's former owners -- that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints would use the new owners to exert control over the proudly non-Mormon newspaper, which was founded more than 130 years ago by Mormon dissidents.
Salt Lake's population is split almost equally between Mormons and non-Mormons, but the church is the dominant cultural, political and economic force in the city. The other daily newspaper in town, The Deseret News, is owned by the church.
The newspapers participate in a joint operating agreement, sharing business functions like advertising and distribution. This relationship has been bitter, with the professional managers of the two sides feuding over business issues. The feud was spiced with the fears of Tribune managers and supporters that the church wanted to control -- and perhaps silence -- the loudest non-Mormon voice in town.
The fact that the church encouraged the MediaNews takeover while fighting the former owner's effort to rebuy the newspaper confirmed the suspicions of many local non-Mormons that the paper they regarded as their own was effectively subject to a hostile takeover.
The former owners sold the newspaper's parent company, Kearns-Tribune, to the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc. in 1997, in a $731 million deal intended to reap the gains from a massive appreciation of TCI stock that was owned by Kearns-Tribune. As part of the deal, the heirs of Senator Thomas Kearns, who bought the newspaper in 1901, secured an option to buy it back.
TCI was bought by AT&T, whose executives were sick of the local feud and nervous about irritating the church just when they were trying to sell cable subscriptions in Utah. In 1999, AT&T explored selling The Tribune to The News. When that sale proved unfeasible, AT&T executives eventually settled on a price with MediaNews, whose flagship newspaper is The Denver Post.
The circumstances of the sale fed local suspicions that Dean Singleton, the head of MediaNews, was a stalking horse for church interests. During three days of meetings with The Tribune's 144 journalists and with civic leaders this week, Mr. Singleton said he met with wary questions about how close his ties were to the church. (He is a Baptist, and has served on an advisory board for Brigham Young University.)
Philip McCarthey, the Kearns heir who apparently is the loser in the fight for control, still insists he has a right to buy back the newspaper. Mr. McCarthey said yesterday that he felt "angry and betrayed" by everyone from the AT&T executive who pushed for the sale to The Tribune's editor, James E. Shelledy, who has agreed to continue in the job.
The Tribune, published in the morning, has a daily circulation of about 143,000; the afternoon News has a daily circulation of 88,000.

HEADLINE: Senate Moves Against Tax-Haven Companies 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to bar companies that move to countries considered offshore tax havens from winning military contracts as Democrats stepped up their emphasis on an issue they think has growing political appeal.
 As part of a record $355.4 billion military spending bill, the Senate accepted an amendment by Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, that would prohibit any company that reincorporates after Dec. 31, 2001, in designated tax havens like Bermuda from receiving Pentagon contracts. 
 "If a U.S. company wants to bid for a contract for U.S. defense work, it should not renounce its corporate citizenship for a tax break," said Mr. Wellstone, who is in a tough re-election fight. 
The practice of American corporations obtaining a mailbox in nations like Bermuda and the Bahamas to avoid taxes has come under increasing scrutiny. The House voted overwhelmingly last week to prohibit such companies from doing work with the proposed Department of Homeland Security.
Two leading Republicans took issue with the Wellstone proposal, saying it could cost Americans jobs because the companies under fire have most of their operations in the United States. Such a ban could backfire by shifting military contracts to foreign companies that do most of their work overseas or inviting trade retaliation, they said. These opponents said such a change in law should be made as part of overall tax revisions under consideration in the House and Senate.
"This is easy to demagogue, but it is a complicated issue in tax policy," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said he had no sympathy for companies that move to offshore tax havens but accused Democrats of playing into public anger over corporate irresponsibility.
"We are in an environment where slapping business around is good politics," he said.
But in a sign of the sensitivity of the issue, lawmakers allowed the amendment to be adopted on a voice vote rather than force senators to go on the record with their positions.
Mr. Wellstone said he had no idea how many companies might be affected by his provision and said he was acting to discourage further moves offshore. But he said about $2 billion in current military-related work was being done by companies now based in offshore tax havens.
Lawmakers cited a few of the several dozen companies that have reincorporated offshore in recent years from a list being circulated by Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee. The list included Foster Wheeler, with $248 million in military and homeland security-related contracts; Tyco International, with $182 million; Accenture, with $144 million; PricewaterhouseCoopers, with $129 million; and Ingersoll-Rand, $39 million.
Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the assistant Democratic leader and a strong proponent of the amendment, said companies could easily escape the ban. "All they have to do is come back where they came from and reincorporate in America," he said. "That is the patriotic thing to do."
Besides Bermuda and the Bahamas, nations that would be covered include Barbados, the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Cyprus, Gibraltar, the Isle of Man, Liechtenstein, Monaco, the Seychelles and other nations designated by the Treasury secretary. The president could waive the restriction in the interest of national security.
The House has already adopted its military spending measure and it contains no such provision on the offshore companies. As a result, the two measures must be reconciled in a conference committee.
The bill the Senate hopes to approve on Thursday represents a $34 billion increase over the current year and finances most of the administration's military priorities, including a 4.1 percent military pay raise.

HEADLINE: After Easy Victories, Brooklyn State Senator Faces a Tough Primary Battle 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
In the 10 years since she was first elected to the State Senate, Nellie Santiago has never faced an election without a Democratic primary challenge. Still, Ms. Santiago, who represents Bushwick and Cypress Hills in Brooklyn, has typically won easily with wide margins over little-known opponents.
 Coasting to victory this year is shaping up to be a far more difficult matter for Ms. Santiago. She is opposed in the Sept. 10 primary by Martin Malave-Dilan, a former city councilman who represented much of the area for 10 years before being forced out of office by the city's term-limit laws. 
 The race, in the 17th State Senate District, has already become notable for its rancorous tone and its extensive backdrop of local politics. The contest is notable for the assortment of political figures who are entangled in it, from district Assembly members to the local congressman.
Ms. Santiago, 60, was elected in 1992 and became the first Puerto Rican woman from Brooklyn in the Senate. She holds a doctorate in education from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
In a recent interview, she said she has focused on economic development in her district and on making capital more widely available to the business owners among her constituents, who are overwhelmingly working-class Hispanic and black. In particular, she said she took pride in having played a major role in negotiations leading to passage this summer of a bill curbing a practice known as predatory lending. The bill is meant to regulate high-interest home loans that are often unaffordable for the borrower, worth more than the house itself and loaded with fees.
"The banks have left out neighborhoods," Ms. Santiago said. "And I have made banking issues a particularly strong part of my responsibility to my constituents. I want our people here to have the same opportunities and access to money and fair-lending practices that everyone else gets."
Mr. Dilan and his supporters contend that Ms. Santiago, who has served five terms, has been inattentive and barely visible within the district, which also includes parts of Williamsburg and Greenpoint. Mr. Dilan has made that issue the focus of his campaign.
"When it comes to this senatorial district, she is never around," said Mr. Dilan, 51. "You never see her at community meetings, at neighborhood events or anything else. Nothing. And when it comes to services to her constituents, there is no semblance of effectiveness."
Ms. Santiago acknowledges that Mr. Dilan is unlike any other opponent she has faced. For one, he has raised $44,000, compared with the $40,000 that Ms. Santiago's campaign reported in a filing last month.
His campaign is also being waged with a great deal of political assistance. Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, a Democrat who runs a vibrant political club in the area, is an important ally. Mr. Lopez's group, the Bushwick United Democratic Club, has an active membership of nearly 400 people. (Mr. Lopez had more than 200 club members collecting 6,600 petition signatures for Mr. Dilan.)
"She is absolutely, totally not visible," said Mr. Lopez, whose Assembly district is within the Senate district. "I go to community meetings and she is never there. No one in this district would dispute that, unless they need psychological help."
Mr. Dilan is campaigning vigorously. One morning this week, for example, he was at a subway stop in Cypress Hills with a team of half a dozen campaign workers, including his son, City Councilman Erik Dilan, greeting residents and passing out literature. "We do this every day and every evening," he said.
By contrast, when asked if a reporter could accompany Ms. Santiago on a campaign appearance this week, an aide to the senator said that she was so immersed in reviewing challenges to her petition forms that she would not be making any campaign appearances for "the next two to three weeks."
Besides Mr. Lopez, there are other forces working against Ms. Santiago. For one thing, United States Representative Edolphus Towns is supporting a candidate challenging Ms. Santiago's position as the female Democratic district leader. (Mr. Dilan is supporting yet another candidate for district leader against Ms. Santiago).
Mr. Towns, meanwhile, is trying to position himself as a continuing presence in grass-roots community politics. Besides working vigorously for the re-election of his son, Assemblyman Darryl C. Towns, the congressman is himself running for the male district leader position in that area.
Nonetheless, Ms. Santiago is not without resources. She has the support of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn and its chairman, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr.
"She has been doing a great job," Mr. Norman said. "We're going to be very supportive of her."
As in previous campaigns, her re-election effort is being managed by her husband, Benito Fernandez, who runs the Brooklyn Manor, a home for mentally ill residents in East New York. Mr. Fernandez said that the campaign would probably raise and spend "somewhere between $100,000 and $150,000." If the past is an indication, the money will be used in the final weeks before the primary for a barrage of literature to voters.
Ms. Santiago said there are two reasons she expects to prevail on Sept. 10. One, she said, "as the ranking member of the Senate Banking Committee, I have a leadership role with the Senate Democrats," which voters understand is a "value to the district."
The other, she said, is Mr. Dilan's unsuitability for a Senate position. "I don't think he knows what it is to draft and pass a bill," she said. "He was a legislator for some time and now he isn't. I think he's doing this just because he needs the work."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Golisano Focus: Job Creation

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
 This is a new 30-second commercial from the campaign of B. Thomas Golisano. It is titled "Three Thousand."

PRODUCER -- Erick Mullen and David Heller

ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with a black screen with these words in white: "It started with $3,000." It then shifts to a scene with Mr. Golisano, dressed casually in a blue shirt, speaking about starting the company he founded. Then there are scenes of Mr. Golisano that flash quickly: one with him walking and talking with a well-dressed man and woman, another with Mr. Golisano standing in a classroom, and yet another with him near a street, immersed in conversation and using a lot of hand gestures. During this, several phrases float across the screen. They include Mr. Golisano's name, then the words "Three Billion Dollar Business," then "7,000 Employees." And finally, "This ad is not paid for with any special interest money."

THE SCRIPT -- A male voice says: "It started with $3,000."

The candidate says: "I wanted to start a pay service for small companies. Nobody would loan me the money. So I took everything I had -- $3,000 -- and started Paychex."

The announcer returns: "Tom Golisano turned Paychex into a billion-dollar business. More than 7,000 employees. He knows how to create jobs."

Then, Mr. Golisano says: "I am running for governor because I believe we can do better. We deserve better."

Finally, the male voice says: "Tom Golisano. If he can turn $3,000 into 7,000 jobs, just think what he'd do for New York."

ACCURACY -- This advertisement makes little in the way of claims. Mr. Golisano did, in fact, start his Rochester-based company. And the company has 7,000 employees.

SCORECARD -- The advertisement effectively promotes the idea that Mr. Golisano has created jobs, a point that is particularly geared to regions of the state battered by economic woes. It says nothing about what Mr. Golisano would to do create new jobs in the state nor anything about his philosophy on any of the political or social issues of the day. It also does not include any mention of political party and is apparently geared toward voters who have felt stung by the downturn in the economy both in New York City and in the western part of the state. JONATHAN P. HICKS

HEADLINE: Accusation Of Conflicts Ata Supplier To Hospitals 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
She was an eager new employee. Her company was the leader in its field, with a stated mission she could take pride in: to lower health care costs by helping hospitals buy supplies more cheaply.
 But in a matter of months, Cynthia Fitzgerald was out of work -- fired, she says, after complaining about her company's business practices, including pressure to steer millions of dollars in business to a former official of the buying group's predecessor. 
 "I don't look good in orange or in stripes," Ms. Fitzgerald said she told her supervisor after objecting to the way another contract was handled. Before long, the company, Novation, arranged to have her "escorted off the property by guards." 
Ms. Fitzgerald's accusations, which are disputed by Novation, are among the most serious to be leveled at this private company, which negotiates medical supply contracts worth $20 billion annually for a third of the nation's hospitals. Novation and another big buying group for hospitals, Premier Inc., have been accused in recent Congressional hearings of self-dealing and conflicts of interest that may have compromised their ability to find the best products at the lowest prices.
Ms. Fitzgerald, 44, made her comments recently under oath in a sealed deposition obtained by The New York Times. It is part of a lawsuit that a small medical device maker, Retractable Technologies, filed in a Texas federal court, accusing Novation and Premier of effectively locking it out of the hospital market. 
The two groups, which negotiate contracts for about two-thirds of the nation's hospitals, deny the accusations and are contesting them in court. 
Novation officials declined to be interviewed for this story. But in a statement, the group said it could not comment on Ms. Fitzgerald's accusations because they had been made in a sealed deposition. 
"We can, however, state that any decision to end Ms. Fitzgerald's employment was based on her work performance only," the statement added.
Ms. Fitzgerald, who once found inspiration in reciting the speeches of Martin Luther King to churchgoers, worked at Novation for just half a year -- long enough, and at a level high enough, she says, to witness contracting processes that made her uncomfortable. "Some of the methods were not above board," she testified. 
"There were undue pressures that were placed on contracting officers" to award contracts not necessarily based on price or quality, said Ms. Fitzgerald, who was herself a contracting officer.
Ms. Fitzgerald specifically complained that Novation for years had given special treatment to Heritage Bag, a garbage bag company in Texas represented by the former official of the buying group's predecessor, John M. Doyle. Mr. Doyle is the founder and former president of VHA Supply, a buying group that in 1998 merged with a smaller group to form Novation.
"I had been informed I would be fired if I didn't award it properly," she said in her deposition. Ms. Fitzgerald said she tried to find out why a seemingly mundane garbage bag contract was "sacrosanct."
"The only explanation that I ever received was that the contract belonged to Heritage Bag, it was going to belong to Heritage Bag, and that the last person who tried to remove that contract from Heritage Bag was in jeopardy of losing their job," she testified.
Novation's hospitals have been spending about $11 million a year on Heritage Bag's products, the buying group said in its statement. 
After Ms. Fitzgerald asked why Heritage's bags -- called can liners -- seemed to be getting favored treatment, her managers suddenly began questioning her competence and fired her, she said. 
Mr. Doyle said favoritism played no role in Heritage getting contracts from Novation.
"We give them as high a quality liner as there is in the industry, and the most competitive pricing in the industry," Mr. Doyle said.
Heritage Bag declined to answer questions about Ms. Fitzgerald's accusations.
The Times, in examining Ms. Fitzgerald's charges, found that Mr. Doyle resigned from the buying group in 1986 amid complaints that he had sexually harassed two female employees and discriminated against a third. 
"If John Doyle were the last man on this planet to have a job, I would starve before I'd go to work for this man again," said Deborah Long, who sued Mr. Doyle and his employer in federal court. She said Mr. Doyle abruptly demoted her during a staff meeting after she refused to let him into her hotel room at a convention. Her lawsuit has since been settled.
Mr. Doyle declined to be interviewed about the three women's charges.
Soon after Mr. Doyle began representing Heritage Bag as a manufacturer's representative, the company got its first contract with his former employer. Heritage has held that contract uninterrupted ever since -- for more than 13 years. Mr. Doyle said he received a commission every time a Novation hospital bought Heritage's garbage bags, but he declined to reveal the amount.
So how good is Novation's contract? 
For one thing, Novation recommends Heritage bags to its hospitals as a good buy. Even so, individual hospitals, consultants and smaller buying groups surveyed by The Times reported that if hospitals shop around they can get better deals on many of those same Heritage bags or on comparable bags made by other companies.
One medium-sized hospital in the Midwest found, for example, that if it were to switch to Novation's products, it would add about $10,000 a year, or about 11 percent, to its garbage-bag budget. The hospital executive who analyzed the prices asked not to be named because of a confidentiality agreement.
"There is much better bag pricing outside the Novation-Heritage agreement" -- sometimes more than 20 percent better, said Bob Bissell, a principal of CoalesCo Ltd., which sets up purchasing cooperatives for small groups of hospitals.
Two smaller buying groups separately compared their prices with Novation's prices for identical bags and each reported that its products were about 3 to 5 percent cheaper, on average, when the numbers were weighted to reflect the most frequently purchased bags. Both of these groups requested anonymity for fear of angering Heritage.
Some critics of Novation believe that products like the garbage bags may cost more because of the fees manufacturers must pay in connection with contracts, which are then built into their prices.
In a written response to questions about its prices, Novation said, "It is possible that on any given day and with respect to any given product, a hospital -- especially a large hospital system -- may be able to obtain a better price than Novation." But, the buying group said, these individual cases did not negate the overall economic benefits its contracts bring to participating hospitals. 
Ms. Fitzgerald joined Novation in 1998 after working as, among other things, a pharmaceutical representative. She said she initially earned praise from management for the way she went about picking companies to supply Novation's 2,500 hospitals nationwide.
Novation made her a senior contracting official, a position with considerable power.
Many companies, particularly the smaller or newer ones, say a supply contract with Novation, the nation's largest buying group for hospitals, can make or break them financially.
To secure these contracts, companies promise to pay Novation a percentage of what hospitals spend on their products, usually 3 percent or less of sales, but sometimes much more. Heritage Bag, for example, paid Novation more than 8 percent in fees.
Ms. Fitzgerald said in an interview that she recalled that Novation pushed to raise more and more revenue from suppliers. To satisfy her managers, she said, she persuaded one contractor, Becton Dickinson, to make an extra upfront contribution of $100,000 in connection with the awarding of a "sole source" catheter contract.
"I hate to say it, but I'm the one who dreamed it up; they told me they wanted to get revenue," Ms. Fitzgerald said, noting that she thought Becton Dickinson deserved the contract, even without the extra payment.
She said she was so proud of having secured the payment that she arranged to have Novation take a picture as the check was being handed over.
She said the extra money was to be used to finance a communication system within Novation.
Federal regulators have cautioned that such upfront payments might be construed as illegal kickbacks if they were used to obtain business.
Both Becton Dickinson and Novation say the payment was proper and legal.
On another occasion, Ms. Fitzgerald complained about a major contractor that appeared to be soliciting confidential information about a competitor's bid. She said she did not want to cooperate. She testified: "I turned to my manager, who was sitting next to me, and said, 'Oh, no. I don't look good in orange or in stripes.' "
She said her complaints were unheeded. 
Ms. Fitzgerald said she first heard about Heritage Bag's apparently special status within Novation from colleagues and from her supervisor. Later, she said, she told her managers she wanted nothing to do with awarding that contract. "I was not going to do that particular contract and if it was going to be done, that management would have to do it," she testified.
Soon after, Ms. Fitzgerald said, the accolades she had once received from management became criticism. "Everything changed," she said. "Suddenly, I was incompetent."
During her deposition, Novation produced her personnel file. In it, according to questions asked by Novation's lawyer, Ms. Fitzgerald was criticized for such offenses as failing to complete reports on time, and failing to complete projects. Ms. Fitzgerald objected strenuously to these characterizations of her work history. 
"I remember those issues coming to light after I made my accusations," she testified. "I thought it was very unusual that none of those issues had ever been raised prior to then."
After her dismissal, Ms. Fitzgerald founded her own medical distributorship. She offered her deposition only after being subpoenaed and said in her testimony she feared Novation would retaliate against her for speaking out about her experience.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Plans for the Neglected East River Shoreline

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
EVEN if more innovative plans are drawn up for the World Trade Center site, only a fraction of Lower Manhattan will be directly affected. Redevelopment of ground zero alone will not shape downtown's future nor solve some of its chronic problems.
 Understanding that, the Alliance for Downtown New York and Community Board 1 have been quietly working on a different kind of plan -- a framework, really -- to guide future development along the perennially neglected East River shoreline, which today is more of a barrier than a waterfront. 
 While it is easy to wonder about the practicality of some suggestions, like turning part of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive into a promenade, the initiative is worth noting. If residents and businesses agree in advance on common goals, they are likely to be far more successful extracting amenities when developers and government agencies propose new projects, although nothing about the plan is guaranteed in advance. 
"It's a unified front," said Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of the community board. "That's a spectacular notion, that we could go to the city and state and say, 'This is what we all want.' "
Waiting on the other side of the parking lots and loading zones under the brooding F.D.R. Drive viaduct are incomparable panoramas of the Brooklyn Bridge, briny breezes on the hottest days and, surprisingly, the calming rhythm of waves hitting riprap.
"Weaving the city to the water" is a goal of the $400 million East River plan, said one of its designers, Marilyn Jordan Taylor of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. That means adding ferry stops to draw more waterborne commuters and creating visual corridors from the financial district to the river.
This is not to happen in a single stroke but as opportunities arise. Because there is an overall framework, every desired amenity does not have to be piled onto a single development. "Doing it incrementally is one way to address the issue of resource constraints," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Downtown Alliance, which runs the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District.
The message to builders, he said, would be: "This is good for the business community and good for the residential community. You're likely to have a relatively easy time of it as long as you're in accord with this blueprint."
The blueprint was actually laid down in the 18th century, when piers sprouted from the shoreline and any number of streets in Lower Manhattan ended at the water in the form of wide berths, or slips, whose names endure to this day as Peck Slip, Burling Slip, Old Slip and Coenties Slip.
"Rather than overwrite that, we wanted to work with the history," Ms. Taylor said. That led to the proposal that a new marina be created just north of Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport and that a new ferry landing be constructed next to the Whitehall terminal.
As for the slips and other east-west streets, the planners imagine them as landscaped urban "rooms," with trees and open space gained in some cases by narrowing the roadways, in other cases by eliminating parking spaces.
At a cost of about $35 million, the outer half of the F.D.R. Drive would be opened to pedestrians south of the Brooklyn Bridge. The inner half of the roadway would carry two-way traffic, separated from pedestrians by a landscaped median. This would not be a contemplative oasis, Ms. Taylor conceded, but would add open space along the water.
The most expensive recommendation, around $70 million, would be to relocate the Battery Park underpass ramp that now emerges between Whitehall and Broad Streets. Moving it one block north would create a plaza in front of the landmark Battery Maritime Building, which is to be redeveloped. No decision has been made on what will go there. 
The city transportation commissioner, Iris Weinshall, will not comment on the plans until she has reviewed them more closely, a spokesman said.
The Downtown Alliance financed the planning effort, which was managed by Ann Buttenwieser Consulting and involved Ken Greenberg of Greenberg Consultants, the engineering concern of Arup and the real estate consulting firm of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler.
"We're very excited about their initiative," said Andrew M. Alper, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, who called it a "nice complement" to the anticipated redevelopment of Governors Island and the creation of a new Brooklyn Bridge Park across the East River.
Even in embryonic form, the waterfront plan may help shape the enormous Guggenheim Museum proposed for the piers between Old Slip and Maiden Lane.
Though well publicized, Frank Gehry's rendition of a cloudlike, titanium-clad building is still in the conceptual stage, said Laurie Beckelman, deputy director of the Guggenheim. The final design might incorporate a second-story connection to the F.D.R. Drive promenade and a view corridor along the axis of Wall Street, which bisects the Guggenheim site.
"If this is something helpful to think about, we're open to it," Ms. Beckelman said. "The community has to be our partner, big time. We're sincere about this. This is a collaboration."

HEADLINE: SENATE KILLS PLAN FOR DRUG BENEFITS THROUGH MEDICARE 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
The Senate today killed legislation to provide prescription drug benefits promised to the elderly by politicians of both parties. But it overwhelmingly passed a bill intended to give all Americans greater access to low-cost generic versions of brand-name medicines.
 Given the ideological divisions revealed in the Senate debate, lawmakers said the elderly might have to wait several years for Medicare coverage of the drugs they take for heart disease, stroke, arthritis and other ailments. The measure on generic medicines faces an uncertain future in the House. 
 Senators of both parties said they would have to answer to voters this fall for their failure to deliver Medicare drug benefits. Each party blamed the other today. 
"We go home empty-handed," said Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee. "Our seniors are the ones who lose."
Senator Zell Miller, Democrat of Georgia, said, "Both parties will pay a steep price at the polls."
The outcome appeared to be a major setback for Democrats, who control the Senate. Democrats had initially hoped to campaign as champions of Medicare drug benefits this fall, but they may have lost some of their historic advantage on the issue. The House, controlled by Republicans, passed a bill to provide Medicare drug benefits through private insurance companies last month.
Democrats vowed to keep fighting. "We will be back next month, next year and the year after -- as long as it takes until every senior citizen has the comprehensive benefit they deserve," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
The Senate is scheduled to begin its August recess on Friday. In more than two weeks of impassioned debate -- an extraordinary commitment of time on the Senate floor -- lawmakers rejected four separate proposals to provide coverage of prescription drugs under Medicare.
There was no consensus about how much to spend, how generous the benefits should be, or how to balance the roles of government and private industry in running the program. 
By a vote of 49 yeas to 50 nays, the Senate today defeated a proposal to provide drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries with low incomes or high drug costs. The proposal fell far short of the 60-vote majority needed to keep it alive under Senate budget rules.
Democrats had billed the proposal as a bipartisan compromise, a down payment on what was really needed. But it won support from only four Republicans: Susan Collins of Maine, Tim Hutchinson of Arkansas, Gordon H. Smith of Oregon and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. Five Democrats joined 44 Republicans and one independent in voting against the proposal. The five were John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and Ben Nelson of Nebraska. 
Then, by a vote of 78 to 21, the Senate passed the generic drug bill, which would reduce the ability of brand-name drug companies to delay the approval and marketing of generic products.
Generic drugs are biologically and chemically equivalent to brand-name medicines, but usually cost much less, so sales of the brand-name drugs typically plummet after generic competitors enter the market.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the generic drug bill would reduce total spending on prescription drugs by $60 billion, or 1.3 percent, over the next 10 years. The bill had support from consumer groups, labor unions and many large corporations that pay for prescription drugs for their employees.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, the chief sponsor of the generic drug bill, said pharmaceutical companies had invented many wonder drugs, but he declared, "Their cost is so high that if you are not very wealthy or do not have a good medical plan, you cannot afford them."
Twenty-eight Republicans, 49 Democrats and one independent voted for the generic drug measure.
"The onus is now on the House to act in a similarly bipartisan way," Mr. Schumer said.
Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, who led lobbying against the generic drug bill, said it would not produce significant savings for consumers, but would discourage innovation by reducing the economic incentives for drug research.
House Republican leaders said they would consider taking up legislation on generic drugs after the August recess. There are no immediate plans for a conference committee to try to meld the House Medicare bill and the Senate generic drug bill.
Despite the stalemate on Medicare, Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said: "I don't think this is a time to be cynical. It's a time for people to get engaged, to let members of Congress know how deeply they feel about the importance of getting some assistance with their escalating prescription drug costs."
Senate Democrats originally wanted to offer drug coverage to all 40 million Medicare beneficiaries, at a cost of $594 million over 10 years. After that proposal died last week, Democrats scaled back their demands. Under the $390 billion proposal rejected today, Medicare would have provided drug coverage to beneficiaries with drug costs of more than $3,300 a year or incomes of less than $17,720 a year for an individual and $23,880 for a couple.
The measure passed by the Senate includes two significant amendments. One would make it easier for pharmacists and drug wholesalers to import prescription drugs from Canada, where drug prices are often lower because of government regulation. The other would allow states to use the purchasing power of their Medicaid programs to negotiate drug discounts for millions of people who are not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, said, "American consumers pay the highest prices in the world for prescription medicines" and could save millions of dollars by importing drugs from Canada.
The Bush administration opposed relaxation of import rules, saying it could expose consumers to unsafe, counterfeit or contaminated drugs. 
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois portrayed Senate Democratic leaders as obstructionists. "The Senate has again let down senior citizens in their time of need," Mr. Hastert said. "While the Republican-led House got the job done weeks ago, the Democrat-led Senate didn't."
But the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said Republicans had blocked the latest Medicare proposal at the behest of special interests. "The drug companies told them they shouldn't vote for it," Mr. Daschle said.
The issue of drug costs will reverberate in election campaigns and in the halls of Congress for the rest of the year.
Several House members, including Representative John Thune, Republican of South Dakota, have introduced legislation like the generic drug bill passed by the Senate. Lobbyists for brand-name drug companies said they would make herculean efforts to keep those bills off the House floor, but Democrats said they would try to force a vote.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who was an author of the generic drug bill, said brand-name drug makers had exploited loopholes in existing law to delay the marketing of generic products.
Under current law, a maker of brand-name drugs can often get a 30-month delay in federal approval of generic drugs by filing a lawsuit that alleges infringement of its patents. Some companies have delayed generic competition for years by repeatedly filing new patent claims for brand-name drugs already on the market.
Mr. Schumer said that some brand-name companies had blocked generic competition by claiming patent protection for incidental features of their products, like the brown bottle in which a medicine is packaged.
The bill passed today would allow only one 30-month delay for each drug product. In addition, it would outlaw collusive agreements under which brand-name drug companies pay generic companies to keep generic products off the market.
The collapse of Medicare legislation in the Senate was a personal and political defeat for Senator Daschle. He brought the legislation to the Senate floor on July 15, but never articulated a strategy for passing Medicare drug benefits.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 3, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Thursday about a Senate vote against coverage of prescription drugs for some Medicare patients misstated the 10-year cost of the Senate Democrats' initial plan to cover all 40 million of them. The amount was $594 billion, not million.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
I.B.M. Opening A $2.5 Billion Specialized Chip Plant

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: EAST FISHKILL, N.Y., July 31 

 BODY:
I.B.M. opened a sprawling and sophisticated new semiconductor factory here today that cost more than $2.5 billion to build and equip, the largest single capital investment the company has ever made.
 The factory, which opens as the computer chip business is in a slump, is a costly and risky move for I.B.M. But it is also an expression of confidence by the company that it can remain a technology leader in the highly competitive global semiconductor industry, and a commitment that the best place to execute that strategy is in the Hudson River Valley of New York. 
 I.B.M. is an exception among computer makers in that it still invests heavily in research to advance the design, manufacture and materials used in semiconductor chips. It is spending more than $500 million a year on semiconductor research and development. 
The factory will produce a wide range of specialized semiconductors used in everything from the largest mainframe computers to cellphones and video-game consoles.
The new plant is part of I.B.M.'s push to gain a strong lead in chip making beyond the personal computer business, where Intel and East Asian chip producers hold the advantage.
"The core of our strategy is to lead in technology and attack the high-performance segments of the market," said John Kelly, senior vice president in change of I.B.M.'s technology group.
An advantage to having the semiconductor fabricating factory here, some 60 miles north of Manhattan, Mr. Kelly explained, is that it is situated very close to its research laboratories in nearby Westchester County. To stay ahead in advanced chip technology, he said, moving innovations out of the labs and into the factory as fast as possible is crucial.
"What we call the lab-to-fab time should be as close to zero as possible," Mr. Kelly said. "If our strategy were anything but to be on the leading edge, we'd have put the plant in Asia."
The new factory, which will begin normal production early next year, will employ about 1,000 people. In remarks during a ribbon-cutting ceremony today, Gov. George E. Pataki said he also expected the installation to generate thousands of additional jobs in the Hudson Valley area for contractors and suppliers catering to the factory. He praised I.B.M. for being "a critical partner in our economic development efforts" in New York State.
In a brief speech, Samuel J. Palmisano, I.B.M.'s chief executive, emphasized that it was important to make long-term investments despite the current slump in the technology business. "To play to win in technology, you innovate and you lead," he said.
But manufacturing technology products is a costly and cyclical business. In June, I.B.M. announced that it was taking a charge of more than $2 billion against earnings. The biggest reasons were the cost of getting out of the business of manufacturing hard disks for storage, which it sold to Hitachi, and shutting down some of its older semiconductor operations.
Mr. Kelly said that the demand for advanced chips, like those produced at I.B.M.'s installation in Burlington, Vt., is strong. "I need more capacity in that end of the market," he said, "and this is factory is critical to meeting that growing demand."
If I.B.M. has miscalculated the demand, it will suffer badly as both the high operating costs and depreciation on the huge capital investment for the East Fishkill factory drag down earnings.
But industry analysts said that the plant is likely to be insulated from a fall-off in one or a few segments of the semiconductor market. It is highly automated and designed to shift flexibly to produce many different kinds of chips to suit demand. "The diversity is the big difference with this plant," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a research firm. "It gives I.B.M. the capability to make so many different kinds of custom chips, and the world is going to custom chips."
The 140,000-square-foot plant is a testament to advanced manufacturing technology. The 300-millimeter silicon wafers -- about the size of a regular pizza -- are shuttled around in enclosed plastic pods, which ride on overhead tracks. They drop down from wires automatically into machines, sheathed in stainless steel and glass, for each stage of processing and fabrication.
Throughout the 500 processing steps, which typically last 20 days, the wafers are not touched by human hands. The circuits etched into the chips are less than one-thousandth the width of a human hair.
Human operators are there to monitor the systems, catch errors and fine-tune the production process for greatest efficiency. Because each of the hundreds of processing machines is self-enclosed, and essentially airtight, the uniforms that operators wear are less constricting than in the previous generation of chip plants, where they looked like space suits.
The operators at the East Fishkill factory wear light nylon uniforms, light blue shoe covering and translucent hairnets made of paper. They look more like workers in a bakery.
Yes, said Richard Brilla, director of the new plant, "but the doughnuts are a lot more costly here." Each wafer, holding hundreds of chips, is worth $6,000 to $10,000 apiece, depending on what insulation, circuitry and materials are used.

HEADLINE: New Report Shows U.S. Economy Slowed Significantly for Quarter 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
The Commerce Department estimated yesterday that economic growth slowed sharply in the recent quarter from April through June and reported that last year's recession was both longer and deeper than originally thought.
With consumers becoming more cautious, state governments cutting spending and the trade deficit widening, the economy expanded at an annual rate of just 1.1 percent in the second quarter, down from 5 percent the first three months of the year.
 "The economy is on a much weaker foundation than thought," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a research firm in West Chester, Pa. Growth, he added, has come "to a virtual standstill." 
 The growth spurt after Sept. 11, which ended last year's recession, appears to have faded, leaving the economy vulnerable to a new downturn if oil prices rise, stocks fall further or another surprise causes consumers to cut their spending, economists said. Absent such a shock, however, the economy is likely to improve gradually this year, helped by a mild recovery in business investment that continued last quarter.
As part of its regular revisions, the Commerce Department said that new data showed that the economy shrank throughout the first three quarters of 2001, rather than only in the summer period. Some analysts define a recession as two consecutive quarters of contraction, and last year's downturn, which the official arbiters at the National Bureau of Economic Research dated as beginning in March, now qualifies under that standard, too. (The experts have not yet identified an official ending to the recession, but most economists believe a rebound began sometime around the end of last year or the beginning of this one.)
By showing that the recession clearly preceded the Sept. 11 attacks, the revisions could take some of the shine off of the economic reputations of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and former President Bill Clinton. 
Growth slowed to a crawl in Mr. Clinton's final six months in office, and the long expansion did not even stretch into the first quarter of 2001, when he left office. Throughout last spring, meanwhile, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the country could avoid recession even though it is now clear that one had already begun. He has said more recently that the attacks might have caused the recession.
Speaking to reporters at a meeting with his cabinet, President Bush said yesterday that the economy has now grown for three straight quarters, after having shrunk during the previous three.
"I'm very optimistic," Mr. Bush said. "The facts are that inflation is low, interest rates are low, productivity is high."
Yesterday's meager growth numbers surprised many economists, and the stock market fell after the release of the economic report before recovering, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closing at 911.62, up almost 1 percent. A survey of manufacturing executives added to economic worries by suggesting that both production and new orders slumped in July.
Analysts still expect the Fed to keep its benchmark interest rate at its current low level in coming months to encourage spending, but few predict further cuts. Unemployment is likely to continuing rising this year, although not sharply, economists said.
The most troubling sign in the Commerce Department's report may have been a further spending slowdown by consumers. For much of the last two years, Americans increased their spending at a healthy clip even as stocks were falling and businesses were sharply reducing their investments.
In the second quarter, however, consumer spending grew at an annual rate of only 1.9 percent, adjusted for inflation and normal seasonal variations, down from 3.1 percent in the first quarter and 6 percent at the end of last year.
In fact, the total value of American goods and services sold in the second quarter actually declined slightly. The economy grew because companies increased production in order to keep their inventory levels essentially flat, after more than a year of cutting their stockpiles.
For the economy to improve, consumers will have to increase their spending in future months and buy more of those stockpiled goods. The decline in the stock market may give them pause, but the return of zero-percent financing by automakers and still-low mortgage rates should help lift spending, economists said.
State and local governments also stopped expanding this spring, after having used tax revenues from the long expansion to grow rapidly in the late 1990's. Now governors and legislatures are cutting the budgets of schools, hospitals and road-building programs, among other things, to make sure they keep their budgets in balance.
Federal spending increased 7.4 percent during the second quarter, partly because of new military programs and other responses to Sept. 11.
Businesses reduced their spending for the seventh consecutive quarter, breaking the record for the longest such streak since the Commerce Department began keeping records in 1947. Companies are still trying to recover from an investment binge in the 1990's, fed by the easy credit of a bull market, that has left them with far more capacity than they can profitably use.
But the spending drop was only 1.6 percent, the smallest since the declines began in late 2000. While the building of new factories and other structures dropped markedly, spending on equipment and software rose 2.9 percent, its first increase in almost two years.
"Technology is improving so rapidly that businesses, even with low capacity utilization, are finding it necessary to add equipment," said Brian S. Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, a brokerage firm in Chicago. "That's good news."
A large jump in imports, which reduced growth by statistically replacing American-made products, also gave economists room for optimism. Some said companies essentially hoarded goods to prepare for the possibility of a strike by dock workers on the West Coast and that imports should slow in the future.
Yesterday's revisions indicated the economy began to weaken significantly in 2000, as the stock bubble started deflating and companies realized many of their forecasts were too rosy. The government's broadest measure of corporate profits fell 2.2 percent in 2000, rather than having risen 6.2 percent, as reported earlier.
Significantly, productivity -- the amount that the average worker produces in an hour -- now appears to have increased less between the middle of 2000 and the start of this year than government estimates had initially shown. The gains of the last two years now seem closer to the paltry increases of the 1970's, 1980's and early 1990's than to the rapid gains of late 1990's, said Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University.
If the economic boom and the stock-market bubble were the main causes of the productivity spurt, instead of new technology and business strategies, the country's long-term economic outlook would worsen somewhat.
With more refined data, the Commerce Department said that in the first three quarters of last year, the economy shrank 0.6 percent, 1.6 percent and 0.3 percent, respectively.
"Many people thought that we could have avoided a recession without 9/11," said Mr. Wesbury, one of the few forecasters to have predicted a recession early last year. "This puts the lie to that."

HEADLINE: McCall Criticizes Cuomo's Plans to Use His Father's Help in the Campaign 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

 BODY:
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo landed squarely in the thick of the Democratic primary for governor yesterday as State Comptroller H. Carl McCall suggested that his opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo, had to "run home for dad" for support.
 "If you were out in the street, in a battle, and you were kind of losing, you might run home for dad," Mr. McCall said of Andrew Cuomo, igniting a tit-for-tat among the campaigns that suggested the former governor might loom large in the race. 
 Mr. McCall's remark came a day after the Cuomo campaign confirmed that the former governor would campaign for his son, making speeches, visiting churches and community centers and perhaps filming a commercial.
A spokeswoman for the former governor said he was unavailable to comment.
But political analysts had plenty to say about the former governor's entrance into the race, with the prevailing notion that he presents a double-edged sword to Andrew Cuomo.
Until now, Andrew Cuomo had gone to some lengths to ensure that the former governor kept a low-profile in the campaign so that "in no way can this look like the fourth term of Mario Cuomo," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Institute for Public Opinion at Marist College.
Mario Cuomo is, in most polls, popular among hard-core Democrats. But when he lost to Gov. George E. Pataki in upstate New York, it was in no small part because he was blamed by many voters for the economic problems there. 
"The problem for Andrew is that Mario overstayed his welcome and his popularity in Erie went down the toilet that last term," said Gerald A. Goldhaber, an independent pollster in Buffalo. "The trouble for Andrew is that his whole image and charisma reminds people of Mario."
Other analysts said that while the former governor could give a boost to his son in the primary, it could severely damage him in a race against Governor Pataki, whose campaign aides declined to comment yesterday on the former governor.
"Clearly among Democratic primary voters, Mario is popular but less so among independents and Republicans," Mr. Miringoff said.
Andrew Cuomo seemed to make the most of Mr. McCall's remark, casting it as a pattern of personal attacks from the McCall campaign and asserting that the comptroller had the former governor to thank for his job.
It was "also nice to have a governor," Mr. Cuomo said, who "fought very hard to appoint you as comptroller of the state of New York. In politics, people often have short memories."
Mr. Cuomo was referring to Mr. McCall's appointment as comptroller in 1993 after the resignation of Edward V. Regan. While the appointment was made by the Legislature, Mr. Cuomo's camp says the former governor influenced legislative leaders to pick Mr. McCall. McCall partisans dispute this.
"It's one thing, you want to attack me," Andrew Cuomo said. "I'm silly enough to run for office and expose myself to this." He added that even "by the normal New York standards, attacking my father, attacking my wife is going too far."
He was referring to comments made months ago by Representative Charles B. Rangel, a McCall supporter, who suggested that Kerry Kennedy Cuomo, Andrew Cuomo's wife, was not as prominent as other family members.
Mr. McCall's aides denied that their side had attacked the Cuomos and tried to play down the comptroller's comment, saying it came after he had given several noncommital responses about the elder Cuomo. But the day before, Mr. McCall's campaign criticized Mario Cuomo for missing a deadline to file a report about his political action committee and called it a slush fund.
Both Democratic candidates did have an issue-based campaign theme for the day -- Mr. Cuomo again calling for corporate accountability and tougher penalties in New York State for corporate abuses, and Mr. McCall calling for recruiting 10,000 new public school teachers a year by creating a program that would subsidize graduate teaching degrees in exchange for five-year teaching commitments.
Meanwhile, the campaign of B. Thomas Golisano, the billionaire entrepreneur who is seeking a ballot line on which to run for governor, suffered a blow yesterday when the New York City Board of Elections said it was investigating a claim that Mr. Golisano's candidate for lieutenant governor had registered and voted twice last year.
A Board of Elections official said that an early review indicated that the candidate, Dan Mahony, a New York financial adviser who is seeking to run on the Conservative Party line, had apparently registered to vote using two addresses.
The board's investigation was the result of an article in The New York Post yesterday that said Mr. Mahony might have registered using an altered birth date and address, while retaining his registration at an old address.
Mr. Mahony did not respond to a telephone message left at his home. But Erick Mullen, a spokesman for the Golisano campaign, said Mr. Golisano had full confidence in Mr. Mahony and that the charges were the result of Governor Pataki's efforts to discredit Mr. Golisano.
"We're confident that this is part and parcel of a dirty tricks campaign," Mr. Mullen said. "George Pataki is terrified of the polling booth. But this election will not be decided in the courtrooms or in the political back rooms. We're confident that Dan Mahony will prevail." 
Mollie Fullington, the governor's campaign spokeswoman, said of the voting claims, "These are serious allegations and they should be investigated."
