HEADLINE: AT LEAST 7 KILLED AS MILITANTS BOMB JERUSALEM CAMPUS 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET and JOHN KIFNER

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 31 

 BODY:
A powerful bomb hidden in a bag and left on a table by Palestinian militants tore apart a bustling cafeteria during lunch at Hebrew University here today, killing seven people, including at least three Americans, and wounding more than 80.
 Through a bedlam of screams and crashing glass, students fled in horror from the cafeteria, in the Frank Sinatra Student Center, some trailing blood onto the concrete courtyard of Nancy Reagan Plaza. 
 Because of the campus' diverse student body -- it is one of the few enclaves here where Israeli Jews and Israeli Arabs still mix -- students said they had felt safe, even as new violence threatened the city this week. Arab students were among the wounded, hospital officials said, as were foreign students.
In Washington, the State Department reported the deaths of the three Americans, two women and one man. One victim, Janis Ruth Coulter of New York City, was identified tonight by the American Friends of Hebrew University. 
The State Department declined to identify the American victims further as consular officials worked to notify relatives.
An administration official said there might be more Americans among the dead. He gave no further details, except to say that the identification process was continuing. The Israeli consul in Boston, Hillel Newman, told The Boston Globe last night that four Americans had been killed in the attack.
Philip Reeker, a department spokesman, called the attack "absolutely tragic and outrageous."
President Bush condemned the bombing and said it was perpetrated by "killers who hate the thought of peace and therefore are willing to take their hatred to all kinds of places, including a university." 
The bombing at the campus, on Mount Scopus, was the second in two days in Jerusalem. The Islamist group Hamas claimed responsibility for the bombing, saying that it acted in retaliation for Israel's killing last week of a top Hamas leader. Fourteen others, including nine children, died in that attack, in which Israel bombed a house in Gaza City. 
Spencer Dew, 26, a divinity student from the University of Chicago studying here for the summer, was eating on the patio when he heard the blast, then smelled gunpowder. Lacerated by flying glass, he joined the fleeing crowd, then returned for a notebook, which had also been pierced by glass. 
"I know there are justifications -- bad justifications," he said of the political violence, his shirt spotted crimson and his khaki pants torn as he left a hospital here. "It's killing college students. That's no political solution for anything. It's killing college kids." 
As emergency workers cleared the site, Abeer Salman, 19, a student from the Arab village of Beit Safafa, sat on the plaza steps, stunned.
"I was across the plaza," she said. "My friend wanted to get something to drink. After two minutes we heard a blast, and we can't find her."
The campus is fenced, and guards check the bags of those who enter. But some students complained that the security was porous. An investigation by a campus paper in January warned that a cafeteria would be an appealing, accessible target. 
"The security tries to do their best," said Kobi Cohen, the student union president."But there are a lot of holes in the fence. A lot of guards don't check the bags well."
Mr. Cohen, who helped evacuate the wounded, said, "We always believed that because there are Arab students here and Arab workers, nobody will try to hurt us here." 
The attack was unusual in that it appeared not to be the work of a suicide bomber. Police officials said initial investigation suggested that the bomb was hidden in a bag. 
Israeli officials said the attack fit a Palestinian strategy of killing civilians. "This is a continuous effort by the Palestinians to kill as many Israelis as possible in order to sabotage the peace process," said Gideon Meir, a senior Foreign Ministry official. "It has nothing to do with what happened in Gaza City a week ago."
The Palestinian Authority, led by Yasir Arafat, issued a statement saying that it "absolutely condemns the attack against Hebrew University" but adding that it blamed Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, for provoking violence.
After back-to-back bombings killed 26 people here more than a month ago, Israel began a ground offensive in the West Bank to suppress Palestinian violence. 
But Palestinian militants vowed retaliation after the bombing last week. After five people were injured in the suicide bombing here on Tuesday, Mr. Sharon met senior security advisers before today's attack to discuss ways of coping with suicide bombers, and the group endorsed the idea of deporting members of the killers' families. Tonight, Israeli military officials convened to consider possible retaliation. 
Ron Krumer, a spokesman for the Hadassah Medical Center, where some of the wounded were taken, said the victims suffered "penetrating injuries, with lots of metal elements, such as bolts and screws and nails, all over their bodies."
The bomb sprayed blood across the ceiling tiles, tore apart wooden chairs and scattered the antique radios decorating the cafeteria. A large jar of pickled radishes sat unbroken on one counter, as an officer a few feet away used large tweezers to pick evidence out of a pool of blood. 
Students jotted down lists of friends and frantically dialed their cellphones, checking off the names of those who responded. Others called home to say they were all right. 
"I got delayed; I'm the luckiest man in the world," Allistaire Goldrein, 19, of Liverpool, England, told his worried father, calling from England. Mr. Goldrein said he ate in the cafeteria every day and was delayed today by another student.
"I was coming around the corner and suddenly there was this huge explosion," he said. "I can't describe it -- huge. The very foundation of the stone structure was shaken."
Mr. Goldrein said he raced inside. "It was carnage in there," he said. "Carnage, anarchy. It was disgusting. I saw dead people. I saw people with no heads. There was a guy, I gave him mouth to mouth, but he was dead."
Just outside the campus this afternoon, the police detained scores of Arab men, including some who appeared to be students, keeping them standing in the sun for several hours as they searched for suspects.
Representatives of an anti-Palestinian faction arrived at the blast site and unfurled a banner declaring, "It's them or us" and "Expel the Arab enemy." Dror Lederman, 26, a student of economics and accounting, angrily accosted one man. "Get out of here," he said. "You come every time. You come to dance on the blood."
Students watched in shock as emergency workers carried their peers away on orange stretchers, through an area where graduation ceremonies are held. "I was standing in the Forum and watching them bring people on stretchers, and I saw blood and shoes and I.V.'s on the ground," said Sophia Aron, 19, of Los Angeles, a student from the University of California, Davis, who is studying here for a year. "Right in the Forum. It freaks me out. But I'm not leaving."
Dr. Mahmoud al-Zahar, a political leader of Hamas, blamed Israel for the attack. "Such operations will continue until the elimination of the occupation," he said. Hamas leaders consider all of Israel to be occupied territory, not just the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, which Israel occupied in 1967.
Shlomo Avineri, a political science professor at the university, said: "This is beyond the pale, to attack a university, and it shows what the war is about. It's not about the settlements. It's not about occupation. It's about the very existence of a Jewish population in this country."

HEADLINE: Handling of Penny Stock Plan Is Under Inquiry in Hong Kong 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 31 

 BODY:
A precipitous plunge in penny stocks here last Friday, prompted by a proposal to delist some of the lowest-priced stocks, provoked a series of moves today by regulators and market administrators as investors continued to complain bitterly.
 Antony Leung, the financial secretary and third-ranking government official here, announced that a two-member panel would investigate how the stock exchange and regulators had handled the drafting and release of the proposal. The Securities and Futures Commission of Hong Kong said today that it was investigating whether markets were illegally manipulated on Friday. 
 The chief executive of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, the for-profit company that operates the stock exchange, apologized at a legislative hearing today. "I send my heartfelt apologies to shareholders who have suffered as a result of the market's response to some of the proposals in our consultation paper," the executive, Kwong Ki-chi, said. 
The plunge last week erased $1.3 billion in value from penny stocks here. The stock exchange withdrew its delisting proposal on Sunday and said that it would issue a new proposal in October and give the public three months starting then to comment on it. But many penny stocks have still not fully recovered.
The stock exchange had proposed to delist -- permanently remove from trading on the exchange -- the stocks of companies with share prices that stayed below 50 Hong Kong cents (6.4 American cents) for 30 consecutive trading days.
Also to be delisted were the stocks of companies that lost money for three consecutive years and had a market capitalization of less than 50 million Hong Kong dollars ($6.4 million) for 30 consecutive trading days.
Delisting requirements are found on most large stock exchanges, including stock exchanges in the United States. The stock exchange's proposal to introduce such rules here highlighted the extraordinary number of nearly worthless shares of money-losing companies that are still traded in Hong Kong.
The Securities and Futures Commission, a regulatory agency here, released a separate report last Thursday that calculated that 72.9 percent of the stocks traded in Hong Kong have share prices of less than 20 American cents.
Mr. Kwong, the stock exchange chief executive, and other officials said today that many companies should have been able to meet the withdrawn proposal on share-price minimums by consolidating their shares. One way to do this would be through reverse stock splits.
Few companies would actually have been delisted if the original proposal had gone ahead, he added.
But he also acknowledged that Hong Kong, unlike many other countries with important financial markets, does not have an equivalent of the "bulletin board" or "pink sheet" trading of penny stocks in the United States that have been delisted from the major exchanges. 
Very low share prices are more profitable for brokers because the spread between the bid and offer prices is frequently a tenth of a cent here, and that is a larger percentage of the price of a very cheap stock.
In his testimony, Mr. Kwong emphasized that the exchange had been publicly discussing various versions of delisting requirements for a full year, and expressed surprise that the publication of the proposal last Thursday had provoked such a strong market response.
Citing market sources, The South China Morning Post reported today that "a group of brokers met on Thursday night and decided to sell certain penny stocks in a bid to create panic and incite retail investors to follow." The purpose of the selling was to stop the delisting, said the newspaper, which was also the first to report that the securities commission here was investigating.
David Webb, the editor of a nonprofit Internet site, Webb-site.com, that covers corporate governance and economic issues in Hong Kong, said that the controversy put Mr. Kwong's company in an especially awkward position. As a for-profit company, it stands to benefit financially from a thinning of the ranks of very small companies on the stock exchange, because these companies' listings require a lot of paperwork but generate limited trading.
"I don't think they can choose to service only the most profitable companies," he said.
Some brokers have called for Mr. Kwong's immediate resignation, but Mr. Leung warned against any action now and said that the panel of inquiry should be allowed to investigate and file its report, due by Sept. 10. Emily Lau, a senior opposition lawmaker, agreed that no immediate action should be taken.
The government appoints 8 of the 15 directors of the company as well as the chief executive; Mr. Kwong is a former civil servant. The government merged the territory's stock exchange, which used to be owned by its members, with the futures market here and then listed it on the stock exchange in 1999.
The two members of the panel of inquiry are Robert Kotewall, a prominent lawyer in private practice here and former member of various governance and advisory bodies on financial services issues, and Gordon C. K. Kwong, a shipping executive and former chairman of the Hong Kong stock exchange's listing committee.

HEADLINE: Bush Criticized by Lawmakers on CorporateGovernance 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
Less than 24 hours after a grand display of bipartisanship at a White House ceremony celebrating President Bush's signature on a major corporate-fraud bill, lawmakers today criticized Mr. Bush for what they called an abrupt watering down of the legislation. The Democrats also raised questions about an offshore subsidiary of the Harken Energy Corporation formed when Mr. Bush was on the company's board.
 The criticisms signaled that the Democrats planned to continue using the nation's corporate scandals as a political weapon against the president, who remains personally popular even as voters express serious worries about the economy and the rocky stock market. 
 Mr. Bush, for his part, tried to restore consumer confidence in the face of new government statistics showing that the economy cooled off sharply in the second quarter.
"We're heading in the right direction," Mr. Bush said, putting an unusually sunny interpretation on a Commerce Department report that the nation's gross domestic product grew by 1.1 percent from April through June, down from 5 percent in the first three months of the year.
As Mr. Bush was speaking, Democrats were rapidly maneuvering away from the cheerful tableau of unity that the White House had created in the East Room on Tuesday, when Democrats and Republicans stood behind the president and applauded him as he signed the bill, initially resisted by the White House, that cracks down on corporate fraud and the accounting profession.
Today, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, was joined by a Republican colleague, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, in criticizing the president for what they said was a weakening of a provision designed to protect corporate whistle-blowers. The two senators wrote the provision.
A statement interpreting the provision was released by the White House only hours after the bill was signed. The statement said that the administration would provide federal job protection to employees who cooperate with an investigation authorized by the House or the Senate, but made no mention of protection for employees who might speak more informally to a single member of the House or Senate.
In a letter to the president today, Mr. Leahy and Mr. Grassley called the interpretation narrow and said it was "at odds with the plain language of the statute and risks chilling corporate whistle-blowers who wish to report securities fraud" to individual members of Congress.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader who had been the first to shake the president's hand after the bill signing, joined in with his colleagues.
"I can't believe that before the ink is even dry, the White House would be acting to diminish its strength and power," Mr. Daschle said at a Capitol Hill news conference. "It does cause me to question how serious this administration is with regard to corporate responsibility."
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, responded that administration lawyers had determined that they needed to clarify the provision and that it was up to Congress to determine through its own rules who got protection. "Congress has that authority if they so choose it," Mr. Fleischer said.
Mr. Daschle and other Democrats also seized on a report in The Daily News of New York about a Cayman Islands subsidiary created by Harken when Mr. Bush was on its board. Mr. Daschle said it was possible that the subsidiary was similar to the kind of tax shelter that Republicans and White House officials have recently criticized, an assertion disputed by Mr. Fleischer.
Mr. Bush, when asked today about the subsidiary, suggested that its purpose was not to avoid taxes. "I think we ought to look at people who are trying to avoid U.S. taxes as a problem," Mr. Bush said to reporters this morning. "I think American companies ought to pay taxes here, and be a part -- good citizens."
Democrats also sought, with questionable success, to focus attention on Vice President Dick Cheney's handling of tax issues during his business career. On Capitol Hill, they circulated a report from Citizen Works, a group founded by Ralph Nader, saying that the Halliburton Company had not paid taxes in five of the six years that Mr. Cheney was its chief executive. The report also said that Halliburton had increased, to 44 from 9, the number of subsidiaries in offshore tax havens. Mr. Cheney's office referred questions about the matter to Halliburton.
But Halliburton said tonight that Citizen Works had confused the company's tax refunds with its liabilities, and that it had paid taxes in five of the six years. "They have the numbers backwards," said Wendy Hall, a spokeswoman for Halliburton.
Ms. Hall said the increase in offshore subsidiaries stemmed largely from acquisitions, including Halliburton's 1998 combination with Dresser Industries. In any case, she said, Halliburton had never used offshore subsidiaries to shelter income earned in the United States, the practice that has been drawing political heat in Washington.
"Halliburton does not shift income from the U.S. to foreign subsidiaries to avoid U.S. taxes," she said.

HEADLINE: Because of 9/11, a Uniting River Now Divides 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY

DATELINE: LAJITAS, Tex., July 25 

 BODY:
On the night Lilia Falcon was born 31 years ago, her mother headed north. The Mexican hospital nearest to her family's tiny village meant a trip of 160 miles south over dirt roads. The trip north was half as long. So a boatman ferried her mother across the Rio Grande, and Lilia Falcon entered the world in the hands of an American doctor.
 The journey might have violated American law, but Ms. Falcon's mother was abiding by the unwritten law of the Big Bend Country, a scarcely populated region of remote desert and jagged mountains named for the abrupt northward turn of the river. For generations, people on both sides have crossed the Rio Grande to shop, to work when work could be found or to share company in a place removed from the outside world. 
 But even here, the ripples from Sept. 11 are being felt. The Border Patrol, acting in the name of domestic security, has put an end to the unofficial rowboat crossings that local and federal officials had tacitly allowed for years. In May, Border Patrol agents raided the crossing here, arresting more than 20 people, including the boatman. Two similar crossings in Big Bend National Park have also closed. 
People here agree that the nation must remain vigilant against terrorism, but they say the closings are a misguided solution that weighs most heavily on people who are already among the poorest of the poor. Marriages cross the river here, as do most families. Now, anyone caught crossing the river faces a $5,000 fine and possibly jail time.
"These crossings have been around for generations," said Pete Gallego, a Democrat who is the area's state representative. "That river is not a dividing line. It's just a geographic feature, because people on both sides depend on each other to make a living."
The practical effect is that what once was a 15-minute trip by rowboat can take six hours because of the drive, particularly rough on the Mexican side, to reach the region's only official crossing, at Presidio, Tex. Unable to make such a trip daily, many construction workers who have work permits and jobs in the United States but homes in Mexico are sleeping in tents or trucks. Others are packed into a bunkhouse. About two dozen children on the Mexican side, some American citizens, are cut off from the only school.
The two small Mexican villages that depended on tourists from Big Bend National Park are devastated. The restaurant Ms. Falcon's family ran in the village of Boquillas has closed. A month ago, Ms. Falcon left Boquillas for the United States, searching for work so she could send money home. She saw her mother recently when she went down to the river.
"She was on the other side," Ms. Falcon said. "She was crying and so sad. She would throw kisses at us. My mother is right there, yet she is so far away."
The new policy has sparked protests and unity rallies on the American side and is creating a bureaucratic tangle as the Park Service explores ways to reopen the park crossings to Boquillas and to the village of Santa Elena. Mr. Gallego's office is researching whether a third crossing at Lajitas, a resort just west of the national park and about 225 miles southeast of El Paso, could be made an official port to the village of Paso Lajitas across the river.
"We're not going to get the federal government's attention for very long," Mr. Gallego said, citing the many procedural hoops involved.
The federal government began investing greater resources along the border in the 1990's, increasing the number of Border Patrol agents to crack down on illegal immigration and drug smuggling, particularly in El Paso, San Diego and along the Rio Grande Valley. The monitoring tightened even further after Sept. 11.
In more populated places along the border, the new security measures have meant longer delays in crossing. Yet because these areas have more official ports of entry, people with proper paperwork still cross back and forth every day. In the Big Bend, a region with more than 400 miles of international border, Lajitas was once one of several Class B ports, unpatrolled crossings that could be used by people with legal status. But those designations were removed in the 1990's, leaving the bridge at Presidio as the only official port in the huge and remote region.
Still, until recently, boatmen regularly shuttled tourists and locals over the three unofficial crossings, often charging $1 for a ride to Mexico and $2 for the ride back, a small reminder that life is never equal on the border.
"All our family, they live in Mexico," said George Garcia, an electrician who lives in Terlingua, about 10 miles inland from Lajitas. "We used to cross at the spot for 10 years or more than that. We used to go to Mexico every weekend or sometimes two days a week to see our family."
Since 2000, the main source of employment in the region has been a resort being built at Lajitas, which has brought construction work to an area accustomed to double-digit unemployment. But on May 10, the resort's general manager, Dan Carroll, said he was inside his house overlooking the crossing spot when he heard a helicopter roaring down the canyon above the river. Border Patrol trucks quickly arrived. About 20 people were detained on immigrations violations.
Mr. Carroll said work permits for about 70 employees, since approved, were being processed at the time of the raid. He said those workers are now essentially trapped, separated from their families. About 35 live in a bunkhouse provided by the resort, while others sleep in trucks or tents.
Pablo Caballero, a spokesman for the Border Patrol office in Marfa, Tex., which covers the Big Bend area, expressed sympathy for people on both sides of the river but said agents were simply upholding the law. Many residents said the Border Patrol conducted the raid because they were embarrassed by news media reports that depicted the region as having a porous border. Mr. Caballero said his office was aware of the reports, but he attributed the raid to other factors, including having 20 new agents thanks to more federal money.
"We had always patrolled that area, and if we saw anyone crossing there illegal, an arrest was made," Mr. Caballero said. "The difference is before we didn't patrol that area as frequently as we patrol it now."
He added, "Sept. 11 did change our lives."
Law enforcement officials also believe that the closing of the crossings could help reduce drug trafficking. Smuggling is not as severe here as in more populated areas, like El Paso, yet significant amounts of Mexican marijuana do pass through. Mike Keene, a special agent with the regional office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said drug smuggling had dropped noticeably since the crossings were closed and the Border Patrol increased overall monitoring.
But he also said the traffickers' routes were far more extensive than the three crossings used by local people. Drug agents have identified 90 trails used by traffickers over a 400-mile stretch of the border, often in places where trucks can ford the river. These trails, locals say, would make far more likely entry points for terrorists than the unofficial crossings where they would instantly be noticed.
"If anybody out of the area showed up, we'd all notice them," said Rick Page, who runs the century-old trading post in Lajitas. "We're all related."
Frank Deckert, superintendent of Big Bend National Park, said he respected that the Border Patrol needed to uphold the law, but questioned the wisdom of closing the crossings. For decades, park rangers have worked with Mexican villagers, teaching children about ecology and holding an annual international festival. The park has also encouraged tourists to cross for meals at the restaurants, even erecting signs that point to the crossings. The crossings are also listed in local guide books.
Mr. Deckert said he was talking with Customs officials to see if rangers could be trained and essentially deputized as Customs agents, thus allowing the crossings to reopen.
For residents of Lajitas and nearby Terlingua, many of whom came to this isolated, rugged place to get away from the rest of the world, the closings have caused great anger.
Residents gathered at the Lajitas crossing to show solidarity with their neighbors in Paso Lajitas. Lt. Col. Patricia Kerns, a judge advocate general in the Air Force Reserve who lives in Terlingua, has organized local opposition to the closings and is trying to set up an August meeting with the Border Patrol and officials in Washington. Others say the crossings should be made official ports with full-time agents checking people who pass through, thus ensuring security while providing access for locals.
"They are our community," Colonel Kerns said. "It was like if in your neighborhood they put up a wall and said, 'You can't talk to them anymore, and they can't talk to you anymore.' "
Ms. Falcon, meanwhile, is back in the country where she was born. She has spent her life traveling back and forth across the river, but she had figured she would be in Boquillas for the foreseeable future. She was helping her mother run the restaurant, and she said every day brought excitement as tourists from all over the world appeared out of the park brush for a meal. In a village with only one telephone and no gas station, it was as if the world was coming to her.
Now, she is living in an almost empty apartment in Fort Stockton, Tex., near her cousins. She has not found a job and is applying for food stamps. She and her two daughters were sleeping on a linoleum floor until a customer from the restaurant who learned of their plight bought them beds and a kitchen table. The man also helped deliver food and clothes to the people in the village.
He rowed across and handed the goods to the grateful villagers, but he never got out. Ms. Falcon stood on one side, her mother on the other. They could only wave.

GRAPHIC: Photo: For generations, people on both sides have crossed the Rio Grande near Lajitas, Tex., to shop, work and visit relatives. Since a Border Patrol raid in May, those crossings have ended. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)(pg. A18) Map of Texas highlighting Lajitas: Unofficial crossings near Lajitas, Tex., are now officially closed. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: 2 Fed Nominations Approved by the Senate 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
The Senate today approved the nominations of two economists, Ben S. Bernanke and Donald L. Kohn, to serve on the board of the Federal Reserve, bringing the policy-setting panel to full strength.
 Mr. 
Bernanke, a Princeton economist who advocates explicit targets for acceptable inflation as a way to keep prices in check, and Mr. Kohn, a senior Fed staff member and a trusted lieutenant of the agency's chairman, Alan Greenspan, cleared the Senate on a voice vote. 
 Earlier in the day, the nominations were approved by the Senate Banking Committee.
The approvals will bring the Board of Governors to its full strength of seven members, all of whom vote when the central bank sets interest-rate policy. The Fed's next meeting is on Aug. 13.
Mr. Bernanke, 48, will serve the rest of an unexpired term that ends on Jan. 31, 2004, while Mr. Kohn, 59, will serve a full 14-year term that would date from Feb. 1, 2002. 
Wall Street economists and former Fed governors said the two candidates could provide continuity should Mr. Greenspan leave when his four-year term as Fed chairman ends in June 2004, when he will be 78. President Bush has now picked four of the seven Fed board members.

PUB-DATE: August 2, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A Brazilian's Work in the 70's Now Looks New

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
TO organize delirium." It is the phrase Haroldo de Campos, the Brazilian poet, came up with to explain what his friend Helio Oiticica was up to. I couldn't put it better.
 Oiticica's name may not ring a bell, although in the last decade he has finally become known outside Brazil and beyond cult followers. Before he died in 1980 at 42, he was one of those deeply charismatic figures (like Lygia Clark) who contributed to the great experiment that was Brazilian art in the 1950's and 60's. The military government that came to power in 1964 gradually ended a cultural efflorescence that was South America's equivalent of Paris in the 20's or New York after World War II. 
 Not that New Yorkers or Parisians paid much attention at the time. Oiticica (pronounced oy-tee-SEE-kah) remained on the margins of Europeans' and Americans' consciousness at best. 
Better late than never: one of the benefits of 21st-century economic and cultural globalization is the overdue nod toward artists like him, who turn out to have been doing things 30 or 40 years ago that pass for new today.
Witness the show now at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, originally organized by Carlos Basualdo for the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio. It features works from the 1970's, when Oiticica left Brazil and settled in New York City for nine years. His trajectory is instructive. He began in the 1950's making abstract paintings and sculptures, colorful geometric constructions, a little like big origami, in a familiar European modernist idiom. The works sometimes hung from the ceiling. By 1960 these had evolved into structures large enough to walk into.
Then (in what seemed like a big leap, although it evolved naturally out of the previous sculptures) he started to experiment with unconventional materials: he made works from tents, like homemade shanties, to sleep in, and filled big jars with colored dirt you could dig your hands into.
He made miniversions of Earth Art, constructions made of stones, cement blocks and plastic bottles picked up from the street and studiously arranged, and he also designed banners and capes. He talked about "fusing together color, structures, poetic sense, dance, words, photography" -- about appropriating "things of the world which I come across in the streets, vacant lots, fields, the ambient world, things which would not be transportable but which I would invite the public to participate in."
The world is a museum, he said. There's art everywhere.
He became what Dan Cameron, the New Museum's senior curator, calls a social sculptor, staging ad hoc events, conceiving what has now come to be called (the word can make your heart sink by this point) installations. People were invited to walk barefoot through sand, dance to music, parade, smell incense, put on colorful clothes and buff their nails.
It all sounds quaint, perhaps, but at the time, and especially where Oiticica was coming from, it was radical and fresh. To encounter his work from the 60's today, even if you are somebody congenitally resistant to this sort of art, is at least to sense the openheartedness, which for Oiticica was the reason to make art in the first place.
In Brazil he worked among the residents of Rio's slums, making a virtue of their material poverty. The work had an implicit social thrust, but it was not explicitly political. It dovetailed, formally speaking, with Happenings, Fluxus and much else going on in Europe and the United States, but with specific local roots -- local roots and a universal message. Oiticica wanted nothing more than for people to kick off their shoes and to immerse themselves in the karmic pleasures he devised.
In 1970 he was included in the "Information" show at the Museum of Modern Art, then won a Guggenheim fellowship to come to New York. He stretched out his stay, taking odd jobs and ending up struggling to make ends meet, a familiar arc. He first lived in a loft on Second Avenue across the street from the Fillmore East (the show includes his funny little Super 8 film of the theater and the neighborhood), then moved to Christopher Street.
He threw himself happily into the worlds of experimental cinema, rock 'n' roll and downtown art. He saw performances by Yvonne Rainer and Yoko Ono. Works by Robert Smithson, Gordon Matta-Clark, Dan Graham and Peter Campus all must have rung a bell. He befriended Jack Smith, whose four-hour slide shows in his loft in the East Village made a particularly big impression on him.
So did John Cage and Andy Warhol: Oiticica seems almost to have wanted to be a Brazilian Warhol, to create his own Factory, to make his own version of Warhol's films, to immerse himself in the whole Warholian universe of underground gay culture, drugs and celebrity.
Out of this he made what's at the New Museum: erotic photographs of young men as a slide show set to Cagean sound bites from the radio. With Neville D'Almeida, a Brazilian filmmaker, he devised quasi-cinemas, multimedia environments he called Cosmococas. Oiticica would organize these in his loft, but he also wrote elaborate instructions so they could be re-presented elsewhere. These were dedicated to pop stars like Marilyn Monroe and Jimi Hendrix.
Three of them are in the show. In a room slung with colored hammocks, a Hendrix soundtrack plays as slides of his album "War Heroes" flash on the walls and ceiling with lines of cocaine in different patterns on the album. Oiticica and D'Almeida called these cocaine drawings.
More cocaine drawings, this time featuring Monroe, from the photograph on the cover of Norman Mailer's book about her, flicker in another room filled with sand and balloons.
The soundtrack is Yma Sumac, the 50's Peruvian singer and Latin music diva. Last, among scattered mattresses and pillows, are cocaine drawings of the filmmaker Luis Bunuel, from a cover of The New York Times Magazine.
I suspect the descriptions of the works make them sound juvenile or pointless, which they are not. A buoyancy derives partly from the music and also from a sly humor, self-mocking and pervasive. Oiticica seems to have been without pretense, and this allowed his work to be vulnerable. "Creleisure" was a word he concocted for idly participating in art that is incomplete without the visitor's contribution. His work depended on other people's open minds.
Unlike his earlier art, I should add, these New York works had a slightly aggressive tone that he no doubt picked up from the streets, even though it didn't really seem to suit his temperament. He plugged into the chaos that was the city in the 1970's and found the place both seductive and depressing.
The art bespeaks a naivete that is charming and anachronistic. Cocaine as a pigment for drawing and an outlandish symbol of delirium and lawlessness is a concept that seems to come from another time.
The textbook significance of Oiticica's work is its foreshadowing of current video installations and other multimedia creations. Oiticica was a low-tech pioneer. That alone is not why his work is worth seeing, although it's a pity the Guggenheim Museum canceled its plans to present a full-scale Oiticica retrospective that was in Paris a decade ago.
It would have seemed prescient to exhibit him before the onslaught of 90's installation art.
Instead we get this late, somewhat tangential slice of his career. So be it. It's a reminder of an artist willing to take risks. We can still learn a thing or two from him. Art was for him a state of mind and a condition of the heart -- a university for the soul with an open-admission policy.

"Helio Oiticica: Quasi-Cinemas" remains on view at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222, through Oct. 13.

Below, a view of "Cosmococa 3 (CC3) Maileryn," a 1973 slide series with sand and balloons, which is also at the museum. (Photographs by Helio Oiticica/$;Projecto Helio Oiticica)(pg. HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Gilt by Association: Less Status, More Room

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
ASPEN. Palm Springs. Woodstock. Southampton. Palm Beach.
 These are historic names that resonate with status, prestigious playgrounds for the select few, nestled in spectacular settings. 
 Then there is Basalt. And Cathedral City, Saugerties, Hampton Bays and Stuart.
Never heard of them?
That's because they are border towns, notable mainly for the fame of their neighbors. But they may be comparative bargains for second-home buyers seeking access to chic enclaves without living in them. These towns offer easy access to ski slopes, beaches and trendy restaurants and clubs without necessarily demanding a six-figure down payment. 
They bestow on their residents the joys of reverse snobbism. Border town residents are confident enough not to have to carry around their pedigrees or their Louis Vuitton luggage.
The downside? Telling people you spent hundreds of thousands of dollars for a beautiful vacation home in . . . Basalt. Then having to give the required addendum to mystified friends: it's next to Aspen.

Basalt, Colo.
WHY: A classic Western river town, Basalt is 18 miles northwest of Aspen, the cosmopolitan ski resort. Aspen Mountain is 20 to 45 minutes away, and for summer fly-fishing and rafting on the Grand Fork and Frying Pan Rivers, which converge in Basalt, it's more central than Aspen. Like Aspen, it is a historic 19th-century town that has some Victorian houses dating from the 1880's.
"It's very reminiscent of Aspen 30 years ago," said B. J. Adams, who owns B.J. Adams & Company, a real estate brokerage company in Aspen. "A lot of 100-year-old homes are being bought and renovated and beautifully landscaped."
Still, Basalt, which has about 2,800 year-round residents, is mainly a bedroom community for people who work in the area, which means there's less of the tourist trade that some people say has begun to erode some of Aspen's charm. 
Basalt seems poised to take off. Architects, interior designers, real estate brokers and contractors have built offices there.
"Well-educated, professional people are now in Basalt," said John Cottle, a 22-year resident and a principal in Cottle Gray Beal & Yaw, a local architecture firm. "Even if someone has the economic means to live in Aspen, Basalt's a viable choice."
WHAT IT WILL COST: In Basalt, a 2,500- to 3,500-square-foot house will cost around $700,000. Smaller houses go for $450,000. At the low end is a $289,000 three-bedroom tract house in a subdivision. At the high end is a $5,595,000 working cattle ranch on 136 acres, with an 1889 farmhouse. 
In Aspen, the average house price is $3.4 million, and prices of $1.5 million for a small one- to three-bedroom house -- what locals call a scrapper -- are not uncommon.
CONTENDER: Carbondale. A little more agricultural in character, a little farther down Highway 82 from Aspen and perhaps a little less quaint than Basalt. The cost of a three-bedroom, two-bath house is $300,000 to $1 million, said Ms. Adams, the Aspen real estate broker.

Cathedral City, Calif.
WHY: Palm Springs, the grande dame of desert resorts, has already undergone a face lift. Want to buy a midcentury modern glass house on a green fairway? Too late. It's sold. And the Spanish-style villa you fantasized about isn't available at a discount.
Fifteen minutes away is Cathedral City, in the foothills of the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains. The Cove, an old section of town, has a few houses with flat roofs and lots of glass that were built in the late 1950's or early 60's. 
"The Cove is interesting and funky," said Trish Wortman, a broker at Marilyn Perlin Realtors Inc. of Palm Springs. "You can have an inexpensive cabinish home next to a 3,000-square-foot modern house."
Cathedral City, known as Cat City, lacks the nouveau hipness of Palm Springs. It was never hip. This town of 47,000, which started as a blue-collar bedroom community for hotel workers in Palm Springs, is now attracting people during the winter season, about 15,000 a year. Frank Sinatra never lived here, but second-home owners can still golf at the 108 courses in the Coachella Valley.
WHAT IT WILL COST: In the newer areas like Rio Vista or Panorama, prices range from $140,000 for a starter home to $300,000 at the high end. Condominiums close to golf courses are $70,000 to the low $100's. A four-bedroom contemporary with a flat roof and a guest house is listed at $379,000. 
In Palm Springs, a three-bedroom, 1,500- to 1,800-square-foot house starts at $200,000 and goes up to $600,000; condominiums range from about $60,000 for a 600-square foot one-bedroom unit to $240,000 for a two-bedroom, 1,200-square-foot unit within walking distance of the city center.
CONTENDER: La Quinta, about 10 miles southeast of Cathedral City, is surrounded by scenic golf courses and three mountains. Single-family homes here cost $150,000 to $700,000.

Hampton Bays, N.Y.
WHY: The physical beauty of the Hamptons knows no borders. Hampton Bays has the glistening waters of Shinnecock Bay to the south and the Great Peconic Bay to the north. And Hampton Bays has something Southampton does not: marina space.
Often considered the working-class Hampton, Hampton Bays is predominantly a year-round residential community with many first-time homeowners. It is also the most densely populated and economically diverse hamlet in the town of Southampton. 
It does not have social cachet, prompting some less secure residents to try to bask in the reflective glory. "People will sometimes say, 'I live in Southampton township,' " said Deidre Ciraco Francolini, the manager and an associate broker at Coldwell Banker Dunesview Properties in Westhampton Beach.
WHAT IT WILL COST: A two-bedroom, 1,200-square-foot house here will cost about $300,000, while a modest starter home is $200,000. A house on the water will demand a premium: $400,000 on a creek to $1 million on a bay (at least $500,000 less than in Southampton). 
In Old Harbor, a four-bedroom colonial with a pool and garage is on the market for $495,000, and on the Rampasture Peninsula, a three-bedroom waterfront ranch is on the market for $850,000. 
In the neighboring towns, Ms. Francolini said, even the smallest home would start at $400,000, and for larger houses away from the water, the range is more typically $650,000 to $2 million.
And no one is surprised when a large luxury house on the water sells for $7.5 million, Ms. Francolini said.
CONTENDER: East Quogue is a little pricier than Hampton Bays, but even so, it is still less expensive than the "name" Hamptons.
A large subdivision, Southampton Pines, was recently built here, and its 160 new homes, ranging from 2,500 to 4,000 square feet, are priced at $550,000 to $800,000. In East Quogue, a four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath colonial within walking distance of a private beach typically costs $500,000.

Saugerties, N.Y.
WHY: Woodstock has everything. It is a legendary artists' colony with cafes, the Woodstock Playhouse and bars with live music that rival Bleecker Street's. Ten miles east, Saugerties has always been in Woodstock's shadow. Its Main Street recalls the 1950's.
"My father always said that Saugerties is the town that never happened," said Gail Cadden, an illustrator and longtime Woodstock resident.
But Saugerties does have the Hudson River and some stately Victorians, and it has started a farmers' market (every Saturday from July to October). Many people from New York City buy vacation homes in the mountains near Saugerties because they are less expensive than those in Woodstock. 
"The property values have never escalated the same way that the Woodstock property values have," said Elda Zulick, a real estate broker in Saugerties. Many second-home owners, Ms. Zulick said, are producers, writers and artists who appreciate being near Woodstock but not in it. 
"I like Saugerties because it's a little more laid-back," said Stuart Bragg, an advertising executive in the health care unit of Foote, Cone & Belding. He lives on the Upper West Side and bought a three-bedroom ranch house in Saugerties earlier this year.
"Woodstock is a place where New Yorkers have always gone to get away or drop out of the New York scene," he said. "Saugerties is more like a regular American town."
WHAT IT WILL COST: As house prices in Woodstock have climbed, those in Saugerties have, too, but just not quite as much. Prices range from $85,000 for a small house of approximately 1,000 square feet in good condition to slightly more than $1 million for large houses in the mountains or on the river.
A contemporary two-bedroom house on less than an acre would cost about $240,000 in Woodstock, but a similar three-bedroom house in Saugerties is on the market for $189,000. A two-bedroom, one-bath cottage on an acre lot would be $135,000 in Woodstock, $85,000 in Saugerties.
CONTENDER: Phoenicia, nestled in the Woodland Valley of the Catskills, is a more rural community, a little farther from Woodstock but close to the Belleayre ski resort.
A four-bedroom Victorian farmhouse with a stream in back is available for $179,000, and a two-bedroom house with a separate cottage on eight acres bordering state parkland is $259,000, said Sheri Safier, a associate broker at Westwood Metes and Bounds Realty in West Hurley, N.Y.

Stuart, Fla.
WHY: In Palm Beach, the sumptuous romper room for the rich, the average price of a house on less than an acre with no water in sight is $1.6 million. Oceanfront? $15 million to $18 million. The east coast of South Florida is densely populated and has little waterfront property available, period, forcing people to migrate up the coast.
That is what makes Stuart an attractive alternative, even though it is not exactly a satellite of Palm Beach.
Stuart is on the Atlantic about 40 miles north of Palm Beach, and it also has the Intracoastal Waterway and St. Lucie River. In Stuart, the farthest house from the ocean is still only seven miles away. Stuart has a historical downtown with cobblestones and fine restaurants, and even in traffic, Stuart is still just 45 minutes from the West Palm Beach International Airport. Among the perks: strict zoning and no industrial areas. The population in 1991 was 113,000; now it has risen 15 percent, to 130,000.
Stuart is developing as a second-home community. "Right now, baby boomers in their late 30's and 40's are coming from New York and Connecticut to buy the waterfront," said Michele Post at Re/Max of Stuart.
WHAT IT WILL COST: A three- to four-bedroom house, not on the water, will bring about $200,000. The going rate is $2 million for oceanfront, and $400,000 on the canals. Two-bedroom condominiums on nearby Hutchinson Island cost $225,000.
CONTENDER: West Palm Beach is the traditional place for shoppers priced out of Palm Beach. Separated by a causeway from Palm Beach, West Palm has houses that cost $300,000 to $400,000. Town houses and condominiums are $100,000 to $150,000, said Abe Himelstein, the branch manager of Prudential Florida WCI Realty in Boynton Beach.

HEADLINE: As Other Markets Founder, South Korea's Remains Solid 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
It was not long ago that Asian stock markets were among the world's worst performers, battered by the financial crises that spread from Thailand in the summer of 1997 to South Korea by November, almost bringing the Korean economy to its knees.
 Now, as markets in Europe and the Americas continue to slump, weighed down by worries that the economic recoveries in many leading industrial nations may be faltering, South Korea has proved to be remarkably resilient. Since hitting a low in September, the Seoul market's benchmark index has risen 50 percent. While, the index fell 1.41 percent today, it remains up 2 percent for the year -- outperforming most major Asian markets and exceeding by far markets in the United States and Europe. 
 "Asia is more robust than the United States or Europe," said Pieter van der Schaft, director of economic research at Barclays Capital in Hong Kong. "The economic cycle is basically positive. Asia has come ahead of the United States in terms of domestic demands."
A downturn in the United States market "definitely influences the Korean market negatively," noted Chang Won Chang of the Korea Finance Institute. But "up to this point, we cannot see any out flight" of investors pulling out of South Korea, he said.
The Korean economy demonstrated its resilience today with a sharp increase in exports. The Commerce Ministry reported that exports for July rose nearly 20 percent, to $13.65 billion -- the biggest gain in nearly two years. Shipments of semiconductors and other electronics products accounted for much of the gain, but motor vehicles also increased significantly.
The rising value of the Korean currency, the won, and new signs of weaknesses in the economies of the United States -- the biggest overseas market for South Korea -- and Europe are raising concerns about South Korea's ability to sustain that pace of growth, however. South Korea ships around 20 percent of its exports to the United States, which on Wednesday reported that economic growth slowed sharply in the quarter from April through June. 
Still, Lee Sung Kwon, chief economist for Good Morning Securities, one of Seoul's leading Korean securities firms, cited "very stable domestic demand" as reason for confidence in South Korea.
The restructuring and discipline that Korean companies were forced to adopt because of the 1997-1998 economic crisis should serve to protect industry in South Korea, he said.
"Since 1998 we have undergone a very painful process so we have trimmed the size of our corporate sector," Mr. Lee said. "We focus on core business areas and have cut off the weak areas. The focus on high value-added areas has returned competitiveness."
Unlike Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan, which had downturns last year, he noted, South Korea "grew by 3 percent, and I am sticking to my estimate of 6.2 growth for this year."
At the same time, analysts say Korean companies have gone far toward overcoming their habit of exaggerating earnings, basing lofty sales records on sales to related companies, since the 1997-1998 financial crisis. 
"We have more confidence in Korean corporate strategists," said Hank Morris, a longtime financial consultant here. "What's gone on before won't be tolerated."
South Korea learned its hardest lesson three years ago during the collapse of the Daewoo group, then the country's second-largest conglomerate. By the time the accountants had uncovered the real story several months after Daewoo acknowledged that it could not repay its loans, the group's liabilities were estimated to exceed $80 billion.
"Korea is in a good position," Mr. Morris. "They have begun to attack their accounting ills in the wake of the Daewoo collapse, and they will continue to do so."

HEADLINE: Russia Withdraws Sale of Lukoil, Calling Price Too Low 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
The Russian government has abruptly pulled a plan to sell nearly 6 percent of Lukoil, Russia's biggest oil company. 
 While the cancellation of the share sale sets back Moscow's privatization plans, the move was greeted with relief by analysts and investors here. The sale of 5.9 percent of Lukoil on the London Stock Exchange would have come at a time when markets in Europe and the United States are sliding and investors have been cool to new offerings. 
 The Russian government deliberated until late into the night on Wednesday, but then withdrew the offering, which was expected to raise some $700 million. Government officials indicated that the price being offered by large international investors was not high enough.
Shares of Lukoil rose 3 percent in trading in Moscow today.
"Everyone understands that this is not a proper time for privatization or any other sales," said Konstantin Reznikov, an oil and gas analyst with Alfa Bank, a Moscow-based brokerage firm. "The market conditions are terrible."
Indeed, analysts contrasted Wednesday's decision favorably to past efforts by the Russian government, which had often sold valuable assets on the cheap during the economic chaos of the 1990's. 
Vladimir Malin, the chairman of Russia's State Property Fund, was quoted by Bloomberg News as saying that the "time of privatizing Russian companies at any price is over."
The flagship privatization of Lukoil would have left the government with an 8 percent stake. It would have been the largest privatization since the sale of Onaco, another oil company, in 2000. 
"The government is pretty serious about protecting its own interests," said Kaha Kiknavelidze, an oil and gas analyst with Troika Diolog in Moscow. "That means stability in Russia. Russia does not need this privatization that badly this year."
Still, the Ministry of Finance has announced that this year's extra budget revenue would be only a third of the amount originally planned. 
"Russia is still running a surplus so it's not a disaster," said Roland Nash, head economist at Renaissance Capital, a brokerage firm in Moscow. "But they're becoming a bit less fiscally conservative."
Investors who had bid to buy the Lukoil shares said that they had not lost interest in the stock, and would buy when the government was finally ready to sell. 
Lukoil has also applied for a listing on the London Stock Exchange, which it expects to receive next week. It will be the first Russian company with a full listing on the London market. Investors will be able to convert their Russian shares into global depository receipts, which are easier to trade.
"On a 10-year view, this is one of the best investments you could make in Russia," said Ian Hague, a partner at Firebird Management L.L.C., a New York-based equity fund that had bid for Lukoil stock. 
Other Russian companies have also said they would hold back from selling stocks and bonds abroad any time soon. The Tyumen Oil Company recently put off a $500 million Eurobond sale.

HEADLINE: Car Sales in Surprise Jump, And G.M. Leads the Pack 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Car and truck sales in the United States rose a surprising 8.6 percent in July, largely because of aggressive incentives from automakers.
 The General Motors Corporation reinstated zero-percent financing early last month, a reprise of the incentives it offered after the Sept. 11 attacks. As a result, its combined car and truck sales led the industry, rising by 23.9 percent in July compared with figures for the month a year earlier. 
 Most of the increase came on the strength of truck sales, which posted a 36.7 percent increase. Preliminary figures indicated that higher sales pushed G.M.'s share of the United States car and truck market to 30 percent, a level it had not reached since February, said Paul Ballew, the chief industry sales analyst at G.M. 
"In the midst of a seemingly endless stream of negative economic and industry stories, the auto industry had positive results," Mr. Ballew said. "And there's no way to describe G.M.'s performance in July other than to say it was terrific."
He noted that two-thirds of G.M. buyers in July opted for no- or low-interest financing, a percentage that is higher than usual; most traded in vehicles made by other companies. The strong sales depleted inventories more than expected, prompting G.M. to increase production for the third quarter.
Other automakers followed G.M.'s lead on incentives by offering interest-free or low-interest financing in addition to cash rebates. But G.M. benefited most.
The Ford Motor Company said its car and truck sales rose 1.5 percent, its first year-over-year increase for 2002. In addition to financing incentives, Ford is offering rebates that are as high as $7,000 on the Lincoln Continental. Not counting sales from its Volvo, Jaguar and Land Rover import brands, however, Ford's sales were up a scant 0.7 percent.
Combined car and truck sales for the Chrysler Group, which offered zero-interest loans and a seven-year or 70,000-mile power-train warranty in early July, fell 4 percent.
Sales for the entire industry, which had lagged in recent months, were stronger than analysts and auto company executives had predicted. The increase translated into an annual selling rate of 18.1 million vehicles, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. Automakers sold 17.2 million vehicles in all of 2001.
"Economists are all doom and gloom, but American consumers are ignoring them and living their lives," said Ron Pinelli, an analyst at Autodata Inc. in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.. "They see a good deal on a car and they respond. Consumers went where the deals were."
Indeed, sales at Mitsubishi, on the strength of heavy incentives, soared 46.3 percent, its best single sales month ever. Toyota Motor, which is offering incentives of up to $1,300 a vehicle, had a sales increase of 4.6 percent for its best-ever July. Sales at its Lexus luxury division rose 4.5 percent. Honda said its sales rose 7.9 percent, and sales by its Acura division increased 1.6 percent. The rest of the imports had mixed results: BMW, Porsche, Hyundai, Kia and Suzuki had higher sales; Mercedes-Benz, which is awaiting the introduction of several vehicles, Volkswagen and its Audi division and Isuzu had lower sales. Subaru held steady.
The current round of no-interest financing and other incentives are scheduled to expire in late August and early September, but auto executives said they expected strong incentives to continue into the near future. Indeed, Mr. Ballew said G.M., which has led the incentive charge over the last year, would remain aggressive in the marketplace.
The incentives are making it possible for households to add more cars and trucks, leading to the higher-than-expected sales, said Gary Dilts, senior vice president for sales at the Chrysler Group. "The affordability index is the best it's been in 25 years," he said. 
Still, automakers acknowledge that they may be poaching sales from the future and warn that shaky consumer confidence and the roller-coaster stock market could hurt sales. Nonetheless, they predict that the industry will sell 16.5 million to 17 million vehicles in 2002 and about the same in 2003.

HEADLINE: U.S., in Shift, Says It Backs Latin Bailouts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Just days after suggesting that he would oppose new financial aid for battered South American economies, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill signaled today that the United States was now willing to back bailout plans for two of the hardest-hit nations, Brazil and Uruguay. But he pointedly left out a third, Argentina.
 Mr. O'Neill, whose comments on the financial troubles in Latin America over the last month have upset financial markets and set off a diplomatic tiff with Brazil, used a news conference here today to mend some fences. 
 Sticking carefully to scripted remarks, unlike many previous occasions, Mr. O'Neill praised Brazil and Uruguay for pursuing sound economic policies, and offered some encouragement but no new help to Argentina, whose economy fell into a swoon late last year after several years of economic struggles. The Treasury secretary leaves for a swing through South America on Sunday.
"I continue to favor support for Brazil and other nations that take appropriate steps to build sound, sustainable and growing economies," Mr. O'Neill said.
His comments suggested that the United States would not block Brazil's efforts to negotiate a new package of loans from the International Monetary Fund. Plagued by growing questions about its ability to repay all its debt, and with its currency plunging in value, Brazil -- South American's largest economy by far -- has struggled in recent weeks to avert a full-scale economic crisis.
Brazilian officials arrived in Washington this week for talks with the monetary fund. Thomas Dawson, the fund's spokesman, told reporters today that it was in negotiations on an "active, urgent basis."
The positive signals from the Treasury Department and the fund helped Brazil's currency stage a strong recovery today. The currency, the real, was up nearly 10 percent, after losing nearly a third of its value this year.
Mr. O'Neill said he planned to assure Uruguay that he would support new assistance to help reverse a sharp economic deterioration in that country. Thousands of workers staged a four-hour strike in Uruguay today, the third day in which banks there have been closed. 
"Uruguay deserves the ongoing support of the international financial community for its commitment to sound economic policy," he said.
But Mr. O'Neill offered no such assurances of support for Argentina, which the Bush administration views as having mishandled its economy. He hinted that the United States does not believe Argentina has yet taken all the necessary steps to bring its budget deficit, debt and currency under control.
Since taking office, the administration has looked skeptically on bailout packages for struggling nations, saying it is a waste of taxpayers' money to pour aid into nations that cannot, in the long run, repay all their debts.
It has been under increasing pressure, however, to help in Latin America, where after years of movement toward market economies and democracy there is a growing popular backlash against stringent economic policies.
The American stance toward the region's problems has been complicated by bad feelings set off by comments made on Sunday by Mr. O'Neill. Asked on Fox News Sunday about aid to the region, Mr. O'Neill said he would not be bringing any offers of help with him on his trip.
He said aid would be forthcoming only after Latin American nations could assure that the aid "doesn't just go out of the country to Swiss bank accounts."
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, enraged at the implication that his government was corrupt -- something Mr. O'Neill's office said he never meant to imply -- said he would not meet with Mr. O'Neill unless he retracted his statement, according to reports in the Brazilian news media. Brazil summoned the United States ambassador to lodge a protest.
The reaction from Brazil led the White House to offer conciliatory words on Tuesday, and Mr. O'Neill offered more today.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Economic Reports Are Disappointing, and Shares Plunge

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled yesterday as new economic data showed that manufacturing was weaker than expected in July and several companies reported disappointing earnings.
 But unlike a few weeks ago, the sharp drops in the three main stock market gauges came after a modest rally, which began on July 24, that led some analysts to say that stocks were near or at their bottom. So yesterday's declines may not be so worrisome if investors believe that the market is just bouncing around its bottom. 
 The news yesterday, however, provided reminders of the problems that led to the four-month sell-off that sent the stock market to a five-year low just more than a week ago. All three gauges added to their losses in late trading and finished just off their lows for the day. 
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 229.97 points, or 2.6 percent, to 8,506.62. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 26.96 points, or 3 percent, to 884.66. The Nasdaq composite index fell 48.26 points, or 3.6 percent, to 1,280.00.
Among the stocks leading the market lower were 3M, I.B.M., Microsoft, Cisco Systems, Wal-Mart and Citigroup.
Bond prices rose as the weaker economic data hinted at lower interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.39 percent from 4.47 percent on Wednesday. The price rose 19/32 , to 103 24/32 . The yield on the two-year note, which is particularly sensitive to economic growth expectations, dropped to 2.13 percent, a record low, from 2.25 percent on Wednesday.
The Institute for Supply Management said that its factory index fell to 50.5 in July from 56.2 in June, raising worries that the economy could slow significantly or even fall into another recession, just months after the previous one appeared to have ended. 
"It makes us nervous," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, referring to the new manufacturing data and a report on Wednesday that the economy grew at only a 1.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter. "We don't know if this is telling us this is a pothole and we will bounce back, or if this is some new retrenchment in the business community that will slow us down."
Mr. Glassman said that he was very surprised by the steep drop in the new orders component of the index. It plunged to 50.4 in July from 60.8 in June. A reading above 50 means there is still growth; a reading below 50 means a decline.
The arrests of the former chief financial officer and the former controller of WorldCom on fraud charges also focused investor attention on financial scandals. Some analysts expect more disclosures of accounting trouble before Aug. 14, the date set by the Securities and Exchange Commission for top executives to begin certifying the accuracy of company financial statements.
Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates, said there might have been "a period of corporate distraction" as senior executives studied their financial statements, which could explain the slowdown in July. But if not, he said, the cause could be a new credit squeeze, which would be much more damaging to the economy.
The 41 percent drop in second-quarter profit reported by Exxon Mobil is another sign that the strong rebound in corporate earnings that many analysts have forecast for the second half of the year may not materialize. Shares of Exxon Mobil fell $3.11, or 8.5 percent, to $33.65.
Even some of the positive news could still conjure up worries among investors. The Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, said that he supported additional financial aid for Brazil, which needs billions of dollars to help it meet its debt payments. Mr. O'Neill's comments are good news for Brazil but also underscore the shaky outlook for Latin America if assistance does not arrive soon.
The news that the Williams Companies, the troubled energy concern, will receive an infusion of $3.4 billion from loans and asset sales means the company could avoid bankruptcy. But it also reminds investors about how much trouble some energy companies are in.
The stock of the PG&E Corporation, the owner of California's biggest utility, plunged 30 percent after the company said that the credit rating of its subsidiary, PG&E National Energy Group, was cut to junk bond status by Standard & Poor's.
While Mr. Glassman said it was not yet clear how serious the threat of an economic slowdown is, he said that the new economic data was enough to make him consider changing J. P. Morgan's growth forecast for the second half of the year. That forecast calls for 4 percent growth at an annual rate. "You'd have to say that it is feeling right now like 2 percent to 3 percent," he said. --------------------

Manufacturing Sluggish
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Manufacturing grew more slowly in July, while construction spending in June fell to its lowest level in almost two years, according to two reports released today. A third report said that new claims for jobless benefits went up last week.
The Institute for Supply Management reported that its index of business activity dipped to 50.5 in July from 56.2 in June, a sign that manufacturing was growing sluggishly, although it was still the sixth consecutive month in which manufacturing activity increased. An index above 50 signifies growth in manufacturing. 
In another report, the Commerce Department said construction spending declined 2.2 percent in June from May. That pushed down the value of construction projects to $820.8 billion, the lowest since August 2000. 
In a Labor Department report, more Americans filed new claims for unemployment insurance last week. For the week ending July 27, new applications for job benefits rose by a seasonally adjusted 20,000 to 387,000. 
The more stable four-week moving average of claims, which smooths weekly fluctuations, edged up last week to 386,000. The moving average has been below the 400,000 mark, a level associated with weakness in the job market for seven weeks.

HEADLINE: With Unfinished Agenda, Congress Juggles Compromise and Confrontation 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Just a few days ago, the 107th Congress was racking up a string of unexpected achievements on corporate responsibility and trade despite divided party control. But the collapse of prescription drug legislation in the Senate showed that other issues remain stubbornly intractable.
 This conflicting impulse toward compromise on some issues and confrontation on others has been a hallmark of this Congress, which has come up with an unexpected list of accomplishments for both President Bush and the Democrats, yet still has a substantial unfinished agenda. In addition, there are powerful forces tugging in each direction as the midterm elections approach. 
 Republicans who control the House and the Democrats who run the Senate each have a symbiotic need to show voters that they have had legislative success. At the same time the two parties still have deep ideological differences on many issues that pull them apart, and the minority party in each house usually wants to see the majority fail.
As a result, the session -- which still has a bankruptcy agreement, pension protections, election overhaul, a domestic security department and spending bills in the balance -- might yet end in a burst of new legislation or a partisan implosion.
Many of the year's achievements have occurred when unexpected events overrode traditional divisions. The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 produced swift action on aviation security, on new powers for the nation's intelligence agencies and on a resolution empowering the president to use force in Afghanistan. Concern over the nation's vulnerability is still likely to produce legislation to create a domestic security department.
Similarly, the stock market meltdown and a string of corporate scandals propelled legislation to ensure more corporate accountability. "It just got to a crescendo of proportion that it couldn't be ignored by anybody," said Senator Jon Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey.
But this late in the Congressional session, with elections looming closer, a key to whether the jousting sides will want an achievement or a campaign issue can be found in the parties' election-year themes and how vulnerable each side feels when confronted with the attacks of the opposition.
"Politics is about offense and defense," said Carter Eskew, a former strategist for Al Gore, "and it's about choosing your moments."
With an eye to the fall elections, Democrats are keeping the issue of corporate malfeasance front and center and accusing Republicans of being the party of special interests and big business. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, stood today next to a teary WorldCom employee who had lost his job and life savings at age 57 and pledged that the Senate would begin a drive to pass pension protections in September. Mr. Daschle also asked why there had been no prosecutions in the Enron collapse.
Republicans are running against the Senate Democrats as obstructionists who must be removed from the majority in order to pass President Bush's agenda. Republican leaders handed out a report card today for Mr. Daschle that showed a string of "Incompletes."
"You know, in the classrooms of America, if you have a report card with this many 'Incompletes,' you're held back a grade," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader. "In this case, the solution is for the majority to be taken back and put into Republican hands."
To some extent, every issue is being judged by whether it furthers or blunts these two lines of argument.
Aware that there are pitfalls for their party from the jittery stock market and perceptions that the Bush administration is closely associated with corporate America, Republicans quickly sailed beyond the president to join Democrats in enacting tough measures to fight corporate malfeasance. 
President Bush then signed it into law with a White House ceremony that gave him joint ownership of the legislation -- somewhat to the frustration of Democrats who had pushed it forward. "I've seen conversions before," Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said wryly. "This is the biggest since Paul at Damascus."
Today, when Mr. Daschle spoke of the Senate's intent to take up a pension bill in September, Republicans let loose with a barrage of press releases saying the House had already passed such a measure. The National Republican Senatorial Committee, the party's Senate campaign arm, also sent all its campaign managers a long list of research showing Democratic ties to corporate interests that they could bring up on the stump.
The economy also drove Mr. Bush to make a renewed press for the trade negotiating authority that he called essential to bring in new trade deals to further growth. To win, Republican negotiators agreed to the kind of package of worker assistance, including a new health care entitlement, they had resisted in the past.
The prescription drug debate had a different dynamic. Aware that it would be a blow to his party not to pass a prescription drug benefit, Mr. Daschle devoted more than two weeks of debate to the issue and attempted a last-ditch compromise when the Democrats' measure could not get the 60 votes to prevail.
But Democrats and Republicans could not get beyond their profound philosophical difference over whether they want the program to be delivered through Medicare, a government program, or though insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.
Republicans used the Senate's failure to make the case that Mr. Daschle has not led. "Tom Daschle is either unwilling or unable to pass the legislation that Americans need," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip. 
The Democrats countered with their argument that the Republicans back special interests. "The Republicans cannot say no the drug companies," said Mr. Daschle, blaming them for the legislation's collapse.
Senator Gordon H. Smith, an Oregon Republican who had tried to broker a compromise, blamed both parties, saying, "In this place there is more emphasis on political ads than public policy this late in the Congressional session."
