HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
A World Of Sports, And Trouble

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
AVAILABLE until yesterday on the Web site of Andrei Medvedev, the Ukrainian tennis player, were several photos featuring the latest rogue in the unending Winter Olympics figure skating riddle, Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov.
 In one photo now making the rounds, Tokhtakhounov, who federal prosectuors have accused of being in Russian organized crime, sits all chummy with his arms around Medvedev and Marat Safin, along with Yevgeny Kafelnikov, who, like Safin, is Russian. 
 What does this suggest, or prove, in relation to the federal charges Wednesday that Tokhtakhounov is a fixer of the infamous Olympic pairs competition, beauty pageants and -- pardon the redundancy -- ice dancing? 
Nothing, nothing at all, but it should red flag us to see the bigger picture, the threat of intercontinental crime in a sports world without borders. 
We celebrate, with good reason, the globalization of our professional sports industries. Major League Baseball is stocked with Latin Americans and, increasingly, Asians. The National Hockey League is loaded with skilled Europeans. The National Basketball Association, after more than a decade of sending slam dunks abroad with the manifest mandate of a fast-food chain, is now experiencing the inevitable evolution.
Major League Soccer is a small subculture of many cultures. Women's leagues in basketball and soccer have opened up American shores to many an international professional. North America is where the big money is for professional skating tours, for those few Olympic heroes whom the public doesn't dispose of like a fortnight of old newspapers.
Above all, there is a reason why, since 1980, there have been four Olympics in the United States, and just one, for comparison's sake, in Russia. The center of the free-market universe beckons one and all, but when the world is invited to join us in sport, there is always a chance the underworld will come, too.
Many of our imported athletes are from countries with new and struggling free-market economies, with high unemployment and poverty rates, with mob activity that is loosely constrained, and some undoubtedly with ties to American organized crime. The athletes -- young, impressionable and vulnerable -- bring their own sets of baggage. 
In 1994, for instance, a Russian gangster admitted to trying to extort $150,000 from Alexander Mogilny, and it was feared that several other Russian players in the N.H.L. might have been involved in shakedown attempts. Soon after, Pavel Bure came under scrutiny for associations with a member of Russian organized crime.
"Organized crime in many of the countries these athletes are coming from pretty much operate without great resistance, probably more like it was in the States in the 1920's and 1930's," a sports executive who has worked around the world, including Russia, said yesterday. "There's a lot of betting on the games. Some of these places are so poor, they'll pretty much try anything they can."
Would Tony Soprano stoop to bribing skating judges? Trying to fix an ice dancing competition is like irrigating the ocean. Ice dancing, not a sport, should not even be in the Winter Olympics. What can you say that Tokhtakhounov got caught trying to corrupt the crooked? He was sloppy. The F.B.I., monitoring Tokhtakhounov for unrelated reasons, aided by the Italians, stumbled into our salacious winter scandal, into the court of Larry King. 
Most of the sniffs of American organized crime in sports have led nowhere. For decades, the feds have been unable to lay a glove on Don King. Stories of N.B.A. stars consorting with the mob were met with 20-minute internal investigations that seemed to satisfy all.
Sports executives would rather have Michelle Kwan skate across their tongues than admit to impropriety, much less the possibility of organized crime infiltration. At the first sign of turbulence, new I.O.C. President Jacques Rogge took the easy way out in Salt Lake City when he declared the pairs skating a draw, sending the French judge to the gulag, when he should have ordered a thorough restructuring of figure skating under the threat of suspension from the next Winter Games. 
His solution created more questions than it answered, as does Wednesday's arrest. All it tells us is that characters of questionable repute are out there -- in the ears of skating judges, on tennis Web sites, and who knows where? 
What is being done about it? In all likelihood, nothing.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: City Harassment Suit Settled 

BYLINE:  By Al Baker (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 A man who sued the city for what he considered harassment after he complained on television in 1997 about a traffic-ticket trap near the Bronx Zoo has settled the case for $290,000. The man, James E. Schillaci, was later arrested that year on a 13-year-old warrant for traffic violations. In his suit, Mr. Schillaci, now 55 and an unemployed limousine driver, contended that the arrest was city harassment and violated his civil rights. A federal judge has not yet filed the final dismissal order, said Michael L. Spiegel, Mr. Schillaci's lawyer. A city spokeswoman said the city admitted no wrongdoing but determined that settlement was in the city's best interest. Al Baker (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing Connecticut: Hartford: $812 Million Budget Deficit 

BYLINE:  AP (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Connecticut ended the last fiscal year $812 million in the red, State Comptroller Nancy Wyman, left, said yesterday. 
A drop in income tax revenue can be blamed for more than half of the deficit, as falling stock prices, job losses and a generally weak economy cut into people's personal incomes, she said. "The Sept. 11 attacks and recent revelations of corporate fraud added to the economic instability over the last fiscal year," Ms. Wyman said. State lawmakers and Gov. John G. Rowland reached a budget deal in June, agreeing to use the state's entire Rainy Day Fund to cover $595 million of the debt. They likely will borrow money to cover the remaining $217 million.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: National Semiconductor Reduces Forecast 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 National Semiconductor said yesterday that its first-quarter sales would rise less than forecast on reduced orders for chips used in personal computers and related peripherals. Shares fell in extended trading. 
Sales in the quarter ending Aug. 25 will be about the same as the fourth quarter's $419.5 million, the company said in a statement. The company said in June that first-quarter sales would increase from 6 percent to 8 percent from the previous quarter. In the first quarter a year ago, the company reported sales of $339.3 million. National Semiconductor's chips are used in a wide range of electronic devices, from PC's and cellphones to so-called Internet appliances that can use the Web. Consumers have cut purchases of such products on growing concern that the economy may not soon improve. "With everything else we're seeing in technology, it doesn't shock me," said James McBride, a fund manager at Kornitzer Capital Management, which has $2.5 billion under management including 399,305 National Semiconductor shares. "They were doing well and now" the economy and declining corporate and consumer spending on computers have caught up with them, he said. Shares of the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell as low as $15.97 in after-hours trading. They dropped 98 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $17.13 during regular trading.

HEADLINE: 10 Asian Nations Join With U.S. in Pledge to Fight Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Ten Southeast Asian nations joined the United States today in pledging to "prevent, disrupt and combat" global terrorism through increased sharing of information and intelligence, winding up a regional conference in Brunei at which North Korea and Washington took a first step toward renewed dialogue.
 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell signed the agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations before flying here for meetings with top Indonesian leaders on terrorism and military cooperation on Friday. The declaration commits a region that is battling extremist groups, including some with links to Al Qaeda, to strengthening counterterrorism training, exchanging financial and immigration data and working to create joint programs with the United States. "It's not a project; it's a base for projects," one senior American official said. 
 Some members of the group, known as Asean, had worried that the agreement could lead to an increased American troop presence in the region, where American forces have already helped the Philippines fight the Abu Sayaf guerrilla group.
But at a news conference, Secretary Powell said he did not expect that would be so. Instead, he called the agreement with Burma, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos and Malaysia "a political declaration" of mutual cooperation.
The diplomatic buzz centered on the sidelines conversation between Secretary Powell and the North Korean foreign minister, Paek Nam Sun, who met informally on Wednesday morning for a 15-minute chat to discuss renewed security talks.
The meeting was part of a series of recent overtures by the North to the United States, Japan and South Korea. Today, Mr. Paek told reporters in Brunei that the two countries had agreed to resume dialogue, and that the State Department's top Asian expert, Assistant Secretary James A. Kelly, would soon visit the North. But a senior American official said no such commitment had yet been made.
The social highlight of the Asean meetings is the final night's gala, at which delegations perform satirical songs and skits. Secretary Powell's offering revolved around his performance last year, when he sang the Marty Robbins ballad "El Paso" and wound up in a rolling death-clinch on the floor with Makiko Tanaka, then Japan's foreign minister.
As usual, journalists were barred from tonight's show. But Secretary Powell and his aides repeated their performance for reporters aboard his plane en route here, including an elaborate video in which his wife, Alma, begged him: "Do not embarrass the family again that way," and an aide impersonating a television reporter suggested that Secretary Powell might lose his job to the socially conscious rock star Bono.
Suddenly, President Bush himself appeared on screen, speaking into a phone saying: "Colin, we have to talk," and complaining how the Russians outdid Secretary Powell last year. When Secretary Powell tried to explain how busy he had been working on the Middle East and other diplomatic hot spots, the president cut him off: "Yeah, whatever. Look, Colin, we're a proud nation. I hired you to be the best. Start practicing. Colin, just don't let me down."
Senior State Department officials said that when Mr. Bush's face and voice appeared, the audience of foreign ministers and officials was briefly stunned, thinking the president might actually be on a live teleconference to the ballroom. Then they exploded in laughter.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 3; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 2278 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

Now Playing

"AUSTIN POWERS IN GOLDMEMBER," starring Mike Myers, Beyonce Knowles and Michael Caine. Directed by Jay Roach (PG-13, 90 minutes). This third installment of the "Austin Powers" franchise is a very funny shambles, embellished with amusing celebrity cameo bits that range from Steven Spielberg to the Osbournes, and jam-packed with clever puns and puerile double-entendres. But for all the fun it kicks up, the movie feels bloated and chaotic. Mr. Myers adds a dull fourth character, the villainous Goldmember, to a repertory that already includes Austin, Dr. Evil and Fat Bastard. Mr. Caine appears as Austin's suave, still-swinging father, the British master spy Nigel Powers, and Ms. Knowles of the pop group Destiny's Child is a Pam Grier parody named Foxxy Cleopatra. The movie recycles several of the most popular notions from the second "Austin" film, "The Spy Who Shagged Me," most notably a silhouette sequence that appears to be a bizarre autoerotic ritual. What holds it all together is the manic exuberance of Mr. Myers's imaginary world, which suggests a Pee-Wee's Playhouse for eternal adolescents (Stephen Holden).

"THE BOURNE IDENTITY," starring Matt Damon and Franka Potente. Directed by Doug Liman (PG-13, 113 minutes). Mr. Damon plays Jason Bourne, a C.I.A. superassassin with amnesia who is chased across Europe in the company of a charming German waif (Ms. Potente) by his employers. There are espionage writers who use the genre to explore the complexities of geopolitics, but Robert Ludlum, on whose novel this competent, enjoyable picture is based, was not one of them. At a time when thrillers are shadowed by real-world anxieties, the implausibility and irrelevance of this movie, which amusingly imagines the C.I.A. as a supercompetent, virtually omniscient operation, comes as something of a relief. Mr. Damon handles his character's existential crisis with fierce adroitness, and Mr. Liman's direction has an old-fashioned swiftness and efficiency (A. O. Scott).

"K-19: THE WIDOWMAKER," starring Harrison Ford and Liam Neeson. Directed by Kathryn Bigelow (PG-13, 138 minutes). Mr. Neeson and Mr. Ford play Soviet naval officers wrestling for control of a nuclear submarine -- with each other, and with the vessel itself, a malevolent embodiment of totalitarian hubris and bureaucratic incompetence. Ms. Bigelow, one of the best pure-action directors around, turns a sturdy, conventional script -- a hybrid of "Alien" and "Mutiny on the Bounty," with many nods to submarine movies of the past -- into a swift, tense drama of dueling egos and mechanical catastrophe (Scott).

"THE KID STAYS IN THE PICTURE," with Robert Evans. Directed by Brett Morgen and Nanette Burstein (R, 93 minutes). Mr. Evans's story of sauntering into the right place at the right time and still feeling underappreciated is the focus of this movie, in which he serves as star, subject and unreliable narrator. The documentary travels through Mr. Evans's days as a young actor to his sojourn as the head of Paramount Pictures, when the studio released a storied cluster of hits like "Rosemary's Baby" and "The Godfather." "There are three sides to every story: my side, your side and the truth," Mr. Evans intones, acknowledging his subjective take. But despite -- or perhaps because of -- his skewed viewpoint, this film succeeds (Elvis Mitchell).

"LIKE MIKE," starring Bow Wow, Eugene Levy and Morris Chestnut. Directed by John Schultz (PG, 100 minutes). A 13-year-old orphan named Calvin (Bow Wow) turns around the fictional Los Angeles Knights pro basketball team, courtesy of a pair of magic sneakers that he finds. Calvin's new powers are observed when he wins a chance to shoot against a spoiled N.B.A. star during a halftime stunt. Naturally, he's asked to join the team. The successful kid rapper Bow Wow is a talented actor whose boyish eagerness here is a marked contrast to his taciturn rappadocio. The director's breezy steadiness keeps the movie from hitting us over the head -- well, not too hard, anyway, no small feat since the steroid-juiced sentimentality of the ending may force some to flee before the outtakes unspool under the credits (Mitchell).

* "LOVELY AND AMAZING," starring Catherine Keener, Brenda Blethyn, Dermot Mulroney and Emily Mortimer. Written and directed by Nicole Holofcener (R, 91 minutes). This smart, acidic comedy by the director of "Walking and Talking" could be described as a West Coast answer to "Sex and the City," minus that series' high-gloss glamour and erotic joie de vivre. Ms. Keener and Ms. Mortimer are sisters, both attractive and in their 30's, who have major self-esteem problems and poor taste in men. Ms. Blethyn is their vain mother who develops complications after liposuction. The movie zeroes in on contemporary narcissism with a relentless, needling accuracy that illustrates exactly the way some people allow their insecurities to poison their intimate relationships. But once it has limned its characters (Ms. Keener's is by far the most vivid), it doesn't go anywhere in particular (Holden).

"MEN IN BLACK II," starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Rip Torn, Rosario Dawson and Tony Shalhoub. Directed by Barry Sonnenfeld (PG-13, 82 minutes). If your memory of the first one is a little hazy, don't worry: that was the point all along. And, in any case, this sequel provides the same pleasant, pointless mixture of whimsy and kineticism. Of course, like the "Ghostbusters" and "Austin Powers" sequels (to give only two out of several thousand possible examples), the fun has diminished because the novelty has worn off. Mr. Smith and Mr. Jones coast along, joined by Mr. Torn and Mr. Shalhoub (and a talking bulldog) from "Men in Black," and a host of creepy, scaly, funny aliens, including Ms. Boyle, her icy charms enhanced by hundreds of slimy tentacles and an extendable green tongue (Scott).

* "METROPOLIS," starring Rudolf Klein-Rogge, Gustav Frohlich and Brigitte Helm. Directed by Fritz Lang (not rated, 120 minutes). Lang's silent modernist fever dream -- a nightmarish grand opera of romantic love, alienated labor and technological power -- is one of the most studied and imitated films of all time, and has been reissued many times. Except for a brief theatrical run in 1927, though, the movie as Lang made it has never been seen. This latest version, the result of a four-year restoration project using archival materials and new digital techniques, may not be the director's cut, but it is as definitive a "Metropolis" as we are likely to see. The new 35-millimeter print is beautiful, the score has been newly recorded, and Lang's swirling, visionary stew of Christian symbolism, Expressionist set design and political anxiety is more grand and troubling than ever (Scott).

"MINORITY REPORT," starring Tom Cruise and Colin Farrell. Directed by Steven Spielberg (PG-13, 140 minutes). This atmospheric new thriller is a muscular and dense exercise of skill and verve. (Ironically, this exercise may be the most adult film that Mr. Spielberg has made in some time; it's about the bloody blurring of passion and violence -- a compassionate noir.) In 2054, a law enforcement unit called Pre-Crime exists to stop murders before they begin; three Pre-Cogs -- beings who float in a nutrient-rich fluid -- can predict when a crime will be committed and know the identity of the perpetrator. When the unit's chief, John Anderton, is accused of a crime he hasn't yet committed, he's soon on the run. Mr. Cruise does as much sprinting in this picture as he has in his entire filmography. The fluid bursts of quick-cut images seen on the monitors also show that Mr. Spielberg isn't about to be shown up by those quick-fingered, compulsively exhibitionistic upstarts like David Fincher. With "Minority Report" he toys with the idea that there's more -- and less -- to Mr. Cruise than meets the eye and says we shouldn't trust our eyes anyway. But doesn't he always? (Mitchell).

"MR. DEEDS," starring Adam Sandler and Winona Ryder. Directed by Steven Brill (PG-13, 91 minutes). It could be said that the remake of Frank Capra's "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," starring Mr. Sandler in the title role, is redundant, since the actor has been remaking Capraesque movies for most of his career. As in Capra's original 1936 classic, Longfellow Deeds still lives in Mandrake Falls, is an aspiring greeting-card poet and has no patience for pretension. And once again, he is left a fortune by a distant relative: adjusted for inflation, the amount is $40 billion instead of $20 million. He's taken to New York, where he'll presumably be enticed by the city. Mr. Sandler's films are always about the arrogant getting a deserved comeuppance at the hands of humbler types, but this is the first time he seems a little smug himself. "Mr. Deeds" has him rehashing a role he has performed so many times before he could be doing this picture in his sleep. The result is likely to be that he'll put audiences to sleep (Mitchell).

* "ROAD TO PERDITION," starring Tom Hanks, Paul Newman and Jude Law. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 119 minutes). This solemn, rain-washed period gangster film based on a graphic novel is a cool but stately work that achieves the grandeur of a classic Hollywood western. An exploration of father-son relationships viewed largely through the eyes of a 12-year-old boy, it follows the fugitive journey of Michael Sullivan (Mr. Hanks), a hit man for the mob outside Chicago, who flees the wrath of the middle-level boss (Mr. Newman) who is also his surrogate father. Filled with memorable tableaus, the movie is a serious picture show whose cinematography by Conrad L. Hall lends every frame an Edward Hopper-like mood. Mr. Newman (with an Irish brogue) steals the movie as Rooney, the mob boss faced with agonizing life-and-death choices. Mr. Hanks holds his own as the movie's enigmatic antihero on a vengeful mission: a killer-for-hire with a social conscience and a devotion to his young son (Holden).

"SCOOBY-DOO," starring Freddie Prinze Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar. Directed by Raja Gosnell (PG, 105 minutes). The old Hanna-Barbera cartoon was cheap, silly and occasionally charming in its blithe stupidity. This adaptation, combining live action with 3-D computer-generated animation, looks pretty expensive, and its stupidity is, for the most part, charmless. The human cast -- Mr. Prinze, especially -- does a good-humored job of sending up and paying homage to the old show, but its efforts are overwhelmed by a relentless pop music score, hideous special effects and a plot that violates all the rules of the old series for no good reason (Scott).

* "STUART LITTLE 2," with Geena Davis and Hugh Laurie and the voices of Michael J. Fox, Melanie Griffith and Nathan Lane. Directed by Rob Minkoff (PG, 72 minutes). Determinedly unhip and utterly engaging, the sequel to "Stuart Little" (based on E. B. White's classic children's book) is even better than the original. Once again, the blend of live action and animation is virtually seamless. The characters are more sharply drawn than before, the newest addition being a duplicitous jewel-thieving bird (voice of Ms. Griffith) under the thumb of an evil falcon (James Woods). The role of the spoiled family housecat Snowbell (Mr. Lane) has been beefed up, and Mr. Lane turns the character's every peevish complaint into an amusing comic barb. The zesty action sequences find Stuart tooling wildly around New York and doing battle with the falcon in a model airplane. This is one family film franchise that respects the innocence of childhood without becoming saccharine (Holden).

* "SUNSHINE STATE," starring Edie Falco, Angela Bassett and Mary Alice. Written and directed by John Sayles (PG-13; 141 minutes). Mr. Sayles's panoramic exploration of life in Delrona Beach, a fictional Florida coastal town in the throes of development, is as rich and even-handed a mosaic of American life as any filmmaker has brought to the screen. The overlapping stories revolve around two families, one white, the other black, who are being pressured to sell their property to greedy developers. Among more than a dozen characters who cross paths in the course of the story, the most compelling are Marly Temple (Ms. Falco), a sardonic young woman who runs her family's motel, and Desiree Perry (Ms. Bassett), a former teenage rebel who returns after a 25-year absence to confront her straitlaced mother (Ms. Alice). More than a probing civics lesson, the movie takes the political and spiritual pulse of our restless national psyche (Holden).

* "TADPOLE," starring Sigourney Weaver, Aaron Stanford, John Ritter and Bebe Neuwirth. Directed by Gary Winick (PG-13, 77 minutes). At its most evocative, this fragile wisp of a movie with its moody, hothouse New York atmosphere suggests a contemporary descendant of "The Catcher in the Rye." Its protagonist (Mr. Stanford) is an intellectually precocious 15-year-old preppie who fancies himself in love with his 40-something stepmother (Ms. Weaver), who is unaware of his passion. A casual sexual encounter with her best friend (Ms. Neuwirth) over Thanksgiving break leads to an attempted cover-up that resembles a sophisticated French farce. Ms. Neuwirth practically steals the movie as the kindhearted but libidinous chiropractor with whom he enjoys a one-night stand. For all its delicate charms, the movie, shot in two weeks, is ragged around the edges and has a slack cynical ending (Holden).

HEADLINE: Dubya's Double Dip? 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
If the story of the current U.S. economy were made into a movie, it would look something like "55 Days at Peking." A ragtag group of ordinary people -- America's consumers -- is besieged by a rampaging horde, the forces of recession. To everyone's surprise, they have held their ground. 
 But they can't hold out forever. Will the rescue force -- resurgent business investment -- get there in time? 
 The screenplay for that kind of movie always ratchets up the tension. The besieged citadel fends off assault after assault, but again and again rescue is delayed. And so it has played out in practice. Consumers kept spending as the Internet bubble collapsed; they kept spending despite terrorist attacks. Taking advantage of low interest rates, they refinanced their houses and took the proceeds to the shopping malls.
But predictions of an imminent recovery in business investment keep turning out to be premature. Most businesses are in no hurry to go on another spending spree. And those that might have started to invest again have been deterred by sliding stock prices, widening bond spreads and revelations about corporate scandal.
Will the rescuers arrive in the nick of time? Not necessarily. This movie may not be "55 Days at Peking" after all. It may be "A Bridge Too Far." 
A few months ago the vast majority of business economists mocked concerns about a "double dip," a second leg to the downturn. But there were a few dogged iconoclasts out there, most notably Stephen Roach at Morgan Stanley. As I've repeatedly said in this column, the arguments of the double-dippers made a lot of sense. And their story now looks more plausible than ever.
The basic point is that the recession of 2001 wasn't a typical postwar slump, brought on when an inflation-fighting Fed raises interest rates and easily ended by a snapback in housing and consumer spending when the Fed brings rates back down again. This was a prewar-style recession, a morning after brought on by irrational exuberance. To fight this recession the Fed needs more than a snapback; it needs soaring household spending to offset moribund business investment. And to do that, as Paul McCulley of Pimco put it, Alan Greenspan needs to create a housing bubble to replace the Nasdaq bubble. 
Judging by Mr. Greenspan's remarkably cheerful recent testimony, he still thinks he can pull that off. But the Fed chairman's crystal ball has been cloudy lately; remember how he urged Congress to cut taxes to head off the risk of excessive budget surpluses? And a sober look at recent data is not encouraging.
On the surface, the sharp drop in the economy's growth, from 5 percent in the first quarter to 1 percent in the second, is disheartening. Under the surface, it's quite a lot worse. Even in the first quarter, investment and consumer spending were sluggish; most of the growth came as businesses stopped running down their inventories. In the second quarter, inventories were the whole story: final demand actually fell. And lately straws in the wind that often give advance warning of changes in official statistics, like mall traffic, have been blowing the wrong way. 
Despite the bad news, most commentators, like Mr. Greenspan, remain optimistic. Should you be reassured?
Bear in mind that business forecasters are under enormous pressure to be cheerleaders: "I must confess to being amazed at the venom my double dip call still elicits," Mr. Roach wrote yesterday at cbsmarketwatch.com. We should never forget that Wall Street basically represents the sell side. 
Bear in mind also that government officials have a stake in accentuating the positive. The administration needs a recovery because, with deficits exploding, the only way it can justify that tax cut is by pretending that it was just what the economy needed. Mr. Greenspan needs one to avoid awkward questions about his own role in creating the stock market bubble. 
But wishful thinking aside, I just don't understand the grounds for optimism. Who, exactly, is about to start spending a lot more? At this point it's a lot easier to tell a story about how the recovery will stall than about how it will speed up. And while I like movies with happy endings as much as the next guy, a movie isn't realistic unless the story line makes sense.

HEADLINE: Stock Exchange Abandons Plans for a New Headquarters Building Across the Street 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the exchange was abandoning plans to build a new headquarters building across the street from its historic site at 11 Wall Street, effectively ending a deal that was aggressively pursued by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
 But the chairman, Richard A. Grasso, added that the exchange was considering constructing a second trading floor within New York State but outside Lower Manhattan. Though it has not settled on a location yet, Mr. Grasso said the new site would be either within the five boroughs of New York City or elsewhere within the state. 
 Tension rose between the city and the exchange after the Bloomberg administration asked in May that the stock exchange double its investment in the plan for the new trading complex, to $900 million. The higher investment was required, administration officials said, because the proposed project would cost taxpayers too much.
The new site will be used simultaneously with the current floor, splitting the exchange's operations between two sites for the first time. 
"We are looking in the five boroughs as well as outside the five boroughs," Mr. Grasso said at a news conference yesterday. "It's important for me not to create a vision that we are about to drop anchor somewhere else."
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said in a statement: "I can't imagine the New York Stock Exchange would abandon New York City in its moment of need. We remain hopeful that the stock exchange will stay on Wall Street, but should they insist on splitting up their operations, we have offered them many viable alternatives throughout the city."
After it was reported on July 24 that the stock exchange was considering moving some operations to Westchester County, Mr. Bloomberg said doing so would "let the terrorists win" by damaging the city's economy. Mr. Bloomberg said that "Brooklyn and Queens make an awful lot more sense" than Westchester for a new stock exchange location. 
The exchange's deal with New York City, which Mr. Giuliani tried to complete in his last days in office, had attracted criticism from some community and civic groups. The deal would have provided more than $1 billion in land, cash, tax breaks and other subsidies, making it one of the city's largest deals to keep a single company from leaving.
Originally, the plan had been for a 50-story tower to be built over the new trading complex. Rental income from the tower would have provided the city with the money to offset the cost of acquiring the property.
But after Sept. 11, Mr. Grasso considered that idea too risky. Apparently afraid that a tall tower connected to the stock exchange would be too easy a target for terrorists, Mr. Grasso said the previous deal was "not a saleable transaction."
Bettina Damiani, a project director at Good Jobs New York, a budget watchdog group that opposed the deal, said yesterday that the stock exchange pact "represented all that's wrong with corporate subsidies in New York." She said the deal was forged largely in secret and had already cost the city millions of dollars. "Kudos to Mr. Bloomberg for standing up to them," she said.
Under the 1998 deal with the Giuliani administration, the city committed to buying the block bound by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place, at an estimated cost of $450 million.
The city is paying $3 million a month to hold onto the land for the project, has agreed to pay $160 million for an apartment building on the site, and made a $22 million down payment on the $220 million purchase of an office building at 23 Wall Street.
City officials would not comment last night on the status of the agreement to buy those buildings.

HEADLINE: Trash Plan Alters Mix Of Winners And Losers 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Garbage in New York City has always been about pain and gain. Some residents and neighborhoods are plagued by stink and noise and the other irksome effluvia of trash collection. Others see only clean streets, with the clanking machinery of transport and disposal all but invisible. 
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to refashion the system with giant trash compactors and barge-transport docks in each borough would reshuffle the winners and losers in New York's garbage game -- perhaps by a little, perhaps by a lot -- sanitation experts, environmentalists and city officials say. 
 The final tally of winners and losers and how much really changes depends on the many questions that remain about how the system would work, and whether it would work at all, the experts say.
On the surface, the winners look easy enough to spot. The system, once complete, would eliminate the need for truck-based transfer stations and the diesel exhaust that residents and environmentalists say have fouled neighborhoods like Williamsburg in Brooklyn, the South Bronx and Jamaica, Queens. Staten Island would be spared any hint of reopening the Fresh Kills landfill, which absorbed all the city's trash for decades before closing last year. The system of transfer stations would also be operated by the city -- not private contractors, as a previous plan called for -- thus signifying a victory for municipal workers.
Losers include Manhattan, which the Sanitation Department under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had found unsuitable for trash compacting because of space constraints at its three transfer stations. At least two of the three might have to absorb some nearby property to make the system work, say city officials and other people familiar with the sites. 
But the things that might not change at all are just as interesting. 
A plan devised by the Giuliani administration, for example, to ship more than half of the city's residential trash to Linden, N.J., for train transport was declared formally dead under the Bloomberg plan, which was announced on Wednesday.
But the Linden plan might live again. A spokesman for Allied Waste Industries, which was to operate the plant, said Linden would still be attractive, if only for its rail connections, and would probably be an element of Allied's bid to take the containers being packed in New York.
Some trash might also eventually find its way once again to a part of the city that nearly mutinied over garbage a decade ago, Staten Island. 
Although Staten Island officials say they have been promised by the Bloomberg administration that the borough will never again be formally designated by the city as a collection point for trash -- private companies, wherever they are, would be allowed to compete for contracts to transport the containers.
Both the mayor and the Staten Island borough president, James P. Molinaro, said, for instance, that if the Howland Hook Container Terminal, a big cargo handler not far from Fresh Kills, wanted to bid for some of the work -- loading the containers for transport out of the city by ocean-going barge, or perhaps eventually by rail -- it could.
Mr. Molinaro said that sealed containers would present no environmental insult or offense to residents and that jobs for the port were worth fighting for.
"If Howland Hook wanted to bid and won the bid, God bless 'em," he said.
The huge volume of commercial waste generated in New York, most of which comes from Manhattan's offices, restaurants and hotels, is another unknown that could tilt the winners-and-losers list. The city's sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, and Mr. Bloomberg both said they wanted to explore the possibility of having the retrofitted stations take residential trash -- their primary function -- and commercial waste too, which is disposed of by private companies using fleets of trucks.
If the new stations in Manhattan cannot be made big enough or efficient enough to take both kinds of garbage, however, the current system that so many people hate -- truck-based transfer stations in the poorer parts of Brooklyn and Queens -- could be here to stay, some experts say.
On the other hand, if the Manhattan stations could be adapted to take commercial trash, Mr. Doherty said, it might only be possible by operating around the clock, which would be another chit on the loser list for Manhattan, since that would mean more trucks coming and going. At the 91st Street site on the East River, which is one of the smallest of the city's transfer stations, the truck approach road goes right by a playground and recreation area called Asphalt Green that was filled with children yesterday. 
"If the best they can do is squeeze in just enough for the residential, then you've locked in a truck-based system for commercial waste in perpetuity," said Tom Outerbridge, a senior vice president of the Port Ivory Recycling and Transfer Alliance, which has proposed a large compacting facility in Staten Island, and so has economic reasons for questioning the mayor's plan.
Most environmental groups had kind words for the mayor, because his plan would reduce truck traffic, and because, they said, it would be fairer to poor parts of the city where the truck stations are now concentrated. But they said they were disappointed there was no formal link between fixing the export problem and restoring the recycling system, which was suspended for glass and plastic last month because of budget cuts. Without recycling, they said, the long-term volume of trash will only grow, whether the new system works or not.
"The community groups are clearly the winners here, but from an overall policy view, the plan falls short in that it doesn't incorporate a means of reducing the trash flow," said David Higby, the solid waste project director for Environmental Advocates, an Albany conservation group.

HEADLINE: Senate Grants Bush Authority On Trade Deals 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
The Senate agreed today not to interfere in trade deals negotiated by the White House, giving final approval to an accord requested by two presidents over eight years. Bush administration officials said they would immediately use the long-sought authority to accelerate trade talks stalled for years by partisan differences.
 In a last vote before leaving Washington's heat for an August recess, senators from both parties voted 64 to 34 to give President Bush the negotiating authority that members of Congress had denied to President Clinton for much of his tenure. Last week, a more divided House of Representatives agreed to the same bill, which now goes to the White House for the president's signature. 
 A majority of Democrats voted against the bill, and some senators expressed strong reservations about the effect that liberalized trade would have on the jobs of American workers. But after House and Senate negotiators agreed last week to include a package of subsidized health insurance and job-training benefits for workers who lose their jobs to foreign competition, 20 Democrats joined 43 Republicans and one independent to give the Bush administration what it wanted.
The trade promotion authority, formerly known as the fast-track process, means that Congress has agreed not to change any deal the administration makes with a country or trading bloc. The five-year agreement, however, does not give the executive branch quite the free hand that presidents had before the last fast-track law expired in 1994.
Under the bill passed today, Congress can still veto any deal -- and many members said they hoped to do so if an agreement jeopardized American jobs -- but the administration can negotiate without fear that the details will later be changed.
"This gets us off the sidelines, where we've been for years, and gives us the opportunity to go on offense," said Donald L. Evans, the secretary of commerce, exultant at one of the administration's most decisive victories. "If you don't have the authority to negotiate, it's awfully hard to deliver an agreement."
President Bush, calling the action a "historic moment," congratulated supporters of the bill in a conference call after the vote.
"What you all have done is you have made it much more likely somebody is going to be able to find work, some farmer is going to be to sell his product," he said.
But opponents said that while the bill might be good for exporters, it could be damaging to textile and other manufacturing employees who will be undercut by foreigners who work for lower wages. Several senators said they were not satisfied that foreign trading partners would not employ child labor or abide by environmental standards, and others said that American negotiators have allowed countries to impose unfair tariffs that keep American products out of their markets.
"Every pound of T-bone steak that goes into Japan has a tariff on it, a 38.5 percent tariff," said Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, a major beef-producing state. "And this is after our negotiators reached agreement with them. Do our ranchers have a complaint? I think so, I believe so. Because the trade circumstances with respect to beef in Japan are not fair, and everyone knows it."
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said that the first trade agreements likely to be completed were with Chile and Singapore, possibly by the end of the year. The administration also hopes to have agreements with five Central American countries -- Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala -- by the end of Mr. Bush's term, he said. 
By 2005, he said, negotiators hope to complete work on the 34-nation Free Trade Area of the Americas, a plan first put forward in 1994 to integrate most of the economies of North and South America into a single free-trade bloc. It is similar in concept to the NAFTA agreement with Mexico and Canada. President Bush also wants an agreement soon with Morocco, in hopes of supporting its economic and political reforms, Mr. Zoellick said.
Although the final bill dropped the Senate proposal allowing a Congressional veto over any weakening of laws prohibiting the dumping of foreign goods, it does require the administration to consult with Congress on such laws, and theoretically allows Congress to halt any deal under negotiation. But both sides said they believed the bill would actually result in a closer relationship between the White House and Congress on trade issues.
"Given the trust in this delegation of authority to the administration," said Max Baucus, a Democratic trade supporter from Montana, "Congress expects the administration to honor and respect that trust by working closely with members on these issues."

HEADLINE: California Examines Ways to Manage Energy 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif. 

 BODY:
Two years after electricity shortages sent prices soaring and blackouts rolling across the state, California, the standard-bearer for power deregulation gone wrong, is just beginning to figure out how its power market will operate beyond the next few months.
 In mid-July, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission disclosed its new plan for the wholesale power market in the Western states. On Wednesday, the commission released its broader-reaching recommendations for markets nationwide. 
 In California, the commission will continue to control bids to supply power, which it began doing last summer during the state's energy crisis. After Sept. 30, the ceiling on bids will rise to $250 a megawatt-hour from $91.87. 
The commission adopted other measures that it said would prevent generating companies from withholding power to inflate California prices, but some doubted the commission's ability to control market players. Representative Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon, the ranking Democrat on the House Resources subcommittee on water and power, called the new rules arcane and the commission "toothless" for its lack of authority to punish wrongdoers with fines.
The commission also recommended a change in management at the Independent System Operator, the nonprofit company that runs California's grid and oversees power trading, to further separate control from the state. Experienced managers from fields like banking and communications, as well as energy, should be members of a new governing board for the operator, said Nora Mead Brownell, one of the commissioners. The current board consists of a staff member from the governor's office, a lawyer from a consumer lobby, the president of an association of Silicon Valley manufacturers and is headed by Michael A. Kahn, a top litigator who is an ally of the governor.
California policy makers frowned on the commission's initial ruling. In a statement issued on July 17, Gov. Gray Davis decried the higher price limits. "California has been buying all the power it needs this year in the $20-to-$50 range on the spot market," Governor Davis, a Democrat, said. "The price caps make no sense and this order just invites more mischief by energy generators."
Mr. Kahn said the commission's orders "do a disservice to the people of California and could cost consumers billions of dollars." He asserted that changes in the governing board were unnecessary and potentially harmful and that, on balance, federal regulators had offered proposals that would weaken protections against market manipulation. In its ruling in mid-July, the commission rejected the Independent System Operator's proposal for a mechanism to impose stricter controls when power prices appeared to differ strongly from costs of generating electricity.
Mr. Kahn also called the commission rash for insisting on changes before the utilities recover from their financial straits and the state's long-term contracts for power expire. "Obviously, the cloud of the generators in Washington, and the Bush administration, is so strong that they had to do this quickly and precipitously," he said.
The reaction from power generating companies struck a sharp contrast. "The governance issue is probably the single most important," said Steve Huhman, a director of regulatory affairs for one energy company, the Mirant Corporation. "At least, we'll feel that the decisions are justified by science and not by politics."
The commission gave generating companies another victory by requiring California to create incentives for generating and transmitting companies to build new capacity in high-demand and bottleneck areas on the electricity grid. Nationwide recommendations from the commission included similar provisions.
In releasing its proposed rules for wholesale power markets, the commission focused on what it said were the advantages of using one system for the whole country: less possibility of manipulation and more access to cheap power for customers in underserved areas. 
But not everyone who watched the West's crisis unfold thinks that the new rules will work. "They know we have a dysfunctional system," Mr. DeFazio said. "They're going to attempt to layer a hugely complicated market-based system on top of that to solve the problems in the current market-based system. I fear that it will be more manipulable, more volatile, because of the changes."
With the future of the wholesale market in California somewhat clearer, the state government is left to work with utilities to ensure that reasonable retail rates accompany a constant surplus of power.
Economists have argued that customers would have to face more realistic prices for power. During the state's power crisis, California's utilities ran up huge debts because they could not pass wholesale price spikes on to bill payers. Making retail prices more flexible, these economists argue, would encourage consumers to use electricity sparingly at peak times. 
But there is a crucial corollary, said Frank A. Wolak, a professor of economics at Stanford University and chairman of the market surveillance committee for the Independent System Operator. Mr. Wolak wants consumers to have two options: to buy power by the hour at close-to-market prices or to protect themselves against volatile prices by contracting for kilowatt-hours in advance.
How would consumers figure out exactly how much power they might need for the next month, six months or a year? 
"You're going to have to be a bit more intelligent about your energy consumption," he said. "But just like with your cellphone minutes, you're going to have to say, 'O.K., I'll get it pretty close to right.' "
The commission's newly proposed rules would encourage long-term contracts between generating companies and utilities, but utilities will have to decide whether to make such contracts available to consumers.
Robert D. Glynn Jr., chairman of the PG&E Corporation, which owns one of California's three giant utilities, agrees with Professor Wolak on the need for forward markets, but he doubts that real-time pricing for consumers is realistic.
"I've never believed," Mr. Glynn said, "that there's going to be a person or a group or a family sitting on a sofa watching a TV show, and up in the corner of the screen is a little meter, and someone jumps up and says, 'Look, the power price has just dropped, let's turn the washer on.' "
Yet of the two strategies, real-time pricing looks more likely to become a reality than allowing consumers to buy power in advance, said Paul Clanon, the director of the energy division of the Public Utilities Commission. That would still leave consumers vulnerable to short-term volatility in power prices.
With much unresolved in the market, generating companies are biding their time before committing to building enough new plants to ensure that California can keep prices in check.
"With all these things that have been going on out here, any rational investor is going to think twice," Mr. Huhman said. "Clearly we need to see a more stabilized environment and know what the risks are."
Governor Davis has spent plenty of time in his campaign for re-election emphasizing the 6,400 megawatts in new capacity that generating companies have built during his term, thanks in part to the lucrative long-term contracts. The federal commission, however, pointed out in its ruling that plans for 20,000 megawatts of capacity had been canceled or delayed since January 2000. 
New plants have given the state enough capacity for the next few years, said Severin Borenstein, director of the Energy Institute at the University of California. The respite will not last, though.
"Over any multiyear time period, California depends on the creation of new power supplies every year," he said. "It is important that there be projects coming through the queue."
Elena Schmid, the vice president for corporate and strategic development of the Independent System Operator, conceded that California needed to settle its plans for the future before the new capacity would appear.
"The environment in California now is not an inviting environment for people to come in," she said. But she remained hopeful that the problems were being sorted out, if slowly.
"You can't live through what we've lived through and not learn something," she said.

HEADLINE: Employment Data Raise Questions About Economic Recovery 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Determined to hold down labor costs in a weak and uncertain economy, the nation's employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to a bare minimum, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
 The latest data raised fresh questions about the faltering economic recovery, suggesting that growth will be modest at best. 
 The unemployment rate remained at 5.9 percent, the same as June, as 86,000 people who might have been listed as unemployed and job hunting dropped out of the labor force instead. The number of temporary workers, which had been growing in earlier months and usually rises as the economy is beginning to improve, shrank in July. 
Total employment, based on a survey of companies, rose a bare 6,000 -- an almost imperceptible gain. Still, July was the third consecutive month in which employment went up instead of down.
"The real question I have is whether the labor market is beginning to turn around or whether the stock market will short-circuit that process," said William Dudley, director of domestic research at Goldman Sachs. "Alongside the net hiring in July, there were more than enough signs that were disturbing."
Employers cut the average workweek by an unusually large three-tenths of an hour, to a flat 34 hours. Not since the Labor Department began to track the average workweek in 1964 has it been as short, except in two unusual months: January of 1996 when a blizzard struck the East Coast, and October of last year, in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
The glum labor report, which helped send the stock market down again, came as a number of economists moved from expecting a strong recovery in the second half of the year to concern that the economy might face a longer period of weak growth. Reinforcing that impression, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders fell sharply in June, indicating a setback in industrial output after several months of improvement.
Consumers, however, continued to sustain the recovery, as they have for months. Their spending rose in June by the largest amount in two years and personal incomes increased by a similarly smart amount, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
But here, too, the signals were mixed. While the Commerce Department's report covers an array of personal income, even counting as income the health insurance premiums that companies pay on behalf of their employees, the Labor Department focuses only on the average hourly wage of the nation's 90 million workers outside the ranks of management. It rose in July by 4 cents, to $14.79 an hour, but from a 12-month perspective, the annual increase through July was 3.2 percent. That has edged down from 4 percent in January. 
Manufacturers, construction companies and state and local governments all shed workers -- a total of 53,000, seasonally adjusted -- but none as many as the temporary help industry. There, employment declined by 35,000.
As the economy recovers from recession, employers often hire temporary workers before committing themselves to permanent hires, and that had seemed to be happening. Until July, temporary employment had risen for four consecutive months, a total increase of 145,000 jobs. The setback last month made a considerable dent in that gain.
"If the August employment report turns out to be similar to July's, we would be worried that the economy was at best in a sideways waffle," said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis forecasting and research firm. 
By that, he meant an annual growth rate for the economy of 1 percent or less, far below the 3 percent or more that most economists consider necessary to generate jobs month after month and keep unemployment from rising. The government reported on Wednesday that overall economic activity in the second quarter advanced at an annual rate of just 1.1 percent, down from a 5 percent rate in the first quarter.
The Bush administration gave the July job numbers an optimistic interpretation. "The good news is that July's unemployment rate was essentially unchanged from the previous month," the secretary of labor, Elaine L. Chao, said in a statement. She also said that long-term unemployment -- people out of work and collecting jobless pay for 15 weeks or more -- had declined in July "after rising continuously for more than a year."
But several of Wall Street's forecasters saw enough bad news in the employment report to predict, for the first time, that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates by the end of the year. Until now, they have argued that the Fed would probably postpone a rate increase until late in the year, when they expected the economy to be growing strongly enough to make it necessary for the Fed to begin moving to keep inflation under control.
Economists at Goldman Sachs even went so far as to predict yesterday that before the end of the year the Fed would cut the key short-term rate it controls by three-quarters of a percentage point, to only 1 percent. "The economy is growing well below trend," Mr. Dudley said. "In that environment, does the Fed want to risk a Japanese-style outcome? No. They'll take out insurance to prevent that."
For all the gloom in the jobs numbers, there were significant strengths. Employment rose in retailing, wholesaling, transportation, mortgage banking, real estate, auto repair and, above all, health services, which generated 29,000 new jobs in July. Total employment in the nation held at 130.8 million. Nearly 1.8 million jobs had been lost from March of last year through last April, and the rebound since then is 94,000, including 66,000 in June.
The relatively large June rise came as a result of a revision announced yesterday. The original estimate had been 36,000.
Many economists see the meager job growth since April as evidence of the determination of employers to hold down labor costs. More evidence came in the rise of 191,000 part-time workers in July who sought full-time hours and could not get them.
Such data does not offer a good omen for the third quarter, says Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist for Deutsche Bank North America. "Total hours worked in July were less than the average worked in the second quarter," he said. "We started the third quarter at a lower level than the weak second quarter."

HEADLINE: Russia Says It May Reconsider Its Nuclear Plant Deal With Iran 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Russia, under pressure from the Bush administration, indicated today for the first time that it was prepared to reconsider plans to continue building nuclear reactors in Iran that American officials fear could be used in a covert program to build nuclear weapons.
 After a third day of meetings here in Moscow with American officials, the minister of Russia's nuclear energy agency, Aleksandr Y. Rumyantsev, said in a statement that Russia would take into account "political factors" before deepening its assistance to Iran, according to a statement released by his ministry. 
 The Russian statement, muted as it was, came at the end of sometimes pointed talks here between Russian energy and security officials and an American delegation led by Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham. 
Last week, on the eve of the delegation's visit, the Russian government announced that it planned to build as many as five more nuclear reactors in Iran after completing an $800 million, 1,000-megawatt reactor on the Persian Gulf, at Bushehr, as early as next year. The plans were included in a document outlining a 10-year program of economic and scientific cooperation between Russia and Iran.
Today Mr. Rumyantsev repeated Russia's insistence that its cooperation with Iran was limited to civilian development of nuclear energy and not the development of nuclear weapons. But he appeared to take note of the objections raised by Washington. The statement suggested that Russia was prepared to abandon any further cooperation with Iran on nuclear programs, even though Russian officials have said all week that they have the right to continue the project at Bushehr, as well as other peaceful nuclear energy programs.
"As to the prospects of cooperation with Iran in the peaceful use of nuclear energy," the statement read, "the draft of the long-term program for the development of trade, economic, industrial and technological cooperation between Russia and Iran through 2012 only mentions the existing technical possibilities. Their implementation depends on many factors, including political factors."
On Thursday, Secretary Abraham accused Iran of "aggressively pursuing nuclear weapons" and bluntly called on Russia to cease all assistance, including the completion of the plant at Bushehr. "No one should be under any impression that there is anything but the utmost concern on this question on our part," Mr. Abraham said, "and those concerns have been frankly and directly conveyed during our meetings here."
With its statement today, Moscow appears to be trying to play down the divisions in the interests of the closer Russian-American cooperation now evident in a variety of areas. Among these are the protection of the world's energy supply at a time of uncertainty over the prospects of an American war against Iraq.
The issue remains sensitive, though. Mr. Rumyantsev canceled a news conference today, and Mr. Abraham, who met with him for a third day, made no public remarks. The statement said discussions would continue when Mr. Rumyan-tsev and Mr. Abraham meet in September at the conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Iran has maintained that the Bushehr plant is a civilian project and has allowed international inspectors from the atomic energy agency to visit the site.

HEADLINE: Most Bets Lie On a Decline In Fed Rates 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
With the economy looking less healthy than before, Wall Street is beginning to expect that the Federal Reserve Board will cut interest rates again within the next few months in an effort to stave off a double-dip recession.
 "Fed officials are likely to ease" in the final quarter of this year, Edward McKelvey, senior economist for Goldman, Sachs, said yesterday. He said he expected the federal funds rate, the key rate that the Federal Reserve controls, to fall to 1 percent by the end of the year, down from 1.75 percent now. 
 That is more than most expect, but in the futures market yesterday -- where speculators can place their bets on what will happen to that rate -- the December futures forecast a decline to 1.5 percent by year-end. It is the first time that the market has forecast a quarter-point cut from the current level, already extremely low by historical standards. 
By contrast, in late March, when the economy seemed to be growing well -- and the Dow was 2,000 points higher than it is now -- the futures market was forecasting substantially higher interest rates by year-end, an increase of at least 1.5 percentage points.
The Federal Reserve's open market committee meets on Aug. 13, and the market consensus is that it will not move then. But the futures market indicates that there is a better than 50 percent chance that the Fed will cut rates by a quarter point at its September meeting.
Some think such a move should be made quickly. Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig Securities, said yesterday that the revisions to earlier economic data announced earlier in the week showed that the economy "was never as healthy" as it appeared to be, and that it now "looks rather peaked." He said he thought the Fed should lower rates at the August meeting.
The stock market weakness yesterday was concentrated in economically sensitive stocks. Within the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 2.3 percent, the biggest stock declines came from United Technologies, 3M, General Motors, Dupont and other companies vulnerable to a slowdown. By contrast, the three Dow stocks that did the best yesterday -- Philip Morris, Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble -- make products for which a recession would do little to hurt demand.
The consensus forecast still calls for the economy to avoid recession, but the recent news, which has included surprisingly low factory orders, stagnant employment growth and a slowdown in nonresidential construction, has increased the worry level.
"The odds of a double dip are increasing, but I'm not convinced yet," said John Vail, chief strategist of Mizuho Securities USA. "My forecast is for slow, sluggish growth."
David Wyss and Rick McDonald, economists at Standard & Poor's, said one disturbing factor in yesterday's employment report was a downturn in hiring for temporary jobs. "Through the first half, temp jobs led the economy," they wrote in a report. "We argued this showed that employers were uncertain, and hiring temps rather than permanent workers. In July, they didn't hire either."
Nonetheless, they expect the economy to stay out of recession and the Fed to keep rates steady for the rest of this year. 
The major stock market averages remain above the lows they reached in late July, however, when there was great hand wringing over a lack of investor confidence. Since then, there have been two very strong days, which were not wiped out by yesterday's sharp declines. 
Moreover, not all the economic data has been weak. Auto sales rebounded in July, helped by a new round of zero-percent financing. Strong auto sales in late 2001 helped keep that year's recession from being a deep one, to the surprise of many economists.
Politically, a new recession starting now could be dicey for President Bush, who no doubt recalls that the recession that began in July 1990 and ended in February 1991 ended up playing a significant role in his father's failure to win re-election. 
Since World War II, there have been four recessions that included parts of a presidential election year or the year before one. In each subsequent election the incumbent party lost the White House. Besides 1992, they were 1960, when John F. Kennedy was elected over Vice President Richard M. Nixon; 1976, when Jimmy Carter defeated President Gerald Ford; and 1980, when Ronald Reagan defeated President Carter.
On the other hand, recessions early in presidential administrations do not seem to be very harmful, perhaps because they can be blamed in part on predecessors, or perhaps because recoveries tend to be well along by the time the next presidential election occurs. The presidents Dwight Eisenhower, Nixon and Reagan were each re-elected despite recessions that ended during their second year in office.
One problem for presidents is that the National Bureau of Economic Research, which officially certifies recessions, is not known for speedy conclusions. It has yet to determine when the last recession ended, although most economists say it was in the October-to-December period of last year. Its announcement that the 1990-91 recession was over came after Bill Clinton had won the 1992 election.
All that makes it likely that the White House will, at the least, not be upset if the Fed does decide to cut rates further. And further worrying about economic weakness could lead some economists to call for additional tax cuts to provide more money for consumer spending.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
StockGauges Fall 2% or More On Jobs Report

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday on reports that employers added few jobs in July and on weak outlooks from Disney and other companies. The three major market gauges were down 2 percent or more on the day and gave up all or most of their gains for the week.
 The latest economic data is raising doubts among investors about the durability of the economic recovery from the recession that is widely said to have ended late last year. A weak recovery or another recession -- which analysts refer to as a double dip -- would make a rebound in corporate earnings difficult and would undermine the outlook for stocks. 
 "This has to go down as a very disappointing week," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany.
Before the stock market opened yesterday, the government reported that just 6,000 new nonfarm jobs were created last month, far below forecasts of 60,000 to 70,000 jobs. Earlier in the week, reports showed that the manufacturing sector cooled last month and that the overall economy grew at an anemic annual rate of just 1.1 percent in the second quarter.
The news ended a rally that began in the middle of last week to lift stocks off their five-year lows. The sharp gains, which continued through Wednesday, convinced some analysts that equities were at or near their bottom.
Because markets often bounce around considerably when the bottom is near, it is hard to conclude what the ensuing sell-off of the last two days portends.
"If job growth falters, then income growth will be insufficient to generate consumer spending anywhere near the pace that is consistent with a sustained economic recovery," said David Greenlaw, chief United States fixed-income economist at Morgan Stanley. He said that the sharp drop in the average work week was a big surprise and that the soft data on hours worked "point to declines in both industrial production and housing starts" in July.
James Pritchard, a church administrator in Memphis who moved some of his portfolio back into stocks in June, said, "It will be a bit up and down until we see a sustainable recovery." 
Caution about the economic outlook was heightened during the day when Goldman, Sachs senior economist Edward F. McKelvey sent an e-mail message to clients that said the firm was cutting its economic forecast for the second half of the year and predicted that the Federal Reserve would cut its short-term interest rate target by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 1 percent, by the end of the year.
During the recent stock market rout, investors were repeatedly reassured by President Bush, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and some Wall Street strategists that the economy was sound and the economic recovery well under way.
"We thought there was a disconnect between the stock market and the economy and once stocks focused on the fundamentals again, they would rally," Mr. Johnson said. "But the stock market was sending us an accurate signal that either the economy has hit a soft spot or is in for a sinking spell or recession."
In his message, Mr. McKelvey said that "although Fed officials undoubtedly share our view that double dip is not the central case, we believe they will want to take out more insurance against that possibility."
A rally in the last 40 minutes of trading, including a 100-point surge in the Dow Jones industrial average, helped mitigate the day's pain. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 193.49 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 8,313.13, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 20.42 points, or 2.3 percent, to 864.24. The Nasdaq composite index was down 32.08 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,247.92. For the week, the Dow was up 0.6 percent and the S.& P. 500 index was up 1.3 percent. But the Nasdaq was down 1.1 percent.
The weaker economic news and the rout in the stock market sent investors into bonds, driving prices higher and yields, which move in the opposite direction, sharply lower. That drop in rates is one positive for the economic outlook. Lower rates can encourage borrowing and the refinancing of home mortgages, both of which can free up money for consumer spending and help offset the drag of falling stock prices.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.29 percent, down from 4.39 percent on Thursday. The price rose 24/32, to 104 16/32. The 10-year note has a big influence on home mortgage rates and this decline, if it holds, should push them lower. The average national rate on a 30-year Freddie Mac home mortgage was 6.43 percent this week, not far from the lowest level in three decades.
James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer of Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, said the sharp decline in interest rates made him less worried about the outlook. In addition, he said that the stock market had already been signaling that the economy would have no growth for a quarter or two. So, he concluded, "I think it's positive that the stock market is essentially up over the last two weeks even though the economic reports are getting weaker."
Mr. Greenlaw of Morgan Stanley is not talking recession either. But he said the new data was troubling enough that Morgan Stanley was reducing its economic growth forecast for the second half of the year. Just weeks ago, that forecast was for 4 percent growth, at an annual rate. Mr. Greenlaw said that a report on Monday would cut that pace to at least 3 percent.
A sharp outflow of money from stock mutual funds in June and July shows that investor confidence has been shaken. According to AMG Data Services, July outflows will exceed $30 billion, the worst month since AMG began collecting data in 1992. Although AMG reported net inflows of $2.2 billion in the week ended July 31, almost all of that money -- $2.1 billion -- went into international or global equity funds, which means many investors were avoiding American stocks.
Among the stocks leading the market lower was Walt Disney, which said late Thursday that its fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 7.1 percent. The company also said that bookings at its theme parks for the fourth quarter were down 10 percent. Shares of Disney declined $1.52, or 9 percent, to $15.31.
Travelers Property Casualty fell $1.10, or 7.3 percent, to $14, after Citigroup said it would distribute most of its controlling stake in the company, keeping 9.9 percent of the stock. Travelers went public in an initial public offering in March, at $18.50.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Clouds Gather Over Baseball's Pristine Scene

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
TWO major league superstars were sitting in the grass at Miller Park in Milwaukee watching the All-Star Game festivities last month and talking about everything they saw. There was baseball in front of them, the sun was shining, and laughter completed the picturesque scene. The only things missing were a picnic basket and a blanket.
 But the scene quickly veered away from peacefulness when Lance Berkman turned to the always-chatty Curt Schilling and asked him what was going to happen in the always uncertain labor situation. Berkman wanted to know if Schilling felt the players would wind up on strike this season. A television camera secured the conversation and Schilling's stern response. 
 "We better not," Schilling said.
Three simple, revealing words: We better not. The players keep repeating that they do not want to strike, even as they have held countless meetings in which Aug. 16 has been mentioned as a potential strike date. The players rightly feel the threat of a strike is the only leverage they have, because the owners can lock them out after the season and implement new work rules. If the players do not act, they believe the owners will force-feed them a radically changed system.
Still, a strike, however logical the players argue it might be, would be another devastating punch to a sport that is floundering as it tries to keep its product viable. Attendance is down, payrolls are up, distrust of Bud Selig and Donald Fehr is constant, and disgust with the financial heft of George Steinbrenner is rampant. There are too many problems in baseball. Another strike would make arena football in August suddenly seem appealing. Losing any games would be a fiasco.
"Disappointing wouldn't even measure it," Schilling said as he sat in the third-base dugout before the Mets' game against Arizona was rained out at Shea Stadium last night. "That's not even a word on the scale if there were to be a work stoppage."
Schilling claimed that every major leaguer felt the same. As both sides continue negotiating, it is intriguing to wonder how the talks might be influenced if a marquee player suddenly voiced a differing opinion about the need for a strike. Someone like Schilling. He has thrust himself into the forefront before, including sending an emotional electronic message, posted on ESPN.com, for those affected by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
Not now, fellas, Schilling could say. We must find a solution. We cannot put the game on hold with the economy staggering and with the one-year anniversary of the attacks looming. The union has long been united, so it is a fantasy to think any players would publicly denounce a strike. The owners would probably pounce on it as a weakness instead of viewing it as a building block. But it would be interesting.
"It's not going to happen," Schilling said. "It's very simple. If the owners are truly bargaining in good faith, we're close to a deal. The difference is minimal when you're talking about a $3 billion industry. If we strike, it would be because the owners want to implement their own work system."
Even though a player might wish he could say no to a strike, do not expect a single defection. Besides, no owner has scampered to a microphone to say that his side must keep games this season and the next. The owners are obsessed with enforcing a new system.
Everyone loses if there is a strike: owners, players, fans. Someone might win in the long term, and that is what this disagreement is over, but in the short term no one wins.
Schilling would suffer. He is a gaudy 18-4 with a 2.83 earned run average and a major league-leading 219 strikeouts for the defending World Series champions and could become the first pitcher since 1990 (Bob Welch, 27-6) to win 25 games. Schilling should make 11 more starts, and that would give him no chance for 30 victories, which last happened for Denny McLain (31-6) in 1968.
But even the thought of 30 in August is surprising. If there is a strike in two weeks and the season never resumes, Schilling might not even get to 20 for the second straight season. Selfishly and statistically speaking, a strike could harm the 35-year-old Schilling more than other players.
"My team is in first place and I've made more money than I'm ever going to spend," he said. "Why would I want to strike? But it has nothing to do with what I'm going to make. It has to do with how the game has been regulated and how the rules should apply."
Schilling was the first Diamondback on the field yesterday and he stood in foul territory and watched the Mets take batting practice. One of the best pitchers in the majors looked like any other fan waiting for an autograph or a foul ball. It was another nice scene. With luck, those scenes will continue. With luck, the season will continue. It better.

(Photographs by Associated Press)
