HEADLINE: Master Storyteller or Master Deceiver? 

BYLINE:  By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
HE was a spellbinding storyteller, a figure of mesmerizing charm. The South African-born writer Sir Laurens van der Post, who died in 1996 at 90, sold millions of copies of his novels and nonfiction books, including "The Lost World of the Kalahari," about the plight of the South African Bushmen, which became a popular BBC television series. 
 Van der Post was a Jungian mystic and a spiritual adviser to Prince Charles; according to British newspapers, he taught the prince to talk to his plants. In 1982 Charles made him godfather to his heir, Prince William. Van der Post was also a close friend of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, exerting an influence on her policy in South Africa. 
 He had a following in the United States as well. For several years, he gave the Advent sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The year he died, he attended a celebration of his work in Boulder, Colo., and 4,000 people came. 
But according to a new biography, "Teller of Many Tales: The Lives of Laurens van der Post," by the British journalist J. D. F. Jones, published here last month by Carroll & Graf, van der Post was a fraud who deceived people about everything from the amount of time he actually spent with the Bushmen to his military record during World War II. His claim that he had brokered the settlement in the Rhodesian civil war was a lie as was his insistence that he was a close friend of Jung's, Mr. Jones says. 
And when it came to women, der Post was a bounder. In the early 1950's, when he was 46, he seduced the 14-year-old daughter of a wealthy South African winemaking family, who had been entrusted to his care during a sea voyage. She became pregnant, and although he sent her a small stipend, he never publicly acknowledged the daughter born of the relationship.
"I discovered to my astonishment that not a single word he ever wrote or ever said could necessarily be believed," Mr. Jones said in an interview from his home in Somerset, England. "He was a compulsive fantasist." 
When "Teller of Many Tales" was published in Britain last year, under the title "Storyteller: The Many Lives of Laurens van der Post," it created a mini-sensation. The book had a gleeful reception in many British newspapers. The reviewer for The Economist of London called the book "hilarious." The Daily Telegraph said it was "bold, brilliantly researched and fascinating," though a critic for The Spectator dissented, calling it "an utterly ruthless hatchet job." Lucia Crichton-Miller, van der Post's daughter, also offered a passionate defense of her father. "I think it a profoundly dishonest book," she said from London. "The worst is the malign selection of evidence."
Mr. Jones knew van der Post slightly, he said, and had been an admirer of his early work. "You have never in your life met a man so charming," he said. "It was staggering." When van der Post was in his late 80's, Mr. Jones proposed writing his biography, but van der Post didn't want one while he was still alive. After his death, Mr. Jones approached Ms. Crichton-Miller, who had been a colleague of his at The Financial Times of London, where he was an editor. Ms. Crichton-Miller agreed to cooperate with him and provided access to her father's archives. 
The lies began with the stories of his childhood, Mr. Jones said, in books like "Venture to the Interior," his 1951 best-selling account of his travels in Nyasaland (today Malawi), interwoven with Jungian mysticism. Van der Post claimed descent from minor Dutch aristocracy, and said that his father had been a senior statesman and a high-ranking barrister, a "kind of prime minister." In fact, Mr. Jones says, his father came from a family of minor distinction and was a lower-status law agent who processed routine legal documents. 
In "The Lost World of the Kalahari" and other writings, van der Post claimed to have had a Bushman, sometimes a half-Bushman, nanny, from whom he derived his special, instinctive knowledge of the group. In fact, Mr. Jones says, there is no record of such a person, and van der Post did not encounter the Bushmen, the indigenous people of South Africa, until he was an adult. He spent about two weeks with them despite assertions that he lived among them. In his writings, van der Post depicted the Bushmen as primitive, instinctual, childlike, whereas white men were logical, reasonable, intellectual. In "The Lost World of the Kalahari," published in 1958, van der Post claimed he had discovered the Bushman paintings of the Tsodilo Hills, when in fact they had been well-known to Europeans for close to 50 years, Mr. Jones writes. 
Van der Post also lied to the women in his life, Mr. Jones says. He juggled affairs with numerous women simultaneously, keeping them secret from one another. In 1934, he settled in England with his first wife, Marjorie, and his son, John, on a farm probably bought for him with money from the Queen Mother's cousin Lilian Bowes Lyon, with whom he was having a relationship. 
In 1936, the same year his first daughter, Lucia, was born, van der Post met Ingaret Giffard on a boat to South Africa. In 1938 he sent Marjorie and his two children to South Africa with the argument that war was imminent. He didn't see his children for nearly 10 years. He and Marjorie eventually divorced, and he married Ingaret after the war. They lived together even after she became ill with dementia in later life, though for 30 years he also had a mistress, Frances Baruch.
In books about his war experiences, and his autobiography, van der Post cast himself as a war hero. His trio of autobiographical novellas, "The Seed and the Sower," about being a prisoner of war in a Japanese prison camp was the basis for the 1983 David Bowie movie "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence."
In 1942 van der Post, then an acting captain, was captured by the Japanese in Java. In books and speeches, he claimed he volunteered for an extra beating to save his fellow prisoners, but that account was also disputed in written statements by some of his fellow prisoners, said Mr. Jones. Van der Post also said that after the Allied victory, he had been "military governor of Batavia," in Java, now part of Indonesia, but he was not, Mr. Jones says.
Regarding Mr. Jones's assertions about her father's war record, Ms. Crichton-Miller said: "All I can say is that throughout my life I have met people who were in the prisoner-of-war camp in Java who said they did not know how they would have lived without my father."
And as far as the amount of time her father actually spent living with the Bushmen, said Ms. Crichton Miller, "J. D. F. misses the point of my father. What my father did was give poetic force to the Bushmen."
"He was not pretending to be an anthropologist or a scientist," Ms. Crichton Miller said. "I think there is no doubt that he didn't want to spell it out that he had been there only a few weeks." 
She also disputed Mr. Jones's assertion that her father had not been an intimate of Jung's, pointing to the observation of a member of Jung's inner circle, Barbara Hannah, that van der Post and Jung had been very close friends. As for Mr. Jones's allegations about her father's relationship with a 14-year-old girl, "I'm afraid I think that's true," Ms. Crichton-Miller said. "He was not a saint. He hurt people. He hurt me. But by God, he was fascinating." 
Bonny Kohler-Baker, whom van der Post seduced and abandoned when she was 14, is the mother of van der Post's other daughter. She now lives outside New York City under a different name, and would not discuss the book. But her daughter, Cari Mostert, in a phone interview from the Eastern Transvaal in South Africa, said she had been brought up to believe that her maternal grandmother was her mother and that her mother was her sister. She said her grandmother had told her when she was 10 that van der Post was her father. Ms. Mostert described meeting her father for the first time when she was 12, when she and her mother had surprised him in Los Angeles, where he had a speaking engagement: "I was crying, and he was crying."
Ms. Mostert said she had confronted him once again, as he arrived in Johannesburg airport, and he had said that her grandmother had lied in saying that she was his daughter. She claimed that she had sent her father over 50 letters, but that he had never replied. "I thought he is such an upright, a noble human being," Ms. Mostert said, "if he would only understand . . . " Her voice trailed off. 
In the 1970's van der Post met Prince Charles through mutual friends. In 1987 he took Charles on a four-day trip to the Kalahari, telling the prince, "This is the real Africa." Mr. Jones states that sometime in the mid-70's, Charles began having psychoanalytic treatment with Ingaret, who was a Jungian analyst, and then with van der Post's friend Dr. Alan McGlashan. Diana, Princess of Wales, was also treated by Dr. McGlashan during the troubles in her marriage, Mr. Jones writes. 
Charles told van der Post his dreams, and van der Post drafted some of his speeches. When van der Post died, Charles set up an annual lecture in his honor.
But van der Post's most significant influence occurred during the South African struggle over apartheid, Mr. Jones says. Van der Post hated Nelson Mandela and championed the Zulu chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, whom he saw as a foil for the African National Congress's Communist beliefs. He arranged meetings between Chief Buthelezi, Charles and Mrs. Thatcher. Mr. Jones argues that van der Post had helped convince Mrs. Thatcher to oppose sanctions against the South African government and not to embrace Mr. Mandela.
As van der Post lay dying, Mr. Jones says, Charles visited him. At his memorial service, Lady Thatcher read the lesson and Chief Buthelezi spoke. Nonetheless, Mr. Jones writes, there were apparently some who doubted van der Post even when he was alive.
Mr. Jones says that when a doctor who knew him was asked the cause of his death, the doctor replied, "He was weary of sustaining so many lies."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Expanded Trade Powers for Bush May Help Singapore

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Few people have more reason to be pleased about President Bush winning expanded powers on trade than George Yeo, Singapore's minister of trade and industry.
 For the last 21 months, Mr. Yeo, a bookish trade official, has led Singapore through nine rounds of negotiations for a free-trade agreement with the United States. Mr. Bush's new trade promotion authority, which Congress reinstated on Thursday for the first time since 1994, makes it easier for the two sides to have a deal completed by the end of this year. 
 With the new authority, "we will be able to close remaining outstanding issues," the ministry said in a statement today.
Singapore and Chile are expected to be the first countries to win free-trade agreements. If Singapore and Washington reach an agreement and the Bush administration passes it to Congress for ratification, legislators will have 90 days to approve it -- without amendments.
"I believe that both Singapore and Congress would like to have some successes in the trade area quickly," said Landis Hicks, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore.
Negotiating a deal with tiny Singapore, with no textile industry or agriculture, may seem relatively unremarkable next to wrangling concessions from Japan or Europe. 
But as Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, has been quick to point out, Singapore is America's 10th largest export market. American companies have more than $23 billion invested here.
The deal will clearly have more impact on Singapore. By some estimates, the duties saved under the deal would swell Singapore exports to the United States by 7 percent a year, adding almost a percentage point of additional annual economic growth.
Singapore needs the help. After shrinking 2 percent last year, its economy is on track for 4 percent growth this year. But its critical electronics industry is still shrinking and unemployment is hovering just below 15-year highs.
With China luring an increasing amount of investment and trade away from Southeast Asia, Singapore has been anxiously seeking more far-reaching economic ties. It has already signed free-trade deals with Japan and New Zealand.
Just what separates the United States and Singapore is something neither side has disclosed. But there are possible areas of disagreement.
American lawyers, for example, want Singapore to open its legal services so they can practice law and represent clients in Singapore's courts. Bankers want Singapore to open its financial industry so they can establish more branches and reach out to more of Singapore's savers. Software companies want Singapore to make using pirated software a crime. Drug companies want protection for their test data. 
Some experts doubt that Singapore will yield enough to make a big difference. "I have to be somewhat skeptical if there will be a big impact on the economy," said Desmond Supple, managing director at Barclays Capital in Singapore. 
Another sticking point concerns rules of origin. Singapore is a major transshipment point for goods coming from as far as the Suez Canal to the South China Sea. In April, Mr. Zoellick and Mr. Yeo agreed that some products from two Indonesian islands near Singapore should be included in the agreement as an economic balm for Singapore's giant, impoverished neighbor. But how the agreement will ensure that products from other Asian nations, seeking to exploit that advantage, are not shipped through Singapore for export to the United States remains unclear.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Singapore's financial district dominates the waterfront. After shrinking 2 percent last year, Singapore's economy may grow 4 percent this year and could benefit from a trade agreement with the United States. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Bush Will Travel to the 3 Sites To Commemorate Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 2 

 BODY:
President Bush will travel to New York, Pennsylvania and the Pentagon on Sept. 11 to commemorate the anniversary of the terrorist attacks, the White House announced today.
 In New York, Mr. Bush will visit ground zero in Lower Manhattan. In Pennsylvania, he will visit the field in Shanksville where United Airlines Flight 93 went down. The stops, including one at the restored Pentagon in Northern Virginia, will be part of an extensive day of commemoration that Mr. Bush's aides and speech writers are planning. 
 A spokeswoman for the White House, Claire Buchan, announced the plans on Air Force One as Mr. Bush flew for the second time this summer to his parents' vacation house here. On Saturday, the president is to attend a fund-raiser for Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, traveling by boat. Otherwise his sole public plans for a three-day weekend include golf and, possibly, fishing.
On Monday, Mr. Bush leaves for Pittsburgh, where he will meet the nine coal miners who were rescued last Sunday. On Tuesday, he will sign a trade bill at the White House, have his annual physical examination and leave for what aides call a 25-day "working vacation" at his 1,600-acre ranch in Crawford, Tex.
To underscore the nature of the vacation, Ms. Buchan announced political and policy trips that Mr. Bush will make from the ranch, where the temperatures typically exceed 100 degrees in the summer. The president, she said, will use Crawford as a base to travel to Arkansas, California, Iowa, Michigan, Mississippi, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, South Dakota and Wisconsin. In all, she said, he will visit 15 cities to talk about education, the economy and trade.
Mr. Bush will also be the host of an economic conference on Aug. 13 at Baylor University in Waco, Tex. The next week, as the administration continues to debate when and how to invade Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld will visit. Later, officials expect, Mr. Bush will meet President Vicente Fox of Mexico at the ranch.
The White House announced that Mr. Bush would meet President Jiang Zemin of China in October, also at the ranch.
Before Mr. Bush left Washington this morning, he promoted what he said were his administration's recent legislative accomplishments, particularly a bill that gives him the right to negotiate trade agreements without Congressional interference. The Senate passed the bill on Thursday. 
"It goes to show that when we put our partisanship aside, when people stop all the yelling and hollering and finger pointing and say, 'How can we help the American people?' we can get a lot done in this town," Mr. Bush said.
In Maine, Mr. Bush is staying at the Bushes' century-old summer house on Walker's Point, a promontory into the Atlantic, without his twin daughters or Mrs. Bush, who is in Texas. Mr. Bush's parents and brother Marvin and sister Dorothy are here. Last month, Mr. Bush celebrated his 56th birthday here. This time, Ms. Buchan said, there is no particular occasion for the visit. 
"The president," she said, "is a family man."

HEADLINE: City Proposes a Land Swap To Control Trade Center Site 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
New York City officials have proposed a swap in which the city would take over the World Trade Center site in exchange for giving the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey the land beneath La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, an official involved in the rebuilding effort said yesterday.
 The Port Authority has not yet responded to the proposal, which was made informally through a third party in the last week, according to the official. There is no certainty that an agreement will be reached. 
 Such a deal, if completed, would give New York City and New York State officials control of the process of rebuilding Lower Manhattan without worries about whether revenues from commercial space at the trade center would satisfy the financial needs of the Port Authority or New Jersey. Those needs were at the heart of the six initial land-use proposals for the site, made in late July, which were greeted with strong criticism by New Yorkers from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on down. 
Under the proposal, the Port Authority would gain permanent rights to the operation of the airports, which are two of its largest sources of income and would otherwise be subject to a significant increase in lease payments in the coming years.
The Port Authority currently pays $3 million annually for the land leases at the two airports, but negotiations that are under way to extend the Port Authority's lease, which ends in 2015, are likely to increase that amount substantially.
Any potential deal is likely to be weeks if not months away. If an agreement is reached, it will have to be approved by the governors of New York and New Jersey and, possibly, by each state's Legislature. In addition, the financial terms of a proposed deal are likely to present sticking points. 
But several officials from the city and the two states who have heard about the proposal said yesterday that they were intrigued by it. The idea has provoked enthusiastic discussion among some of the civic and urban planning groups that have been closely following the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan.
"I think it's a brilliant idea," said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association, an independent urban planning organization. "It is in the regional interest, and it would fix a big problem for both agencies by clearing up the very confusing lines of authority downtown and out at the airports."
Spokesmen for the city and the Port Authority would not comment directly on the proposal yesterday. A spokesman for Mayor Bloomberg, Edward Skyler, said, "A lot of interesting ideas are being circulated, and the mayor is interested in exploring all of them."
A spokesman for the Port Authority, Peter Yerkes, said the negotiations between the city and the authority regarding the airport leases "are ongoing and have been positive."
But, he said, those talks have not yet involved discussion of the land swap. "The focus of the talks has been centered on reaching an agreement on updating the leases under the same basic structure we currently have," Mr. Yerkes said.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said the governor did not yet know enough about the proposal to be able to comment. "If this is something that the city wants to sit down and talk about, we're willing to listen," Mr. McKeon said. 
Officials in the office of Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey declined to comment.
While the proposal is still in an embryonic stage, the official who has been involved in the rebuilding effort said the deal's financial details "can work out in such a way that it is a win-win for everybody."
The Port Authority, the official said, "gains a new lease on life" by ridding itself of the need to make expensive annual rental payments to the city for the right to operate the airports. A renegotiated lease for the airports would probably require the Port Authority to pay more than $60 million annually.
In the long term, that could benefit New Jersey officials too, supporters of the idea say, because owning the airports would give the Port Authority an added measure of stability.
The city, meanwhile, would gain control of the trade center site, and Mr. Pataki "will look like he is acting in the interest of the city of New York," the official said. 
The governor is likely to retain a hand in the planning and rebuilding of the trade center because federal money for the recovery is funneled through the state. That would mean that the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation or some similar agency would probably continue to oversee the rebuilding process.
Since Sept. 11, the Port Authority's control of the World Trade Center site has been an increasingly irritating thorn in the side of many city and state officials who are involved in the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan.
The six initial land-use plans, which attracted almost universal scorn when they were released last month, were created under requirements set by the Port Authority. The agency said all of the designs had to replace all of the office, retail and hotel space that was destroyed at the trade center. The resulting drawings were criticized as trying to force too many buildings onto the site, which was also required to have a memorial.
Turning the trade center site over to the city would eliminate the Port Authority, and therefore New Jersey, from the planning process. But it would also open the rebuilding project to many other government regulations that could significantly slow the progress of downtown's recovery.
For example, city property is subject to the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, which dictates a review process involving hearings and approvals by the local community board, the borough president, the City Planning Commission, the City Council and the mayor. 
In addition, the site would be subject to federal environmental reviews. Because the Port Authority is an interstate agency operating under consent of Congress, it is not subject to those federal statutes.
One reason that the rebuilding of the former 7 World Trade Center was able to begin so quickly was that it was not subject to those regulations.
If a swap is agreed upon, it is not clear whether it will be an even exchange or if the deal will require the payment of cash or other compensation from one party to another.
The Port Authority currently derives $130 million in annual revenue from the lease of the World Trade Center site. From that amount, it has been paying about $28 million annually to the city in lieu of property taxes. Those payments were the result of an agreement struck when the trade center was created to compensate the city for the loss of taxes on the 16 acres of trade center property. That land was privately owned and condemned by the city and then turned over to the Port Authority.
At the least, a land swap involving the trade center and the airports would represent a remarkable reversal in relations between the city and the Port Authority. 
The Port Authority has leased the land and operated the airports since 1947. The current leases are set to expire in 2015, and the city and the Port Authority have waged many battles over whether or not the leases will be extended.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani consistently denounced the Port Authority and its operation of the two airports. Mr. Giuliani said that the Port Authority diverted $150 million annually in city airport revenues into other projects that mainly benefited residents of New Jersey.
Although the Port Authority said it was willing to renegotiate its lease for the airports and pay far more than its current $3 million in annual rental payments, Mr. Giuliani said he wanted the city itself to control the airports.
But by the spring of last year, Mr. Giuliani conceded that he could not persuade Gov. George E. Pataki to help the city wrest control of the airports from the Port Authority.
Mr. Bloomberg's approach to the Port Authority has been much different. During his mayoral campaign, Mr. Bloomberg said he did not necessarily believe that the Port Authority should be ousted from its role operating the airports.

HEADLINE: Congress's Mixed Handiwork 

 BODY:
Americans who have grown accustomed to bad news may be surprised to find that Congress, now off for summer vacation, actually racked up some real accomplishments this year. On Thursday, for instance, the Senate gave final passage to a bill authorizing President Bush to engage in new global trade talks. No president has had such authority since it expired in 1994. A sweeping corporate responsibility law has also been enacted. The list of unfinished business is long, but voter impatience could force more action in the fall. 
 Since Sept. 11, President Bush and the House Republicans have pretty much set the agenda. But in a power shift, recent weeks have belonged more to the Democrats in the Senate. They called the tune on corporate responsibility, throwing Republicans onto the defensive. The G.O.P. charges that Tom Daschle, the majority leader, is obstructing the establishment of a Homeland Security Department, but that's not so. Until two months ago, Mr. Bush and the Republicans were doing all they could to block the Democrats from passing just such a bill. 
 Mr. Daschle's performance in the spotlight has been shaky. He failed to round up the votes to pass a bill providing prescription drugs for the elderly. He could not win passage of an overall budget resolution to set spending levels for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The worst part, for him, was that these defeats came as much at the hands of Democrats as Republicans. Several Democrats defected from the party's own version of the prescription drug benefit, and on the budget, too many Democrats were prepared to bolt from their party's anti-tax-cut line and endorse a Republican drive to expand and extend the Bush tax cuts of last year.
Republicans will be campaigning this fall on the idea that "Daschle Democrats" have been both weak and obstructionist. In fact, many of the areas where progress is snagged -- welfare, energy, overhaul of the bankruptcy laws -- are instances in which blocking a bad bill is much more useful than doing something just for the sake of looking productive. There is no reason, on the other hand, not to pass election reform. It would be a disgrace, after the Florida debacle of 2000, for Congress not to fix the way our national elections are run, though House and Senate versions remain caught up in a fight over how much to require the states to do.
When legislators tour their districts, geared to sell their versions of who killed the prescription drug bill, they may find that what most concerns their constituents is their eroding economic security. Polls show voters' attitudes shifting rapidly, though perhaps they are not yet ready to throw incumbents out en masse. Among lawmakers these days there is a mood of deep wariness. The best way for them to work out their angst is to come back soon and get more accomplished.

HEADLINE: A Time for Candor on Iraq 

 BODY:
With all their talk about forcing a regime change in Iraq, President Bush and his aides are creating the 2002 equivalent of the 1939 "phony war" in Europe -- the period following the German invasion of Poland when everyone knew war was coming but the guns remained silent. The anticipation of war stirs uncertainty and puts people on edge, which is the way the country, already shaken by Sept. 11, is feeling these days. It is time for Mr. Bush to level with the nation about his intentions and to talk candidly about why he feels military action against Iraq may soon be necessary, and what the goals, costs and potential consequences of a war would be.
 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee's hearings on Iraq this week usefully addressed some of these issues. But the testimony came from outside experts. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and other top officials continue to dodge serious questions about Washington's plans. The by-now-familiar refrain that Mr. Bush has not yet made any decisions about Iraq may literally be correct, in the sense that he may not yet have approved a war plan, but it smacks of the semantic games that administrations often play to disguise very real preparations for war. 
 One argument for war often floated by officials ought to be disposed of quickly. Military action against Iraq may be justified, but not in response to the terrorism of Sept. 11 or Al Qaeda. To date there is no reliable evidence that Baghdad had any serious connection to either. The dangers posed by Iraq have more to do with protecting American interests in the Middle East than with warding off fresh terrorist attacks on American cities. 
Iraq is believed to have secret stores of the kind of biological and chemical weapons that terrorists would love to get their hands on. But so do Russia and other countries. While a future link between Iraq and terrorism cannot be excluded, there appears to be no evidence so far that Baghdad means to share its deadly arsenal with others. 
The primary challenge from Iraq comes in the Mideast. Saddam Hussein has already invaded Kuwait, sent Scud missiles against Israeli cities and used poison gas against Iran and Iraqi Kurds. With a rebuilt arsenal of unconventional weapons, Iraq could try to gain control over the Persian Gulf oil fields on which Western economies depend. It could also terrorize Israel. Those are challenges that would justify American military action if they could not be reliably prevented by other means. 
America's goal should be to ensure that Iraq is disarmed of all unconventional weapons. That is what the cease-fire resolution ending the Persian Gulf war called for, and it has still not been achieved. To thwart this goal, Baghdad expelled United Nations arms inspectors four years ago. Now the U.N. is again demanding that Iraq agree to unimpeded inspections. Baghdad's reply so far has been ambiguous. Removing Mr. Hussein from power may be the only way to assure that Iraq fully disarms, but every available diplomatic option should be exhausted first.
If there is no alternative to war, Americans must weigh what kind of combat they are prepared to wage. The Afghanistan model, which relied on a small American force of Special Operations troops working with local anti-government militias, may not be applicable to Iraq, where opposition groups are weak and Mr. Hussein commands the loyalty of more than 100,000 elite troops. It might also leave Washington with insufficient leverage over leaders who succeed Mr. Hussein. A much larger American force might assure a quicker and more thorough military victory, but at the risk of substantial American fatalities. Whatever tactic is used, there may be no way to deter Iraq from using unconventional weapons against American forces. That alone is a good reason for weighing other options.
Military victory in Iraq would leave Washington temporarily responsible for guiding the future of a major Arab oil-producing country in the heart of the Middle East. The first challenge would be preventing Iraq's dissolution. The country's volatile mix of Shiites and Sunnis, Arabs and Kurds has been held together only by brute force. A splintered Iraq would tempt Iran, frighten Turkey and perhaps lead to regional war. Remaking Iraq through prolonged American military occupation, on the model of postwar Germany, seems unrealistic. Yet too rapid an American pullout could allow a new strongman to emerge, rearm and seek revenge. 
When America is attacked, as on Sept. 11, the logic of military response is straightforward and the country goes to battle united and prepared for any necessary sacrifices. A pre-emptive war against Iraq, aimed at heading off a future threat, would be different. It must be preceded by democratic deliberation and informed decision-making. There may be a compelling case to be made for war with Iraq. The administration has not yet made it.

HEADLINE: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE 

BYLINE:  By Anita Gates

 BODY:
NICK BROOMFIELD ran into trouble when he tried to screen his documentary KURT AND COURTNEY (1998) at the Sundance Film Festival. Courtney Love's lawyers wanted the film suppressed, possibly because it seems to suggest that she had something to do with the death of her husband, Kurt Cobain, the young king of grunge rock. Cobain died in 1994, apparently from a self-inflicted shotgun wound, but this film finds several people (including Ms. Love's father) who aren't convinced it was suicide. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin called the film "a memorable group portrait." Needless to say, Ms. Love did not cooperate with the filmmakers, but Mr. Broomfield does finally track her down, confront-ing her as she's receiving an award from the American Civil Liberties Union - Monday at 12:55 and 10:25 p.m. on Sundance. 
 If Jane Horrocks is known to American audiences at all, it's as Bubble, the aptly named office assistant on the BBC's hedonistic sitcom "Absolutely Fabulous." In Mark Herman's LITTLE VOICE (1998), she's a completely different animal. Ms. Horrocks plays the title character, a pathologically shy young woman with a remarkable talent. She can sing exactly - yes, exactly - like Judy Garland, Marlene Dietrich and Marilyn Monroe. The plot (her mother and a sleazy agent exploiting her for financial gain) is tired, but the music is almost impossibly on target and Brenda Blethyn and Michael Caine make a dream supporting cast - Wednesday at noon and 8 p.m. on Oxygen. 
 Nothing goes right for Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) when he sets out to meet his girlfriend's family in Jay Roach's lovable comedy MEET THE PARENTS (2000). His marriage proposal is interrupted by a cellphone call, the airline loses his luggage, and his prospective father-in-law (Robert De Niro) turns out to be a retired C.I.A. agent who enjoys administering lie-detector tests. Over the weekend, Greg meets his girlfriend's perfect ex-fiance, loses the family cat, backs up the sewage system and sets the house on fire. The moral: When everything has gone wrong and you just don't care anymore, courage is born. The sequel, with all major cast members returning, is planned for 2003 - Monday at 9 a.m. and 5:30 p.m., Saturday at 1 and 10 p.m. on HBO.
 Jeanne Jordan grew up on a small family farm in Iowa. When it ran into serious financial trouble, she and Steven Ascher recorded the process in the Oscar-nominated documentary TROUBLESOME CREEK: A MIDWESTERN (1996). The Jordans finally decide to auction their farm equipment, their animals and their Ethan Allen furni-ture to pay the bills. The story has Norman Rockwell written all over it, so Ms. Jordan's sometimes sardonic voice-over is welcome - Saturday at 2 p.m. on IFC. 
 You could make a career out of spotting Alan Cumming in his early nerd roles. There he is in David Mirkin's ROMY AND MICHELE'S HIGH SCHOOL REUNION (1997), playing the former loser who arrives at Sagebrush High's 10-year reunion in a private heli-copter. Lisa Kudrow and Mira Sorvino play the adorable bimbos determined to impress their old classmates, even though they don't have glamorous jobs (one is a receptionist, the other an unemployed sales clerk) or boyfriends. They decide to pose as businesswomen and tell people they invented Post-Its. "Like, I thought of them," says Ms. Sorvino, "but you thought of making them yellow" - Sunday at 8 and 10 p.m. on ABC Family.
 Anita Gates

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
More Cruise Ships Are Calling in Alaska

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
CRUISE lines moved a record number of ships to Alaska for this summer season after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, anticipating less demand for Mediterranean itineraries. But local merchants in Alaska are wondering if the influx of passengers will translate into profits for them.
 Twenty-five ships are visiting Alaska this summer, including some that have never cruised in Alaskan waters, some that have not been there in years and the new 2,600-passenger Star Princess, a ship so large it cannot squeeze through the Panama Canal. Altogether, the ships will sail 431 cruises in Alaska this year, a 9.1 percent increase over the 395 last year. 
 With more than 663,000 cruise passengers in Alaska last year and some 730,000 expected this year, according to the North West CruiseShip Association, the Inside Passage, Glacier Bay and Denali National Park are becoming almost as familiar to cruise passengers as are the Bahamas, Bermuda and Cancun.
The number of cruise ships in Alaska this year is a result of their corporate owners pulling them out of the Mediterranean and the Baltic after Sept. 11. Travel agents have reported that Alaska-bound passengers from much of the rest of the country say they feel safer flying to West Coast ports, including Vancouver, to board ships that will stay in American waters than they do heading to foreign ports to cruise overseas.
Yet, despite expecting more tourists this year, merchants in Alaskan ports worry that visitors' expenditures will not keep pace because of the weakened economy.
"We don't know if gift shops will sell more product, if flight-seeing operators and guide services will sell more trips, or how many cruise operators will book add-on tours into the interior," said Jim Jager, a consultant for the North West CruiseShip Association. Because ships had to discount many of their fares to attract bargain-hunting passengers, he added, "the jury is still out on what this season's passengers are going to do while they are in the state."
Sally Smith, the mayor of Juneau, said she expected a slight increase in the number of visitors to the city and the state. But she added that when she paid a visit in mid-May to welcome Holland America's 1,380-passenger Amsterdam on its first visit to Juneau this year, she was pleased to discover that a big majority of the 1,380 passengers had signed up for add-on packages. Holland America has six ships visiting Alaska this summer, the same as last year, as does Princess Cruises, and they will operate 116 and 106 trips, respectively.
The year has not always looked so promising. A survey in March by the Alaska Travel Industry Association found that early cruise bookings throughout the state were off by an average of 24 percent from the same time last year. Most summer cruises to Alaska and elsewhere are typically booked by January or February.
Nancy Parrott, the leisure market manager for Azumano Travel, of Portland, Ore., one of the biggest travel and cruise agencies in the Pacific Northwest, said that bookings for Alaska got off to a slow start this year. But it has been coming on fast since then, she said, "and we're now experiencing a very strong Alaska season, even a little above last year."
Tourism is Alaska's second biggest money maker, after oil and gas, and cruise ships are a major reason why. A study of the economic impact of the cruise industry on Alaska, commissioned by the International Council of Cruise Lines, found that in 2001 the industry accounted for $550 million in direct spending and more than 14,500 jobs.
Mayor Smith is particularly proud that the cruise industry in Alaska, some of whose ships were convicted of dumping polluted water and chemicals, appears to have cleaned up its act considerably. Princess ships visiting Juneau now shut down their diesel generators while docked and hook up to cables from a power station that provides the ships with hydroelectric power.
That has reduced residents' complaints about visible smoke emissions from visiting ships. Meanwhile, the amount the ships pay for the hydroelectric power goes into a fund that has the net effect of lowering energy bills paid by Juneau customers.
Last July, Alaska became the first state to regulate water pollution from cruise ships. The law permits state inspectors to fine shipowners for violations.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Vacancies Up in Fairfield, but So Are Building Prices

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
COMMERCIAL real estate in Fairfield County is going through a tumultuous time. Office vacancies have doubled from 6 and 7 percent two years ago to 13 to 16.5 percent, depending on which brokerage company is compiling the statistics. and asking rental rates keep dropping.
 But a river of cash is being pumped into the purchase of quality buildings by institutional and deep-pocketed local investors who have fled the stock market and seek stability in the county's real estate market. Prices, area real estate companies say , are approaching Midtown Manhattan's levels. 
 Ed Tonnessen, an executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth Inc., assesses the situation as "a major disconnect -- more capital is coming into the investment pipeline courtesy of Wall Street's underperformance, bidding up prices in light of the anemic market for leasing." 
Trophy office buildings are selling for up to $480 a square foot. That was the price per square foot, for a total of $115 million, paid in June by Scott Landis and Broadway Partners for Pickwick Plaza in Greenwich. The 238,000-square-foot complex of three buildings is fully occupied on long-term leases by Sotheby's, Deutsche Bank, financial services and insurance companies, hedge funds and real-estate investment trusts. "Rent is over $70 a foot," Mr. Landis said.
In Stamford, asking rents are around $28 a square foot annually on the outskirts and rise to the mid-$40's downtown. But rents in the broader market have fallen steadily since 2000. With vacancies in the high 20 percent range in some northern towns, average rental rates have dropped by about $4.75 a square foot to the low $30's in lower Fairfield and the high teens to mid $20's in the rest of the county. 
There is even some slippage in Greenwich, where economic downturns are hardly noticed and rents are the highest in the state. "Asking rents downtown are around $65 a square foot," said Jay Hruska, executive director at Cushman & Wakefield. "Greenwich Plaza is asking $70 a foot for 25,000 square feet of available space, but I don't know of deals that high. Small pockets of space are available in buildings along the West Post Road, including nine buildings at Greenwich Office Park, for $45 a foot."
In the next year, Arthur Sheehan, partner at Delmhorst & Sheehan Inc., a real estate advisory services company, said: "Leasing is going to remain weak. The real estate market typically lags the general economy, and since we see no uptick in New York or the regional economy, I don't expect Fairfield County to perform well."
Last year, during a slowdown preceding the Sept. 11 attack, industry professionals said the situation was manageable, following an overheated rental market in which bidding wars were commonplace. Today, of a countywide total of 44.9 million square feet of offices, some 7 million square feet are vacant, with around 35 percent of that available for sublease. Terms are negotiable, with some landlords offering one to three months of free rent plus renovations and many subleases including furnishings and phone systems.
Blocks of space over 100,000 square feet are available for the first time in years in a handful of existing buildings as well as at 601 Merritt 7, a new 255,000-square-foot building opening this fall in Norwalk, and at Building and Land Technologies' 350,000-square-foot office building under construction next to it. But according to Al Mirin, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis in Stamford, "large spaces are not in demand; the typical deal is 10,000 square feet."
While the buying of buildings continues, indicating confidence in Fairfield's long-term outlook, Dean J. Shapiro, executive director of the Fairfield-Westchester region at Insignia/ESG, says lower Fairfield County has matured to where space, infrastructure and transportation are at a premium, whether the economy is up or down.
"The market is stratifying," he said. "People who are here need to be here and have employees who can afford to live here. But a true headquarters operation runs the gamut from C.E.O.'s to clerks. If you're making $75,000 a year and you're living in Shelton or Monroe or Trumbull, you have over an hour's commute each way. If the same job opportunities apply in Shelton, that's where people will move." 
HE pointed out that Pitney Bowes, founded in Stamford in 1920, was considering selling its 450,000-square-foot building and moving its operation out of town, leaving a small group of executives in Stamford. "I think that's reflective of the market," he said. Sheryl Battles, vice president of external affairs at Pitney Bowes, said, "we are exploring a range of options."
Shelton, in eastern Fairfield County, has profited by an influx of companies disenchanted with the high cost of doing business in Stamford and the difficulty of keeping employees frustrated by Interstate 95 congestion. In the last 20 years, Robert Scinto has developed 2.6 million square feet of offices in 30 buildings in Shelton, Fairfield and Trumbull, where more than 4 million square feet of commercial space has been built or renovated in those decades. Only 11,000 square feet are vacant in the nine buildings that comprise his signature complex, Enterprise Corporate Park in Shelton. "You can attract labor at 25 percent less than Stamford," he said, "rent first-class office space for $18 to $23 a foot, and buy a new house in Naugatuck for $121,000."
Cindy Gabris, an administrative assistant, is typical of a growing number of people who live in eastern Fairfield County and quit their jobs in Stamford to work in Shelton. They took pay cuts of 20 percent or more to end the grinding commute and work closer to home. "Time with my kids is worth more than money," Ms. Gabris said.
But the allure of Stamford for major corporations and real estate companies is undiminished. Equity Office of Chicago owns 1.8 million square feet of offices in eight Fairfield County buildings, predominantly in Stamford. The Davis Companies of Boston has bought and spent millions renovating 1.2 million square feet of offices in eight buildings in Norwalk, Wilton, Fairfield, Trumbull and Milford, and W&M Properties of Manhattan has built or bought 1.8 million square feet of offices in eight buildings: five in Stamford, two in Darien and one in Norwalk. Properties like that are over 90 percent leased even in bad times. 
Older buildings from the corporate campus era have not fared so well in recent years. Greenwich American Center, a 606,000-square-foot headquarters on 150 acres near Greenwich's border with North Castle, was built for the American Can Company 34 years ago. It has changed hands several times, becoming a multitenanted building, and is now owned by GLC Realty. Asking rent for 200,000 square feet of vacant space is $35 a square foot. 
Xerox, a presence in Stamford since 1968, put its 255,000-square-foot headquarters up for sale in March 2001. The 25-acre campus at 800 Long Ridge Road is being marketed by Eastdil Realty at $250 a foot, or $63.7 million. "That's way too high for an old building," said Jeffrey R. Dunne, senior vice president of investments at CB Richard Ellis. Xerox owns the land, and Stamfex Associates owns the building on a lease-back to Xerox. 
Only two companies took a substantial amount of space in Fairfield County during the post-Sept. 11 leasing of backup offices by New York companies in New Jersey, Westchester and the New York City boroughs outside Manhattan. American Express took a 10-year lease on 192,000 square feet at 400 Atlantic Street at around $48 a square foot, but it is moving back to New York. The Thomson Information Publishing Corporation of Stamford is weighing subleasing 150,000 square feet. 
The second deal was struck by Citigroup Asset Management, which at first took 145,000 square feet at First Stamford Place, then expanded to 290,985 square feet on a lease expiring in 2010. It has no plans to move back to New York, according to Brenda Sniffen, Citigroup's facilities manager. Rental rates at Stamford Place's three buildings are in the high $30's. 
Christopher P. Bruhl, executive director of Sacia, southwestern Connecticut's business and industry association, said that vacant office space would be absorbed as companies resume growth. As for housing, he said, "from 1990 Stamford had the largest population growth in the state, 10,000 people. The city has added several thousand units of housing at market and affordable rates, stopping the cannibalization of lower-cost housing through gentrification." 
Delmhorst & Sheehan characterize Stamford as the central business district of the region, arguably validated by the completion of UBS Warburg's addition to its American headquarters on Washington Boulevard. It now measures a million square feet out of a maximum of 1.35 million square feet allowed by zoning, and has the world's largest trading floor.

HEADLINE: Wry, Tuneful Stories, All in 4-Minute Songs 

BYLINE:  By ED WARD 

 BODY:
TO the extent that most people have heard of Stew, it's as the leader of a band called the Negro Problem, a name that certainly draws attention to itself. But TNP, as its fans refer to it, is just one facet of this 40-year-old singer-songwriter's career, and over the last couple of years, he's put out a couple of solo albums that showcase a different approach to his music. 
 Stew was born Mark Stewart in Los Angeles, and as a black youngster with artistic leanings, he had a lot of trouble reconciling the kind of music he wanted to make with the music his peers were listening to. Then he heard the 60's psychedelic band Love, fronted by the enigmatic Arthur Lee, and something snapped. 
 "Arthur was the first person who made me feel I wasn't completely insane," Stew said by phone during a pause on his British tour recently. "I had no models for blacks writing this kind of melodic stuff, so it was a complete revelation, this delicate, almost fey music with what were pretty much baroque gangsta lyrics."
His quest sent him into the Los Angeles punk rock scene, and off to West Berlin in its 80's glory days, where he joined a performance art troupe for several years. All the while, he was secretly writing his wry, tuneful songs, and at the decade's end he headed back home. 
And, with the release of his new album, "Naked Dutch Painter" (Smile), Stew finds himself opening for his idol, Mr. Lee, who was released from prison in December after serving six years on firearms charges, on a tour that arrives at the Bowery Ballroom on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on Saturday and next Sunday. 
Not that there are stylistic similarities between the two men, although Stew uses the word "baroque" about both of them. The word crops up often with him: the liner notes of his new album say that it's "an AfroBaroque Production," and he describes the difference between his work with the band and his solo work by saying: "The Negro Problem is a baroque, busy thing. For the solo stuff, I started from scratch, so 'Guest Host,' my first solo album, was very stripped down, and for this one I got more complex. The goal, though, was to keep the lyrics in the forefront, which is tough for me." He credits his bass player and partner, Heidi Rodewald, with "keeping me in check so that the story isn't overwhelmed."
Ah, the lyrics. Stew's fans fall all over themselves making comparisons. Cole Porter's name is often mentioned, and some Randy Newman, some Warren Zevon and some Ray Davies can be heard in the mix.
"Cole Porter is an easy touchstone for people who are looking at pop with intelligent lyrics," Stew said, "but you can't play my songs for the average person and expect them to get it right away. That aspect of his work is something I'd like to work towards. What I'm doing on this record is an attempt to reach towards Jacques Brel, because I'm very impressed with his work from the 50's. I'd put Brel over Dylan in his ability to put the kind of narrative you usually find in novels, with thoroughly drawn characters and situations in a four-minute song." 
There's no question that the kind of music Stew makes isn't exactly top 40 material, any more than there's any doubt that there's a formidable intelligence behind it. The album's title track, starting with its extremely explicit first line, will certainly snap your ears to attention, is a semicomic meditation on how sexual mores in American differ from those in Europe; it is rendered with an admirable economy of expression and a catchy melody. And "Cold Parade," probably the most complex song on the album, is an unflinching but essentially sympathetic portrait of a lonely man with too much time on his hands. But Stew is just as capable of writing something like "Love Is Coming Through the Door," which is pure pop, with a great hook in its chorus, propelled by the drummer Clem Burke from Blondie.
So who is he writing for, anyway? "I get these really weird college-educated types, and I have a hard-core following of black cats like me, closet outsiders, whose taste doesn't jibe with the community's," he said. "Then there are the guys with John Lennon glasses who spend too much time in record stores, spend more money in them now because they have jobs, and their wives and kids worry about them because they're so serious. In short, people who take music seriously. Without going out on a limb about it, I'd say if you get it, it's for you."
I do get it, and, from the sound of things, so did the audience at a recent weeklong engagement at the Knitting Factory in Los Angeles, where the basic tracks for "The Naked Dutch Painter" were recorded. They were touched up in the studio, and there's no attempt to disguise the fact on the album: the ambience goes from live to studio and back again quite seamlessly. The album is perhaps the finest collection of songs an American songwriter has come up with this year, although I, too, may spend too much time in record stores. 
Meanwhile, there will be a new Negro Problem album in September -- in the punning style of the last one, "Post-Minstrel Syndrome" (1997) -- this one is called "Welcome Black," followed by a short tour of the West Coast and New York.
"I've got to have the whole band, the horns and everything," he said, acknowledging that that attitude limits the amount of touring he can afford to do. That's O.K. with him: better baroque than broke. And that just gives the many who haven't heard him yet time to catch up.

Stew
Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street.
Saturday and next Sunday.

HEADLINE: The Right Thing to Do 

BYLINE:  By Pam Belluck; Pam Belluck is the Boston bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
 I'LL BE SHORT
Essentials for
a Decent Working Society.
By Robert B. Reich.
121 pp. Boston:
Beacon Press. $20.
 As campaign books go, this one seems bolder than most, more willing to put stakes in controversial turf. "I'll Be Short: Essentials for a Decent Working Society," by Robert B. Reich, the secretary of labor in the first Clinton administration, is timed to coincide with his campaign for governor of Massachusetts and titled to play off Reich's ubiquitous, self-deprecating jokes about the fact that he is 4 feet 10 1/2 inches tall. 
It is not the safe campaign rallying cry that a cynical voter might expect. "I'll Be Short" is long on liberalism, an unabashedly passionate call for America to quit making the poor poorer as the rich get richer. And while Reich, a professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University, packs his arguments with economic logic, he ultimately concludes that the best reason to help society's less fortunate is that it's the right thing to do. 
"We're all in this together," Reich writes. "Our common wealth lies not in the fatness of our individual wallets but in the productivity of every one of us."
Reich's central point is that government and business have skipped out on the social contract, which he defines as a three-pronged commitment: as companies do better, their employees should too; working people should be paid enough to support themselves and their families; and public education should allow all of us the opportunity to develop to our full potential. As a result of the sorry shredding of social responsibility, Reich says, even in the financially flush 1990's the average family in Massachusetts, and presumably the rest of the country, lost out. Adjusting for inflation, the typical Massachusetts household ended the decade $4,700 poorer than it was at the start. 
"Should you care? Yes," Reich writes. "After a point, as inequality widened, the bonds that kept our society together would snap. Every decision we tried to arrive at together -- about trade, immigration, education, taxes and social insurance (health, welfare, retirement) -- would be harder to make, because it would have such different consequences for the relatively rich than for the relatively poor. We could no longer draw upon a common reservoir of trust and agreed-upon norms to deal with such differences. We would begin to lose our capacity for democratic governance." These are ideas that Reich has honed over the years, but they are updated for a post-Sept. 11, post-Enron society. 
His solutions involve companies doing more to help their workers, and government doing more to help families. Family-friendly workplaces should be the norm, Reich writes, with flexible work schedules, generous family and medical leave, and help with child care. More companies should provide their workers, including part-time workers, with health care and pension benefits. More companies should invest in employee training programs, and more should let employees participate in boom times with profit sharing and other programs. Companies should also work closely with public schools, providing apprenticeships as a way to hire graduates. 
As for government, Reich writes, it could raise the minimum wage to $7 an hour and expand the earned-income tax credit. And the Federal Reserve Board could allow the economy to grow fast enough so that the demand for low-wage workers exceeded the supply, which would mean their wages would rise. Reich is a fan of giving young families what he calls "a starter nest egg," a cash subsidy or a savings account designed to encourage people to save for the long term. And much more money should be spent on education, from universities on down. 
Reich does his best to make his 121 pages a breezy read. There are some glimpses of formative experiences from his personal life, like the way that he was sensitized to feminism when his wife, Clare Dalton, was denied tenure by the male-dominated faculty of her university. (Dalton, now a law professor at Northeastern University, won a lawsuit against the other institution and used the settlement money to set up an institute on domestic violence.) There is the advice he got from a boy who used to protect him from bullies when they were kids summering in upstate New York. The advice was that "bullies could not really hurt me if I was stronger inside than they were inside." The boy, it turns out, was Michael Schwerner, one of three civil rights workers murdered in 1964 while trying to register voters in Mississippi. 
Politically speaking, the book is not entirely predictable. For example, Reich writes that he favors a kind of school voucher system in which states would pay schools more money per pupil for poor students, and public schools could compete to enroll these disadvantaged students and receive the money that goes with them. "Don't call my proposal a voucher scheme," Reich writes in mock dread that people would think his idea was less than liberal. "Call it anything else. Call it liverwurst." He adds that "liverwurst is an idea whose time has come."

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind 

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

KOBA THE DREAD: Laughter and the Twenty Million, by Martin Amis. (Talk Miramax/ Hyperion, $24.95.) Amis's take on Stalin is like most people's now: the man was false, murderous and paranoid to a degree that defies consideration. But Amis is also deeply vexed at intellectuals who didn't know this soon enough or don't know it yet.

YOU ARE NOT A STRANGER HERE, by Adam Haslett. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.95.) These nine short stories (Haslett's first collection) exhale a desiccated bleakness, a despair mitigated by the characters' continuing desire to be good, to do the right thing despite hopelessness, loss, disease and mental illness.

THE WHORE'S CHILD: And Other Stories, by Richard Russo. (Knopf, $24.) In these short stories the author of "Empire Falls," this year's Pulitzer Prize novel, abandons working-class settings and protagonists in favor of intellectuals caught in late middle age, worried about illness and ambivalent about marriage.

EISENHOWER: A Soldier's Life, by Carlo D'Este. (John Macrae/Holt, $35.) A very thick book about an ambitious, self-confident man; it explores adeptly the events in 1944-45 that tested the limits of Eisenhower's abilities, which were enormous as to organization and political sensitivity but not as to strategic skills.

THE WINTER ZOO, by John Beckman. (Holt, $25.) The hero of this first novel, a young man newly arrived in Poland from Iowa, trades his naivete for lessons in youthfulness; Beckman captures the rush of freshly liberated desires in post-Communist Europe, making his climactic scene a pansexual orgy in a Cracow hotel.

PRAGUE, by Arthur Phillips. (Random House, $24.95.) A first novel set in 1990, far beyond the recently fallen Berlin Wall, where young Americans reveal themselves not as travelers but mere tourists, detached from their surroundings, weightless and immaterial among time-battered buildings and people who have survived wars and uprisings.

DARLINGTON'S FALL: A Novel in Verse, by Brad Leithauser. (Knopf, $25.) A 5,700-line verse novel (10-line stanzas, irregularly rhymed) that invokes the "butterfly effect" of chaos mathematics: a butterfly's random passage starts Russel Darlington on the road to a career in lepidoptery; many years later, a second butterfly lures him to fall from a cliff, crippling him permanently.

HALF IN LOVE: Stories, by Maile Meloy. (Scribner, $23.) Fourteen stories, set mostly in the author's native Montana, among small-time racetracks and failed oil wells, where brides choose wedding dresses to hide branding-iron scars; no one expects an easy life here, and even the young feel their choices constrained by economics and losing habits.

WHEN EVE WAS NAKED: Stories of a Life's Journey, by Josef Skvorecky. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A collection of short stories ranged chronologically along the span of the author's life; the amorous pursuit of teenage girls is a constant presence, but the grand themes of the 20th century will keep intruding.

HEADLINE: Eternal Squeeze 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

 BODY:
CEMETERIES make many people uncomfortable. They can be disturbing, even a bit creepy. They inspire small children to hold their breath while passing. But a well-maintained cemetery can be lovely and luxuriant and it can be a source of family pride. 
 Doris Finch Watson, 78, is the secretary-treasurer and the only paid employee of the 15-acre Middle Patent Rural Cemetery in North Castle. She is fond of cemeteries, especially historical ones, and especially hers. 
 Eight generations of her family have been buried in Middle Patent, including Samuel Banks, who, in 1743, was the cemetery's first customer. An island in the cemetery's small lake, Dorrie's Island, is named for her. Mrs. Watson owns a large family plot in Middle Patent that "can take care of quite a group," she said. 
But Middle Patent, and other cemeteries large and small in Westchester County, are at a fundamental turning point, economically, physically and legally. They are running out of space. Some are in danger of running out of money. Not least among their problems: the downturn in the stock market, which has brought bad news for the dead as well as the living.
Many of the county's smaller cemeteries, both nonsectarian and those affiliated with a church or synagogue, are running out of space for in-ground burials. Middle Patent Cemetery, for example, has room for only a few hundred more graves. And although it is theoretically possible to create new cemeteries in Westchester, it is unlikely that they will be built because of the scarcity and high cost of undeveloped land, said Richard Fishman, director of the Division of Cemeteries in the New York State Department of State, which oversees about 1,900 nonsectarian cemeteries in the state.
The way the cemetery business is conducted is also under examination. A federal court case has been filed in Syracuse that challenges the constitutionality of the New York State Cemetery Law. The case, brought by the New York State Association of Cemeteries, takes issue with the state's prohibition of cemeteries to run for-profit businesses like funeral homes and monument dealerships. Most other states have no such restriction. 
"New York State treats its cemeteries like quasi-charities and quasi-public utilities, but without the legal protection of either," said Bob Fells, external chief executive officer and general counsel of the International Cemetery and Funeral Association in Reston, Va., which filed a brief in suppport of the motion. 
"The very protective laws in New York State are anticompetitive and anticonsumer," he said, adding, "The domino effect is that it's a bad deal for everyone." 
State officials, however, defend the current system.
"It's public policy that the death-care industry is separate from cemeteries, but the cemeteries do compete against each other," said Mr. Fishman, who is responsible for overseeing the management of the 19 nonsectarian cemeteries in Westchester County. Religious cemeteries are owned and managed by churches and synagogues and are not governed by the state law. But sectarian and religious cemeteries in Westchester County charge very similar prices for burials, said John Crawford, who manages three funeral homes in Westchester and has worked with the majority of cemeteries in the county.
While all of Westchester County's nonsectarian and religious cemeteries are nonprofit, they do have to generate enough revenue to make investments that will pay for the maintenance of the cemetery long after every single plot is sold.
While Mr. Fells believes that burial prices will become less expensive in New York if the lawsuit succeeds, some local cemetery administrators disagree. 
"Lot prices in Westchester will always be competitive, based on supply and demand of what we have left," said Chester Day, president of Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla. 
Cemeteries in Westchester can charge what they want for burial rights, as long as they notify the state, Mr. Fishman said. 
BECAUSE Westchester is an expensive place to live, it is an expensive place to die, too. The cost of being buried in the New York metropolitan area, including Westchester, is highest in the state, Mr. Fishman said. Statewide, the average price for a burial plot is about $500, but in Westchester, it's at least $1,000, he said.
Buying burial rights means just that -- the right to be buried -- but the lot owner does not own the dirt and the grass. If a 30-square-foot plot costs about $1,200, that comes to a price of about $1.7 million per grassy burial acre in Westchester.
Generally speaking, the farther north in Westchester, the cheaper the burial plots. Prices at Hillside Cemetery in Cortlandt Manor begin at $875, but they can go as high as $5,000 for a plot for two in Beechwoods Cemetery in New Rochelle. Prices at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale can be as high as $4,500 for an in-ground burial plot and up to $15,500 for an above-ground space. 
While some people buy burial plots when a family member dies, others are enticed by advertising, the death of a close relative or a need to plan ahead.
Nicolina Arpaia, 43, of Hawthorne, whose father-in-law died a year ago, is also the kind of person who arranges major vacations a year in advance and who is thinking about arrangements for her son's wedding before he is even engaged. Recently, she and her husband, along with two sets of in-laws and her parents, who live in Italy, have bought seven additional spaces in a full-body crypt at Ferncliff Cemetery, at a cost of $17,000 to $22,000 for two spaces, depending on location.
"It's like heaven there," she said, "with music all around and in immaculate condition." Because she is a neat person, Mrs. Arpaia said, she is relieved to know that she will be in such a spotless, serene place for eternity. 
Burial prices vary within each cemetery, too, depending on the location of the grave site. At the huge 460-acre Kensico Cemetery, for instance, "we price lowest in the valley, and highest on top of the hills," said Mr. Day, the superintendent there. "It's the same way many homes are priced in Westchester," he added.
The size of a plot also matters. A small marker headstone, flush to the ground, requires much less space than an upright stone. And space for private mausoleums, which are becoming increasingly rare, can begin at about $150,000 at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, a Jewish cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson. But that is before construction: The final cost for a private mausoleum can range between $500,000 and $2.5 million, said Alan Goldsmith, executive director of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan, which runs the 17-acre cemetery.
Likewise, at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, the cost of buying property for a family mausoleum would be at least $105,000, before construction.
Keeping prices as high as possible is essential for many cemeteries because of the Byzantine accounting involved in cemetery economics. Cemeteries are required by New York State to reserve 10 percent of their proceeds in a permanent maintenance fund that goes into a trust, and 15 percent for current maintenance. If the cemeteries do not sustain a steady stream of new business, they will not have enough money to put aside for perpetual care or for daily upkeep, especially after all the grave sites have been sold. 
Although religious cemeteries are under no legal obligation to abide by this rule, many of them try to set aside at least that much. 
At Gate of Heaven Cemetery, a cemetery in Hawthorne which is run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, for example, "We set aside 50 percent of all lot sales in our permanent care fund," James Ford, the superintendent, said. About 80 percent of the cemetery's 250 acres has already been used, he noted, so the size of the fund becomes increasingly important.
Indeed, cemeteries are a place where someone has to mow the grass forever. And someone else has to be able to pay for it.
While some cemeteries are adept at caring for their maintenance funds, which are usually administered by an investment committee, others are not. The general fund and the trust fund at the 63-acre Ferncliff Cemetery in Hastings, for example, totals about $125 million, and is run by an investment committee that hires several investment managers, said Kevin Boyd, the cemetery's president. Ferncliff is perhaps the wealthiest cemetery in Westchester and the second most well-endowed in the state, Mr. Fishman said.
The health of cemetery investment funds is clearly dependent upon the health of the stock market. 
"Swings in the market can change our financial outlook considerably," Mr. Boyd said, "but we're in it for the longest of long terms, and we've had a good return over the past three to five years. It's every cemetery's goal to try to accumulate as large a fund as possible, while generating enough income to support the expense of the operation. We have to maintain these grounds in perpetuity, which is a long, long time."
Other Westchester cemeteries, however, are struggling financially, even under the close supervision of New York State auditors. 
"About six or seven cemeteries in Westchester have very little money in their trust fund," Mr. Fishman said, "and once they finish selling grave sites, they'll be in tough shape to maintain themselves." 
The 38-acre Beechwoods Cemetery in New Rochelle, for instance, has only $3 million in its investment fund, in part because it completed such a large proportion of burials in the 1920's and 30's, when the burial prices were as low as $50 or $60, said Jens Olsen, the cemetery's treasurer. 
If a cemetery goes bankrupt in New York State, it becomes a ward of the municipality, which means that local taxpayers are responsible for its maintenance. Cemetery officials said that is why most towns have a strong not-in-my-backyard reaction to cemeteries.
WHEN local cemeteries try to expand, they are often met with community opposition. Ferncliff Cemetery, which is 90 percent full, fought a legal battle with Hartsdale for six years before it could build a new, $25 million community mausoleum, Mr. Boyd said.
But this only illustrates the problem for future generations of what to do with the dead when there is no more room in the ground. Ferncliff Cemetery has only about 25 years of space left for in-ground burials, Mr. Boyd said. "If the trend toward cremation takes root here," he said, "we could do far more interments than full-body interments." 
Nationwide, about 25 percent of the deceased are cremated, including about 20 percent in New York State, according to figures released by the Cremation Association of North America. The association estimates that by 2025, nearly half of Americans will choose to be cremated, as will about 31 percent of New Yorkers.
At Kensico Cemetery, which does six or seven burials a day, or about 2,000 burials a year, "we'll run out of space for traditional burials by 2075," Mr. Day said. After that, he said, "it's my opinion that we'll see more cremations."
But Richard Brown, the superintendent of Hillside Cemetery in Cortlandt Manor, which is only about half full, has a more creative prediction.
"Maybe in the future there won't be anything like a cemetery." he said. "Your name will be on a big computer for people to look up.
"What it comes down to in the end, is a person wants a place to put his name, like a cemetery, so he knows he existed. Man needs that for some reason."

Where the Fabled and Famous Rest
Cemeteries in Westchester County compete, in part, by bragging about their famous dead, as well as by emphasizing the views and the superb upkeep.
Kensico Cemetery, the largest in Westchester, distributes a colorful sales booklet, which features the cemetery's green rolling hills, cherry trees in full flower and industrious maintenance workers mowing and raking.
"We're known for our care and maintenance." said its president, Chester Day. "We market the cemetery by the way it looks and the service we provide for families." 
Because it is so big, Kensico also has the most diverse group of famous dead. Lou Gehrig and Ayn Rand are buried there, and so are Danny Kaye and Sergei Rachmaninoff, and Flo Ziegfeld and Tommy Dorsey.
At the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, which is run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, the superintendent, James Ford, points out that Babe Ruth, James Cagney and Sal Mineo are buried there. About 3,000 burials a year are performed at the 250-acre cemetery, Mr. Ford said, adding that local celebrities including former New York City mayor, Jimmy Walker, and radio star, Fred Allen, are also buried there.
At Westchester Hills Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, the family mausoleum of Ira and George Gershwin has become a tourist attraction, said Alan Goldsmith, executive director of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan that runs the 17-acre cemetery. John Garfield, Billy Rose and Judy Holiday are also buried there. CARIN RUBENSTEIN

Here, Turf Is Diverse
AT Kensico Cemetery, the families Eng and Menendez are buried side by side, not far from lots that belong to the Actor's Fund and the Salvation Army. Large portions of Kensico Cemetery also include Korean and Chinese graves, in part because the cemetery has a large selection of east-facing hills, a preferred burial spot among Asians.
This diversity makes for compli cated visiting habits in nonsectarian cemeteries. 
Kensico Cemetery, for instance, provides stones for Jewish families, who traditionally place one atop a monument when they visit. They also provided burning baskets for Asian families, who burn paper at funerals, until this summer's drought, when fire danger necessitated the discouraging of this habit.
Asian families often leave food for ancestors when they visit cemeteries, which proves to be troublesome for cemetery maintenance staff, who have to remove the food and plastic containers fast, before savvy racoons discover the accidental feast.
Religious cemeteries have become more diverse as they have grown much less restrictive about who can be buried in their plots.
"There was a time in the past when Jewish and Protestant and Catholic cemeteries had stricter rules about who could be buried there," said James Ford, superintendent of Gate of Heaven Cemetery, a Catholic cemetery run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. A person can be buried at Gate of Heaven if a funeral Mass has been celebrated or if there is a note from the local parish authorizing the burial, Mr. Ford said. But he also acknowledged that a Jewish or Muslim or Baptist spouse can be buried in a Catholic's family plot, no questions asked.
At Mount Calvary Cemetery in White Plains, one of 12 parish cemeteries in Westchester, Jewish spouses are buried under stones that feature a Star of David and a cross, Anthony Ciulla, the cemetery director, said.
At Westchester Hills Cemetery, run by the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan, "anyone can purchase a plot, though the vast majority are Jewish," said Alan Goldsmith, executive director of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. The same is true at Temple Israel Cemetery, where a non-Jewish ceremony is not allowed, although a person doesn't have to be Jewish to be buried there. CARIN RUBENSTEIN
