HEADLINE: Design Is Set for Coast Guard Museum 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE

 BODY:
A GROUP that is working to open the first United States Coast Guard Museum in the country has announced its plans for a glass building near the lower Thames River and next door to Fort Trumbull State Park in New London.
 Urs Gauchat, an architect and the dean and professor of architecture at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, last week displayed his design for the museum: a mostly glass building buttressed on one side by a granite wall that is meant to evoke the look of Fort Trumbull. 
 Although financing for the museum is still in the works, the plan is to build a 40,000-square-foot building with four stories of display space. 
There will be modern interactive exhibitions, ships, buoys, search and rescue boats and an Imax theater. Outside a decommissioned lighthouse vessel will shine a beacon and there will a 120-space parking garage. Last year, those backing the museum organized the National Coast Guard Museum Association.
Speaking at the state park visitors center, the association's directors said they would raise $20 million and added that they were confident the United States Congress would provide another $10 million.
The association intends for the museum to open in 2005, when the public could visit free of charge.
"This is an incredible opportunity," Mr. Gauchat said. "There are 74 military museums of various kinds, but there is only one 5,000-square-foot space devoted to the Coast Guard." Mr. Gauchat was referring to a small exhibition at the Coast Guard Academy on Route 32.
The museum is the latest move in the urban renewal project in this mixed residential and commercial area of New London, which a few years ago was known more for a scrap-metal yard and sewage treatment plant than for its proximity to the waterfront. Now the area includes the new research headquarters of pharmaceutical company Pfizer, while the scrap-metal business has moved out of town. Fort Trumbull State Park, a former military post and later a sonar laboratory, opened last year. Its visitors center was finished this year.
The Coast Guard Academy is a few miles north of this spot, but the academy used to be situated at Fort Trumbull. The Coast Guard's New London station is nearby.
After the association revealed the design last week, its members also announced that they would be signing agreements with the New London Development Corporation for the corporation to take steps to buy the land they want for the museum and later to deed it at no cost to the Guard. The corporation already owns 80 percent of the site the Coast Guard picked, two acres that overlook the state park, said James J. Coleman Jr., chairman of the National Coast Guard Museum Association.
Another board member is State Senator Catherine W. Cook, a Republican from the 18th District. She said the Coast Guard had looked elsewhere in New London and in New Jersey and New York.
The New London corporation has been buying land by eminent domain for the last few years. While the museum association revealed its plans, Foe Hammerone, who belongs to a citizens' group fighting the taking of land by eminent domain, stood outside in protest.
Mr. Hammer, who owns commercial land in another area scheduled for redevelopment, said: "These homeowners were there first. Eminent domain is being used to take things from people."

HEADLINE: As the Economy Crawls, A Firm Looks for the Jobs 

BYLINE:  By JAAN van VALKENBURGH 

 BODY:
JOSEPH B. QUINN talks about pockets of opportunity in New York City and its environs.
 There are job openings in information technology, the security business, the credit and credit-analysis industries and asset management, he says. Teaching and health care also show promise. 
 Advertising budgets are growing, opening possibilities both at companies that place the ads and at ad agencies. "There would be maybe the beginning of a pattern there," Mr. Quinn said. 
But unless you're very lucky or have great connections, you can probably forget about Wall Street, investment banks, publishing and telecommunications.
Whatever their profession, job seekers might want to consider positions or firms not on their career radars a few years ago, Mr. Quinn says. Boutique firms with as few as 10 employees are cherry-picking in a lush crop of out-of-work professionals these days, he says, while larger firms are cutting costs and positions.
Mr. Quinn ought to know. As the newly created job market consultant for New York City at Lee Hecht Harrison, a career-services and executive-outplacement firm based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., he spends his days talking to recruiters, human-resources professionals and his own firm's counselors and poring over trade and business publications, all to get a fix on where the jobs are and where they aren't.
This year, what was once at best a part-time clerical job at his firm has been turned into a full-time one. Traditionally, outplacement agencies, many of which had their start about 30 years ago, haven't been in the business of doing market research for clients, or even finding jobs for them. That was left to recruiters and the clients themselves.
Instead, Lee Hecht Harrison stuck to counseling clients on how to look for work -- how to write a winning resume, how to ace interviews, how to network and even how to decide what career to go into or what career to switch to. Often, its services were paid for by the client's former employer as part of a severance package.
But last fall, its clients in New York City just weren't finding work, according to Jack Stillwaggon, general manager of Lee Hecht Harrison's three Manhattan offices. (The firm also has four New Jersey offices, one Long Island office and two Connecticut offices.) Almost 89,000 jobs were lost that quarter, according to the city's comptroller's office. Since then, the job situation has become even worse, with the unemployment rate going to 8 percent from 6.8 percent.
Then, late last year, news reached corporate headquarters that a couple of counselors in other cities were taking on new, unofficial duties: doing research on local economies and actually helping clients find jobs, rather than just prepare them for their searches. And, they were having some success at it.
As a result, Mr. Stillwaggon said, the company, which has 93 offices in the United States and 77 abroad, made an important policy switch. While Lee Hecht Harrison would not get into the recruiting business, it would offer clients regional job market research, as well as job listings from around the country on a proprietary Web site. And a newly created position, job market consultant, would complete the new tasks in each major market.
Since then, Lee Hecht Harrison has hired more than 50 job market consultants at its larger offices in the United States. By the end of the year, there will be 60.
The insights that Mr. Quinn has gained from his research into the local economy aren't terribly reassuring to job seekers.
"There are no huge optimistic signs that I'm seeing," he said. "Most people now, certainly recruiters, are saying, 'We need these eight things, and if you don't have these eight things. . . .' " He added, "It's their market, versus 18 to 24 months ago."
Not surprisingly, the worst place to be job hunting is probably Wall Street, he says. "The near total absence of merger-and-acquisition activity has left investment bankers a very expensive payroll item," he said, and major staff cutbacks are probably inevitable.
But information-technology workers should dust off their resumes, he says. Many recruiters are telling him that this fall will be the best quarter for them in two years, and in all specialties, he says. Skills that will be most in demand include familiarity with Sybase database software, which is often used by financial institutions to manage information, and with C++, an object-oriented language useful when writing large, complex programs.
There also is a need for people who can set up PeopleSoft programs that manage customer accounts, employee information or company financial statements. Later, people will be needed to maintain the system.
But even in information technology, employers are being choosier than ever in filling openings, according to Michael Cohen of Short Hills, N.J., who says he is undergoing the longest stretch -- 10 months -- of unemployment in his 21 years as an information technology worker on Wall Street.
"I spent my career in financial services, and that's an industry particularly hard hit at this time," Mr. Cohen said. He says his skills translate to other professions, but "I'm finding that unexpectedly difficult." Employers are demanding experience in their industries, as well as information technology itself, a hurdle he says he has never faced before. He compares the experience to being in a "rolling fall."
One man's stress, though, is another man's boon. Financial restructurings, or "workouts," on Wall Street mean firms need financial gurus to keep them in the black, or out of bankruptcy court, Mr. Quinn said.
Risk management has never been deemed more important. "Anything on or about making sure the i's are dotted and the t's are crossed," he said. That means accountants, who have received so much bad publicity lately, are in high demand. Just ask Thomas Bogle, director of corporate real estate services at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm. Mr. Bogle was hired nine months ago to expand the department, and he is looking both for new graduates with specialized real estate degrees as well as senior commercial real-estate professionals, he said.
"We are aggressively hiring," he said. "Corporations today are looking to be as efficient as possible."
Farther from the corporate sector, Mr. Quinn says there are ample openings in both education and health care, especially in mid- and low-level positions. "A C.F.O. or C.E.O. or someone in marketing can't go into those positions on a moment's notice," he said.
No matter the field, count on a longer interview process, including more background checks, he says. And until the economy rebounds, consider making a career out of a string of temporary jobs.
"More and more of the work force may be working on a contract basis," he said. In an employer's market, many firms would rather not offer training, benefits, or the financial commitment of a long-term position.
With senior positions scarce, laid-off executives with generous severance packages might consider starting a company, Mr. Quinn says. And for out-of-work managers whose skills aren't up to date or whose specialty is in an industry that isn't hiring, Mr. Quinn says, this might be a good time to put off the job search and go back to school.
"It's actually a great opportunity to do it," he said, "because you won't be missing the boat so much."

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES; 
Call It N.Y.S.E. North

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
IS it true that the New York Stock Exchange, which has been in the city since 1792, might be coming to Westchester? Before you go and bake a pie for the new neighbor, let's examine the whole situation.
 The exchange is known to be considering a second trading floor in addition to its historic site on the corner of Wall and Broad Streets. It needs a backup site to handle extra capacity and in the event of terrorism. But while the chatter about the exchange coming to Westchester has been intense, the details have proven as vague as a Halliburton earnings release. 
 One line of thought was that the N.Y.S.E. was just leaking the story that it is house-hunting in the suburbs to get a better bag of subsidies from the city and then open up its second floor in one of the boroughs. But if we are being used as a pawn, we must ask ourselves an essential question. Why Westchester instead of the king of all pawns, New Jersey? Does becoming pawn-of-choice signal an arrival of sorts, or a comedown? But I'm not here to wring my hands over questions of status, not when the cradle of capitalism might be rolling into town. 
Westchester residents seem somewhat blase at the prospect. Perhaps, what with the stock market's showing all the charm of a defoliant, getting the exchange has the distinct feel of a booby prize. Perhaps they may think we would be better off with a minor league ballpark or even a weekend visit by a traveling carnival. 
But, people, put your 401(k) bitterness aside for a moment. 
Consider that the county has been the home of so many with telepathic trading talent. Ivan Boesky used to live in Mount Kisco and now Martha Stewart has a home in Bedford. And don't forget that before she was a junior senator from New York, a certain Chappaqua resident was a fledgling trader with a run of beginner's luck. 
Furthermore, what's good for Wall Street is good for the county. The county's economy at large would prosper. How am I so certain? I used to work on Wall Street and ate lunch with traders. They ate so much, so quickly, that the rule was: put your hand anywhere near their mouths and you'll pull back a stump. Now, I suppose a case can be made that we're taking a risk by exposing our children to the sight of men consuming entire Reuben sandwiches in a hair under three seconds. But think of the money pouring into our delis.
The county is facing a deficit, and local taxes are on the rise. But if traders started satiating their outsize appetites at local establishments, lush times would follow. Call it corned beef recovery. 
The advantages go beyond the economic to the emotional. The presence of the N.Y.S.E. would give Westchester residents a well-deserved break from constant news about the dangers of Indian Point. All that talk about reserve margins would quickly give way to talk about margin calls; worries about spent fuel pools would turn into outrage over pooled asset accounting schemes; and nuclear fallout fears would be replaced by the fear of owning the latest I.P.O. clunker to go public on the exchange. 
I was so excited about the prospect of the exchange's arrival here that I called the county executive to gauge the exact status of negotiations. But a spokeswoman said that they have not even been contacted about any move. At first, this was puzzling. 
But the Colts football team did famously leave Baltimore in moving trucks under the cover of night. Could the exchange be planning its move to the suburbs in the same fashion? Are the people of, say, Verplanck, going to wake up one morning to the sound of the opening bell? 
They'd be waking up to a more exciting day. Something about the exchange floor invites an excess and flair that could sure liven up your average suburban subdivision. One time, Abbie Hoffman, trying to make some sort of point, threw fistfuls of dollar bills from the visitor's gallery to the floor of the exchange. Traders promptly stepped all over one another to grab the bills and stuff them into their pockets, proving, I guess, that if they haven't eaten lunch yet, traders will sock one another silly for Reuben money that is falling from the sky. And now the chance is there, after 210 years, for Reuben money to start falling to a suburban county's bottom line. It's something to be excited about, but remember: at feeding time, don't be careless with your hands.

HEADLINE: Design That Is Literally Accessible 

BYLINE:  By FRED B. ADELSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY 

 BODY:
MARLENE WEINER, an occupational therapist and one of the 29 interior designers participating in this year's Show House at the Shore, still becomes emotional when she thinks about how her work can help the elderly and the disabled to do something as simple as take a shower alone for the first time. 
 "It is the greatest blessing to make people feel better," and live safely, comfortably, and independently in their own houses, she said. 
 The show house -- this year actually a newly built house and a smaller cottage across the street -- is a fund-raising event, Show House of Champions 1 and 2, sponsored by the Ruth Newman Shapiro Cancer and Heart Fund. The show benefits the Gilda's Club South Jersey, which offers nonmedical support for cancer patients and their families and friends. 
The houses reflect two ends of the price spectrum to illustrate how what is known as universal design can solve the problems of everyday living that the elderly and the disabled face. They include features like stepless entries, wider doors and hallways, nonslip flooring without thresholds, casement windows, sitting work spaces, curbless showers, easy-to-grip lever hardware, offset plumbing control faucets, and grab bars coordinated with the decor. 
When well done, these elements can be be virtually invisible and can benefit everyone, regardless of age or ability. 
The two properties will be open to the public until Aug. 18, then both will reopen in November as a meeting place for the Gilda's Club. By appointment, the public will still be able to visit these universal design properties. 
Situated in the Atlantic Heights redevelopment district here, the main house, which cost about $1.3 million, was designed by Mark Petrella, senior associate at Sykes O'Connor Salerno Hazaveh Architects of Atlantic City. The modestly scaled accompanying cottage was designed by Cristina Buendicho of CB Architects of Ventnor. 
The buildings were financed by the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which uses casino revenue for urban revitalization and community development, with technical assistance from American Association of Retired Persons and the Center for Universal Design at North Carolina State University's College of Design.
The smaller property, with 1,449 square feet of living space, will serve as the prototype for new housing units, like the neighboring Carolina Gardens; the development authority plans to incorporate universal design in all its new construction.
The larger house brings to mind the magnificent Shingle Style houses along the Northeast coast dating from the 1880's. The exterior is sheathed with a textured pattern of shingles of varied shapes, stained Cape Cod gray set against the Nantucket-white trim. Like those 19th-century residences, this two-story home has a prominent gable that not only rises vertically but also expands horizontally; here it is asymmetrically placed to the left. 
The veranda is a significant feature of the exterior and complements the protruding octagon of the kitchen on the opposite side. Because Atlantic City is on a barrier island, the first floor must be raised to prevent flooding. Along with front steps, a gently sloped walkway and a vertical lift in the back provide alternatives to reach the elevated front and back doors. 
Inside, wide halls and generous door openings allow easy circulation through the 3,500-square-foot residence of four bedrooms and three and a half baths. The feeling of grandeur is reinforced by nine-foot ceilings. There is a bedroom and master bath on the first floor, and an elevator provides access to the second floor. The wooden steps of the main staircase have a darker stained edge for those with low vision. 
Universal design features are especially important in the kitchen, bathrooms and laundry rooms (with the elevated front-loading, front-controlled washer and dryer or combo units), where many top-of-the-line options have been installed. The rotating clothes rack in the closet of the upstairs front bedroom and the central vacuum system; the hoseless outlets (called automatic dustpans) in the kitchen are at floor level under the oven and dry pantry, amenities that would suit any house. 
The master bathroom on the first floor contains a toilet-bidet combination, and the upstairs master bathroom has a multiple-use bathing area to accommodate a variety of physical conditions. The soft tub has the sheen of porcelain over a cushioned surface that provides safety for the user while maintaining water temperature.
No expense was spared in the kitchen. With the deliberately distressed finish of the off-white wood cabinetry and the countertops with a Pompeian red strip to identify their edges, this luxurious space functions for standing or seated cooks. All appliances have front-panel controls for easier operation; the oven door swings open, not down. A two-drawer dishwasher efficiently assists with clean-up.
The rooms are handsomely appointed, and the landscaped and furnished deck off the master bedroom on the second floor should not be overlooked. Unfortunately, some spaces seem too cluttered for wheelchair users or anyone with limited visibility. 
In the cottage, Ms. Weiner of Interiors for Independence, the only designer who specializes in universal design environments, created a vibrant, marine-themed bathroom. Her work demonstrates that less can be more.
Universal Design Demonstration House Show House of Champions 1 and 2, North Carolina Avenue at Absecon Boulevard, Atlantic City. Through Aug. 18. Information: (609) 345-8182

The dining room is below left. (Photographs by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Co-op Board to Buyer: Information Please 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
"IT is one of the most personally invasive experiences in most people's adult lives," said Douglas Wagner, president of Benjamin James Real Estate, a Manhattan brokerage firm, referring to the "board package" that prospective buyers submit when they want to buy an apartment in a co-op building.
 The written material, sometimes several hundred pages thick, provides an exquisitely detailed financial and personal portrait. "It is time consuming, tedious and confusing," Mr. Wagner said, "and yet many people take on the challenge in exchange for the privilege of owning property in Manhattan." 
 For apartment purchasers, it is also unavoidable. "It is the way we do business in New York City," said Paul Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, another Manhattan-based brokerage firm. "Eighty-five percent of our market is still co-ops rather than condos, and if you want to see the entire marketplace and everything available, this is what you will be up against." 
That does not mean that people seeking to buy co-ops elsewhere in New York City and its suburbs are not called on to pull back the curtains on their lives, financial and personal, to a panel of strangers, but they usually do not have to do so to such a painstaking extent. "In Manhattan they want more detail," said Gregory J. Carlson, executive director of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives and Condominiums, which represents 450 buildings, 90 percent of them co-ops, primarily in Queens, Manhattan and Brooklyn. 
Want to buy without having to divulge things you might not tell your spouse, your mother, your psychiatrist? 
In the past, people who balked at baring their financial souls to a group of strangers, turned to condominiums -- where residents purchase real property rather than shares in a corporation -- instead. Unless they can prove the buyer is attempting to commit fraud in some way, by law condo boards are not entitled to reject a buyer on financial grounds without buying the apartment in question themselves. Despite that, condominium boards, too, are becoming more particular about financial credentials. And landlords with rental properties are also requiring tax returns, credit histories and reference letters. 
But the breach of privacy remains greater in the co-op arena, especially in Manhattan. 
"There are two parts to acceptance by a board," said Ronni Lynn Arougheti, president of Heron Ltd., a management company, and Heron Residential, a brokerage. "They want to make sure the person buying is financially capable of carrying the apartment, and they want to make sure the person will make a good neighbor." 
The board package, usually put together under the tutelage of the broker, can be voluminous, sometimes running many hundreds of pages.
Every building has its own set of requirements, beginning with a purchase application form, either one devised by the board or a standard form put out by the Real Estate Board of New York, that gives such basic data as names and addresses of all potential occupants (children and pets included), occupations, income and education.
But that is only the preface. "Employment must be verified with a letter from the employer that states the job title and annual income," Ms. Arougheti said. "That letter should also say that while it cannot guarantee a bonus, it has awarded them in the past. It should also discuss future raises."
Full disclosure of net worth is critical, and more than any other single factor can tip the balance toward or away from approval.
"A financial statement, which is also provided by the managing agent, often a standard form that has the approval of the co-op board, must be filled out in detail, and substantiating statements must be provided to back up all numbers," said Susan Renfrew, the new president of the Charles H. Greenthal brokerage firm. Until June she was director of East Side sales at Insignia Douglas Elliman.
"Some boards," she said, "require three months of bank and brokerage statements, checking accounts, retirement accounts, lists of any other real estate owned and mortgages held. 
"Two years of tax returns are standard," she continued, "along with W-2 forms. If the purchaser is selling an apartment, a contract of sale for that may be required, along with an appraisal of worth and mortgages still held. 
"If there is to be a mortgage on the new purchase, the mortgage application and commitment letter are included."
In addition, stocks and bonds, life insurance, 401(k)'s and other retirement accounts, trust funds and alimony are taken into consideration. Every line item must be verified, so banks are called upon to substantiate balances. "If an investor has a diverse stock and bond portfolio, we need statements going back 60 or 90 days and 12 bank statements," Mr. Wagner said.
But salary counts for more than investments, whose value tends to fluctuate, especially now. "It's nice to know there are investments to fall back on in case of need, but when we assess the ability to carry an apartment, we look at income," said David A. Rockwell, a senior vice president at Marsh & McLennan who has been president of a 128-unit co-op in Chelsea for 12 years.
"If you are an investment banker largely dependent on bonuses, we would discount the bonuses. If you made $250,000 to $500,000 two years ago, we wouldn't expect that this year." 
Neil J. Binder, co-owner of the Bellmarc Companies and author of "The Ultimate Guide to Buying and Selling Co-ops and Condos in New York City," agreed. "If you have a commission income, the board will want a stronger balance sheet, a lot more wealth to offset uncertain income." 
Entrepreneurs who own their own businesses face a special challenge.
"It is impossible to easily evaluate the value of a business and the amount of income it generates," said Arthur I. Weinstein, a lawyer who is vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. "A letter saying, 'I pay myself X amount of dollars' is difficult, and even the authenticity of tax returns is difficult. 
"People send in photocopies of tax returns, and in smaller buildings they are almost always accepted as accurate," Mr. Weinstein said, "but a building that does more rigorous exams could ask for certification from an accountant or even a copy from the I.R.S."
Such reports are usually covered by the co-op's nonrefundable application fee -- typically, $500 -- although there could be additional charges if an investigation is particularly extensive, Mr. Weinstein said.
By and large, liquid assets that can be readily converted to cash weigh more heavily than personal possessions like art, antiques, yachts and vintage cars, but those, too, must be listed, along with appraisals of their worth. 
"The area of most concern for boards is liquid assets," Ms. Renfrew said. "They want to know if anything were to happen to buyers, if they lose their job or their company downsizes, that there are immediately funds to cover the maintenance. Often, they are looking for twice the value of the apartment in liquid assets. On the Upper East Side the most sought-after buildings may want to see five times the value in liquid assets." 
In Mr. Weinstein's view, concern about the availability of funds can sometimes be exaggerated. "Under current law in cases of default, a co-op's claim for unpaid maintenance takes precedence over most other claims, bank loans, personal debt, credit card debt," he said. "So when a person is in arrears on maintenance, the co-op board almost always gets paid."
By contrast, Mr. Carlson said, "As a rule of thumb, in the boroughs other than Manhattan, they are looking for two to five times the annual maintenance in liquid assets, as opposed to the total value of the unit."
BOARDS also require that reference letters go into the package, typically three personal recommendations attesting to the purchaser's standing in the community and sense of responsibility and three business letters describing professional reputation and dependability. 
"You want diversity in your letters and you want to avoid controversy, so we tell people to avoid using very visible politicians or religious figures," Mr. Purcell of Insignia Douglas Elliman said. "We like to get letters from people who live in co-ops." 
In a course called "Admissions Issues" that he teaches for board members, Mr. Weinstein said, "We urge buildings to call the letter writers asking, 'Did you write that letter?' and 'Is there anything else you would like to add?' That may turn up things people don't want to put in writing."
In Mr. Weinstein's experience, "how hard it is to put together the package is a function of the value of the apartment."
"If it ranges from $75,000 to $350,000, the review is generally based on the documents as submitted," he said. "But from $375,000 up, they start to look for accountant verification. Almost all buildings have at least a rudimentary credit report and as you go up the scale, that might include litigation history. Buildings want to know if the applicant has a habit of suing over inadequate hot water or gets into disputes with neighbors." 
The prospect that a candidate might haul a board into court could be enough to tilt it toward rejection. Boards are not compelled to divulge why they turn applicants down so long as they do not violate city, state and federal civil rights laws banning discrimination on the basis of race, creed, color, national origin, age, disability, sexual orientation, marital status, citizenship, children or occupation.
No one keeps records of the number of rejections, but in Mr. Weinstein's experience, they occur less commonly than rejections by lending institutions.
In fact, some boards, especially outside Manhattan, will help candidates whose net worth falls below expectations, in particular young people at the beginning of their careers, by letting them use guarantors or put funds in escrow. Guarantors must be willing to open up their own financial records.
"We try to work with people," said Mr. Carlson, speaking as a member of the board at his own 424-unit building in Forest Hills, Queens. "If someone is on the borderline and is taking a 15-year mortgage, I look to see if they would qualify for a 30-year mortgage," which would mean they would have lower monthly payments and could more easily fit the board's requirement for ratio of housing expenditure to income. 
Rather than conceal whatever blemishes they may have, buyers are urged to address problems with candor. "If there is anything in your application that raises issues, like bad credit in the past, address it up front," Ms. Arougheti said. "Candidates who do that fare better than those who wait for the board to detect something."
What impresses one board might have no positive impact for another. For example, Mr. Wagner said, "We had one buyer for a loft on Prince Street who included 10 pages of photos of his art collection because he wanted to demonstrate that he was not only financially worthy but that he was similar to people already in the community." 
That might not be so effective uptown, where boards are more concerned with bank accounts than with art. "It is safe to say that Fifth and Park Avenues and Central Park West have the most arduous demands," Mr. Purcell said, "but there are some lovely buildings on side streets that are very particular, too." 
In some ways, the board package is meant to be as enlightening to the prospective purchaser as it is to the board. Some of them include documents that purchasers must sign certifying that they understand and accept regulations. 
"Every co-op has rules that pertain to renovation, when you can do repairs in the building, where you can store bicycles and strollers," Ms. Renfrew said. "The purchaser must agree to abide by them and must also sign a lead paint form in which the seller discloses whether they have knowledge of the presence of lead."
Then there is the divisive issue of pets. Some buildings ban dogs altogether, others impose weight limits and still others hold themselves out to be "pet friendly." 
"There is one board that required a certificate from dog obedience school, and I have buyers who don't have one because the husband trained the dog himself," Ms. Arougheti said. While some board members advocated requiring that the dog be sent to a certified training school, the final decision was to admit the dog, and its owners. 
BEFORE the package, a copy of which must be made for each member of the board -- most have seven -- is submitted, it is reviewed by the managing agent and sent back to the prospective buyer's broker if it is deemed lacking in any way. 
"Incomplete applications are not submitted and yet we still get incomplete applications," said Ms. Arougheti, who is the author of a guide called "Hints for Expediting the Process." 
"Usually boards want the package in a certain order," she said. "Some insist on dividers, some say no dividers, some want them loose leaf, some want them bound. Some accept cover letters, other specify no cover letters."
To Christopher Thomas, senior vice president and director of sales for the Brooklyn office of William B. May, distinctions in board attitudes are largely dependent on geography and size. 
"The differences are to a certain extent due to the fact that we have different types of co-ops here," he said.
"Large 100-unit co-ops are the norm in Manhattan and the exception in the landmark areas of Brooklyn we handle: Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and Cobble Hill. And most large organizations are constrained by their size to be less flexible and need to rely more heavily on well-established policy."
Furthermore, he continued: "For the most part architecture in these neighborhoods is four stories. So in many instances we are dealing with co-op boards that consist of the entire population of a building."
That generates a much less formal process. "Typically," Mr. Thomas said, "the seller runs into the neighbors while they are taking the garbage out and says, 'Oh, by the way, I found a lovely couple to buy. Let's meet so we see if we all feel comfortable.' They get together, usually in the seller's apartment, and if it seems they like the lovely couple, then they ask for the package as confirmation." 
Mr. Thomas believes boards "have gone overboard in Manhattan."
In his area in Brooklyn, he said, "the question they want answered is simple: 'How much is it safe to expect that our new neighbor will earn and will that cover the costs of living in this building?' Most boards see their mandate as verifying the financial qualification of the buyer to purchase at a specified price, but they do not have the desire to be overly intrusive."
GEOGRAPHY is not the only determinant of board behavior, said Mr. Binder, the Bellmarc executive. "When the economy is strong," he said, "boards are tougher and when things weaken, they become a little more accommodating because sellers are more desperate to sell. In a good market they know it's not hard to find another buyer."
Roberto Viceconte, a lawyer, has sat on both sides of the fence. When he bought his co-op in a building in East Rockaway about two years ago, he was taken aback by the amount of information he had to provide. 
"You feel exposed," he said. "We are brought up to be very private about certain things. No one sees our paychecks, tax returns or bank statements. Now you are moving into some place and you have to show all that information to your potential neighbors so you can get in. It's kind of frightening." 
Then he was elected to the board. "Now I understand why we need that information," he said. "Ultimately, we must see if they are financially capable."
When all is said and done, the memories recede. Mr. Viceconte said he does not recall the contents of financial statements when he encounters buyers in the elevator months after approval is granted. "Once we're done with those packages, they are destroyed, and we forget the details," he said.
In fact, Mr. Purcell said, "Finding a property, negotiating, getting a mortgage, moving are stressful in and of themselves. Then add in the element of being judged by a group of strangers, which can be an incredible experience -- like getting into a fraternity or sorority. But we have a unique capacity to forget how painful it is -- and sometimes we even go through it again."

HEADLINE: A State With a History Of Overlooking Its Past 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

 BODY:
TUCKED in the rolling hills at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains, the former country manse of the Cooper-Hewitt iron barons awaits visitors. In a two-hour period on a pristine summer day, a lone family stops by Ringwood Manor to be guided through the 51-room National Historic Landmark.
 Walking up the stairs, they could have reached out and touched a John Singer Sargent oil portrait of Peter Cooper. Directly across from the priceless painting are rusted coils popping through an Empire settee, where the silk seat was destroyed by a squirrel 25 years earlier. 
 On an equally sunny day a week earlier, at Monmouth Battlefield in Manalapan, site of the Revolutionary War's most artillery-laden battle and one of Washington's most decisive victories, a man walks his beagle through a vast, grassy field. 
Had the solitary figure bothered to go in the visitor's center, he would have found one small poster detailing Washington's triumphs there. He might also have wished to trace the route of the battle using the lighted three-dimensional model there, though that would have been impossible. It has not worked for 10 years.
Often referred to as the "crossroads of the American Revolution" -- where American soldiers first turned back the British -- New Jersey boasts more Revolutionary War battle sites than any other of the other colonies. Moreover, much of the country's Industrial Revolution began here, labor unions were born here, the phonograph and incandescent lightbulb were invented here, and the father of the theory of relativity lived and died here.
Yet while historic sites like Biltmore Mansion in North Carolina, which surpassed Ringwood Manor as the country's largest home at the turn of the century, or Valley Forge National Park in Pennsylvania, where Washington trained his troops to fight at Monmouth, enjoy a steady stream of visitors in summer, most people in New Jersey are not even aware of the richness of the state's history, never mind where to find it.
History has always been viewed as something of a stepchild in New Jersey by the state agencies that support it -- perhaps because historians are by nature unassuming and therefore less adept at lobbying for financing. Or possibly it is another example of the low self-esteem in which New Jerseyans hold themselves. Whatever the cause, New Jersey's history does not seem to get the respect it deserves.
Frustrating many history advocates is what they see as the state's failure to recognize the value of maintaining these sites, not only to protect the state's past but also to tap into the burgeoning trend in heritage tourism. New Jersey lags far behind other states like Virginia, Pennsylvania and New York, which has turned history tourism into a major industry.
David Cowell, president of the Advocates for New Jersey History, said the effort to promote heritage tourism here began only about five years ago, after a survey by the Center for Urban Policy Research found that visitors in New Jersey were spending $432 million annually, $89 million of which could be directly linked to history-related activities. Yet the state has continued to dole out financing with an eyedropper.
"Heritage tourists provide much more economic benefits than any other form of tourism," said Barbara Mitnick, chairwoman of the New Jersey Historic Trust. "If the state would just realize this, maybe they'd invest in these sites instead of thinking they're pouring money down a hole."
To be sure, not all the state's history is unrecognized. In recent years, a groundswell of support from various groups and a savvier approach to securing grant money has managed to keep many of the state's independently run historic sites humming.
But New Jersey's historic jewels -- those owned and operated by the state -- are in their worst shape ever. Buildings that have been neglected for years await attention as the state's capital improvement budget has been slashed; artifacts valued at millions of dollars are deteriorating because of substandard conditions and a lack of maintenance; programs, staffing and hours have been reduced; and the department that oversees these properties is both leaderless and rudderless.
While all state agencies took significant blows in the recent round of budget cuts, sites and activities tied to the state's colorful history were among those hardest hit.
For instance, $2 million of New Jersey Historical Commission's $4.5 million in grants for 2002 were frozen and then lost after Governor-elect James McGreevey requested last December that all spending be suspended. This year the commission was appropriated just $2.5 million, though in a last-minute reprieve the Treasury Department added another $1 million.
The Garden State Historic Preservation Trust Fund is currently sitting on $11 million in grant funds for "brick-and-mortar" work on historic sites because the state's hiring freeze has prevented the New Jersey Historic Trust from hiring someone to review the 2002 and 2003 grant applications. But even if these funds were to be freed up, they could not be used to finance programs or restoration at state-run historic sites.
"The state-owned sites are in the biggest trouble, and these are the most important sites in the state," said Michael Zuckerman, executive director for the Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts. "They have never been adequately funded, even through the boon years of the 90's."
As many see the problem, the state's historic sites lie buried beneath two layers of government, neither of which puts preservation as a top priority. The division of parks and forestry -- an arm of the Department of Environmental Protection -- operates the state's 57 historic sites, many of which are within the park system itself.
"We're very low down in the pecking order," said Mr. Cowell, who for years has been lobbying either to move the sites from under the auspices of the of the environmental agency, or to create a separate cabinet-level department for history. Several history-related entities, like the state museum and the state archives, were reassigned to the Department of State after a 1997 task force report outlined the sorry state of New Jersey's heritage. But the major sites -- like Princeton and Monmouth Battlefields, Washington's Crossing, Grover Cleveland's birthplace, Batsto Village and Ringwood -- remained within the parks system.
For his part, Bradley M. Campbell, the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, said it made sense that the historic sites remain under his department's gaze, not only so park employees could care for the buildings and grounds, but also because in difficult financial times like these, money could be channeled from other sources within the agency.
Acknowledging what he called "a backlog of neglect" at the state's historic sites, Mr. Campbell said his department was "looking to find nonstate sources of funding for urgently needed projects."
Yet in preparing his budget, it was clear that Mr. Campbell was not looking toward state funds to solve the problem. In the first round, the environmental agency recommended eliminating all capital financing for the resoration of historic sites. This came after the department froze $8.4 million of the $16.5 million appropriated for 2002 capital improvements. In the end, $2.5 million was allocated for capital projects for 2003 within the parks division, the lowest level in the last four years. While the appropriation for capital improvements in the 2003 budget was reduced by more than 80 percent, the parks division's operating budget was reduced by slightly more than 3 percent, from $39.9 million to $38.6 million. 
Last week Mr. Campbell announced the release of $9.3 million of frozen and deferred expenditures as well as $1.8 million for Rockingham in Kingston, Washington's last wartime headquarters where he wrote the farewell orders to his troops, and an additional $2.5 million for a variety of projec ts in the fiscal year 2003, fulfilling Governor McGreevey's promise to spend more than $10 million on capital improvements in the parks this year.
Many refer to Rockingham, a 300-year-old house, as the poster child for what has gone wrong with the state's historic sites. Last summer it was relocated and protected with weatherproofing and tar paper while awaiting the release of the $1.8 million for restoration.
"We're working with treasury to release some of the frozen funds to move forward with a collection of projects we expect to announce soon," said Mr. Campbell, noting that in recent years, money had been appropriated but not spent. "We expect to spend more in parks' capital projects than has been spent in recent years."
In addition to Rockingham, said the acting parks director, Dick Barker, the sites to benefit from the new funds are the central railroad terminal at Liberty State Park, the crown jewel in the state park system, which will receive $3 million of the total $9.3 million, Batsto Village's visitors center, the Barnegat Lighthouse and the general store at Allaire Village. 
Other major projects, like shoring up the 18th-century ruins at Long Pond Ironworks in New Milford, or installing temperature controls at Ringwood Manor to preserve the mansion's multimillion-dollar art and artifacts collection, continue to be put off. Smaller "nonessential" projects like providing a public restroom at Grover Cleveland's house or fixing the lighted model at Monmouth Battlefield have little chance of ever being addressed. 
"We just defer those jobs," said Mr. Barker. "They just don't get done. The holes in the roof might get a little bit worse, the buildings and facilities will deteriorate for another year. There are lots of concerns when you're talking about our historic resources."
With so many projects going wanting, the skeptics have yet to be convinced of Governor McGreevey's commitment to historic sites, especially when looking at the huge gaps in the park division's current management team.
In May, the Department of Environmental Preservation cited Gregory Marshall for his work on behalf of historic preservation. While most other awards went to historic sites or projects, Mr. Marshall was chosen because "every so often, someone surfaces whose contributions to the advancement of historic preservation and the preservation of historic sites in New Jersey is so deserving of recognition that an award is given to one individual." 
Three months earlier, Commissioner Campbell had fired Mr. Marshall, who for 18 years was director of the division of parks and forestry. While Mr. Marshall was considered by some park employees to be a taskmaster, he was generally regarded as an earnest advocate of historic sites. A group of concerned citizens, including Mr. Cowell and Maureen Ogden, a former assemblywoman and champion of the state's historic past, met with the commissioner to try to save Mr. Marshall's job, but "it was already a fait accompli," according to Ms. Odgen.
Among Mr. Marshall's initiatives was the American Revolutionary War campaign, which resulted in a brochure and driving tour guide of 22 Revolutionary War sites throughout the state. 
"We had some very good projects going on that were halfway in the pipeline until the budget got screwy," said Mr. Marshall, who now works for the National Park Service in New York Harbor. "Life is about priorities. You have to make decisions about what gets done and what doesn't."
Shortly after Mr. Marshall left, his deputy director, Carl Nordstrom, who had been with the department more than 20 years, left to take a nongovernment job. Mr. Barker had also put in for retirement, but agreed to stay on as acting director until Nov. 30, by which time Commissioner Campbell said he expected to have hired "an excellent replacement."
The parks division suffered more loss when many of the senior management team chose to take an early retirement package offered by the state as a cost-cutting measure. Since July 1, all four of the regional superintendent posts have been vacant, while six park superintendents and 20 other park employees chose early retirement. For now, Mr. Barker said he was looking into interim appointments while awaiting permission to begin filling the more crucial posts.
Commissioner Campbell said he preferred to view the clean sweep as an opportunity. "A generation of leadership has moved on, which presents short-term challenges," he said, "but it also opens us up to new thinking and a more diverse government."
This is the opportunity that awaits: The Task Force on New Jersey History, which spent 18 months investigating the resources and producing a four-volume report in June 1997, concluded that the state needed to spend $10 million to hire adequate staff for programming, operations and outreach at its historic sites, plus another $17.5 million to meet the conservation needs of the millions of historic artifacts belonging to New Jersey.
In the meantime, with limited funds and a reduced staff, public programming at many historic sites has taken a serious blow. 
Besides a dedicated corps of volunteers, most of the history-related activities fall to the 24 historic interpretive specialists working throughout the park system, whose job description includes everything from curator to tour guide. Several of the 57 historic sites have no staff on hand, and many of the sites are open to the public less than 10 hours a week. 
For example, the Craig House, used as a field hospital to treat British soldiers during the Battle of Monmouth, is open four hours each Sunday from May to October, with the entire staff consisting of volunteers from the Friends of Monmouth Battlefield State Park.
For years, Richard Walling, president of the Friends, has been asking the state to pay for construction of a tour road through the park and to restore a second house to be used as a museum dedicated to women of the Revolutionary War. In 1994, $1 million was budgeted for new fencing, landscaping and interpretive signs. Eight years later, Mr. Walling said, the state is still working on the text for the panels.
"This is a national landmark, the equivalent of Mount Vernon," said Mr. Walling. "Yet as you drive around, you see nothing to indicate the battle of 20,000 men that took place here. No markers, no monuments, no cannons. There's no vision, no long-range plan for this park, just as there's no vision or plan for all the historic sites in the state."
Indeed, some sites have had to curtail public visits because of the poor condition of the structures. In its heyday, Batsto Mansion in the Pine Barrens, home of one of the country's earliest ironmasters and later of the Philadelphia industrialist Joseph Wharton, had seven tour guides with two or three groups touring the mansion at any given time, said Bud Wilson, a local historian.
But the building's cracked foundation and shifting porch was causing concerns not only for the integrity of the building but also the safety of visitors themselves. Consequently, the mansion was recently closed so the state could determine how to save it. The structural survey has been completed, but Al Payne, the project engineer for the parks division, said the restoration work, estimated at $600,000, was not included in the current budget cycle.
Short of an actual capital outlay, supporters have been pushing for a dedicated source of financing for the state's historic sites, either through a bond issue or a surtax on hotels, restaurants and other tourist-related industries. But so far, the Legislature is not buying.
"We need strident, outspoken advocates for New Jersey's history and a stable source of funding for these sites," said Ms. Ogden. "Some of these buildings and artifacts, if they are ignored for another 10 years, are just going to be lost and that's too bad."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Investment Clubs Are Zeroing In on Real Estate

BYLINE:  By LEAH BETH WARD 

 BODY:
AT a recent club gathering at J J North's Grand Buffet, an all-you-can-eat restaurant in Portland, Ore., dozens of people took turns introducing themselves to the crowd of more than 100. "Hi, my name is Josh," one of them said nervously, "and I just did my first investment this week." Cheers erupted, and Josh Fuhrer, 28, a local part-time actor, blushed with pride.
 Mr. Fuhrer wasn't talking about just any investment. He and the others in the group, many of them undoubtedly concerned about volatility on Wall Street, are turning their attention instead to Main Street and the physical assets that they can see, touch and drive by -- from studio apartments to single-family homes to multi-unit apartment buildings. The Northwest Real Estate Investors, as the Oregon group is called, meets regularly, in almost support-group style, to trade tips and swap stories about real estate investing in the Portland region. 
 Whether the club and others like it will reap long-term profits remains to be seen. Nonetheless, the popularity of these groups has been climbing rapidly. 
National figures are hard to come by, but real estate investment clubs from New York City to Charlotte, N.C., to Portland say their ranks are swelling. The National Real Estate Investors Association, which offers services to clubs (www.nationalreia.com), estimates that there are some 600 real estate investment groups nationwide, nearly double the number just two years ago. Several have popped up recently in Arizona, Ohio and Texas, for example.
The Portland club was incorporated last August with 30 members; it now has 160. Interest has been so strong that it has added two meetings a month, bringing the total to three. The group has also had to book larger meeting space, according to its president, Mark LaNore, a loan officer at the Lighthouse Financial Group, a mortgage company in Portland.
Mr. LaNore and others say that now is a good time to invest in real estate: demand is high and interest rates are low.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 6.43 percent for the week ended Friday, according to Freddie Mac, a government-sponsored buyer of home mortgages. That was up from 6.34 percent the week earlier, the lowest since the agency began tracking the rate 31 years ago.
Sales of existing homes, meanwhile, have been brisk for much of the year: they were running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.1 million in June, and the National Association of Realtors is forecasting record sales for the year. And new-home sales rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of one million in June, a record.
"There is more money chasing real estate than there is real estate," Mr. LaNore said. "It's nuts, but it's the game right now."
That is where real estate investment clubs are supposed to help. The clubs serve as an informal repository for available inventory. Buyers and sellers announce at meetings what they are looking for or what they have for sale. Then they trade business cards. Members can also attend workshops and meet professionals -- lawyers, accountants and real estate agents who can give free advice on deals.
Real estate clubs, of course, have been around for many years -- at least as long as the phrase "no money down," the pitch of late-night TV real estate promoters who sell tapes, videos and books on how to become a millionaire without sweating the equity. Most real estate clubs, though, don't stump for such salesmen, preferring to let inexperienced members learn the ropes by mingling with the more seasoned members.
Nicholas Zampetti Jr. of Bogota, N.J., president of the Metropolitan Real Estate Investors Association, says his club doesn't promote real estate as a fast path to riches. "Long term, the money is in holding on to property, not flipping it," he said, referring to the practice of buying and selling quickly for a profit.
His group started during the 1985 real estate boom but lost membership in the bull market for stocks of the 1990's. Now the club is growing again. "With the Dow down, we're seeing 25 new members a month, Mr. Zampetti said. "It used to be just about seven."
ASK real estate club members what they like about investing in property and they invariably cite its tangible nature. (Try kicking the tires of a mutual fund, they say.) They also like the fact that they can pick their property investments. A 401(k) plan portfolio is typically limited to the offerings of a mutual fund company chosen by an employer. As Enron employees have learned so painfully, an employer does not always encourage diversification of the plan's holdings.
As an investment, real estate has fared much better than the stock market of late. An investment of $1,000 at the height of the stock market in March 2000, would be worth $1,501 today if the money had been put into real estate mutual funds, for example, compared with $639 if it had been placed in a fund mimicking the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, or $211 if invested in the Nasdaq composite, according to Lipper Inc., the fund-tracking company.
Many financial advisers say real estate has a place in the average investor's portfolio because of its relatively low volatility and relatively high yield. But real estate assets can be what Michael Acton, a pension fund adviser in Boston, calls "lumpy," or illiquid.
"Most individuals are probably not well served by going out and investing in real estate," said Mr. Acton, director of research at AEW Capital Management of Boston, which has about $7 billion in real estate under management for pension funds and institutions.
As an alternative, Mr. Acton advises people to consider publicly traded real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, which invest in real estate, from shopping malls to industrial parks.
REIT's have done well so far this year. The average dividend yield is about 6 percent, according to the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts, while share prices have far surpassed those of stocks.
Dennis R. Capozza, a professor of finance and real estate at the University of Michigan School of Business in Ann Arbor, also urges caution. Newcomers to real estate investing, he said, are likely to make many of the same mistakes as novice stock investors: overpaying, selling too quickly or holding too long, or simply being unable to obtain crucial information as fast as those who are closer to the market.
"All the problems you have with amateurs in the stock market you also have in real estate," Mr. Capozza said.
Mr. Fuhrer, the actor from Portland, might once have agreed with such an assessment, but he says his real estate club and the connections he has made through it have helped him learn the ropes.
Mr. Fuhrer says he began studying real estate on his own a few years ago and recently paid the $95 in annual dues to join Northwest Real Estate Investors. After his first meeting, he said he took the leap. A friend who is a real estate agent was looking for someone to buy assets from a court-ordered dissolution of a partnership; the properties were being sold at less than their market value to satisfy a judgment. Mr. Fuhrer sensed a deal and told his friend that he could find an investor to buy the undervalued assets for 80 cents on the dollar. He began networking at the real estate club and met John E. Laine-Reinders, whose company, Creative Capital Networks, buys discounted properties for investors. 
The two worked out a deal that gives Mr. Furher a finder's fee of 5 percent of the equity in each property for sale. Mr. Laine-Reinder's investors will spruce up the properties and sell them at market value. As many as 27 properties, mostly single-family homes, could be sold under the deal over the next year. Mr. Fuhrer says he stands to make as much as $80,000 over the coming year on the deal.
"Investing in real estate doesn't just mean you have to buy property. I'm not out any cash or credit," he said.
SOMETIMES club members pool money. Wesley Barney of Flushing, Queens, president of the Ultimate Investors Real Estate Club, which started about 15 years ago, said he recently joined with an accountant and a roofer to buy a 12-unit apartment complex, whose owners were late on payments, in Independence, Mo. He had learned of the property through his real estate club contacts and approached the bank holding the mortgage. His group negotiated a new loan and the bank avoided having to categorize the original loan as a nonperforming asset. Mr. Barney's group, meanwhile, now has a source of income.
Not every deal is as smooth. Kraig Mead, 42, of Milwaukie, Ore., who arranges transportation for commercial shippers, said he found himself in a jam when a fixer-upper house he bought two years ago turned out to be a former illegal methamphetamine lab. Mr. Mead remodeled the home, putting $20,000 into flooring, wallboard and carpeting. He moved in with his family and started a home day care center. Then one day state health officials showed up and declared the house a hazardous site. The day care operation shut down and the Meads moved out. Mr. Mead, who is now looking to sell the place, is liable for the cost of testing for contamination and any resulting cleanup. He said he has been told that the cost could range from $3,000 to $50,000. State officials must certify the cleanup.
"Don't forget that you are responsible," he advised club members at a recent meeting, "even if it wasn't your fault."
What is his advice, in hindsight? Call state health and environmental officials before buying anything to make sure that it is not on a list of properties to be seized for cleanup. 
Robert Mularz, 56, of Livingston, N.J., a credit manager for a plastics company, also advises average investors not to expect to get rich quick. "I learned that it's very time-consuming and that you can make mistakes," he said.
On the other hand, he advises newcomers not to fall victim to "paralysis of analysis," or overanalyzing a deal.
"Fear kept me from getting started for a long time," he said. "Now I'm sorry I didn't start sooner."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT; 
Some Breathe Easier With Plant's Last Gasp

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
For most New Yorkers, the debate over the city's decision to stop recycling glass and plastic on July 1 is abstract, turning on environmental and budget issues. But on Casanova Street in industrial Hunts Point, the consequences of the change are painfully concrete.
 That's where Hunts Point Recycling Corporation, one of four companies under contract with the Department of Sanitation to receive and process materials for recycling, once ran a round-the-clock, 1,500-tons-a-week operation. More than 100 people, mostly Bronx residents, have lost their jobs as work has slowed to a halt, leaving eight employees doing mostly cleanup. Even they will be laid off within a few weeks. 
 "We're finished, we're done," said the company's general manager, Jeffrey Berkowitz.
Ruben Gonzalez, one of the remaining workers, added: "The only alternative is unemployment benefits. And when that runs out, what are they going to do?" 
Mr. Gonzalez, 39, was referring to workers who had already been laid off, but he could have been talking about himself. Along with his wife, an unemployed factory worker, he is raising three children in the nearby section of Melrose.
Still, as the workers struggle, some residents are happy that the company will be gone. In a neighborhood plagued by asthma problems that many believe are related to the thousands of trucks that stream through every week, the elimination of 300 weekly recycling trips is welcome. 
"It's a problem with people losing their jobs, but it's better for us," said Carmen Reyes, who lives near the plant. "There are a lot of asthmatic families out here."
Problems with the recycling company went beyond its trucks. Neighbors, community activists and union officials complained that the plant was filthy and working conditions were poor.
The company still owes $300,000 to the city, said a Department of Sanitation spokeswoman, for violations that included litter outside the station and failure to clean the inside floors. Last week, rats outnumbered workers processing cardboard, which is still being recycled, in the only one of four buildings still operating.
Mr. Berkowitz admitted that the company had violations, but defended its practices.
"My feeling is, we were not a bad neighbor," said Mr. Berkowitz, who called activists who criticized his operation rabble-rousers. Given the contract he was obliged to uphold and the physical restrictions of the plant, "what they wanted to see was an impossibility," he said.
The plant's replacement may not please the community. Mr. Berkowitz said that a waste management company was negotiating to buy the space. SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; 
Bring In da Noise, And You'll Be Fined

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
In the last five years, the so-called rebirth of Smith Street has been, by all accounts, a smashing economic success. But as a sleepier, more old-fashioned way of life gives way to a flourishing nightclub and restaurant scene, the strip has discovered a big-city woe: noise ordinances and the stiff penalties that come with them.
 Garrett McConnell, the owner of a Smith Street performing arts studio and wine bar called the East End Ensemble, one of five businesses ticketed recently, said she has received three violation notices from the city's Department of Environmental Protection, each carrying fines starting at $1,750. Ms. McConnell said she keeps the club's doors and windows closed and does not allow people in the garden after 10 p.m. But until a city inspector paid a visit, she had not been told there was a problem. Four nearby bars received similar violations, she said. 
 Charles G. Sturcken, chief of staff for the agency, said inspectors are not required to give warnings. "If noise is audible from the outside of the premises, we have the right to issue violations," he said, adding that fines usually start at $700. 
Capt. Thomas J. Harris of the 76th Precinct, who has met with local business owners to discuss the problem, said his precinct had not received any complaints about the five businesses affected.
As economic development and lower crime rates have made the neighborhood more attractive, Captain Harris said, "I think we're the victims of our own success."
Given that there are 40 clubs and restaurants along the 14-block strip, most of them having arrived in the last three years, the number of complaints and offenses have been few, said Bette Stoltz, executive director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation. "We're really talking about a very small percentage of people whose sensitivities are greater than almost everybody else," she said, "or who, on the other end of the spectrum, lose control over their own environment." 
If the city continues to issue summonses and impose fines, which can double and quadruple with subsequent ticketing, some Smith Street business owners fear that their enterprises might be in danger. 
"We're talking about $10,000 worth of fines," Ms. McConnell said. "You could put a lot of small businesses out of business really quick." TARA BAHRAMPOUR

HEADLINE: F.Y.I. 

BYLINE:  By ED BOLAND Jr.; E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com

 BODY:
 The Secret Subway

Q. I was told New York's first subway tunnel was built in secret. How was that possible and why was it done?

A. It was possible because the tunnel was only about a block long. The work was done on the sly because of one man's determination not to be bullied by City Hall.
 By the mid-1800's, the streets of Lower Manhattan were choked with pedestrians and trolleys. Enter one Alfred Ely Beach, inventor and co-owner of The New York Sun. Beach had heard of a pneumatic mail tube that had been built in London in 1866 and used air pressure to move parcels through tunnels underground. He had also heard of thrill seekers sneaking into the tube to hitch rides on those parcels. An idea was hatched.
Beach was determined to build a pneumatic tube to carry people, and he was equally determined not to be taken to the cleaners by Boss Tweed, who received kickbacks on every construction project and trolley fare in the city. Building the subway in secret was the only way to avoid City Hall's sticky fingers.
In 1868, Beach rented the basement of Devlin's Clothing Store on the corner of Broadway and Warren Street, and the clandestine work began at night. As workers dug the 312-foot tunnel beneath Broadway, from Warren to Murray Street, bags of soil were carried away on covered wagons with muffled wheels.
Once the tunnel was dug, Beach built a giant fan to move a car in the tunnel. He spared no expense on the waiting room, which included a fountain, chandeliers and a grand piano.
On Feb. 28, 1870, Beach opened his pneumatic subway, and an astonished public clamored to take the 25-cent ride. Boss Tweed, however, was not a fan. He had Gov. John Hoffman veto legislation to extend the subway to Central Park. Beach tried again in 1873 after Tweed's fall, but a financial panic set in that year and subway plans fell by the wayside.
Eventually, Beach gave up and his tunnel was used as a shooting gallery and wine cellar. Beach died in 1896, eight years before a subway system was built in New York.

Gateway to the 7 Seas

Q. When I drive along West Street in Manhattan across from Little West 12th Street, I see an old metal arch that says "White Star" and "Cunard Line." What is its history?

A. The rusting old arch on Pier 54 recalls the days when luxurious passenger ships were the stylish way to cross the ocean. The arch was a gateway for passengers of the two cruise lines.
It was on this pier in 1912 that the cruise ship Carpathia unloaded survivors picked up from the Titanic disaster. In 1915, the pier was the launching point for the fateful voyage of the Lusitania. A total of 1,200 people died when it was torpedoed by a German U-boat.
Today, the Hudson River Conservancy owns the arch and the pier. Alex Dudley, a conservancy spokesman, says the arch is still structurally sound and will probably be refurbished.
The conservancy will incorporate the arch into the Hudson River Park, 550 acres of waterfront parkland extending from Battery Park to 59th Street. Although exact plans for the arch have yet to be determined, the entire park is scheduled to be completed in 2005.

A Brazilian Patriarch

Q. I recognize most of the names on statues around Bryant Park, but Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva has me at a loss. A little help, please?

A. Chances are he was before your time. Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva (1763 to 1838), is regarded as the architect of Brazil's independence. A geologist, statesman and scholar, he was a contributor to the Constitution of Brazil. Jose Lima's sculpture of Bonifacio was a gift from Brazil to the United States in 1953. ED BOLAND Jr.

HEADLINE: GOOD EATING; 
Taking the Plunge

BYLINE:  E-mail: eating@nytimes.com

 BODY:
 Despite the shaky economy, new restaurants continue to open around the city. Here are a few that have opened this year. 

ALMA
(718) 643-5400; 187 Columbia Street (Degraw Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; $; $25 and Under: 7/10/02

Alma may be in an odd place -- near a shipyard, car lots and a live poultry market -- but it would be hard to find better Mexican food anywhere in New York. Gary Jacobson's cooking is thoughtful and precise, with distinctive splashes of spice and heat and brilliant sauces.

ATELIER
**
rating: two stars
(212) 521-6125; 50 Central Park South (Avenue of the Americas), in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel; $$$$; Review: 6/5/02

The chef, Gabriel Kreuther, has an elegant touch and a distinctive way with herbs and vegetables, treating them like co-stars instead of supporting players, in nearly every dish at this ambitious, refined restaurant.

CARNE
(212) 663-7010; 2737 Broadway (105th Street); $; $25 and Under: 5/8/02

In an area with plenty of inexpensive restaurants, one was lacking: a grown-up place for a well-made cocktail, a thick steak and good wine. Carne delivers with plain but satisfying appetizers, juicy cuts of meat and a thoughtful wine list.

CRAFTBAR
(212) 780-0880; 47 East 19th Street (near Park Avenue South); $; $25 and Under: 3/6/02

Craftbar, the new, casual adjunct to Craft, sets itself leagues beyond the typical low-rent sandwich shop. And yet, its snacks, soups, salads and sandwiches, supplemented each day by two meat, fish and pasta dishes, exude the simplicity of a wine bar.

FIAMMA OSTERIA
***
rating: three stars
(212) 653-0100; 206 Spring Street (Sullivan Street); $$$; Review: 5/22/02

This beautifully realized restaurant, the latest addition to Stephen Hanson's restaurant empire, is satisfying in every way. The chef, Michael White, plays variations on traditional Italian food while staying rooted in the core principles of Italian cooking.

OLICA
***
rating: three stars
(212) 583-0001; 145 East 50th Street (near Lexington Avenue); $$$; Review: 3/20/02

Olica is an even better restaurant than its predecessor L'Actuel. Jean-Yves Schillinger's food is serious and well presented, with the simplicity and clarity that only a complex culinary tradition can produce.

WASHINGTON PARK
**
rating: two stars
(212) 529-4400; 24 Fifth Avenue (Ninth Street); $$$$; Review: 6/12/02

Washington Park, with its pale lemon walls, straw-seat chairs and waiters in Thomas Pink shirts, takes its casualness seriously. The sunny, airy surroundings seem perfectly suited to the simple market-inspired cooking of Jonathan Waxman.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Term Insurance Turns Long Term

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
TERM life insurance started as a type of coverage that people bought year to year. Then it gradually became a long-range proposition, with 20-year policies the most popular. Four years ago, insurers began extending the term to 30 years in many parts of the country, and in the last two weeks such policies quietly became available in New York for the first time.
 The 30-year policies have their advantages. They lock in a set annual cost that, because of inflation, becomes gradually more affordable. The policies also protect against the danger that a person's health will deteriorate and make new coverage either exorbitant or impossible to get at any price. 
 But consumer advocates, and even some insurers, say the longer term policies are not for everyone. They caution, for example, against making a 30-year commitment.
"Look at your own life," said Melvin J. Feinberg, a senior executive at the New York Life Insurance Company, which does not plan to sell the longer-term policies. "Do you think in any way you could have predicted how your financial needs were going to change over the last 30 years?"
People lose their jobs, take pay cuts, divorce and as a result, often drop their coverage. That can be particularly costly with 30-year policies because their premiums often run about three times the premiums of 10-year policies. 
Glenn S. Daily, a life insurance consultant in Manhattan, said a shorter policy might be preferable because prices have been dropping sharply for term life, which provides coverage for a specified period, as opposed to whole life, which extends over a lifetime. Better, he says, to buy 10 years of coverage with the possibility, at expiration, of buying a new, cheaper policy. To guard against a change in health that makes getting a new policy impossible, Mr. Daily suggests buying a 10-year policy that guarantees future coverage, albeit at higher premiums.
The ideal customer for a 30-year policy, he said, "is somebody who just wants to buy coverage and not have to think about it again for a very long time."
"You get the invoice every year and you pay it," he said. "It's simple, and there is something to be said for that." It is also substantially less expensive than whole life coverage.
Four companies are now selling 30-year term life in New York, according to Byron Udell, the chief executive of AccuQuote, an online and telephone brokerage firm that offers coverage from hundreds of companies. The North American Company for Life and Health Insurance of New York introduced the first of the policies in the state on July 22, he said. The annual premium was $790 for $250,000 in coverage for a 45-year-old man who did not smoke and was in excellent health. But the William Penn Life Insurance Company of New York and the Union Central Life Insurance Company quickly came out with the same coverage for less: $690 a year for William Penn and $730 for Union Central. Last Wednesday, the SBLI USA Mutual Life Insurance Company offered the coverage for $837.50. (That same customer would pay, on average, around $225 a year for a 10-year policy and $400 for 20 years.)
"Almost all the major companies are working feverishly to bring out their version of these policies," Mr. Udell said. "There will probably be a dozen of them out there by Labor Day."
The 30-year policies have become the second-best-selling term coverage, he said, accounting for 20 percent of his sales, behind 20-year policies, at 55 percent. At John Hancock Financial Services, which plans to sell the policies in New York by year's end, Paul Strong, a vice president, said the longer coverage was likely to appeal to younger customers. "Maybe 40 and below," he said. "We're talking in terms of a family and taking them through college. The 30 years hits that pretty well. And you have that peace of mind."
UNTIL April, insurance laws in New York had included various restrictions that made it virtually unprofitable for insurers to offer 30-year term life. But after heavy lobbying by the insurance companies, the State Legislature, noting that the coverage was available in other states and that customers seemed to want it, decided that it was time for a change.
Mr. Udell says 30-year term policies can lead to lush profits for insurers from customers who cancel their coverage. But he says he values the security of the longer policies. 
"They give the client the flexibility to walk away anytime during the 30 years," he said. "But they assure the client that the carrier cannot walk away."
