HEADLINE: Business; 
To Start a Men's Line, A Pitch to Women

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: HINGHAM, Mass. 

 BODY:
ARNOLD B. ZETCHER, the president and chief executive of Talbots, has had a good time opening his mail. A woman in California sent him family portraits of herself, her children and her mother all dressed in Talbots clothing. Another woman sent him a photograph of her closet door, which she had painted red after the Talbots signature storefront. Then there was the customer who mailed him blue pajamas she had ordered through the catalog. She did not like the color and asked him for the pink ones. 
 Talbots depends on a loyal customer base of older, conservative women who feel a bond with the company. 
 "We do have what I feel is a very special kind of relationship," said Mr. Zetcher, who joined Talbots as president in 1987. He sends his best customers personalized, if mass-produced, letters and gifts like scarves and chocolate. Devoted women 35 and older have kept the 846 Talbots stores worldwide profitable while other retailers have lost money. 
Now Mr. Zetcher is exploiting that loyalty. His company has started photographing a 24-page supplement to its fall catalog that will introduce Talbots clothing for men. 
With a firm belief that the way to a man's closet is through his wife, Mr. Zetcher expects the company's current customers to buy generously for their male loved ones this holiday season, easing them into the idea that Talbots is for guys, too. 
A splashy rollout is unlikely. Mr. Zetcher is introducing this line with excruciating care, after months of focus groups in which men were grilled about everything from sweater preferences to store decor.
"We have done a massive amount of research just to establish what the logo is going to be," Mr. Zetcher said. As a result, the company traded the gold oval logo, still used for women's clothing, for a subdued pewter background with blue letters that say Talbots Mens. 
If the catalog supplement, which features sweaters, shirts, trousers, sports jackets, ties and some outerwear, gets a nibble from its 750,000 recipients, Talbots plans to open six men's stores in 2003. 
Earnings at the company, based here, rose 10 percent last year, to $127 million, on a 1 percent increase in sales, to $1.61 billion, which included $267 million from its catalogs. 
Men's clothing is not exactly a growth industry. With domestic retail sales of $50.9 billion last year, it is roughly three-fifths the size of the women's clothing industry. And most apparel retailers have suffered from the weak economy. NPD Group Inc., a market research company in Port Washington, N.Y., said sales of both men's and women's clothing fell about 7 percent last year. 
But officials at Talbots, aware that most men consider clothes shopping a chore, see a niche in giving men a small, tasteful selection of brand-name clothes that will not overwhelm them. "In every market, there's often a local, independent, upscale men's retailer, a great local men's store, and that's more of what we're looking to provide," Mr. Zetcher said. "It's not this vast sea of merchandise. It's a nicely edited, upscale assortment in a nice environment with a high degree of service."
The company's slow wade into men's clothes reflects a lesson learned in 1997, when Talbots abruptly stocked shelves with short hemlines and Day-Glo colors that customers shunned. Sales slumped. "We blew it," Mr. Zetcher acknowledged. "We got too young. The styles and colors weren't right. It was just a lot of things that went wrong."
"But we learned from it," he said. "We put a lot of things in place to prevent that from happening again."
He calls them his checks and balances: an executive merchandising committee now consults with store directors, and Mr. Zetcher personally examines new styles before they come near a store. 
"We've got a few more hands in the pot," he said, including his own. "I spend an awful lot of time talking to the customer. I do have a sense of what classic is and what the customer might like." 
For the men's division, he has arranged for a separation of powers similar to management of the Talbots Kids line, which became its own department five years ago. "We are not really afraid, because we are segmentized," he said. "We have different people doing different things, and there are only a few of us involved in all of the things."
One of them is Harold B. Bosworth, senior vice president of the company, general manager for Talbots Kids and now the overseer of the men's division. Even when talking about men's clothes, he is thinking about women. 
"Women are willing to pay more for men's clothes" than their own, Mr. Bosworth said. They will demand more in return, however. 
"The expected quality in men's wear is perceived to be better," he said. "You better execute and deliver a better product."
THE design has been left to John Phillips, who once was in charge of design at Federated Department Stores merchandising group. So far the offerings include no suits, but plenty of other staples, like an Italian wool and cashmere blend sport coat, a mercerized cotton pullover, and a fawn-colored leather jacket. A V-neck sweater, the color of squash, is about as fashion forward as Talbots Mens is willing to step. 
Kurt Barnard, an industry analyst who writes Barnard's Retail Trend Report, said Talbots is trying to muscle in on a sector with established players like Brooks Brothers and Jos. A. Bank.
"It is going to be difficult for Talbots to wrest market share from competitors that are not going to easily let go," Mr. Barnard said.
More significant, "it's difficult to go through a sex change in any form whatsoever," he said. "It does carry risks. There is no question in my mind that a store that has always symbolized fashion in women is going to have a hard time saying to men, 'Come on in, it's cool here.' "
Few women's clothing brands have effortlessly added men to their clientele. Adrienne Vittadini and Anne Klein both fell short with their men's wear ventures. Liz Claiborne and Jones New York have had some success, but their main showcases are department stores, where men are already willing to tread.
The road is difficult both ways. Nautica, historically manly, pulled back from women's sportswear in 1998 after two unsuccessful ventures, one through a licensee, but it is currently trying to make a go of Nautica jeans and sleepwear for women. The theory is that an established label, even one associated with a particular sex, holds more sway with consumers than an unfamiliar name.
Even going gender-neutral can be a touchy subject. Limited Brands is changing its Structure label to Express for Men, already raising eyebrows among young men who think of Express as their girlfriends' destination at the mall. 
Being a guy, Mr. Zetcher is aware that men might cringe at shopping in the same stores as their wives. Talbots will experiment with sites to determine if the men's stores should adjoin the women's stores, stay a safe distance away at the opposite end of the mall or stand alone.
He puts faith in the focus groups. "This masculine thing is really important, and if we can accomplish that, we're quite confident there will be great acceptance," he said. 
There will have to be. He can't rely on the wives and mothers forever. "It can't just be women buying for men," he said. "Down the road, it's got to be a good mix."

HEADLINE: Suzuki Beefs Up Its Car Warranties 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
THE automakers' warranty wars escalated last week, with Suzuki firing the latest volley. Saying it now offers "America's best warranty" -- a claim that other automakers dispute -- Suzuki said its 2002 and 2003 vehicles would be covered, as of Thursday, by a powertrain warranty of seven years or 100,000 miles, whichever comes first.
 Suzuki's bumper-to-bumper warranty -- covering repairs for the entire car, excluding normal wear -- remains three years or 36,000 miles. The powertrain coverage kicks in after the basic warranty expires, and covers major drivetrain parts like engines, transmissions and axles. Suzuki also offers roadside assistance for three years. 
 Hyundai and Kia are offering powertrain coverage of 10 years or 100,000 miles, and bumper-to-bumper coverage of five years or 60,000 miles, plus roadside assistance for five years regardless of mileage. Isuzu's drivetrain warranty is the nation's longest, at 120,000 miles or 10 years, on top of basic coverage of three years or 50,000 miles.
But Suzuki says its new warranty is better than those because it can be transferred to a vehicle's future owners. Also, the company charges no deductibles for warranty work. Other companies offering long warranties either don't allow them to be transferred if a car is resold, impose limitations on such transfers or charge deductibles.
Allowing transfers and repealing deductibles "creates the best value for the customer," Cam Smith-Arnold, director of corporate brand marketing for the American Suzuki Motor Corporation, said in an interview.
Warranties have become a more important selling point as automakers try to prove they are making higher-quality vehicles. "We're seeing long warranties instituted by companies who believe they have a perceived challenge in the quality area -- Hyundai, Kia, Isuzu, Chrysler and now Suzuki," said Joe Ivers, a partner with J. D. Power & Associates, the market research firm. "In our quality surveys, those same companies typically rank below average. Their warranties are a new promise of quality, or a form of consumer protection if they have difficulties."
Hyundai started the warranty offensive by offering a powertrain warranty of 10 years or 100,000 miles for 1999 models. The company needed to convince consumers that its products, notoriously poor in their early years in the American market, had become better.
The strategy worked. Hyundai has improved more than any other company in J. D. Power's quality surveys, and its sales growth has been among the industry's highest. Sales at Kia, which is owned by Hyundai's Korean parent company, have also soared since its warranty was expanded.
"We still claim ours is the most comprehensive in the industry," said Mike Anson, a spokesman for Hyundai Motor America. "We
trademarked 'America's best warranty.' "
Other companies followed Hyundai's lead, including Isuzu. In early July, DaimlerChrysler, which had experimented over the last year with long warranties on some models, said it would offer what it called "an industry leading" powertrain warranty of seven years or 70,000 miles on all Chryslers, Jeeps and Dodges. Chrysler says its internal warranty costs dropped 20 percent in the 2001 model year and are now half of their 1996 level.
Mr. Ivers of J. D. Power said Chrysler's initial quality -- measured in the early months of ownership -- had improved, but the long-term durability of Chrysler vehicles remained a problem. In comparison, he said Ford and General Motors were in a stronger position and had less need to offer long warranties. "I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for them to jump on the bandwagon," he said.
Suzuki will market its seven-year warranty along with buyer incentives -- no down payment and no interest charges for up to five years -- under the slogan "Zero, zero & 7." Although the company's advertising sets an Aug. 31 expiration, Ms. Smith-Arnold said the warranty offer would be extended.
"We felt a lot of manufacturers were focusing on very good finance offers or very good warranties," Ms. Smith-Arnold said. "We thought we could take the lead in offering both with a very generous term. Our intention is to keep that going as long as it is affordable because it has been very successful for us."

HEADLINE: In the Hamptons, It's All Altitude 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. 

 BODY:
ON a midsummer Friday afternoon, a few minutes before 5:30, a convoy of expensive cars filled with wives, children and butlers moved slowly down Meadow Lane, rumbled past a sign that announced a dead end and rolled to a stop next to dunes.
 To the casual observer, the cars, parked in the middle of nowhere, might have looked odd, the only sounds a lonely ocean breeze and a gentle crashing of waves. 
 Then a child cried out, his arm pointing toward a black dot in the sky. The dot drew closer, and the air rippled with noise. Two minutes later, a twin-engine Sikorsky helicopter settled its bulk onto a landing pad concealed by waving sea grass. 
Four men debarked and picked up four briefcases that the pilot had set on the tarmac. Then the chopper pulled into the air and nosed westward toward Manhattan. The men climbed into the waiting cars. 
Commuting by Sikorsky is a far cry from the John Cheever days when Daddy arrived on the 6:07 to Greenwich after downing a gimlet in the bar car. Helicopters as casual transportation have long been the province of the wealthy, and the heliport at East 30th Street in Manhattan caters to a steady stream of people like Henry Kravis, Ron Perelman and Ellen Barkin. But this summer even regular Joes -- O.K., well-to-do regular Joes -- are flying, despite the uncertain economic climate.
Patrick Day, the director of charter marketing for Liberty Helicopters, one of about a half-dozen companies offering commercial service to New Yorkers, said that his 40 to 50 flights a day represented an increase of 30 to 40 percent over last summer's number.
Todd Rome, president of Blue Star Jets, which arranges private air travel, has seen a similar increase in requests for helicopters from the city to summer resorts like the Hamptons, Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard. "On Monday morning from Manhattan, you can see so many of them coming in it's like a cloud," he said. 
Mr. Rome said that many of his New York clients, feeling the economic chill, had skipped vacations to Europe and instead were traveling the Eastern Seaboard. 
Still, the main reason for the surge in chopper commuting is the hot, honking, congested, gas-guzzling, are-we-there-yet car traffic, which has increased considerably in the last two years. 
According to the New York State Department of Transportation, the number of cars passing over the Shinnecock Canal, the entry to the South Fork of Long Island, rose 18 percent from April 2000 to April 2001 to an average of 28,954 a day. The numbers for April 2002, not yet tabulated, are expected to be relatively flat.
The bridge over the canal, where Route 27 narrows from a four-lane highway to a two-lane rural route, is the choke point for Hamptons traffic, said Samuel Schwartz, a former deputy transportation commissioner in New York City. "It is now backed up by noon on Friday," he said. "That makes the whole trip really unpleasant." Kenneth Day, a San Francisco business consultant (he is not related to Patrick Day), said that he had been "totally freaked out by the traffic" during a drive to the Hamptons last summer.
"I cannot sit in traffic like that," he said. "It just makes me too agitated." For a visit to friends in the Hamptons this summer, he took a helicopter. "It's expensive, but I don't come every weekend like some people, so it's entirely worth it," he said.
Jeff Hyman, the president of Gabriel Aviation in New York, a commercial service, said that his usual 70 flights a day on busy summer weekends, primarily to the Hamptons, have increased between 5 and 10 this year. 
"The high-end people with bulletproof net worth are continuing to fly during the down economy," Mr. Hyman said. "But I am also starting to see more entrepreneurial people, and people who are just incredibly fed up with the traffic. The attitude is changing because people who do business in New York see the traffic and say, 'My time is worth more than that.' "
Flights on Gabriel Aviation's service, sold in packages, cost about $400 each way, with each chopper carrying four or five passengers. So for a summer of weekend commuting, fliers need to have $7,000 or more to burn. If you're a lawyer billing a few hundred dollars an hour, that's probably a good investment, given that the average trip from Manhattan to Southampton takes 30 to 40 minutes by helicopter, and two to five hours by car. 
Few helicopter travelers said they had safety fears. There has been only one fatal helicopter crash in the last five years in the New York area, according to statistics from the National Transportation Safety Board. In April 1997, a corporate helicopter owned by Colgate-Palmolive crashed into the East River and one passenger died. 
Mr. Hyman said that the public perception that helicopters are dangerous has been culled from the movies and news. "That's because most people see them crashing in war movies or doing a Medivac or rescuing someone off a mountain," he said. 
The helicopter trip from Manhattan to Southampton couldn't be more serene. Commuters get a quick glimpse of Manhattan before heading into Queens, where fields that at first look curiously stubbled with gray turn out to be cemeteries. Those yield to acres and acres of closely packed two-family houses, which give way to Floral Park, where homes have backyards and above-ground pools. From there, an exurban patchwork forms: car dealerships in Bay Shore, a shopping mall in Islip, baseball diamonds, the striated green fields of farms, horses in pastures, tennis courts, golf courses and finally the oceanfront mansions of Quogue, leading to the helipads of Southampton and East Hampton.
Crisscrossing through it all are the roads and highways -- the Cross-Island Expressway, the Southern and Northern State Parkways, the Long Island Expressway -- all sluggish with traffic.
That midsummer Friday, the lucky fliers alighting in Southampton included Ken Dichter, whose Sean Jean velour warm-up suit flapped in the chopper's wake. Mr. Dichter, an aviation executive, said there was no other way to travel. "With the traffic?" he said. "No way."
A little later the tennis player Jennifer Capriati arrived at the helipad in a chauffeured sedan, waving to a gathering of people as she boarded a flight to Manhattan. She had just finished shooting a spread for Vogue, said Jonathan Becker, the photographer who took the pictures. 
Mr. Becker waited patiently for a helicopter that would pick up the people who had helped him on the shoot: two stylists, who sat with their suitcases on wheels, and a Vogue fashion editor, Phyllis Posnick. 
Bernard L. Schwartz, the chief executive of Loral, arrived in the next incoming chopper and disappeared into the back seat of a sedan. "Where is that thing?" Ms. Posnick said. The Vogue helicopter was nowhere in sight.
"You know," Mr. Becker said, checking his watch, "if it's this late you don't have to pay."
The Vogue chopper was already an hour late. The stylists pulled mobile phones from their rolling suitcases. Ms. Posnick, who looked diaphanous and angelic in her all-white linen outfit, sounded more like someone possessed by Beelzebub as she took to her phone. 
"This is ridiculous," she said, turning to shout into the phone. "No, it's Vogue. I said, V-O-G-U-E."
Ms. Posnick's service, Direct Air, eventually did show up, and gave her a discount. 
An acquaintance had called Gabriel Aviation for the Vogue crew, but with no luck. "There are only so many $2 million machines I have at my disposal at one time," Mr. Hyman, the Gabriel Aviation president, said later.
Standing on Meadow Lane, looking at his watch and chewing on a cigar, Mr. Becker said: "You see, there are drawbacks. Phyllis might be home by now if she had driven."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
If the Formula Says Buy, The Big Institutions Buy

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN

 BODY:
DURING the big market declines of recent weeks, many of the biggest investors have been buying stocks. But that may not signal a belief that the market is about to soar.
 Instead of selling into a downdraft, as some individual investors appeared to be doing, many major institutions -- including government and corporate pension funds, university endowments, charitable foundations, and religious organizations -- have been compelled by ironclad asset allocation policies to do the reverse. The policies require them to buy stocks when the market knocks the value of their equity positions below a desired level -- say, 60 percent of total assets. 
 "It's been our experience that institutional investors weren't part of the sell-off," said Roger Fenningdorf, a principal at Rocaton Investment Advisors, a Darien, Conn., consultant to institutions. "I don't think our clients are happy about what's happened to the markets in recent months, but they haven't been panicking, and they aren't giving up on their asset allocation policies."
This methodical buying, or "rebalancing," by institutions to adhere to asset allocation goals has helped fuel some of the periodic comebacks in the stock market in recent weeks.
"With things in the markets changing as dramatically as they have, we have tended to rebalance by buying stocks and selling bonds," said William F. Quinn, the president of AMR Investment Services, the unit of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, that manages corporate pension assets.
Michael T. Flaherman, the chairman of the investment committee for the California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, the nation's largest pension plan, added: "When we buy stocks, it's not because we are looking at the market and saying, 'It's the right time.' It's because we are looking at our asset allocation targets."
Some professionals say individual investors, who tend to be less resolute in forming or keeping asset allocation targets, might do well to adopt such goals, too.
"Institutional investors know that you have to have patience and you have to have a plan, and you have to stick with it," said Gail L. Bardin, a principal at Hotchkis & Wiley Capital Management, a Los Angeles-based institutional money manager focusing on value stocks. By contrast, the behavior of many individual investors has appeared to be anything but methodical.
Judging from mutual fund outflows over the last two months, many people were selling stocks priced much closer to their cyclical lows than to their highs. In June, net redemptions for equity mutual funds totaled $10.46 billion, after five consecutive months of inflows, according to AMG Data Services, which tracks fund flows. In the first 25 days of July, the cash outflows totaled $30.6 billion, dwarfing the $23.6 billion withdrawn from funds in the month after Sept. 11.
To be sure, some people who sold their stock holdings were nearing retirement or had other needs for money and therefore could not afford to take the chance that equity values would fall further. By contrast, institutions have the benefit of investing truly for the long term.
Many people who were disheartened by losses have sold stocks in the hope of returning to the market in a calmer period. They were essentially engaging in market timing, a practice that has also tempted some professionals.
"Some institutional investors have even asked if they should be moving money into cash," said Michael Odlum, president of Allied Investment Advisors, an institutional and retail asset manager, based in Baltimore, whose clients include pension funds and religious organizations. "We have told them that timing the market is a loser's game. When the stock market begins to recover, it happens really fast and you end up missing some of the critical gains if you're out of the market."
While some institutions, like pension funds, have begun to put some money into alternative asset classes like hedge funds and private equity funds, such moves have generally been limited to a small proportion of their investments. Calpers, for example, has allocated 58 percent of its assets to stocks, 28 percent to bonds and money market funds, and the remainder to private equity funds and real estate.
Thomas McManus, the chief investment strategist with Banc of America Securities, said some institutional investors might have increased their equity stakes more slowly than in previous downturns. But he said that there had been no fundamental shift in asset allocation strategy.
But Mr. McManus also pointed out that the balance of investment power had been shifting over the last two decades away from more disciplined institutional investors and toward more impulsive individual investors, who now have direct control of significant amounts of pension assets through 401(k) retirement plans. The share of total pension plan assets controlled by individuals through defined-contribution plans and I.R.A.'s rose to 46 percent in 2001 from 35 percent in 1990, according to figures compiled by the Investment Company Institute.
"My fear is that individuals have done more damage to their accounts by investing directly," he said. "They hurt themselves by not picking the right manager or right asset allocation."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Was Gordon Gekko Right About Greed?

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN a Tolstoy story titled "How Much Land Does a Man Need?" a peasant named Pahom who longs for loam is granted his wish by the devil. First he gets 40 acres, then 125. Finally, in his acquisitive hunger, he accepts an offer of as much fertile territory as he can encircle in a day on foot. His cost will be just 1,000 rubles.
 Of course, his eyes are bigger than his cardiovascular fitness level, and after walking as much land as possible by sunset, he drops dead. Tolstoy answers the title's question in the very last line: "Six feet from his head to his heels was all he needed." 
 That parable about greed seems especially relevant today, amid the bear market and the constant eruption of business scandals. The novelist David Gates cited it in a recent Newsweek column. But the joke is on us, because Pahom's story was written by a man who inherited a 4,000-acre estate. (For the record, that's 10 miles around.)
What the story really shows is that there is nothing like the dashed material longings of others to bring out humanity's strongest censorious impulses -- nothing, that is, but a whiff of financial apocalypse. I tried a search for all the published references to "greed" of the last 60 days, but there were too many to count. Rest assured that if stocks keep declining, there will be many more -- and that they will come mainly from people of means. 
Greed, it seems, is everywhere. But now that the culture's well-fed opinion makers have uncovered our collective avarice, perhaps we should ask about the nature of this greed that so appalls us. My first instinct was that greed is the term to describe someone else's trying to make money. But that seemed unscientific, so I turned to the dictionary, which defines it as an "excessive desire to have or possess more than what one needs or deserves." 
But what does any of us really "need"? And, on a more complicated level, what do we "deserve"? Does anyone have the right to eat in a restaurant when people in Africa are starving? How can society spend money on punditry while others cannot afford health care?
All that aside, the definition is interesting because of the lexicographer's agnosticism about how much we already have. The implication is that you can be as rich as Croesus, because the crime here is not having, but wanting. In the Bible, after all, it's not money that is "the root of all evil"; in his letter to Timothy, Paul wrote that it was "the love of money."
Americans have never especially warmed to the notion that having is all right, while getting isn't. For one thing, it's bad economics. The world of commerce is not a zero-sum game and, besides, demand is the driver of economic growth. Without demand -- for more, better, bigger, faster, prettier -- the whole system would collapse, and with it the health and freedoms that only affluence can underwrite. Excess is always a little sickening, but John Updike basically had it right when he suggested that money and sex are alike in this way: only too much is enough.
As usual, there is consolation in philosophy. Ivan F. Boesky was probably a little too blunt for comfort when he contended, in his heyday making money on Wall Street, that greed is healthy. (The actor Michael Douglas utters a similar line as Gordon Gekko in the 1987 movie "Wall Street.") Of course, we should deplore astronomical C.E.O. paychecks bestowed by chummy boards, or investors who ignore a company's lack of earnings or prospects. Even capitalism has a moral context.
But is the baseball shortstop Alex Rodriguez "greedy" for getting a $252 million contract from the Texas Rangers -- a willing buyer in an open market? Similarly, is anyone greedy for seeking the highest possible investment returns? 
The system will survive; corporate reforms will occur, seemingly working until the next round of market panic and scandal. And the market will go up again, as it always has.
When will that be? Nobody knows, of course. And even if I did, I wouldn't say. I'm too greedy, just like everyone else.

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Illusion of Entertainment; 
Just Like a Movie, But It's Not

BYLINE:  By NEAL GABLER; Neal Gabler is the author of "Life the Movie: How Entertainment Conquered Reality."

 BODY:
WITH summer comes the annual ritual of the Hollywood blockbuster, aimed primarily at teenagers, and with the blockbuster comes the annual ritual of complaining about it.
 Critics usually focuses on the thin plots, the lame jokes, the lack of characterization and the bombast of special effects. As they see it, many films now use an aesthetic sleight-of-hand that substitutes volume, speed, size and other neurological overloads for the more traditional satisfactions of entertainment, allowing viewers to expend a minimal amount of emotional energy. These are faux movies, and are about the only kind most teenagers respond to. They are also Exhibit A of a larger phenomenon: the illusion of entertainment. 
 For decades, cultural observers have been saying Americans live in a world of their own illusions, built to their specifications and designed to replace the disorder and discomfort of the unmanaged reality people were once sentenced to. As Umberto Eco wrote, "American imagination demands the real thing and, to attain it, must fabricate the absolute fake." 
Entertainment, especially film, with its blend of the real and the fantastic, has long been implicated in this shouldering aside of the genuine. But though entertainment is often blamed for this trend, it is also seemingly immune, because you cannot make a copy of a copy. You know that the French pavilion at Disney World's Epcot is not a real French bistro. But what would an imitation movie or TV show even look like? To talk about facsimiles of entertainment doesn't make sense.
Over the last few years, however, something has appeared that not even the most prescient cultural theorists anticipated. The television producer Phil Rosenthal calls it the "illusion of entertainment," and it is just that -- a form of entertainment that looks and sounds like conventional entertainment but is not, any more than Epcot's Paris is Paris. Something vital is missing. 
In most entertainment, the audience responds emotionally, psychologically, intellectually, even physically. There is a level of engagement, and we usually judge entertainment on the basis of how much engagement it elicits. At its simplest, as in so many teenage movies, the illusion of entertainment eschews other forms of engagement for purely physical effects. At its more complex, engagement is replaced by another mechanism entirely. Instead of character development in movies or full-bodied jokes in situation comedies viewers get a set of signals, a kind of code, that advises them how to respond without having to expend the effort, however minimal, that real entertainment demands. You see or hear the signal and you respond as if you were getting the real thing. Or put another way, you are given the form and you provide the content.
Just compare a conventional entertainment, the director Frank Capra's "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," with its latest avatar, Adam Sandler's "Mr. Deeds" -- by no means the most egregious offender. Both films tell the same story of a naif who inherits a fortune and is taken advantage of by urban sharpies. But that's where the similarity ends. Capra's classic is heavily plotted, quiet and often tender; leisurely paced, its comedy character- and plot-generated. You must watch and listen closely to enjoy it. Mr. Sandler's movie is more skimpily plotted, loud, often violent and frenetically paced. Its comedy is virtually all non sequiturs -- a disappearing butler or a gangrenous foot that is only funny because we know it is meant to be, not because it is inherently humorous. Even the romantic scenes are romantic only because viewers know they are supposed to be, and drippy music signals that they are. Mr. Sandler is working the code. He's stripped Capra down to the absolute basics of form and then added noise and speed.
In mathematics there is something called a derivative -- an expression that stands for another set of expressions. The illusion of entertainment is a kind of cultural derivative. You watch most television sitcoms and, just by the rhythm of the banter and the laugh track, you know how you are supposed to respond, whether the jokes are funny or not. Sitcom writers call this "likeajoke" because it has the form of a joke without the content. Or you go to a big commercial movie, and just by experiencing the rapid cutting and thumping music you know how you are supposed to respond, whether the action engages you or not.
In effect, these entertainments exist largely as a system of reminders of what we once experienced when we watched real entertainment -- movies and television shows that engaged us and made us feel.
OF course, some may argue that the illusion of entertainment is just another name for bad or formulaic entertainment, and the signals and codes are the cultural syntax that everyone grows up with. But the illusion of entertainment is not a matter of quality; it is a matter of kind -- of a different way of processing what we see. Even bad conventional entertainment operates on the principle of engagement; it is just that bad entertainment doesn't succeed in engaging. 
As for formulas, while most people are familiar with narrative patterns and understand what they convey, there is a big difference between old formulaic entertainment and the new illusion of entertainment. Formulas are designed to elicit predictable responses through predictable means -- predictable because they have worked in the past. You show an audience an attractive young man and woman who playfully bicker at the beginning of a movie and it roots for them to wind up together at the end. Or show a bully pushing around a decent fellow and viewers root for the latter to defeat the former. The audience reacts not because it knows the formula -- it reacts because the formula knows the audience.
THE illusion of entertainment doesn't put the audience through those paces. Being a derivative, it is far more emotionally economical. It gets its predictable responses by cuing the audience in how they are supposed to react. And it can do so because the audience, after years of watching movies and TV shows, is now hard-wired to respond. Virtually all Americans have internalized the code. They are sophisticated enough to know that a certain cadence of speech means funny and a certain editing pattern means action and certain saccharine music means melodrama. They don't need the whole apparatus of entertainment anymore, or even formulas. The illusion of entertainment is a shortcut -- entertainment lite.
It is not an altogether unsatisfying shortcut either. Just as Mr. Eco said that Americans prefer the fake to the real, so many prefer the illusion of entertainment to the real thing. The illusion of entertainment cannot provide all the pleasures real entertainment does, but it is far less demanding and challenging. It is also more accessible, and since it lets viewers essentially fill in the blanks themselves, it is more certain in its results. In fact, many people, especially young people, are now likely to judge a movie or TV show by how effectively it provides the forms and activates the codes. 
Not surprisingly, this has been a boon to the entertainment industry. Why struggle to write real jokes when you can write "likeajokes" and get the same effect? In doing so, however, producers of entertainment have not, as some critics assert, necessarily suffered a failure of talent or intelligence. Rather, they may have made a discovery and then exploited it. Just as the makers of kitsch, which is the illusion of art, learned to produce, in the critic Clement Greenberg's analysis, the effect without the cause, so have the makers of the illusion of entertainment learned how to produce the reaction without the reason for it. When the audience so embraces this, one cannot really blame producers for attempting to perfect it.
Obviously, no work of popular entertainment is entirely illusory yet. But real entertainment is endangered -- and not only because the illusion of entertainment is flooding the market. An entire generation has now grown up with the illusion of entertainment. It has grown up with the codes, with "likeajokes" and "likeanaction," and scarcely knows what real entertainment is -- which is why the illusion of entertainment is targeted at the young. For them, the codes are not reminders; they are the thing itself. 
It is bizarre to think that conventional entertainment may someday become a relic with even the old formulas attenuated into signals. Yet that is the future we are edging toward -- a future where entertainment is created by people who don't care about engagement for people who don't even know what engagement is.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Bake at 95 Degrees. Then Buy an Air-Conditioner.

BYLINE:  By MACAULAY CAMPBELL

 BODY:
 Sales of air-conditioners are heating up around the country this year, thanks in part to above-normal temperatures this summer and strong demand for new housing in some regions. Through the end of June, manufacturers shipped 3.9 million central air-conditioning units, a 5 percent increase from the same period in 2001, according to the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute. In June alone, shipments rose 11 percent from last year, the trade group said. Sales of smaller room-sized units are also picking up, a sign that some people were surprised by the hot weather. In June, those sales were $208 million, up from $156 million the year before. MACAULAY CAMPBELL

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Once More With Feeling: Buy American. Please!

BYLINE:  Compiled by Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:
The math couldn't be simpler. If you pay Americans $10 an hour to make shirts, they'll end up more expensive than if you pay a fraction of that to overseas workers. 
Of course, you can try to skew the math by appealing to customers to ignore the price and "buy American," but most shoppers typically stop waving flags the moment they pull out their wallets.
 Consider C. F. Hathaway, the last big company to make dress shirts domestically. After it was sold twice in six years, its latest owner planned to throw in the towel, not to mention the signature eye patch, and close the Waterville, Me., plant. That outraged the Made in the USA Foundation, which is heading a group to buy Hathaway and save 300 American jobs. 
 Joel Joseph, the foundation's chairman, showed his disdain for elementary capitalist math when he said shirt makers should accept lower profit margins. But he does have a plan: market the shirts to union members, socially conscious shoppers and government agencies under orders to buy American.



LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Starting Up in South Dakota

BYLINE:  Compiled by Vivian Marino

 BODY:
If you're looking to strike out on your own in business, you might want to look to South Dakota, Nevada and Wyoming. 
 They were found to be the three best states for small businesses and entrepreneurs, according to the Small Business Survival Committee, a nonprofit advocacy group, which last week released its 2002 Small Business Survival Index. 
 The annual index ranks states' friendliness to small enterprises, based on 20 factors, including taxes, costs for health care, electricity and labor, and crime rates. 
Rounding out the top five were Texas and Florida. The least friendly places, the survey found, were California, New Mexico, Minnesota, Maine, Hawaii and the District of Columbia.
Darrell McKigney, the president of the Small Business Survival Committee, said, "The best policy environment for entrepreneurship consists of low taxes, restrained government spending and regulation, and government fulfilling its duty of protecting life, limb and property."

HEADLINE: Defying China, Taiwan Leader Backs a Vote On Sovereignty 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan said today that separate countries now exist on either side of the Taiwan Strait and voiced support for legislation authorizing a referendum to declare Taiwan independent of China, positions that are certain to anger Beijing.
 Speaking of the Taiwan Strait, less than 100 miles of ocean that separates Taiwan from eastern China, President Chen declared, "Simply put, with Taiwan and China on each side of the strait, each side is a country -- this needs to be clear." 
 He made the comment from his office in Taipei, the capital, in a video teleconference with pro-independence Taiwanese in Tokyo.
President Chen also lent his support to pro-independence forces in his Democratic Progressive Party who want the national Legislature to approve a law making a plebiscite on independence possible. 
"I want to sincerely urge and encourage everybody to seriously consider the importance and urgency of passing legislation on a referendum," he said.
President Chen's statements are the closest he has come to endorsing independence since taking office two years ago. He did not actually say when or even whether a referendum should be held, but stuck to endorsing legislation to make such a referendum possible.
The holding of referendums, he said, "is a basic human right that cannot be withheld or restricted."
An official in the Taiwan Affairs Office of the Chinese government in Beijing said this afternoon that the speech had been noticed. "At present it's the weekend, normal staff aren't on duty, so we haven't an official response yet to President Chen Shui-bian's speech, but the Chinese government won't be deviating from the One China principle," said the official, who declined to be named.
Ever since Chiang Kai-shek and his Nationalist Party supporters retreated to Taiwan after losing China's civil war in 1949, Beijing has maintained that Taiwan is a renegade province, and has consistently refused to renounce the use of force to reunite Taiwan with the mainland.
Cross-strait relations are so sensitive that Beijing seldom issues official statements without approval at the highest levels, which often can take several days. Predicting the level of anger from Beijing is especially difficult now because the party's leadership is at its annual retreat, preparing for this autumn's Communist Party congress, which is held every five years.
There have been signs that the party is embroiled in a struggle over how much power should be relinquished by Jiang Zemin, China's 76-year-old president and Communist Party chief, who is expected to give up at least one of his posts. Many important decisions, on everything from economic policy to relations with the United States, have apparently been deferred until after the party congress, for which no date has been publicly set yet. So it is possible that Chinese leaders will be leery of confronting Taiwan while preoccupied with their own maneuvering.
But when Mr. Chen's predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, said in July 1999 that Taiwan and China had a "special state-to-state" relationship, Beijing responded furiously to the intimation that Taiwan was an independent country. Chinese fighters flew sorties near Taiwanese aircraft over the Taiwan Strait. Alarmed by rising tensions, Washington canceled a visit to Taiwan by American military aides but also warned Beijing that the United States would retaliate if China resorted to military force.
The comments today mark the second time in two weeks that Mr. Chen has made statements certain to draw Beijing's ire. He said on July 21 that his people should "walk down our own Taiwanese road to find Taiwan's future." Mr. Chen made those comments a few hours after the Pacific island of Nauru recognized Beijing and broke diplomatic relations with Taipei.

HEADLINE: Broadway Getting the Jitters As Advance Ticket Sales Fall 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
Since Sept. 11, thousands of Broadway theatergoers have been buying their tickets in a strikingly different way -- much more spur of the moment rather than far in advance -- and anxious producers say the change promises to have long-term effects on how shows are booked, marketed and priced, and even on how much stars will be paid. 
 According to new statistics from the League of American Theaters and Producers, Broadway's main trade group, only about one in three theatergoers is buying tickets more than four weeks in advance. That figure is a sharp departure from the typical 50 percent that producers had grown to expect over the last decade, a period of remarkable prosperity for Broadway as a whole. 
 "The notion of having an advance and being able to plan with that in mind has been a part of the financial infrastructure for a long time now," said Jed Bernstein, the league's president. "If this is a permanent change, it's really going to change the fundamental finances of many shows." 
With a traditional September slowdown fast approaching and a host of long-running shows posting closing notices -- including "Contact," "The Full Monty" and "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" -- Broadway producers have kept a close watch on advance sales, an important indicator of any production's health. With their advances rapidly dwindling in recent months, the two musicals decided to shut down on Sept. 1, "The Allergist's Wife" on Sept. 15.
While all three productions had healthy, successful runs and recouped their investments, the situation is worse for some recently opened shows, and especially plays. "Topdog/Underdog," which won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama, will close next Sunday despite decent weekly sales, because its star actors, Jeffrey Wright and Mos Def, are leaving. With only a limited advance -- and thus no safety net -- the producers decided to close rather than try to recast.
Many other plays, including "The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?" "Proof," "Metamorphoses" and "Noises Off," are facing difficult choices as their advances begin to shrink as well. 
Next month is shaping up to be a particularly cruel period. With two Jewish holidays and Labor Day, September has always been a slow month on Broadway as families avoid the theater for religious services or trips away. But this year, the commemoration of Sept. 11 is adding worries about the public's appetite for theater; only a handful of shows are performing that day -- which is a Wednesday, usually a two-show day. 
Factor in a weak economy and weak advance sales, and some Broadway insiders say they expect producers may just close long-running shows rather than risk a series of weekly losses. 
"It becomes a point where producers who might have ridden out a dry stretch might just pull the plug," said one press agent who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "It becomes a question of being prudent to your investors." 
Even incoming productions are feeling the effects. Only the new season's most talked-about show, "Hairspray," a new musical based on the 1988 movie by John Waters, and "Movin' Out," a dance musical framed around the songs of Billy Joel, have had significant advance sales, and neither is setting any records. "Hairspray," for example, which opens on Aug. 15, has a $6 million advance; "The Producers," last year's hit, had $15 million before it opened. 
Weak advances also inspire the sort of Catch-22 that makes producers wince. To drum up immediate sales, a production will use advertising money budgeted for future weeks, which in turn, raises weekly costs and the need for more advance sales. And so on. 
All of which has made the job of producing a Broadway show, never one for the weak of heart, that much more harrowing. "People are frightened," said another press agent. "I have never heard fear and trembling expressed so clearly."
Theater owners, producers and other industry experts say the drop-off is directly connected to the lifeblood of Broadway: tourism.
"With rare exceptions, what we're finding is that people aren't traveling to near the extent that they were," said Tom Viertel, one of the producers of "The Producers," one of the few shows on Broadway that still have a healthy advance ($18 million, in this case). "People simply aren't taking discretionary travel."
But city tourism officials suspect the declines on Broadway may also have something to do with the type of tourist now visiting the city. 
Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, said recent surveys by her agency found that while the number of tourists this summer was roughly equivalent to that of last summer, their average stay was shorter and the amount of money being spent was lower. "More people are booking last-minute," she said, "and hunting for discount deals."
Of particular concern to Broadway, Ms. Nicholas said, was a decline in the number of group tours from around the nation and individual foreign tourists. 
"They are the ones who would book well in advance, and that's not there right now," she said. "That's been wiped out almost." The stagnant economy and increasingly high ticket prices have probably contributed somewhat to theatergoers' preference for discount tickets, but the major problems began, like all those related to the tourism industry, immediately after Sept. 11, when Broadway attendance plummeted and advance sales for many shows came to a standstill.
With a series of promotional efforts and $1.5 million in aid from the city, Broadway staged a remarkably strong recovery, eventually grossing $643.4 million for the season. (Attendance for the 2002-03 season, now 10 weeks old, is off by only about 5 percent compared with last season.) 
But while the crowds did eventually return, they often did so by buying half-price tickets the day of the performance or buying heavily discounted seats at the last minute. And while advance sales did rebound from last fall, the league's most recent survey, which ended in early June after the Tony Awards, showed that only 37 percent of patrons were buying their seats at least four weeks in advance, down from the usual benchmark of 50 percent. 
One of the inevitable reactions to weaker advance sales is for producers to discount tickets close to the performance date rather than get stuck with an unsalable product. But that strategy can have long-term consequences, especially when the always-tough winter months come around. 
"If you're solving a January problem in November, that's always a bad thing," said Mr. Viertel, referring to the common practice of having half-price sales in January. "You end up sawing yourself off a limb, because when January comes around, those people will have already bought earlier on."
The downturn, Mr. Viertel said, may challenge producers to think of new promotional schemes and marketing ideas to attract audiences. "Who knows when people will begin to feel comfortable about planning ahead?" he said. "So we have to."
Half-price sales and more efficient productions, of course, are not bad for consumers, and on Wednesday, the line around the TKTS booth in Duffy Square was packed five-deep with theatergoers looking for cheap tickets. They were not disappointed; 23 of the 30 current Broadway productions were on sale, including "Phantom of the Opera" -- like so many shows, its advance, once enormous, has shrunk since Sept. 11.
There are some good signs, of course. Several productions, including "Hairspray" and a starry revival of "Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune," are opening before September. Many hope they will jump-start the season as well as box-office sales across the board.

HEADLINE: A New Schools Chancellor Draws Advice, Optimism and Crossed Fingers 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
With the shift to mayoral control, and a host of unresolved governance questions, Joel I. Klein, the incoming chancellor, will be navigating New York City's schools into new territory at a time when the faltering economy is forcing big budget cuts. 
 Nonetheless, many education experts say he will have a strong wind at his back in charting a course -- both because of the mayor's support, and because of the groundwork that is already in place. 
 Rather than proposing sweeping systemic changes, many experts suggest that Mr. Klein's early energies should be trained on finding the city's most successful schools, examining their strategies and replicating them in the lowest-performing schools. Most suggestions for Mr. Klein that emerged in interviews with his predecessors, his counterparts in other urban districts, and education leaders, began with advice for him to recognize the best schools and learn from them. 
"I was very encouraged at the announcement of Joel Klein's appointment, with the mayor saying there is much good in the New York City schools," said Ramon C. Cortines, who resigned as chancellor in 1995 after two years of heavy fire from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "It's been a long time since a mayor said anything good about New York schools. It's important to be a cheerleader for the good things, to recognize successes like the small-school movement and the special schools." 
Celebrating success cannot be the only task in a system where so many schools so badly fail so many children. While the chancellor must certainly address those failures, experts say, it is important not just as a matter of spin to recognize that some schools produce outstanding academic results, even in the most difficult neighborhoods.
"We know there's some excellent schools, some good schools and some bombs," said Frank Macchiarola, another former chancellor. "We ought to be looking at the schools that work, figuring out why they work, and replicating them. You could interview each of the superintendents, ask them to do the data to tell you which schools are doing well and why." 
Wendy Kopp, the president of Teach for America, a nonprofit group that places recent college graduates in troubled urban schools after a summer of training, offered similar advice -- for slightly different reasons. 
"He should spend a couple of weeks, extremely early on, walking around schools that are doing really well, in the lowest socioeconomic areas, and talking with principals to find out why they were able to get such good results," she said. "The most important thing is for him never to waver from the confidence that it is possible to create high-performing schools in under-resourced areas. It's so easy to lose that sense of possibility." 
The more the public shares that sense of hope, she said, the more support the schools will get. "It's potentially going to be easier to get more money when the public has more confidence about what's being done with the money," she said. 
New York's schools are stunning in their sheer size: With 1.1 million students in more than 1,100 schools, the system as a whole will not be easy for Mr. Klein to steer. 
"He is not going to be the captain of a ship, he's going to be a harbor master, and the harbor has 1,100 or 1,200 different ships, some of which are doing well, and some of which are floundering," said Diane Ravitch, a research professor at New York University. 
Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, suggested that Mr. Klein not think of his job as reforming the system but rather as trying to improve 1,100 schools, almost as if each was a branch of a large business. 
"That's a manageable number," Mr. Levine said. "Corporations do it all the time. If the Chase Bank knows Branch No. 37 stinks, it works on fixing Branch No. 37, not changing the whole system. In New York City schools, the job should be to recruit and retain 1,100 excellent principals who have the autonomy and accountability to improve 1,100 schools."
In many cities where mayoral control has brought a new schools chief -- or where a new superintendent from outside has stepped in -- there have been significant centralized reforms, including summer school for failing students, mandatory uniforms, classes on pedagogy for principals, and strict rules on how many classroom minutes must be spent on particular subjects. 
In San Diego, the superintendent, Alan D. Bersin, ordered weekly training on literacy techniques for all principals, and required each principal to spend two hours a day in the classroom. And in Chicago, where mayoral control began in 1995, Arne Duncan, the schools' chief executive, requires two hours a day of reading and writing in every classroom. 
In those cities and elsewhere, the school chiefs have put a strong emphasis on reading and writing, using specific techniques. 
"You have to be bold," Mr. Duncan said. "These are massive institutions, and to have an impact, you have to make significant changes. You can really leverage the mayor's support. There's a tremendous amount of important work that you can get done due to having some unity from the top, in being able to work with the Parks Department and the social services people. But the focus has to be on instruction, on what's going on in the classroom. We have a clear literacy framework, and it's paid off in our test results." 
Some educators hope that in New York, too, mayoral control will bring instructional changes, like required curriculums and teaching methods. 
"I think we should have a prescribed curriculum," Dr. Ravitch said. "As it is, we test on a curriculum, but we don't say what that curriculum is." 
While the shift to mayoral control is, structurally, a profound centralization, many experts do not expect Mr. Klein to impose huge new layers of protocols from headquarters. New York, they point out, is already moving on changes like increased testing and standards and a beefed-up summer school. 
Furthermore, many say that New York's schools already suffer from an overly intrusive headquarters -- and too little flexibility for principals. 
"New York has consistently centralized the wrong things, and decentralized the wrong things," Dr. Ravitch said. "We've created a rule book that takes the place of people using their good judgment. Headquarters should support people in the field and audit their performance. Headquarters shouldn't be telling people what to do every minute. I was talking to a group of principals recently, and they kept coming back to the burden of the paperwork, and how much time they spent on reports. We need to find ways to give principals greater authority over what happens in their building, the resources, the staff, the purchasing." 
There is widespread agreement that good principals, those with a sense of mission and the skill and training to carry it out, are crucial to improving schools -- and that many are hindered by unnecessary bureaucracy. 
A glaring inequity in New York, Dr. Ravitch said, is that the poorest, lowest-performing schools have the least experienced teachers and the highest turnover, a problem that might be addressed by letting their principals pay more to attract and keep experienced teachers. 
Jill Levy, the president of the principals' union, said: "Principals should be able to allocate their money, to run their schools the way they want, and then be held accountable. As a businessperson, if I have a unit that is supposed to deliver a product, but there are all kinds of limits on how they're allowed to deliver it, how can I hold them accountable for their results?" 
Ms. Levy said Mr. Klein's efforts would be complicated by the shrinking budget. 
"There are all kinds of fiscal issues out there," she said. "One thing that's going to be very important is for the chancellor and the mayor to push the campaign for fiscal equity, to be strong advocates with the governor, the legislators and the people to get more money for New York City schools. Joel Klein has a tremendous challenge, taking over the system at a time when the resources are really not available to schools. But it's a moment of real opportunity, too."

HEADLINE: A Hotel Helps Ease Racial Tensions 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
In slick travel magazine ads, big-budget movies and hip-hop videos, this sun-drenched city is billed as an oceanfront oasis with an international flavor that offers something for everyone. To some, though, Miami Beach has never fully lived up to its reputation.
 Off and on for decades, Miami Beach has had a strained relationship with African-American tourists and locals, who contend that the city's embrace of Hispanic, European and white American visitors has not always been extended to blacks. 
 When city officials snubbed Nelson Mandela during a visit here in 1990, local civil rights activists led a two-and-a-half-year boycott of Miami Beach by African-American tourists that cost the city $50 million, by some estimates. Tensions have risen and fallen since, edging up again over the 2001 Memorial Day weekend, when the city did little to prepare for an influx of 250,000 hip-hop fans for club events on South Beach that had been promoted on urban radio stations throughout the country. 
The disorganization led to overcrowded streets and hotels and more than 200 arrests and vocal complaints by local residents and business owners that the weekend had been a blight on the city's image.
Enter R. Donahue Peebles, a multimillionaire developer on a mission. Mr. Peebles bulldozed his way onto the pricey real estate scene in 1996, becoming a major part of Miami Beach's answer to its racial tensions.
As part of a deal to end the boycott, the city agreed to allocate some of its oceanfront real estate and invest $10 million in an African-American-owned hotel. The result is the Royal Palm Crowne Plaza Resort, developed and owned by the Peebles Atlantic Development Corporation.
"The whole idea for the hotel was conceived to be a panacea to restore relations between the black community and leadership in Miami Beach," said Nancy Liebman, who was until last year a Miami Beach commissioner and one of the people criticized for statements she made about the 2001 hip-hop weekend.
"The hotel seems to be a very bright and shining star in the tourism aspect of Miami Beach," Ms. Liebman said. The mayor of Miami Beach, David Dermer, did not return calls requesting an interview.
Given the rocky road to making the Royal Palm a reality, Mr. Peebles said he was not looking for local officials to weigh in. "They should be proud and grateful that my company and I created the Royal Palm, and finished it," he said.
"We built this project under very challenging circumstances," he said. "There was contaminated soil, there was structural defects on the building, the hotel management industry basically collapsed, we had Sept. 11 after that, all those obstacles. The project went over $20 million over budget, and I didn't walk away."
Not only did he have his company and investors to consider, Mr. Peebles also had a personal investment in the Royal Palm, an elegantly appointed, $84 million resort. "I didn't want to be, as a developer, the person who failed to build the African-American-owned hotel," he said. "It would have allowed the city and others who may not be supportive of equal economic opportunity to say, 'Hey, we tried to build an African-American-owned hotel but the developer couldn't do it, so now we don't have that responsibility anymore.' "
Mr. Peebles has not stopped there. He is planning to transform the Bath Club, one of the oldest private clubs in the country, into 20-story condominiums and private villas with prices starting at $5 million.
If the Royal Palm sent a message, Mr. Peebles was making an even bolder statement with the Bath Club. Dating to the 1920's, the Mediterranean Revival-style club was once an exclusive getaway for wealthy snowbirds. Herbert Hoover was a member; in 1996, Mr. Peebles joined too. Soon after, a local newspaper reporter asked how he felt being the first African-American member of a club that had historically excluded blacks and Jews. He said he was stunned.
When he found out a few years later that the club was debt ridden and on the market for a mere $10 million, he bought it. Construction will begin later this year, he said.
Just as his projects blend old-style architecture and modern decor, Mr. Peebles himself is an image of contrasts. He began a recent interview by declaring, "I'm not an African-American businessperson -- I'm a businessperson." But promotional materials distributed by his office repeatedly refer to his business as African-American owned and his projects as African-American firsts.
Mr. Peebles also says he is committed to creating career opportunities for African-Americans. The general manager of the Royal Palm is black, and the hotel staff reflects the diversity he says he is striving for, though the Bath Club's sales and marketing staff is mostly white.
Mr. Peebles says that who he is and what he does involve a dual responsibility. "I'm a businessperson who has just as much of a sense of responsibility to my employees and my investors, but I also feel a sense of responsibility to the community I represent," he said.
The Royal Palm has come to be known as the black hotel, a distinction Mr. Peebles admits is simplistic, but embraces anyway. The hotel has also become a source of pride to some residents and tourists here.
Dwayne Bryant, an African-American firefighter from Newark who was visiting here for the first time on his vacation last week, said he switched hotels when a cab driver told him about the Royal Palm.
"It's long past due," Mr. Bryant said. "There should be more black-owned businesses out here. I mean, this place is for everyone -- it's not just for whites, not just for Latinos, not just for blacks."

HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS TURNING CAUTIOUS ON SPENDING IN U.S. 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Foreign investors, who once joined with confident Americans in a wave of spectacular acquisitions and business spending that helped power the 1990's economic boom, are now turning cautious about the United States economy. That is compounding the current weakness and making it harder to achieve a robust recovery from last year's recession.
 With fresh acquisitions almost nil, foreign direct investment in the United States -- the technical name for acquiring a company or establishing one -- plummeted last year to $124 billion and started out this year at an even slower pace, the Commerce Department reports. That is down from a peak of $301 billion in 2000. 
 Companies from abroad, after a big expansion here in the last two decades, now have a large enough presence in the American corporate sector to strengthen or weaken the economy by their behavior. The hope among economists was that they would renew their spending this year, given all the expectations of a rapid recovery and the bargain prices at which many companies, particularly in the high technology sector, could be purchased. But it has not happened. 
"Foreigners were on the verge of investing again, until their confidence was upended by the corporate scandals and the slide in the stock market," said Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a research firm. "And now they cannot get financing and their own economies back home are weakening."
The steep falloff in foreign direct investment to set up shop in the United States contributed to an even more critical decline in capital investment by foreigners to expand or re-equip their operations here. That spending is off 15 to 20 percent, according to estimates by Joseph P. Quinlan, a global economist at Morgan Stanley, from its peak of $136 billion in 1999.
"The Europeans in particular came headlong into the American market with spectacular acquisitions and huge capital outlays for expansions that have not paid off," Mr. Quinlan said. "After that experience they are going to tiptoe back."
Foreign companies did not just seek out existing American enterprises to take over. They also put up new factories and offices and spent constantly to expand their operations here, rapidly increasing their contribution to the nation's economic growth. Europeans led the charge in the 1990's but the Japanese, despite a long period of stagnation at home, were not far behind.
No aspect of the American economy is more vital for the recovery than capital investment, which is the spending for new factories, machinery, computers, offices and all the other tools of production that contribute to economic expansion. Capital spending generates jobs and income as these tools of production are made and used. Such investments by foreigners have nearly doubled since 1986 as a percentage of total capital spending in the United States.
But now -- instead of bucking the tide, as the Japanese often did in the 1980's by outspending their American rivals -- most foreign companies are pulling back in step with their hosts. And foreign companies seem even less likely these days to take chances than American companies battered by the collapse of the technology boom and the corporate scandals. "That makes the recovery tentative at best," Mr. Zandi, the economist, said.
The Random House division of Bertelsmann, the German media giant, is entering a no-investment mode. It has spent $300 million on a headquarters building at Broadway and West 56th Street in Manhattan that will be ready for occupancy in the fall, and $100 million on information technology and distribution center expansion and upgrades, including turning a warehouse in Crawfordsville, Ind., into a distribution center for children's books.
But once that is done, capital spending plans will be on hold. "We have what we need," said Stuart Applebaum, a Random House spokesman.
The Sony Corporation, whose acquisitions of Columbia Pictures and CBS Records in the 1980's helped to stir a furor over what some American commentators described as the imperial ambitions of Japan Inc., is far less aggressive today. With its home economy in recession, Sony has slashed capital spending by 40 percent worldwide in the last two years and has closed 15 factories, two of them in the United States.
"We are investing less here," Greg Dvorken, a Sony official, said, adding hopefully, "but more strategically."
To be sure, foreign companies are not simply pulling up stakes in the United States. Many are continuing to look for opportunities to invest in what they see as the most promising industries.
In Kentucky, for example, where the state's economic development officials have been particularly successful in attracting new operations, foreign investment has fallen off less than that of American companies. In 1999, a peak year, 68 companies agreed to put manufacturing operations in Kentucky, 10 of them foreign, mainly Japanese and European. In the last two years, Kentucky has managed to attract fewer than 40 projects annually. But the shrunken number still included seven or eight from abroad each year.
Gene Strong, a top official of the state's economic development agency, attributes that achievement in part to Kentucky's strong role in carmaking.
The auto industry is indeed a bright spot in foreign investment in the United States. While Ford, for example, is cutting costs and closing factories, foreign auto makers are expanding, and trying to take away market share.
Toyota, with several operations in Kentucky, is in the midst of investing hundreds of millions of dollars to expand four of its American plants. And Hyundai has just started construction of a $1 billion assembly plant in Hope Hull, Ala. Once finished and operating at full tilt in four years or so, the plant, Hyundai's first in the United States, will employ 2,000 people and produce 225,000 cars a year, says Chris Hosford, a company spokesman.
"Our American sales are rising," he said, "and that justified the investment."
But apart from autos and a few other specialty areas, capital spending by foreign companies is by nearly every estimate falling from the high of $136.3 billion reached in 1998 and again in 1999, the most recent years for which data is available from the Bureau of Economic Analysis. From the low for the decade of $70 billion in 1993, capital spending by foreign companies shot up as the boom gathered steam to those two peak years.
The foreign contribution to the nation's capital spending in the 1990's rose to nearly 9 percent of all capital outlays in America's private sector in 1999 from less than 5 percent in 1986. The economy boomed because of the rapidly rising capital spending, particularly in telecommunications and high technology. And then the plunge in capital outlays set off a recession last year.
Today, consumers, housing, and increased federal spending sustain the weak recovery that apparently began around the beginning of this year. The uncertainty among economists is whether those sectors can hold up until capital spending revives -- once again generating jobs and income. While investment is no longer falling as fast as it once did, that upturn has not happened yet. About the only bright spot was a modest increase, after seven straight quarters of declines, in outlays for software and business equipment in the most recent quarter, from April through June.
Foreign ownership has made its way into almost every industry in the United States, and the recognition of its presence and importance is in striking contrast to the 1980's. Then, Japanese incursions into automaking, banking, entertainment and trophy real estate -- even the purchase of Rockefeller Center -- brought stiff resistance and public warnings about a Japanese juggernaut.
But as confidence in American competitiveness returned in the 1990's, foreign investment was welcomed. Now it has become necessary.
Sensitive to the nation's increased dependence on foreign-owned companies, Robert T. Betz, the just-retired president of Cognis North America, carefully explains how Cognis has dealt with capital spending after sales dropped because of Sept. 11. Cognis, largely owned by Schroeder Ventures, a British firm, is a chemical company in Cincinnati that makes ingredients mainly for beauty and health care products.
"None of our capital spending was stopped," Mr. Betz insisted. "It was reviewed. It was a matter of saying in December that we will do this in April. And we are starting to implement capital spending again now."
But at other foreign companies, cautiousness still reigns. At Coral Graphic Services, a unit of Bertelsmann that has four printing plants in this country, no further expansion is planned now that a new plant opened last month in Kentucky.
"There is always a little capital spending; you have to buy machines once in a while," said Gernot Wolf, a Bertelsmann spokesman.
"But no major expenditures," he added. "Not at all."
