HEADLINE: Coastal Village Preserves Its Nature 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: CASPAR, Calif. 

 BODY:
If California is the land of self-reinvention, Caspar could be the unofficial capital.
 Perhaps only in Caspar, a ragtag conglomeration of weeds and woolly renegades nestled on the Pacific coast just north of Mendocino, would villagers gather to spend a Sunday afternoon discussing the social implications of a spa. Perhaps only in this, yes, rather ghostly looking former mill town would a group of arty, aging back-to-the-landers and urban refugees recruit a family therapist and a landscape architecture professor from Berkeley to help wrest their town from sudden death. 
 They call themselves the Casparados. For five years, this unincorporated village's 500 or so residents -- no one knows the exact number, since Caspar is said to be a state of mind as well as a place -- have waged a sophisticated, impassioned campaign to preserve their town. 
Their crusade began in 1997, when the major landowner here announced that he was selling the heart of the town, about 300 acres including not just the center of the village but also the beach, the Caspar Creek and the hypnotic windswept headlands that collectively make up one of the largest stretches of undeveloped property on the California coast.
Haunted by visions of an oceanfront Ramada, the Casparados seized control of their fate. Instead of protesting, the motley group of former strangers transformed themselves into a nonprofit organization suspiciously resembling a government. Collectively, they began designing a master plan for the town. 
This summer, egged on by the community, the Mendocino Land Trust and a national organization called the Trust for Public Land assembled a $3.5 million patchwork of state and federal money to buy the majestic 71-acre headlands, which had been privately owned since the mid-19th century. Now the property is public, officially part of Caspar Headlands State Beach, California's newest state park.
The Casparados include a onetime drummer for the Byrds, the original writer of "The Muppet Show," the Grammy award-winning producer and songwriter for Sheryl Crow and Shelby Lynne, and a Bronx-born coffee maker who once ran a Hunter S. Thompson campaign for sheriff.
Caspar is considered unusual by professional planning experts, not only for the active stance of its citizens but also for the community-designed town plan -- still being hammered out -- which calls for ecology-sensitive growth, including the addition of 35 or 40 houses.
"We've skirted the hairy edge of Nimbyism," said Michael Potts, 57, the author of several books on living off the grid. Mr. Potts, who came here as a conscientious objector in the 70's, said, "There was no term for 'yes in my backyard.' "
What Caspar is saying "no" to lies five miles down the road, in Mendocino, itself a former lumber town with charming architecture now inhabited by T-shirt shops and $300-a-night bed-and-breakfasts. "Mendocino," said Madelin Holtkamp, executive director of the Economic Development and Financing Corporation of Mendocino County, a nonprofit organization, "is a place increasingly where nobody really lives."
Caspar itself looks improbable -- a combination of empty prairie and a tenuous assortment of buildings coexisting in fog. Among them: hand-built hippie houses; a raucous 100-year-old roadhouse; perhaps the only Norman Rockwell-looking synagogue in North America; and, in an oceanfront neighborhood waggishly called "splendid Caspar," an architectural statement recently featured in Architectural Digest.
"We have big money, new money, old money, people-wishing-they-had money and people-glad-they-don't-have money," said Judy Tarbell, 64, one of the most active Casparados.
This famously scenic coastline from Mendocino north to Fort Bragg -- Caspar being the fleeting speck between them on Highway 1 -- has undergone profound changes in recent years, with tourists displacing timber as the economic mainstay. Georgia-Pacific recently announced that in the fall it will close its mill in Fort Bragg, a traditionally working-class town. While Mendocino's picturesque inns stay afloat with minimum-wage seasonal labor, the average price of housing has soared above $475,000 in Mendocino village, buoyed by weekenders and vacationers breakfasting amid fresh flowers.
The Casparados say they want to avoid a "Mendo-reactive culture."
"We represent all of coastal California that shouldn't be adversely developed," Mr. Potts said. 
Caspar was presented with an unusual set of circumstances -- a huge, undeveloped parcel of coastal land put up for sale by a single owner -- the Caspar Cattle Company, a k a Oscar Smith, 61, who had spent most of his childhood in the town.
In 1990, Mr. Smith bought the 300 acres, once home to 5,000 millworkers, from the lumber company, where his uncle Jim Lilley had been supervisor for nearly 60 years. "I didn't want to see them bulldoze it into nothing," Mr. Smith said.
He, too, had dreams of forging a community here, he said, but he grew tired of environmental and coastal regulators. When the community caught wind of his intention to sell, they began holding boisterous, sometimes contentious monthly town meetings (hence the therapist).
They worked out their vision, with assistance from Randy Hester, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley who helps communities design public spaces.
Dr. Hester urged the Casparados to identify their most "sacred spaces" -- first and foremost the headlands and the creek, with its spawning Coho salmon and lush tangles of wild roses and sweet peas.
"Many California towns, because of growth pressures and second-home development, are facing the question of what they are going to become," he said. "What's amazing about Caspar is the fact that they didn't have a government, yet they've operated with the kind of direct democracy seen in colonial New England."
Meridian Green, a folk singer who has dedicated two CD's to her hometown, including "Live From Caspar," recorded with her husband, Gene Parsons, a former drummer in the Byrds, put it this way: "The community norm is self-expression. So when consensus occurs, that's really powerful." 
Now comes the emotionally charged task of composing a town center that, as the plan advocates, is "unostentatious, beautiful, nurturing." One hundred and forty acres of Caspar is "still up for grabs," Mr. Potts said.
Last month, a wealthy resident stepped in to help the Casparados secure the former grammar school, built in 1912, as a community center, where even the symbols on the flagpole -- the American flag, the state flag and the Earth Flag, in that order -- were the subject of deep philosophical debate.
Though still an unofficial body, the nonprofit Caspar Community now wields considerable local clout. The members have been talking with Habitat for Humanity about building lower-income housing, and they envision a strollable town center with solar-powered houses, shops, cottage industries, electric car hook-ups and perhaps the most important missing amenity, a bakery.
To Mr. Smith, the visions of the Casparados go only so far. "It's easy to hug each other and drink wine and be dreamy," he said. "But at some point someone is going to have to start digging dirt."

HEADLINE: C.E.O. to Retire Over Dating Worker 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: COVINGTON, Ky., Aug. 3 

 BODY:
Ashland Inc., the maker of Valvoline motor oil, said Friday that its chief executive, Paul W. Chellgren, will retire because he had violated a company policy on dating subordinates.
 Stan Lampe, a spokesman for the company, which is based here, said Mr. 
Chellgren violated Ashland's policy on office relationships. The policy, according to a copy provided by Mr. Lampe, states, "A supervisor may not date, or have a romantic relationship with an employee who reports through his or her management chain, even when the relationship is voluntary and welcome." 
 Mr. Chellgren, who is 59, had been chief executive for six years and also was chairman. He will step down effective Nov. 15, under an agreement with the board, Ashland said in a statement. The company, at a time when the economy has been roiled by business scandals, said his departure is not related to finances or operations.
Mr. Lampe declined to provide more details, and Mr. Chellgren was not available to comment. The employee involved was not identified.
A successor to Mr. Chellgren was not named.
Mr. Chellgren joined Ashland in 1974 as an assistant to its chief executive then, Orin Atkins. A year later, Mr. Atkins admitted making illegal contributions to President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign. Mr. Chellgren was named president and chief operating officer in 1992.

HEADLINE: After Lean Years, A Hospital Boomlet 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
IN health care, the 1990's were a C decade, an era of cuts and consolidation. Forced to reduce overhead in the era of managed health care, staffs were trimmed to the bone, and Long Island hospitals merged with each other like crazy. A decade ago, most of the 27 hospitals on the Island were independent; now the local industry is dominated by five health systems, with only six unaffiliated hospitals.
 The 2000's are shaping up as an S decade: spending and specialization. Responding to medical advances and a growing shopper mentality, hospitals are introducing new services and upgrading existing departments. Many are trying to stand out from a crowded field by becoming centers for specialties like heart disease, cancer or emergency services. 
 It sounds like a multimillion-dollar competition for market share, no matter what James Harden says. 
Mr. Harden, the executive director of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's regional care network, insisted that the 50,000-square-foot outpatient clinic it opened in June in Commack was strictly to give its Long Island patients an opportunity to receive cancer treatment closer to home. Mr. Harden said Sloan-Kettering anticipated about 35,000 visits to the Commack clinic, which handles screening, diagnosis, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgical consultations. The center will have a staff of 60, including 12 doctors.
Mr. Harden dismissed any suggestion that Sloan-Kettering was out to compete for patients with Long Island hospitals.
"I don't see where there is a contest," he said. "There are many other fine cancer providers on Long Island, and they have a very important role to play in delivering services."
Local hospital officials aren't buying it. "Most definitely they are a competitor," said Dr. Theodore G. Gabig, the vice president for cancer services at the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, based in Manhasset.
Kevin W. Dahill, the president of the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, which represents the 24 nonprofit hospitals on Long Island, contends that Sloan-Kettering "must be scared" about losing Long Island patients. 
"When Long Islanders are presented with the opportunity, they prefer to stay on Long Island" for medical care, Mr. Dahill said.
Terence Lynam, the North Shore-L.I.J. Health System's director of public relations, noted that his system diagnosed and treated 45,000 cancer patients last year, more than Mount Sinai/N.Y.U. Health Systems, Sloan-Kettering or New York-Presbyterian.
Apparently, North Shore-L.I.J. wants to keep it that way: Mr. Lynam said his system was in the midst of a major fund-raising campaign to expand its cancer treatment program.
Dan Rosett, a spokesman for Stony Brook University Hospital, another Sloan-Kettering competitor, stressed that his institution's Long Island Cancer Center was the only university-based cancer center on the Island.
"As a part of the State University at Stony Brook, we can marshal all kinds of resources and talent from all specialties in the university," he said. "For example, I don't think the other hospitals have a department of biomedical engineering. And we have a center for molecular medicine and biophysics."
Mr. Dahill said that new medical advances were being made all the time and that hospitals were simply trying to keep up.
"There is no question that demand for services -- particularly for new technologies -- is increasing, and the hospitals have to respond by reconfiguring their space and environment," he said. 
"All of the hospitals were built and predicated upon in-patient stays," Mr. Dahill said. "They were built to be almost like a hotel in that regard. Now, with a lot of one-day stays, hospitals are more like shopping malls, and so traffic patterns and parking have changed and facilities have to be updated to reflect the way medicine is delivered."
He also noted the trend toward specialization. "Before hospitals develop a program, they scan the environment and determine what services are needed and what should be offered. What is new is the marketing of those services to the general public.
In the last six months, there has been a great deal of advertising about full-body CAT scans. In the past, marketing was to doctors because only they could appreciate new drugs or X-ray equipment. But much of the new technology is more understandable."
Officials of Long Island hospitals eagerly tout their newest services. St. Charles Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Port Jefferson last month introduced a new type of computer-navigated surgery for joint replacements. 
"We compare it to a global positioning guidance system," said Janet R. Heller, the hospital's director of public relations. "You may know how to get to Peoria, but not to the exact house on Elm Street. This guides the surgeon's hands."
The Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow recently completed an expansion and renovation of its emergency department's waiting room and is about to add another CAT scanning device in the emergency department. The emergency room treated 82,111 patients last year, the most of any hospital on Long Island.
Not to be outdone, the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center in Patchogue is expanding its emergency room from 27,000 square feet to 35,000 square feet. Richard T. Margulis, the hospital's vice president for operations, said it would be the biggest on the Island.
"It will allow patients to be triaged upon entering the hospital and then go to an exam room," he said. "In most every other hospital, you have to sit and wait to be seen. We saw 52,000 patients last year and expect to see 60,000 this year."
Mr. Margulis said the emergency room would use computerized radiography equipment that shows an X-ray on a screen instantly, avoiding the need to develop film. 
Stony Brook University Hospital held the ribbon-cutting last month for a new 30,000-square-foot ambulatory surgery center, but Mr. Rosett, its spokesman, said the best was yet to come: the hospital expects to break ground in coming weeks on a new heart center, the first phase of a $250 million project "to rebuild and reinvent the hospital."
The improvements are not coming because Long Island is some kind of hospital backwater. In May, Modern Maturity, the AARP magazine, called North Shore University Hospital the best in the country. St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn was ranked third.
Some argue that the consolidations of the 1990's paved the way for today's projects.
"The reorganization is still in its infancy," said Mr. Dahill of the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, "but many feel they have accomplished a great deal already in terms of cost reduction and improving medical care."
But Pearl Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Association, said she believed hospital consolidation on Long Island has been "too recent for us to come to any definitive conclusion concerning changes in patient outcome."
"I think we can conclude that the ability to buy in bulk and consolidate administrative functions will lead to economies of scale and cost reduction over the long run," she said, "but if you are talking of patient outcome, it takes several years and quite a bit of statistical data before you can conclude that patient care has improved, stayed the same or worsened."
Whether new buildings improve patient care is certainly subject to dispute. Pouring cold water on the new Sloan-Kettering clinic, Long Island hospital officials are quick to note that all surgical procedures requiring anesthesia must still be performed at Sloan-Kettering's main building in Manhattan.
Dr. Gabig of North Shore-L.I.J. contends that his institution does more than treat cancer after diagnosis. "Because we are a health care network comprised of 18 hospitals, we are in a position to emphasize research and the delivery of services for cancer prevention and early detection," he said. "One of the reasons why you would want to go to a hospital affiliated with the North Shore-L.I.J. system is because we provide a full continuum of care in the sense that we provide care that is local, in your neighborhood. And most importantly, we are there and available around the clock."
"If you go to Manhattan for surgery and Commack for chemotherapy or radiation therapy, what happens if complications occur in the middle of the night or on a holiday?" he added. "The Commack center says wait until the morning. But a local hospital provides care for complications. And our hospitals have access to your records and have better access to your physician or someone who is covering."
Dr. Harvey Finkelstein, an anesthesiologist and pain management specialist, said he believed Sloan-Kettering's Commack clinic would have little impact. "People will still go to their local oncologists, who provide a very high level of care," he said. "There is no impetus for them to go" to Sloan-Kettering.
Dr. Finkelstein said the true test would be whether Sloan-Kettering was able to recruit enough local doctors willing to send their patients to Sloan-Kettering for treatment.
"But what's the incentive for them to do that?" he said. "Many oncologists administer chemotherapy in their office."
Dr. Finkelstein said patients who may especially benefit from having Sloan-Kettering in Commack are those with rare cancers or those in advanced stages of the disease that require experimental treatments. And, he said, it would be a good place to go for a second opinion.
"The question is," Dr. Finkelstein added, "will they be able to steal patients who go there for a second opinion?"

HEADLINE: Business Is Better; the Bartender's Drinking 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Some New York bar and restaurant owners say they knew the economic climate was getting dire when their waiters, waitresses and bartenders vanished during their off hours. For a time after Sept. 11, tips fell so sharply that employees could not afford to spend their time on the drinking side of the bar, where half their drinks were often free. 
 Things are not yet so good, owners say, that employees are spending their off-hours at other bars, where they get no special consideration. But across Manhattan, bar and restaurant owners report more of their employees hanging out after work. 
 "They have more money to spend because tips are real good," said Kevin O'Lunney, the owner of Kevin St. James, a quirky Irish pub on Eighth Avenue at 47th Street. "I only worry about whether they will be at work on time the next day." 
It may be too early to tell whether restaurants, bars and other tourism-related businesses are in full recovery. But, according to employment figures, tourism is one of the few segments of the New York City job market that has shown growth since Sept. 11. And within that sector, bars and restaurants -- among the hardest-hit by the terrorist attack -- are the subsection hiring most quickly.
Restaurants in the city have experienced three back-to-back months of job growth from April to June, according to seasonally adjusted employment data analyzed by The New York Stat, a newsletter on the local economy. In total, the bar and restaurant industry lost about 11,900 of its 161,800 jobs after the attack and since bottoming out has brought back 5,500 workers, even though many of the jobs pay less. 
"No one thought tourism would be back this quickly," said Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist at The New York Stat, who says she believes that tourism is driving the restaurant and bar rebound.
That has been good news for people like Lorraine Dowd, who came to New York last August to live with her aunt in Maspeth, Queens, and quickly found a job as a waitress in a Midtown restaurant. 
Ms. Dowd, 22, was supposed to start on Sept. 12. Instead, she began working a week later. The job paid $40, plus tips, for an eight-hour shift. "It was really slow," she said recently. "There was barely anyone on the street. I liked to remind customers that we did not make a lot of money -- wink, wink; I hoped they would leave a good tip." 
After several months, Ms. Dowd, who grew up in County Kilkenny, Ireland, quit her job, in part because she was unhappy with the money, and considered leaving the country. But in April, she was able to find a job at Kevin St. James. "It was a miracle, but it worked out perfectly," she said.
The signs of improvements in the job market for waiters, waitresses, cooks and other bar and restaurant workers can be seen everywhere tourists roam, from B. B. King's club on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, to the Harp, a bar on 32nd Street and Seventh Avenue that attracts a mix of people coming out of Madison Square Garden and tourists leaving Macy's.
At some bars and restaurants, the rebound is being driven by a mix of tourists as well as New Yorkers and suburbanites who rediscovered Manhattan after Sept. 11. B. B. King's, a blues and jazz club, is one of those places. Employees there said they bonded when times got tough after the attacks, helping provide one another with everything from a place to live to extra cash when tips were bad. As business began improving, workers say, they started hanging out more at the bar.
"It's definitely gotten a lot better since 9/11," said Rachel Bialkowski, 27, an off-duty waitress at B. B. King's who was drinking Scotch at the bar. "We are getting out and spending more money because we can afford to."
At the Harp, sports fans and businesspeople at lunch are returning. The sour economy changed the way the Harp's employees spent their off hours. "We went out anyway," Karolyne Sweeney, a waitress, said of the weeks and months of bad tips at the beginning of the year, while drinking at another bar owned by her bosses. "Now, more money means more beer." 
Ms. Denham, the economist, said that April is a month in which bars and restaurants in New York traditionally begin gearing up for summer crowds. But Ms. Denham said that this year's increases in jobs were much higher than normal, driven in part by an attempt to compensate for deep staff cuts right after the attack.
Ms. Denham added, "The weak dollar has made coming here more attractive for a lot of visitors, and Middle America has picked up some of the slack where international tourists left off."
At Kevin St. James, shiny cutouts of shamrocks dangle from the ceiling, but this is not the average Irish bar. More Williamsburg, Brooklyn, than Old Country, the bar attracts a healthy number of tourists with its digital jukebox that spews a mix of 30,000 pop, rock, jazz and R & B songs, a menu that includes Mediterranean cuisine, and a staff that hails from places like India, Mexico, Ecuador and Bosnia (it did not hurt that the bar gained a bit of a global following through beer.com, which installed a live Webcam above the bar for a while).
Mr. O'Lunney, 26, who opened Kevin St. James three years ago, believes his bar has weathered the worst of this downturn.
"I like to say, 'My family has been serving Guinness for over 100 years,' " said Mr. O'Lunney, a fourth-generation bar owner who remembers serving his first drink at age 6 in a family bar in County Cavan, Ireland. "We have now seen and been through it all." 
The rebound has allowed Mr. O'Lunney to hire people like Ms. Dowd, a short woman with hair the color of obsidian, whose uniform includes sandals with two-inch heels. She arrived at about 9:30 one recent morning. By lunchtime, the bar and a couple of tables were packed with businesspeople and the ironworkers from a construction site nearby. By the late evening, the bar was packed with tourists and others.
Soon, Ms. Dowd was done with work and settling down with a few Heineken beers and a couple of friends, including a waitress from Brooklyn. As she relaxed, Ms. Dowd began pointing to the upsides and downsides of the job: the men who think they are Don Juan (bad); the friendships a bartender can develop with customers (good); and the tips (good right now, and now is what matters).
She considers herself fortunate to have a job. "It was an accident. I was lucky, but it's great craic," she said, using the Irish word for fun that is often reserved for having a good laugh at the most absurd of circumstances.
At 12:59 a.m., with the music blaring but the crowd dwindling, a waitress nearing the end of her shift put the check on the table. As if to make a point about the importance of tipping and their ability to leave a good one, Ms. Dowd and her co-workers at the table laid down $100 on a bill of $48.12.

Business is good, she says, which allows her to be a patron as well as an employee. (Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times); (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 3554 words

HEADLINE: The Rise of the Perma-Temp 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Berger; Leslie Berger wrote about student mental health for the Jan. 13 issue of Education Life.

 BODY:
In a beige classroom so spare that there isn't a poster or a bookcase to warm it, Elaine Bobrove passes out her last reading assignment of the semester -- Langston Hughes's "Theme for English B." It's a clear enough poem, about a black student trying to relate to his white instructor, a perfect assignment for a rainy spring day when Ms. Bobrove's Camden County College students are through with finals and ready to put her remedial reading course behind them.
The impatience for this last class to end is palpable, but the sanguine Ms. Bobrove forges ahead with one final discussion. 
 "So," she starts, "what did you learn from each other and what did you learn from me?" She is echoing the poem's penultimate sentence: "As I learn from you,/ I guess you learn from me -/ although you're older -- and white -/ and somewhat more free." 
 Spinning gold out of air has become instinctive for Ms. Bobrove, an adjunct professor who was paid $1,300 a course last academic year. She has no office (the windshield of her station wagon sports a sun reflector that reads "Adjunct Office") and receives no benefits, though she has taught at Camden County for 20 years. The room where she alternately coaxes and goads literary insights, a sagging ceiling tile its only remarkable feature, is an apt metaphor for a low-overhead, no-frills academic career.
The students shift in their chairs and stare out the windows toward the full parking lots and freshly mown
lawns of their campus in suburban Blackwood, N.J., about 15 miles from Philadelphia. This is one of New Jersey's biggest community colleges, where SAT's are not required, tuition costs $1,860 a year and, as Ms. Bobrove puts it, "We give people second chances." 
"What did you like best, of all the things we read here?" she presses. 
Finally, a young woman breaks the silence by singling out the essay "Arranging a Marriage in India," by the cultural anthropologist Serena Nanda. That fires up her classmate, John Hoffman, who straightens his slouch to defend a man's right to pick his own bride. "You spend your whole lifetime looking at women," he argues passionately. "I don't want to marry that chick. I want to marry this chick I met on the street!" 
"Did it make you think about different cultures?" Ms. Bobrove persists, once the laughter dies down.
"Yeah."
"Good. That's what reading's all about."
Community colleges have always made generous use of part-time teachers; at Camden County, they outnumber full-timers about 3 to 1. Their mission -- to make higher education more accessible -- depends on low tuition. Staffing fluctuates with enrollment. Community colleges are also big providers of vocational training, whose instructors are expected to bring real-life experience into the classroom.
But perma-temps like Ms. Bobrove are becoming more common, not only in cash-poor two-year colleges but also in well-endowed four-year institutions. Forty-three percent of the faculty members at all institutions are part time. Moreover, from 1993 to 1998, the last period for which the Department of Education has compiled data, 40 percent of all institutions took some action to reduce full-time faculty; of those, 22 percent replaced them with part-time instructors.
The cost-efficient, highly flexible system of perma-temps, used for years by community colleges, is serving as a template for the rest of academe, including some of the country's most prestigious universities. At New York University, where part-time teachers voted this summer to join a union, the number of adjuncts (2,700, not including summer instructors) nearly equals the number of full-timers (3,100).
There are several theories about the prevalence of contingent faculty, the most popular and cynical being money. 
"It's just a reality that part-time, adjunct faculty substantially reduce institutional payrolls," said Richard Chait, a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and an expert in how colleges and universities are managed. 
Though their increasing presence has prompted widespread concern -- among parents who want full professors for their tuition dollars and among parity-seeking part-timers who have initiated union drives across the country -- little research has been done on the effects of part-time teachers on education. In the classroom, experts say, the difference in teaching quality between tenured and contingent instructors seems to be indiscernible, especially among students who themselves are increasingly part time. Only a handful of very limited studies have been done on adjunct teaching, and they have found (in some cases, to the benefit of the institutions conducting the studies) that most students are only vaguely aware of their teachers' employment status. 
There are consequences, but they are subtle, experts say -- in the lack of adjuncts' participation in campus life, their absence as student advisers and curriculum planners and in the ultimate vulnerability of a faculty fractured into tiers of privilege, including many without the protection of tenure.
"It consolidates greater authority and power into the hands of the president and provosts, and makes for a more malleable academic labor market," said John Thelin, a historian of higher education who teaches at the University of Kentucky. "I feel that institutional control is more of an issue than money."
The idea of full-time career professors is actually relatively new in America. "Usually what you found from Colonial times until well into the 20th century was a strong reliance on lecturers, tutors, instructors -- a dozen different names -- and these would be a kind of floating pool of talent," Dr. Thelin said. "They were pretty expendable from year to year. It's really only with the exception of a very few institutions that you even find the term 'professor' being used very much until the late 19th century."
That's when the notion of tenure took hold. Intended to safeguard intellectual freedom, it was a direct response to efforts by wealthy industrialists who were underwriting elite universities to suppress their professors' populist ideas. Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, likes to cite the case of a Stanford University professor, a radical sociologist named Edward A. Ross, who called for railroad systems to be owned by governments instead of private interests. The trouble was, Leland Stanford's widow headed the university's trustees and Stanford himself, a former California governor, had amassed great wealth as a railroad builder. "The obvious remedy was to have Professor Ross fired," Dr. Levine said.
After similar arbitrary dismissals, American academe eventually adopted the German university model, with its research-oriented faculty of experts and the protection of lehrfreiheit, or freedom to teach, without political restraints. Today, Dr. Thelin said, the pendulum seems to be swinging back to the more fluid system -- partly because of cost, partly because of control and partly in response to changing attendance patterns, including the advent of online courses. 
"The new student is no longer 18 to 22 and full time, living on campus," Dr. Levine said. "That's only about 16 percent. The new majority is older, part-time working women who want to take an occasional course when they're free. The economy is changing, so people need more and more education, but they don't all need degrees. Universities are trying to adapt to a new era."
Tenure is unlikely to become extinct, he said. For one, competitive institutions will always offer such perks to top names in their field. But there is little doubt that tenure is more and more a luxury. Although 64 percent of the faculty members who retired from fall 1997 to fall 1998 had left tenured positions, only 45 percent of those who were hired were given immediate tenure or tenure-track jobs. 
"The full-time, tenured faculty member is about as representative of higher education today as Ozzie and Harriet are of American society," Dr. Chait of Harvard said.
Some experts suggest that, with the growing distinction between those who teach knowledge and those who create it, not all college instructors should strive for tenure, which is a system designed for scholars engaged in advanced research. A realignment of thinking may be in order.
"The tenure-track model alone is not meeting all the educational needs of a society in which a larger and larger percentage of the population is participating in higher education," said Roger G. Baldwin, a professor at Michigan State University and co-author of "Teaching Without Tenure: Policies and Practices for a New Era." "I'm not advocating the abolition of tenure," he added, "but I do believe there are other educational needs to be filled by other types of faculty."
A self-deprecating woman whose outlook is as practical as her short, silvery shag, Ms. Bobrove would be the first to acknowledge she is far from the cusp of intellectual innovation. She is the face of meat-and-potatoes academia, an unglamorous but essential part of postsecondary education. In many ways, Ms. Bobrove is a typical adjunct professor: she is dedicated but bristles at her perceived second-class status; she works in the humanities, relegated to teaching the basics; though she is completing her doctorate in education, at Widener University outside Philadelphia, she unabashedly prefers the classroom to the library. "I always wanted to work with students; I was less interested in research," she says. 
It is a brilliant, thoroughly unrepentant day in this bucolic part of New Jersey, with azaleas and dogwood blooming outside Victorian mansions. As Ms. Bobrove tools around in her Yankee-blue station wagon, its headrests covered in white doilies, she describes her work and how she came to it without regret.
She left an N.Y.U. doctorate program decades ago to raise a family. She has another life as an educational consultant in Haddonfield Township, where her clients range from children with learning problems to teenagers preparing for the SAT's. Her skill may be decoding literature rather than literary deconstruction, but in her view, teaching others to read well is every bit as important in a democracy as lehrfreiheit. 
"I once ran into a former student in a store who'd come out of the service barely able to read, barely decoding even," she recalls as she circles the campus and finally finds a parking space. "He was working as an accountant in New York City and getting his master's degree. Now, you tell me, in what other country could that happen, where you really can come and make something of your life?" 
Despite her status as a contingent faculty member, Ms. Bobrove is also a mainstay of her department. She typically teaches four courses a semester, for $10,400 a year. (A full-time instructor, for an entry-level salary of $38,000, plus benefits, would most likely teach five courses.) In fact, she helped train her supervisor, Elisabeth Bass. Adjuncts, Dr. Bass said, "are the front lines and are doing the majority of the teaching."
No one could prove it, but the consensus is that Ms. Bobrove's age (which she refuses to make public) and outspokenness, as well as diversity hiring efforts, worked against her when she came up for full-time appointments. With her bachelor's degree from Rochester University and a master's in education from Rutgers, she easily meets the qualifications to teach in a community college. Ms. Bobrove appears to be widely respected. This month, she won a $1,000 academic excellence award, one of three given each year to Camden County College adjuncts. There was a time when she wanted to be a full-fledged professor, Ms. Bobrove admits. But that's no longer the case. "I'm doing this because I truly enjoy the learning and knowing what's going on," she says. "I believe in lifelong learning and feel I'm an example of lifelong learning." 
Still, the inequities between her and her full-time colleagues clearly stick in her craw. Even though adjuncts at Camden have been unionized for several years, they think they are still being exploited. Ms. Bobrove is a co-president of Local 4965 for the American Federation of Teachers. This fall, with their contract expiring in December, she will help negotiate for higher wages, for the ability to buy into the state's health plan and for a seniority system to protect adjuncts from arbitrary replacement. 
Part of a work force in transition, adjuncts are a highly varied group whose plights depend on the glut of degrees and pay scales in their fields. Those in business, law, medicine or the sciences can be handsomely paid in return for their time, while those in the humanities are competing for fewer jobs to begin with and have fewer marketable skills. 
Mark Colby is a classic example of a so-called roads scholar, someone who teaches at more than one campus. It's not that he lacks the right academic degrees or did not study at prestigious institutions: Dr. Colby, 47, has four master's degrees and two doctorates in philosophy -- one from Columbia University and another from Oxford. Despite his blue-chip credentials, he has had to cobble together an academic career because full-time philosophy professors are in such low demand. One college told him it had received 800 applications for a single opening; he's had only about 10 job interviews in a decade. Last spring, he commuted twice a week by train from his home in Queens to his semester-long appointments in New Jersey. Between the nine undergraduate discussion sections he helped operate at Princeton and the two courses he led at Rutgers, he earned a respectable $28,000 for the five-month term. 
"I had expected more with my credentials, to be honest with you," he said. "My letters of recommendation are exemplary. There is nothing wrong with my dossier. But there are so many applicants chasing only so many full-time positions."
Roads scholars represent only a fifth of all adjuncts, according to David W. Leslie, a professor of education at the College of William and Mary and co-author of "The Invisible Faculty: Improving the Status of Part-Timers in Higher Education." Most part-time instructors, Dr. Leslie said, have other occupations and teach part time for pleasure, prestige, family-friendly schedules or extra income.
In a 1998 study for the Department of Education, nearly 60 percent of adjuncts surveyed said they were working part time because full-time jobs were unavailable, but nearly 75 percent also said they preferred a part-time position. Even among part-time humanities teachers at four-year institutions, those who preferred part-time jobs were virtually equal to those who said they were working part time because full-time jobs were unavailable. 
"The good news is that part-time faculty provide an extraordinarily rich source of expertise that institutions might not otherwise find," Dr. Leslie said. "The bad news is that in some fields, there is such an oversupply of qualified people that institutions may be tempted to exploit them. This is a problem mainly in the humanities and the arts. It doesn't seem to be a problem across the board."
Endowed by the lore of Greenwich Village, a renowned film school and celebrity alumni, N.Y.U. has a cachet that Camden County College simply cannot match. Yet the two institutions' adjuncts have similar complaints -- that they are part of a disproportionately large contingent labor pool without job security or comparable pay. With N.Y.U.'s undergraduate tuition at $26,646 a year (with an additional $10,430 for room and board), the expectation may be that the university is full of tenured professors. But its use of adjuncts is slightly higher than the national average.
Last month, N.Y.U. adjuncts decided in a runoff election to join the United Auto Workers. The U.A.W. and the American Federation of Teachers have been courting adjuncts nationwide as the disparities between full-time and part-time faculty have increased. 
Part-time faculties are already widely organized at state institutions. Trustees of the vast City University of New York, which has 7,250 part-time instructors and 5,640 full-timers, recently agreed to pay adjuncts for the extra time they spend working with students -- an unusual, although not unique, perk. The new contract also provides a paid semester off for research for full-time instructors without tenure and creates a new class of faculty member, distinguished lecturer, for artists or professionals who are not seeking tenure.
The successful union drive at N.Y.U. -- creating the largest adjuncts-only union and the first at a private university -- was also a milestone: it is expected to lead to more adjuncts' unions at other private institutions, including the Ivy League.
A spokesman for N.Y.U., John Beckman, said that only a small percentage of teaching was done by adjuncts within the arts and sciences. Most adjuncts -- about 1,900 -- are in specialized schools like the Tisch School of the Arts, the Steinhardt School of Education and the School of Continuing and Professional Studies.
Many programs benefit from working professionals, Mr. Beckman said. "Indeed," he continued, "our estimate is that some 80 percent of adjuncts have a full-time job, and they come to N.Y.U. to teach in their field of expertise and share their experience." 
"The unions," he said, "have sought to obscure the distinctions between, say, a tenured professor of biology, who is conducting research on cancer and teaching freshman biology in the College of Arts and Science, and a professional musician who, as an adjunct, comes to give music lessons at N.Y.U. in our Steinhardt School of Education."
Unions and adjuncts say that such an argument is beside the point, that contingent faculty members are often reappointed year after year, making them virtual staff members with lower pay and no job security and without a hand in curriculum planning. 
Gerald S. Pallor, a 54-year-old freelance television producer who has taught video technology at N.Y.U. for 12 years, said the last course he taught for the Tisch School was restructured in a way that made it confusing for his undergraduates. But he did not complain because he did not want to risk his reappointment. He was also thrown off by a schedule that interfered with the pacing of his courses for the School of Continuing and Professional Studies.
Mr. Pallor, who was dropped as a Tisch adjunct two years ago but continues to teach in the other program, says that after repeated semesters of work for his alma mater he feels entitled to a measure of job security. Administrators declined to comment on personnel matters, but Mr. Pallor said he was not reappointed just as he reached his 10th year and was eligible for a significant raise, from about $3,000 to $5,000 a course. He acknowledged garnering mediocre ratings from his students but said that was not unusual among the faculty. "At Tisch, my last semester was just awful because I didn't know what I was supposed to be teaching because the schedule was so confusing," Mr. Pallor said. "Undoubtedly, students suffer." 
In N.Y.U.'s German department, Michael Schultz described a tortuous caste system in which layers of instructors, all with different titles and pay levels, are increasingly resentful of one another and protective of their privileges. Although a full-time instructor with a fixed contract, Dr. Schultz says he identifies with adjuncts because he feels underpaid for doing work that his tenured colleagues shun. He was hired 10 years ago to coordinate and teach basic language instruction to undergraduates and supervise six to eight graduate students. With a title of senior language lecturer and a salary of $54,000 a year, Dr. Schultz said he felt he was viewed as a technician because he taught reading and writing instead of literary criticism. 
"I am acutely aware on a daily basis that the work I do is considered less valuable," Dr. Schultz said. "I'm bothered by the imbalance of lots of people doing huge amounts of work to educate the undergraduates with little voice and little pay."
On her last day of class, Ms. Bobrove draws hard upon her metacognitive skills to keep the discussion rolling. She turns to Jerry Bailey, a softspoken aspiring veterinarian who graduated from high school six years ago and has been working his way through Camden County College a course or two at a time. Mr. Bailey knows that Ms. Bobrove is part time, but he says he does not feel cheated, recalling that he was so discouraged at the beginning of the spring semester that he almost dropped out. Ms. Bobrove urged him to stay in school.
"Jerry, what did you like?" she asks. 
Mr. Bailey cites the searing essay "The Bill of Rights for Black Men: Walking While Black," which describes Bryonn Bain's unjust arrest in New York City while on break from Harvard Law School in 1999. 
"He thought he couldn't be victimized, and he had failed to recognize there's still prejudice in the world, and here he was a law student," Mr. Bailey says.
Then, in a moment so perfect it would seem scripted if not for Ms. Bobrove's unimpressed expression, Mr. Bailey suddenly thanks her for her dedication. He leaves the anger of Bryonn Bain and seamlessly circles back to Langston Hughes.
"By making me feel successful," he tells her, "it should make you feel successful as a teacher."

HEADLINE: The Baby Bias 

BYLINE:  By Hal Cohen; Hal Cohen is a freelance writer in madison, Wis., and a former contributing writer at Lingua Franca.

 BODY:
When Marcia Inhorn had her first child, she took a paid leave from the anthropology department at Emory University and, on return, took on extra classes to make up the teaching she had missed. But as her hours as a mom started to compete with her hours as a professor, her relations with the department soured. 
 "Some of the senior men saw my reproduction as interfering with my citizenship in the department," says Dr. Inhorn, who has since joined the University of Michigan. "They didn't let children impede at all on their total, engulfing commitment to their careers, and although I did everything I was asked to do quite well, I was giving to my family as well." 
 When she came up for tenure in 1997, there was no mistaking she was a rising star: she had published three books and numerous articles, won a major award and fulfilled her teaching and service requirements. "They couldn't deny me tenure," she says, "but it was written into my documentation, time and again, that I was a mom. That would never happen to a man." 
In a written review, the committee noted that her dedication had faltered -- "due perhaps to the fact that she has recently had her first child and has had to juggle teaching obligations with those of new motherhood." While she always does an excellent job, the committee added, "her own agendas and needs will at times win out over those of the department."
The department chairman at the time, Bradd Shore, wonders what the problem is. "If the expectations for her were somehow unreasonable because she was a mother," he says, "you would see that at the point where she was going to get tenure. The proof is in the pudding, and in the end she got promoted." The department also made "extraordinary allowances," he says, allowing her to take her children to work when necessary. "The university," he says, "does not make special provisions for working mothers by changing the standards for performance." 
Dr. Inhorn throws up her hands. "You simply can't give 100 percent to the academy when you have children," she says.
CREATING a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children," the recent study by the economist Sylvia Ann Hewlett, has rekindled a decades-old lament about the painful choices between childbearing and professional work. But perhaps nowhere has the debate been more heated than in the academy.
It would seem that a university -- with its ability to allow teachers to work from home, its paid sabbatical semester and its famously liberal thinking -- would be an ideal place to balance career and family. But by all accounts, the intense competition, the long hours and the unspoken expectations of the academy's traditionally male culture conspire to make it really, really hard to have a baby and be a professor.
Many women simply put off having children. But the juncture of the biological clock with the tenure clock -- the probationary period, typically seven years, during which an assistant professor must prove herself to her department before receiving a permanent appointment -- couldn't be more inopportune. The median age for receiving a Ph.D. is 34, so by the time a woman is up for tenure, she is 40 and confronting higher infertility rates.
"Creating a Life" caused a stir by reporting that only 67 percent of "high-achieving" women -- lawyers, doctors and executives -- have children by age 40. A forthcoming study by the University of California at Berkeley found that among tenured humanities and social science professors in their 40's, only 38 percent of the women have children, compared with 61 percent of men; in the sciences, it was 50 percent compared with 70 percent of the men. 
The statistics are no surprise to Martha West, a law professor at the University of California at Davis who works with the American Association of University Professors. "Parenting," she says, "is not a welcome event in the academy." 
To help ease women's Hobson's choice, the Association of University Professors approved a model policy last November drafted by Dr. West. In addition to calling for reductions or reorganizations of new-parent workloads, it recommends stopping the tenure clock for up to two years, whether or not a new parent takes a leave, to give new moms or dads more time to fulfill their tenure requirements. 
The tenure system presents parents with several layers of challenges. Three criteria are reasonably objective: scholarship (measured by number of publications) and teaching and service (measured in hours). Children can easily soak up enough time to put any of these in jeopardy. But tenure decisions also rely on a fourth criterion, collegiality -- "a concept that is, almost by design, impossible to define," says Pamela Haig, a researcher with the legal advocacy fund of the American Association of University Women. What with the secrecy of tenure committees, collegiality is sufficiently pliant as a pretext for tenure denial that in 1999 the Association of University Professors flatly recommended that it not be weighed in tenure decisions at all. 
In practice, collegiality means adhering to a mostly unspoken assortment of expected behaviors, and having babies is not on that list. 
Sharon Block, an assistant professor of history at the University of California at Irvine, remembers a comment made last fall by a senior faculty member in her department about what he called the two misfortunes that had caused her to take off much of the previous year: spine surgery and childbirth. "I think that demonstrates what babies are from the academic perspective," she says. "A pain."
In timing and effect on family life, the tenure-track system mirrors partner track at a law firm. But in academia, the personal stakes are higher: after six or more years of preparatory graduate work, tenure-track professors start in the relatively meager $40,000's. They will not earn much more without tenure. They work like dogs. They have virtually zero job mobility. And if rejected for tenure, they're basically fired. In short, dropping off the tenure track means life as a low-paid, low-prestige adjunct or instructor. The majority of these are women -- academia's mommy track. 
Of course, there are academics who are content to be child-free. The Harvard sociologist Barbara Reskin started teaching in the early 70's, when, she says, academic women almost invariably chose their careers over children. "The women who were successful in my field worked all the time -- evenings, weekends, Christmas," so Dr. Reskin opted against children. "It hasn't felt like such a sacrifice," she says, "because the only alternative was not being a sociologist.
THE week after delivering her first child, in 1990, Katherine Bowie went back to teaching anthropology at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. "I felt I had to be Superman," says Dr. Bowie, who was then a 40-year-old tenure-track striver in a very small club: junior faculty mothers. "I was hemorrhaging, as it turned out, but who could I talk to? There weren't any moms around to tell me I was bleeding too much."
The next term, Dr. Bowie took a leave and stopped the tenure clock, but during her absence the department decided not to renew her appointment. "You have to crank as much out as you can on the ten-
ure clock," she says, quoting conventional wisdom, "so you must be some kind of idiot if you decide to try and start a family. Anyone creating distractions for themselves must not be aiming for the top." 
Dr. Bowie appealed successfully -- the administration was pushing women's issues and immediately understood that the dismissal was based on maternity, according to Janet Hyde, the campus's newly appointed vice chancellor overseeing gender equity, who spoke on Dr. Bowie's behalf at the department's appeal proceedings. "I suggested some better ways to think about the issues," Dr. Hyde recalls. "They saw the light." 
Dr. Bowie was reinstated and eventually received tenure. "I worked my butt off researching and writing, to be sure that when I came up for tenure, I would be in unassailable shape," she says. 
Most of her female colleagues waited for tenure to start a family. But by then it was too late, and they were unable. "That's a heavy price," she says.
Dr. Bowie was a pioneer at Madison, which had adopted its tenure-clock policy just two years earlier. She testified before a state senate committee when a systemwide policy was adopted in 1994. "This wouldn't happen again in my department," she says. "People thought about things." 
With young professors increasingly having children, other selective research universities, including the University of California system, have responded with more family-friendly policies. Last year, the faculty union at the University of Massachusetts negotiated a package using elements of the model prepared by the American Association of University Professors. Basically, the more elite the institution, the greater the competition for faculty and the better the policies. 
But most campuses, private and public, make no allowances beyond what is guaranteed by the 1993 Family and Medical Leave Act: 12 weeks off, unpaid, with benefits.
The association's model policy was a flash point for the State University of New York's faculty union, which expects to bargain for a better family leave policy when contract negotiations are held in January. 
For a normal birth, SUNY professors get only the 12 unpaid weeks mandated by law, though any banked sick days can be used to draw salary for half that time; an additional four-month leave can be taken but without pay or benefits. 
In academia, the 12-week leave is awkward, as it usually requires canceling classes for the entire semester, saddling a professor with as much as half a year away from work, unpaid.
"Which is fine if you have a lot of money," says William Scheuerman, the union president. "But most state workers don't." There's always that paid sabbatical semester, but scholars are loath to use it for maternity because they would fall behind nonparents on their research. 
Administrators have concerns about longer family leaves. A professor on leave "requires the chair to assess: do we cancel the classes? Do we go out and hire an adjunct, or do I have someone here who can teach this?" says Stephen Beditz, assistant vice president for human resources management at SUNY at Albany. Relying on colleagues to pick up the load would be unfair, Mr. Beditz adds, but if the department has to hire outside help "then you're looking at some serious resource issues -- there's not a whole lot of slack resources for that kind of thing." 
Mr. Beditz says he worries that formalizing clock stoppage and other accommodations -- currently an individual arrangement between department head and employee -- "would take the prerogative away from the departmental chair, and that would have a deleterious and limiting effect on faculty governance."
The idea of giving new parents more time to fulfill tenure requirements has proved controversial among the rank and file, too. Last winter, when The Chronicle of Higher Education held an online discussion about the new model policy, many respondents were ferociously against special rights for moms (one labeled them prima donnas). And some of these respondents were women. One professor who teaches philosophy at Rice University declared herself "tired of children and breeders getting all the consideration all the time." An assistant dean at Ferris State University in Big Rapids, Mich., complained of "maternity leaves, restricted scheduling and all sorts of 'emergencies"' that put childless people "in a position of assuming tasks from those who do have children." Realize, she wrote, that with childbearing "comes sacrifice and additional responsibilities." 
Whatever a policy allows, the high-pressure culture of tenure-track life often discourages professors from taking advantage of it. For instance, at the University of Michigan, considered a model for family-friendly campuses (M.I.T. has copied its policy), only 14 percent of assistant professors take modified duties and 12 percent stop their tenure clock.
Dr. Block at Irvine, for one, says she dares not extend her tenure clock, a decision that is made at the end of the probationary period in the University of California system. "Everyone said it's career suicide -- senior faculty, chairs, administrators," says Dr. Block, who is entering the fourth year of her tenure clock and is expecting her second child. "From what I've seen, everyone who's taken it is expected to do more." After giving birth the first time, Dr. Block took paid parental leave and medical leave, missing two quarters and then "working ridiculously hard," she says. "I felt I had to prove that having a child didn't negatively impact on my academic work."
Belinda Davis, a history professor at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., extended her tenure clock by a year to get her monograph on World War I Berlin into proofs in time for her 1999 tenure review. But according to two professors on her tenure committee, a senior colleague wondered aloud why she had produced only a single book and a handful of articles -- what would have been expected of an assistant professor on a normal tenure clock -- when she had had an additional year to do more because of her maternity. The committee recommended against tenure. 
While the confidentiality of the proceedings and the murky dynamics of personnel decisions preclude knowing exactly why someone is denied tenure, Dr. Davis is convinced it was the lengthened clock.
"There seems to have been an assumption," she says, "that because I had this so-called extra time I was supposed to have produced more research than what was expected for a normal tenure case." 
Even when denied tenure, making a case for discrimination is difficult. And though amendments to the Civil Rights Act preclude discrimination based on pregnancy, a 1995 ruling established a precedent for considering absence in the tenure decision. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, covering New York, Connecticut and Vermont, ruled against a biology professor who had been denied tenure because, she contended, she had put her academic career on hold to raise a family. Although the case turned on a technical question, the court also commented on family leave. "A policy may discriminate," the decision reads, "between those employees who take off long periods of time in order to raise children and those who either do not have children or are able to raise them without an appreciable career interruption. That is not inherently sex specific." 
Like Dr. Bowie, Dr. Davis appealed on procedural grounds. The department reviewed her case, including the consideration of her extra year. Dr. Davis was awarded tenure the following year. 
The flexibility of the academic schedule can itself be a double bind for new parents. The hours may be flexible, but there are only 24 of them in a day, and the work has no limits for someone trying to earn tenure. A 1999 faculty survey at the University of Michigan found that the average academic worked more than 57 hours a week, tenure-track professors work longer and women work even more hours, devoting additional time to committees and meeting with students. 
"To get half as far, a woman will work twice as long," says Joan Williams, a legal scholar at American University. Which is fine as long as a woman's time is unconstrained, she says, but throw a baby into the mix "and that strategy stops working." Ms. Williams waited until she was assured tenure to start a family. She spent most of two years trying to get pregnant, including a course of fertility treatments, before resigning herself to the lengthening odds and placing her name on adoption lists. Finally, she conceived.
"It's set up as a zero-sum game," she says. "Some women get to have children, but they pay the price of career marginalization, others get to have a career, but they sacrifice motherhood. Men don't pay either price." 
Rather than thinking in terms of choices, Ms. Williams suggests that universities ask themselves, "How might we set up an academic workplace around the heroic assumption that the worker will have kids and raise them, and not farm out the care to someone else?" 
"Young women feel entitled to be here," she says. "They look at what's going on and say, 'This is outrageous."' Until parenting becomes part of work culture, she says, "women are not going to achieve anything approaching equality."

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about the difficulty of seeking tenure while rearing children misspelled the surname of a researcher with the American Association of University Women who cited the notion of collegiality as a criterion for tenure decisions. She is Pamela Haag, not Haig.
