HEADLINE: Tests Are Not Just for Kids 

BYLINE:  By Kate Zernike; Kate Zernike is a reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
One side delivers its demands like a ruler rapping the knuckles: Standards! Accountability! Results! The other fears teaching to the test. Students are not widgets, the argument goes; the artistry of teaching cannot be summed up by a score. States mandate, teachers revolt. Eager competitors stand ready to prove they can do things better.
 Sound familiar? To a nation torn by debates about testing, it might. This time, however, the battleground is not elementary and secondary schools but colleges and universities. 
 For years, higher education was considered immune from the problems plaguing the lower levels of American education. It was a given good, worth every tax dollar, student loan and second mortgage it took to pay for it. Yet with the federal government now mandating a ladder of tests from elementary through high school, the question in K-12 is no longer whether to test but how to test. The shift in that debate has produced a new question: why not higher education, too? 
The nation's colleges and universities, beset by concerns about inflating costs and inflating grades, find themselves hard pressed to resist.
Democratic legislators and the Bush administration alike have publicly proposed that next year's reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, which governs how colleges and universities get federal money, be modeled on the recent legislation requiring elementary and secondary schools to test students and prove their progress. 
Some public universities, including those in Virginia and Utah, are starting to phase in assessments required by the state; this fall, the State University of New York is beginning a major initiative at each of its 64 campuses. States like Missouri and Tennessee dangle financial incentives at campuses where students score well. And some states have added teeth: in South Dakota, for example, students must pass exams to progress to junior year.
Proponents of the liberal arts -- its popularity waning, its English and semiotics majors the butt of light-bulb jokes -- want to prove that their brand of education produces students with marketable skills, too. This coming academic year, 40 to 50 colleges and universities will participate in a study to evaluate their liberal arts instruction, testing students over time to see how well they learn to write and think and analyze. 
Whether pushed by educators or legislators, the efforts are motivated by a sense that higher education has been gliding too much on reputation. Higher education now speaks of its own achievement gap -- not, as in lower education, a gap between scores of black and white children but between what colleges say students are learning and what they actually are. It is no longer enough for a university to say that it accepts only students with high SAT scores; those scores say nothing about what students learn once they're in.
"The real reason we don't test is, we would rather not know," said Frank Newman, a former president of the Education Commission of the States who, as head of the Futures Project at Brown University, promotes accountability in higher education.
"We have a rhetoric about what we do," he said. "That rhetoric is: when you come to our institution you get a great liberal education, you're going to learn to think, you're going to learn about the life of the mind, you're going to learn the great traditions of Western thought. If we start measuring, we will start finding out that you didn't learn how to think, you didn't learn about the great traditions of Western thought. Then we have a nasty little problem on our hands. If we find out that those students can't write well, who do we turn to?"
The focus on accountability reflects the many new demands on higher education -- from students, from legislators, from an increasingly competitive education market. But even more, it reflects a fundamental shift in answering the simple question: what is college for?
Traditionally, college was seen as an experience as much as anything, a chance for self-discovery, broadening the mind, socialization -- at best, an encounter with different kinds of people and ideas, at worst a kind of day care for big kids. But as the college population has shifted -- 18- to 24-year-olds now make up only a quarter of all degree-seeking undergraduates -- the typical college student is focused more on learning practical skills. With these students shaping the market, educators increasingly talk about college as a product -- like pimple cream or fertilizer, something to be judged effective or not.
Not everyone, of course, thinks this is a good thing. But having watched the debate over testing in elementary and secondary education, even critics agree that some form of assessment is on campus to stay. The trick, by all accounts, is to take what K-12 has done and improve on it.
As it was in lower education, the push is coming in part from business leaders, who have grown louder in their worries about how well college graduates are prepared for the world of work.
In 1999, a report by the Business-Higher Education Forum condemned graduates for lack of skills in problem solving, time management, analytical thinking and basic writing and speaking, calling for restructuring curriculum and teaching. The problems might not be as dire as those in lower education, but still, students were not prepared for the jobs employers needed to fill. Johnny could read, but analyze an annual report or write one? Like, no way. More and more companies are deciding that if they want skilled workers, they will have to train them themselves; the Department of Labor estimates that so-called corporate universities will outnumber traditional ones by 2010. 
Interest in assessing college performance actually began in the 1980's, around the time politicians and a raft of reports, including the damning "A Nation at Risk," were calling for more accountability in elementary and secondary schools. In 1990, when the National Educational Goals Panel set its agenda for the nation's students, it included objectives for higher education. The Department of Education began planning a college version of the National Assessment of Educational Progress, which tests a sampling of elementary and secondary school students across the country. It also called for state review boards to assess student progress at all colleges and universities, public and private, that received federal funds.
But higher education lobbying groups revolted, arguing that the federal intrusion was a violation of academic freedom, and both efforts faltered. New Jersey went so far as to get the faculty at its public colleges and universities to adopt a set of common standards and tests to measure them -- only to abandon the effort for lack of money and political will. A decade later, however, lower education is providing a powerful example, making it harder to object this time around.
"The same legislators who say, 'We fixed K-12 this way,' say, 'We can fix higher ed this way,"' said Peter Ewell, who has done perhaps the most extensive study of assessment efforts as a researcher at the National Center for Higher Education Management Systems. 
"Even the champions of higher education in the legislatures are very much in favor of some kind of testing," Mr. Ewell said. "They need some ammunition, because everybody else who wants money is coming in with data -- on roads, on hospitals, on criminal justice. It's in the air in a way that can't be ducked."
Since higher education is not a state requirement like elementary and secondary school, it's hard to make the case for a state obligation to "leave no child behind." But a college education is increasingly seen as an essential credential for the workplace. And since 80 percent of the nation's undergraduates now attend public institutions, it is easier for legislators to argue that higher education is in the public good, and therefore something to be regulated.
Changing demographics, too, have increased pressure for accountability. Older students tend to be more discriminating customers and to want courses tailored to their field. "When I was 18 years old and going to college, I was concerned about where the next beer party was, not what I was learning," said Laura Palmer Noone, president of the University of Phoenix, which accepts students only 23 years old and up. "I would not have called the dean and complained if a faculty member let me out of class early. Our students are doing that. They view this as their time, their money, their experience."
Phoenix, which has taken advantage of the aging college population to become the nation's largest private university, with 125,000 students at locations across the country, spells out a set of "core competencies" for students in each major. At the end of the program, they are given standardized tests to evaluate whether they learned what was advertised. The university compares its results to nationally normed tests -- for example, the Graduate Management Admission Test -- and asks students at other universities to take both sets of tests to judge their reliability. "Obviously, we want to make sure we are teaching students and that they're learning the right things," Ms. Noone said. But the tests also quiet the doubters who say that Phoenix, a profit-making institution, is simply looking to make a buck. "If we can demonstrate that students are learning the equivalent, or in most cases, more than students at other institutions, that answers our critics."
Liberal arts colleges, meanwhile, are competing for the shrinking pool of traditional college students that has been their primary market. With higher education seen more as a job credential, pure liberal arts has become something of a dying breed: only about 3 percent of all undergraduates are enrolled in liberal arts colleges. Testing offers a new way to compete.
"We talk about the virtues and values of a higher education, but we don't have much data to show for it," said Richard H. Hersh, president of Trinity College in Hartford. "We're not going to change perceptions by more rhetoric." Dr. Hersh, a former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, has been one of the country's biggest champions of liberal arts and is now one of its biggest champions of assessment. He is a chief proponent of the Value Added Assessment Initiative, a project that aims to evaluate how much students learn in the liberal arts over the course of their college education.
A value-added test looks at the difference between what students know when they arrive and what they know when they leave, providing a measure of what the school did or did not teach. 
As part of the initiative, 15 colleges and universities across the country participated in a trial round of tests this spring. A four-year study will begin this coming school year at more than 40 institutions, testing students freshman through senior year. The tests are the same across the campuses, making them technically standardized, but they are not multiple choice. Rather, students are presented with a package of information -- data tables, newspaper articles, reports -- on different subjects and asked to write essays, answer questions and plot information on graphs. The goal is to evaluate the kinds of analytical skills that liberal arts programs claim to teach and that employers say they are seeking. 
"If you put tests in play, then people are going to teach to the test," said Roger Benjamin, who developed the project with Dr. Hersh as head of the RAND Corporation's Council for Aid to Education. "But if you have the appropriate kind of tests, we think that's not a problem."
Dr. Hersh points out that outsiders already try to quantify the quality of a college education -- in particular, the U.S. News & World Report's "Best Colleges" rankings. But the magazine looks at factors like how much money the schools spend per student and what percentage is accepted -- factors that are easy to manipulate in the hopes of getting a better score. Though intended to help improve instruction, Dr. Hersh said, value-added results could also be used to create a new set of rankings based on teaching and learning. "Better that we do it, instead of some silly magazine," he said.
Assessment in higher education is still a developing concept, and the word means different things to different people, which makes it hard to compare results. Nowhere is this more evident than in the range of policies from state to state. 
According to "Measuring Up 2000," a survey by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, eight public university systems are in the process of developing some kind of assessment. Most leave it to each campus to choose its own assessment tool. Some use student surveys, some count the number of books in the library and some give tests. This summer, proposals are being approved from each SUNY campus on how it will evaluate learning in 10 subjects -- from a standardized math test at the Oswego campus to a special essay question on the final exam in western civilization, at Geneseo. 
Only six states -- Arkansas, Florida, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas and Georgia -- have the kinds of tests that allow cross-campus comparisons. But even then variations prevent a national perspective: Texas and Florida test basic skills, the kind most people would expect of high school graduates. South Dakota, on the other hand, measures freshmen, sophomores and seniors to evaluate what they learn over time.
The variations reflect the immense variety in the institutions involved. It is easier to settle on one test for all elementary and secondary schools, because they generally share a uniform mission and serve a uniform population. But there are different expectations for a community college than for the state's flagship university.
"Each of our institutions serves different missions, and naturally different levels of students," said Phyllis Palmiero, executive director of the State Council of Higher Education for Virginia, which is phasing in a requirement that all public institutions assess students in six competencies, beginning this past academic year with technological literacy and writing. "What is competent is defined by each institution, so that now you have publicly articulated what it means to be a graduate of this institution," Ms. Palmiero said. "Then each institution devises a way to assess those competencies."
George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., used a standardized commercial exam to measure technological proficiency while the University of Virginia devised its own test on skills like Internet research and Palm Pilot use. "This test represents what a computer-literate person who is a college graduate ought to know to be able to function in today's society," said W. Edmund Moomaw, executive director of institutional assessment at the University of Virginia. "It's important for universities today to be more clear about what they want their students to be able to do. 
"At U.V.A.," he added, "they're smart when they enter and smart when they graduate. But there was anecdotal evidence that some graduates at some universities were not as competent as they should be. Also, education is No. 1 in most state budgets in expenditure, so the government wants to know what's happening with the money as we spend more and more of it."
The state council has posted results on its Web site in the kind of report card that K-12 schools use. "Yes, a degree is a statement of achievement, but what does it really stand for?" said G. Paul Nardo, a council spokesman. "We're trying to give meaning to that degree. We're hoping that by defining it, it will get better."
Whatever the approach, a consensus exists on one point: assessment in higher education will never look the way it does in K-12, with its emphasis on high-stakes tests required for graduation or grade promotion. Value-added tests, for one, are intended to judge how well the colleges are teaching, not to pass or fail students.
In lower education, assessment starts by establishing standards for what students must know to graduate -- literary works or terms, historical events, basic math, grammar and composition -- and then tests to see whether they have learned them. Colleges are much more diverse and more specialized, so it is far more difficult to agree on what the standards should be.
"There is no department of critical thinking," said Mr. Ewell of the National Center for Higher Education Management Systems. "Getting a social scientist and a historian and a physicist to agree on what critical thinking means for a sophomore is tougher than it looks. It's much tougher than getting a bunch of high school English teachers to say what good writing should look like."
There are other hurdles. Proponents fear that because value-added tests don't produce individual grades, students will not take them seriously, making the results invalid or even useless. 
Others worry about the misuse of tests. "Accountability is usually a code word for blame," said Jane V. Wellman, senior associate at the Institute for Higher Education Policy in Washington. "These tests can be pretty blunt instruments." It is too tempting, she said, for states that want to link results to state money to use test results as the only measure of quality, ignoring the complexities of the different institutions. That could punish community colleges, which generally accept any student who applies, and reward big research institutions, whose students arrive at a higher level. "The poorly financed public institution may be doing a better job than Harvard," Ms. Wellman said. 
Michael S. McPherson, president of Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., fears that the tests promise too much. They might offer some hint as to which professor or school does better, but it is hard to say why, and the danger is in grasping at easy answers. "If the measures become important guides, they will lead schools to overemphasize the measured at the expense of the immeasurable," he wrote in a special issue of Peer Review, the journal of the Association of American Colleges and Universities, devoted to the debate over value-added testing. "If it turns out that improvement in the speed with which one can assemble a Lego robot is a reliable indicator of value added, and if that measure becomes a significant factor in college choice, you can expect the sales of Lego kits to universities to skyrocket." Still, Dr. McPherson supports the idea of measuring the quality of learning. And most everyone points out that the arguments against assessment in higher education are the same arguments that were initially made against assessment in lower education -- and that now schools test students in almost every grade above the third. 
"If higher education doesn't do this itself, someone from the outside will," Dr. Hersh said. "I'm not saying we can measure everything we'd like to. I'm not sure everything worth teaching is measurable. But if we're going to take seriously the language in our catalogs about higher learning, why don't we at least try to see if that's what we're doing?"

What Should You Get Out of College?

Interviews by Julie Flaherty

Richard C. Levin
President, Yale University
"We hope our students emerge with, obviously, the capacity to read and think about the world, to do that with clarity, to express themselves with clarity. But most of all to have acute critical intelligence, to be able to think critically about issues, to analyze them, to come up with their own conclusions under any circumstances."

Nancy Cantor
Chancellor, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
"For students to be leaders in this complex world they need to be able to work with a diverse group of people. They have to be able to handle challenges and novelties that come up. They need to understand the context in which they live and the differences around the world. There isn't a pat answer anymore to this world, so the best we can do for students is have them ask the right questions."

Lee C. Bollinger
President, Columbia University
"An undergraduate education is a time to explore the great thinking that has occurred over time about subjects that endure. The university is about being able to move intellectually within a whole array of views. It is enormously
difficult and requires moving outside your own little way of seeing the world. It's actually a quite frightening experience. The world will always be for you a more difficult and complicated place than perhaps you would like it to be." 

Leon Botstein
President, Bard College
"The primary skills should be analytical skills of interpretation and inquiry. In other words, know how to frame a question. How do you evaluate the safety record of an airline? How do you evaluate the risk when you smoke? The ability to understand the debate about economics, about Social Security or prescription drugs -- any issues you like. How does one distinguish truth from fiction, demagoguery from serious argument? In this is also the capacity for intelligent empathy, the ability to understand the other side even when you may not share it. You should not be dependent on the sources of information, either provided by the government or by the media, but have an independent capacity to ask questions and evaluate answers.
"A college education has to engender a lifelong habit of curiosity, as opposed to becoming more convinced that you are an authority. It has to provide the capacity to take deep enjoyment in aspects of human expression that are not commercial -- literature that is not blockbuster, theater that is not moneymaking. 
"Finally, and terribly important, is that students develop a sense of value that is beyond material gain, beyond wealth and fame and power. It is about the way you conduct your life both as a private individual and as a citizen."

What Do Employers Want?

Mimi Collins
Spokeswoman, National Association of Colleges and Employers
"Employers very consistently cite good communication skills as important, both verbal and written. Honesty and integrity are second, teamwork skills are third, interpersonal skills fourth and strong work ethic fifth. Employers are looking for people who can work together, which is one reason communication is the top skill, year in and year out. They look for all the getting-along skills.
"One of the things that colleges do emphasize is helping students get internships where they can get some going-to-work skills, and that plays into what employers value."

Thomas M. Thivierge
Director of talent acquisition, General Motors
"We do look for ability to learn, because most students don't leave college with the ability to do the jobs initially. They need to show initiative, decision making, even though they may have not made a lot of decisions in their lives. Then we try to measure their results orientation. We want to get a sense of, if given a project, how do you get it done. Teamwork is very influential. This one is really abstract: we call it motivational fit. Are you tenacious? Can you overcome barriers? In large companies, that's important. Diversity comes into that: are you able to work in a diverse environment?
There are some hard skills we look for, too. We're making CAD/CAM donations at the universities to make sure students use that technology. We found that students weren't using it enough. 
"A lot of students go to college and don't know what they want to be when they grow up. What we're asking is for them to make a choice. Do I want to build products? Do I want to be in information technology? If you want to work in finance, you better be getting a degree in accounting. We don't hire generalists right at the start. Once you've developed that core functional expertise, we'll pay for you to get broadening education. But at first you've got to know what your focus area is."

Sharman Mailloux Sosa
Senior technical recruiter, Microsoft
"We look for students who are strategic thinkers, who can think about the bigger picture, think about long-term challenges. We want people who can jump into ambiguous problem spaces and still be very successful, who don't necessarily need to have a manual to assess a situation, people who can address a problem even when there is not a lot of clarity in it."

Phyllis PalMiero
Executive director, State Council of Higher Education for Virginia
"You have to be pretty portable now. The interest has been basic skills. Every graduate should have these basic competencies: be able to write well, have some level of technologic literacy, have the ability to perform qualitative analysis, be scientifically literate, have strong oral communication, as well as strong critical thinking skills."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Is the Chief Ready For His Close-Up?

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
THE television cameras had barely started rolling when Sally Lee got that sinking feeling -- literally.
 Ms. Lee, the editor in chief of Parents magazine, was standing atop a sand dune that had been trucked in to the outdoor lot of NBC's "Today" program in May for a live interview about children's swimsuits. But as Katie Couric pelted her with questions, Ms. Lee felt her feet sinking. First, her heels disappeared as she smiled weakly at Ms. Couric, who stood next to her on solid ground. Then her ankles were gone. Finally, she said, "I was up to my knees and still trying gamely to continue the conversation." 
 Fortunately, the five-minute segment ended before the dune could swallow her, but Ms. Lee vowed to be better prepared for future television interviews, right down to planning what shoes to wear.
Hers was a minor embarrassment compared with the bloopers involving some executives as television appearances become a bigger part of their job descriptions.
"Blame it on the 24/7 news environment," said Lee Duffey, president of Duffey Communications, a public relations firm in Atlanta that provides media training to executives. "Technology has made around-the-clock news a reality, and most executives, especially C.E.O.'s, can't escape the spotlight."
Nor should they want to. In the post-Enron world, public relations experts say, TV appearances are crucial for bolstering consumer and shareholder confidence. "Corporate stakeholders need to be reassured, and television can deliver mass exposure," said Sheri Baer, the broadcast director at the Hoffman Agency in San Jose, Calif., which provides media training to top executives.
But television can be a scary prospect -- terrifying, even -- for some executives, who fear that they will look ridiculous or, worse, say something that could get their companies in trouble. As a result, some go to great lengths to prepare, sometimes by taking public speaking courses or hiring media trainers.
At Mr. Duffey's firm, requests for such coaching have increased sharply. "Media training used to be a specialty service that only a few of our really high-level C.E.O. clients were interested in," he said. "But in the past year or so, every single one of our clients has asked for it."
Janette Mandell, a group manager for Greenough Communications, a public relations agency in Boston that represents technology clients, estimated that 40 percent of its new business in the last year had come from business leaders seeking media coaching. Many have made mistakes in front of the camera, she says, and want to avoid repeating them.
Consider Neal Creighton, the chief executive of GeoTrust, an information security company in Wellesley Hills, Mass., that has been bombarded with calls from journalists since Sept. 11. In late September, he was interviewed for an ABC news program and, wanting to appear solemn, refrained from smiling or gesturing. Alas, he lamented, "I looked like a corpse; I was Dead Man Talking."
Mr. Creighton signed up for a media training course with a firm that put him through a battery of mock interviews. His coach helped him become more animated by instructing him to nod his head and make eye contact with viewers. As a result, he said, he looked much more lively on a spot shown recently on a Delta Air Lines in-flight program.
Michael Linton, the former chief executive of the American operations of Adecco of Switzerland, a temporary staffing agency, needed guidance when CNBC asked him to appear on a program last month to talk about unemployment. Mr. Linton doesn't own a television set and knew about CNBC only vaguely. As panic set in, he hired media coaches to pose likely questions.
"The coaches actually asked harder questions than the real interviewer did," Mr. Linton said. He learned not to agree with everything the interviewers said. "When I'm under pressure, my tendency is to just smile and go along with the party line," he said. But his coaches made him stop and think about the questions first. In the CNBC interview, he said, he was able to question some of the reporter's assumptions about unemployment statistics.
Such practice sessions can also keep executives from putting their feet in their mouths. Ms. Mandell recalls a mock session in which a software chief executive lost control after she said her "sources" had told her he was planning to sell the company. "His eyes grew wide and he leapt out of his seat and barked, 'Who told you that!' " she said. "When the whole room erupted in laughter, he knew he'd made a big mistake." The lesson, of course, is to keep calm.
She advises clients to develop 30-second sound bites detailing the information they want to get across, to help them refrain from babbling or divulging information they shouldn't.
Sometimes, trainers tag along on real interviews to make sure that nothing goes wrong. Mr. Duffey recalls one occasion when the chief of a health care company began sweating profusely under the lights.
"The interviewer was with a news magazine," Mr. Duffey said, "and his favorite tactic was to wait until his subject got really sweaty and then move in with a really tough question, so that the subject would look really panicked." But Mr. Duffey saved the day by interrupting the interview to request a break for his client to change into a fresh shirt.
NOT everyone is a fan of executive coaches. "Media coaches teach you to watch every word you say," said Vivek Wadhwa, chief of Relativity Technologies, a software company in Cary, N.C., who previously took a small army of public relations consultants on TV interviews. No more. "Everything I said was scripted and few people ended up quoting me," he recalled.
Now, Mr. Wadhwa says, he blurts out the first thing that comes into his mind -- a risky strategy, perhaps, but one that he says has paid off with positive coverage. Although he has occasionally angered viewers, he says he doesn't care. "I'm more interested in being myself and communicating a message about my company," he said. "If I tick off some people along the way, so be it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Neal Creighton, chief of GeoTrust, took a media training course after a television appearance that he characterized as "Dead Man Talking." (Michael Dwyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
The Fed'sEvolving Comfort Zone

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
DURING the last two decades, the Federal Reserve often seemed to adopt a policy known as "opportunistic disinflation," a fancy way of saying the central bank should not necessarily attack inflation during periods of economic expansion.
 Instead, the Fed would permit the inflation rate to remain more or less steady while the economy was growing briskly, and wait for a recession or slowdown to bring inflation down. Then, when the economy started to recover, the Fed would raise interest rates to cap inflation at a lower level than in the previous business cycle, thereby ratcheting down inflation step by step, as the economy went through its inevitable ups and downs. 
 The approach was not always followed, and under Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman since 1987, the central bank has looked with disdain on rules and academic theories and favored pragmatic, even seat-of-the-pants policy making. 
Still, opportunistic disinflation was seen by some Fed economists and many outside analysts as the best way to describe the central bank's basic operating philosophy in an era when achieving price stability was a primary goal in monetary policy.
But the Fed has pretty much achieved price stability. And in this time of post-bubble jitters, excess capacity and falling asset prices, inflation suddenly seems less of a threat, or at least a more easily managed one, than deflation.
"It's the end of an era," said Jim Glassman, an economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "The long-run goal is no longer to push inflation lower."
As a result, opportunistic disinflation has become outmoded, if not irrelevant. So economists inside and outside the Fed are trying to develop new policy models that would help guide the central bank as it confronts a faltering recovery, little upward pressure on prices and concern about the kind of deflationary spiral that has afflicted Japan.
"We've never had to worry about this before," said Laurence H. Meyer, a former Fed governor. "But now that we're at price stability, we're going to face it routinely. We're going to have to decide whether or not to behave in some especially vigorous way to insure against deflation."
The broad outlines of the Fed's evolving new approach are already emerging. For one thing, Mr. Greenspan appears willing to be extraordinarily patient about raising official interest rates from their current, extremely low levels. The Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks stands at 1.75 percent, where it has been since December.
Economists do not expect the Fed to raise rates before year-end; if the stock market continues to tumble, the Fed's next move may even be to cut rates.
If inflation begins to show signs of revival, Mr. Greenspan knows from long experience that he can act quickly to snuff it out by raising rates. But because there are virtually no signs of inflation, he has signaled that he will not raise rates simply because they are low, but will wait for evidence that the economy has recovered fully from the recession last year.
Another characteristic of the post-inflation Fed is likely to be a willingness to act decisively to head off deflation.
The Fed has made extensive studies of Japan's mistakes in getting into its recessionary, deflationary swamp and has drawn one major conclusion: that it is best to cut interest rates quickly and aggressively if deflation looms, even if rates are already at very low levels, as they are now. 
OBVIOUSLY, it would be best if the Fed could avoid any situation in which it must shoot its remaining monetary ammunition to avert a crisis. On that score, there is a school of thought that the Fed needs to try to hold inflation at a level above what it might otherwise consider price stability, which in recent years has been around 2 percent, as measured by the Consumer Price Index.
Mr. Meyer said the Fed is on a "maintenance diet," trying to stay in a comfort zone between inflation and deflation. But, he said, it will be all but impossible to stay in that zone all the time, at least as it is currently defined, given the economy's vicissitudes.
The solution, Mr. Meyer said, is to set an inflation target that is high enough to build in a buffer, so that if the economy is suddenly hit by deflationary forces it will not sink into deflation. Better that, he said, than temporarily pushing inflation above a target that is set too low when a deflation threat comes along and then reining it back in again when the threat has passed.
"That would put you through a roller coaster," he said. "You want to save pre-emptive action for a truly compelling situation."

HEADLINE: A Tortoise, Many Hares And a Web of Convergence 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
MEL KARMAZIN says Thomas Middelhoff is an extraordinarily talented chief executive, as talented as any in the United States.
 But Mr. Karmazin, the no-frills New Yorker who is president of the media conglomerate Viacom, cultivates a very different style from Mr. Middelhoff, the big-thinking German who until last week ran the media conglomerate Bertelsmann. 
 In a commercial he commissioned for German television, Mr. Middelhoff appeared wearing a "Star Trek" uniform under the slogan, "We pursue big ideas -- no matter where they lead us." Mr. Karmazin showed up for a recent conference call with institutional investors in a T-shirt that said, "We will not do anything stupid." He says investors are clamoring for copies of it. 
The differences between Viacom and Bertelsmann run far deeper than slogans on T-shirts, of course, and they say a lot about why Viacom today is the world's most valuable media empire, while Bertelsmann jettisoned Mr. Middelhoff last week and is likely to ditch many of his imperial ambitions.
Viacom is the only global media conglomerate that never succumbed to the allure of the Internet. It has steadfastly resisted the defining "big idea" of the 21st-century media business: that the Internet will profoundly transform the way people consume information and entertainment, necessitating radical changes in the way companies distribute their movies, television shows, music and magazines.
It is not that Viacom rejects the importance of the Internet -- or even the notion that it is changing the habits of consumers, particularly young ones, in ways that will generate exciting new businesses.
But unlike Bertelsmann under Mr. Middelhoff, Vivendi Universal under Jean-Marie Messier or AOL Time Warner under Gerald M. Levin and Robert W. Pittman, Viacom did not bet its corporate ranch on convergence -- the marriage of old-line media assets with Internet-age technology.
At Viacom, the Internet functions largely as a brand extension -- a vehicle to enhance the company's existing properties, from Paramount Pictures and MTV to CBS and Blockbuster. 
Mr. Middelhoff, Mr. Messier and Mr. Pittman, the chief operating officer at AOL Time Warner, were all shown the door within three weeks of one another. So if career survival is any guide, Viacom's pragmatic approach appears to have been the right bet.
"Convergence may be the most expensive word in history, said David Geffen, the prolific entrepreneur who is co-founder of DreamWorks, the movie studio, with Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg. "It has cost people billions."
Like most media moguls, Mr. Geffen does not dispute the contention that digital technology is blurring the boundaries between the television, the PC and the telephone. But a huge number of multimillion-dollar investments has shown that extracting a profit from this convergence is extraordinarily difficult, particularly when companies try to meld assets from disparate industries -- say, cellular phones with Hollywood entertainment.
THE upheavals at AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and Vivendi stemmed in part from the inability of their top executives to cope with the unwieldy goliaths they had created. "Nobody has an expertise that runs across every single medium," Mr. Geffen said. 
But, he added: "It is still early. Maybe a generation from now, it will be a different story."
Viacom is not the only company that has steered a conservative course. Neither the Walt Disney Company nor Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation made bets on cyberspace that altered the direction of their companies. But of all the global players, Viacom has an Internet strategy most firmly rooted in the here and now.
MTV.com, the Web site for Viacom's ubiquitous music video channel, offers surfers the chance to listen to music, watch streaming video or buy tickets for concerts by bands like the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Yet the site, among the most heavily visited on the Web, is at heart an electronic billboard for MTV.
"Our strategy is tied into these strong brands, and in having a platform to cross-promote them," Mr. Karmazin said.
That is the vocabulary of an advertising salesman, which Mr. Karmazin is, and it is worlds away from the high-flown phrases of Internet evangelists. Mr. Levin, the former chief executive of AOL Time Warner and architect of the 2001 merger that created it, once likened the Net to the ancient library at Alexandria -- enormous, democratic and free.
Over the last three years, Mr. Karmazin said, he has read more than 100 business plans for Internet start-ups seeking to be acquired by Viacom. Some were more than start-ups: Sumner M. Redstone, Viacom's chairman, turned away Mr. Pittman when he proposed in mid-1999 that Viacom buy America Online.
In almost all cases, neither Mr. Karmazin nor Mr. Redstone was able to justify the high price of the start-ups, based on their projected long-term contribution to Viacom's sales and profits.
"These things are de minimus to a company of our size," Mr. Karmazin said. "They are not transforming. So you sit there and you say to yourself, 'Why in the world would I pay an exorbitant price when the thing is only going to be a small part of my company in five years?' "
In Mr. Middelhoff's four years atop Bertelsmann, his forays into the Internet were all about transformation. He fervently believed that the Web was reinventing the way people buy books and CD's, two of Bertelsmann's core products. After trying to buy Amazon.com, Mr. Middelhoff poured hundreds of millions of dollars into online stores like BOL.com and CDNow.com.
The losses piled up, and the ventures were eventually folded into Bertelsmann's traditional book and music clubs.
Mr. Middelhoff's most prominent Internet crusade -- if not the most costly -- was Napster, the online file-sharing service that vowed to revolutionize the distribution of recorded music. Napster was vilified by the major music companies as a pirate in pioneer's clothes, but he lent it $85 million and tried to turn it into a subscriber-based service.
Trouble is, Mr. Middelhoff could not persuade the other major music companies to withdraw their lawsuits against the service. Even as they were quietly putting together their own online ventures, AOL Time Warner, Vivendi and others effectively drove Napster into bankruptcy. Under Bertelsmann's cautious new bosses, its future looks dim.
Pioneers, the cliche goes, end up with arrows in their backs. Mr. Middelhoff's defenders said Napster could have leapfrogged ahead of an Internet wave that threatens to engulf the music business.
"Middelhoff was breathtaking in the leadership roles he took," said Porter Bibb, the managing director of Technology Partners, an investment advisory firm in New York. "If he had brought the other music executives with him, he might have been able to turn the Internet into a viable distribution medium."
But current and former Bertelsmann executives said that in his fervor, Mr. Middelhoff misjudged the mood of the music industry, as well as the perceived threat that Napster posed to its business.
Even at Bertelsmann's music division, BMG, executives debated often and stridently the wisdom of the Napster investment. Most of the unit's top executives left soon after the investment was announced, though some say the exodus was initiated by Mr. Middelhoff as part of an overdue house-cleaning.
"Music is an ideal business to attack through the Internet," one former senior executive said. "But Napster implants the idea that content doesn't cost anything, and that is extremely dangerous."
Mr. Middelhoff did not respond to requests for an interview.
If he was a mogul ahead of his time, Mr. Messier and Vivendi, a French water company founded during the reign of Napoleon III, seemed even more divorced from reality. 
Mr. Middelhoff's Internet ventures, though risky, were driven by the desire to expand Bertelsmann's existing businesses. Mr. Messier, an investment banker with no experience in media, used convergence as a rationale to cobble together businesses with little obvious connection.
"Some of these deals were marriages of convenience, which were justified as marriages of convergence," said Michael J. Wolf, the head of the media practice at McKinsey & Company.
Beaming music and video, through a wireless Internet connection, to a customer's cellular phone was a pet project of Mr. Messier's. He made it the cornerstone of his pitch for Vivendi's $34 billion acquisition of Seagram Ltd., which owned the Universal film studio and music company.
THE project seemed far-fetched from the start. Vivendi owns 44 percent of Cegetel, a long-distance provider that, in turn, owns a majority of France's No. 2 cellular company, SFR. Before Vivendi acquired Seagram, it teamed up with Vodafone, the British cellular giant, to create an Internet service, known as Vizzavi, which claimed a potential market of 80 million people.
Mr. Messier's idea -- which in these sober times seems almost quaint in its Dick Tracy futurism -- was to transmit clips of Universal's movies and songs to the cellular phones of these customers.
"The overall vision is really to be the media group and the content group which gets the best usage of direct customer relationships on a global and multiplatform basis," Mr. Messier said in an interview last year, during the brief heyday of his empire-building.
Unfortunately for Mr. Messier, two of his platforms -- telecommunications and the Internet -- collapsed as industries. And the Seagram purchase left Vivendi staggering under $18 billion in debt.
Last month, with Vivendi's stock price cratering and its loan covenants near default, Vivendi's board replaced Mr. Messier with a retired pharmaceutical executive, Jean-Rene Fourtou. He is expected to disassemble much of what his predecessor built, starting with Vizzavi.
Mr. Messier's defenders say he was on the right track in seeing the potential for wireless Internet access. But even the Japanese cellular provider NTT DoCoMo, which pioneered multipurpose pocket phones with its I-mode service, has had trouble selling the third generation of these gadgets.
Mr. Redstone of Viacom said the mistake that some media companies made was to overestimate how quickly new technologies -- even one as potent as the Internet -- would alter people's habits.
"Behavioral patterns don't change that easily," he said. "Americans are passive. They will continue to write checks and shop at stores," he added, referring to the plans of AOL Time Warner for electronic shopping.
Mr. Redstone built one of the country's greatest fortunes on the unchanging habits of consumers. He continued to own movie theaters long after experts predicted that they would be put out of business by rented videocassettes. He bought control of Blockbuster Entertainment at a time when industry forecasters said the home video market would be wiped out by interactive television.
Viacom's stock has been hurt by the downturn in advertising revenue, on which MTV, Nickelodeon, CBS and its other businesses are heavily dependent. But it has not suffered nearly as much as its rivals.
With a market capitalization of $67.2 billion, Viacom is worth four times as much as Vivendi, three times as much as the News Corporation and nearly twice as much as the Walt Disney Company. It is worth one-third more than AOL Time Warner, though it is more than half the size in revenue.
Analysts attribute much of Viacom's current favor on Wall Street to the fact that it avoided the costly Internet missteps of other media companies. As important, it has so far avoided the management upheaval that often accompanies mergers of old- and new-media companies.
"Viacom does a great job of cross-promotion," Mr. Bibb said. "Karmazin has got Dan Rather doing spots for '60 Minutes II' on 1010 WINS," one of two news radio stations in New York owned by Viacom.
Contrast that to AOL Time Warner, where Mr. Pittman was unable to persuade the company's divisions to cooperate in selling basic advertising packages to clients. Time Warner always had a tendency toward warring fiefs, but that tendency was aggravated by resentment on the part of Time Warner executives toward their new AOL colleagues, whom they viewed as arrogant.
"The fiefdoms at Time Warner are here to stay," said John Tinker, the head of research at Blaylock & Partners in New York. "That dreaded word 'synergy' is dead for at least a couple of years."
INTERNECINE rivalries also hurt Mr. Middelhoff at Bertelsmann. Founded in 1835 as a publisher of Lutheran hymnals, Bertelsmann, which is privately owned and based in Gutersloh, Germany, is so decentralized that the pay of senior executives is tied to the performance of their units, not the overall company.
Executives at the company said that in tandem with his push into the Internet, Mr. Middelhoff was trying to centralize control of Bertelsmann in his hands. When he announced the investment in Napster, for example, he did it without BMG's management.
Mr. Middelhoff also vowed to take Bertelsmann public by 2005. In the end, his ambitions collided with Bertelsmann's controlling shareholders, the family of Reinhard Mohn, who feared that their power would be eroded.
The ouster of Mr. Middelhoff and his counterparts has prompted much talk that the company will return to an old-media industry. That is misplaced, however, and some experts say, even a little dangerous.
Convergence -- whether defined as the melding of content and distribution or the fusing of traditional media properties with the Internet -- is already well under way.
Unless companies learn to harness digital technology and the Internet, experts say, they risk having the underlying economics of their businesses sabotaged by it. Viacom's go-slow approach might make sense for a film and TV company that is lubricated by advertising. It makes less sense for Vivendi and Bertelsmann, with vulnerable music companies.
Barry Diller has stood at the treacherous intersection of old and new media for a decade. Perhaps that is why he seems unruffled by the latest turmoil in the boardrooms of big media conglomerates.
"The underlying issue, of course, is executing what you have converged," said Mr. Diller, who runs USA Interactive and oversees Universal Pictures and the other American properties of Vivendi. Doing so "takes time and patience, and it takes not having the rug pulled out from under you prematurely," he added.
That is cold comfort for Messrs. Middelhoff, Messier and Pittman, three prophets of convergence whose words, for now at least, have fallen on deaf ears.

HEADLINE: Bush's Shame 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka 

 BODY:
Watching the pathetic, mealy-mouthed response of President Bush and his State Department to Egypt's decision to sentence the leading Egyptian democracy advocate to seven years in prison leaves one wondering whether the whole Bush foreign policy team isn't just a big bunch of phonies. Shame on all of them.
 Since Sept. 11 all we've heard out of this Bush team is how illegitimate violence is as a tool of diplomacy or politics, and how critical it is to oust Saddam Hussein in order to bring democracy to the Arab world. Yet last week, when a kangaroo court in Egypt, apparently acting on orders from President Hosni Mubarak, sentenced an ill, 63-year-old Saad Eddin Ibrahim to seven years at "hard labor" for promoting democracy -- for promoting the peaceful alternative to fundamentalist violence -- the Bush-Cheney team sat on its hands. 
 The State Department, in a real profile in courage, said it was "deeply disappointed" by the conviction of Mr. Ibrahim, who holds a U.S. passport. "Disappointed"? I'm disappointed when the Baltimore Orioles lose. When an Egyptian president we give $2 billion a year to jails a pro-American democracy advocate, I'm "outraged" and expect America to do something about it.
I'm also frightened, because if there is no space in Egypt for democratic voices for change, then Egyptians will only be left with the mosque. If there is no room in Egypt for Saad Ibrahims, then we will only get more Mohamed Attas -- coming again to a theater near you.
Mr. Ibrahim's "crime" was that his institute at the American University in Cairo was helping to teach Egyptians how to register to vote, how to fill out a ballot and how to monitor elections. The Egyptian court accused him of embezzling funds from the European Union, which supported his efforts. The outraged E.U. said no such thing ever happened.
This monkey trial was really about an insecure, isolated Mr. Mubarak quashing any dissenters, and it is much more important than it looks -- because so many more people are watching than we think. The other day, I interviewed a leading Sri Lankan human rights activist, Radhika Coomaraswamy, director of the International Center for Ethnic Studies. We started out talking about Sri Lanka but ended up talking about Mr. Ibrahim, whom she knew, and America.
"What is the nonviolent alternative for expressing discontent and promoting change ?" she asked me. "It's democracy. When you remove any democratic alternative, the only route left in many countries for expressing discontent is religious fundamentalism. Saad is the alternative democratic voice, and if we don't protect it we're just inviting more violence."
This ties in with a larger concern that human rights activists share toward America today -- a concern that post-9/11 America is not interested anymore in law and order, just order, and it's not interested in peace and quiet, but just quiet. I am struck by how many Sri Lankans, who are as pro-American as they come, have made some version of this observation to me: America as an idea, as a source of optimism and as a beacon of liberty is critical to the world -- but you Americans seem to have forgotten that since 9/11. You've stopped talking about who you are, and are only talking now about who you're going to invade, oust or sanction.
These days, said Mrs. Coomaraswamy, "none of us in the human rights community would think of appealing to the U.S. for support for upholding a human rights case -- maybe to Canada, to Norway or to Sweden -- but not to the U.S. Before there were always three faces of America out in the world -- the face of the Peace Corps, the America that helps others, the face of multinationals and the face of American military power.
"My sense is that the balance has gone wrong lately and that the only face of America we see now is the one of military power, and it really frightens the world. . . . I understand that there is always a tension between security concerns and holding governments accountable for human rights. But if you focus on security alone and allow basic human rights violations in the name of security, then, well, as someone who grew up in America and went to law school there, I find that heartbreaking."
So do I. How about before we go trying to liberate a whole country -- Iraq -- we first liberate just one man, one good man, who is now sitting in an Egyptian jail for pursuing the very democratic ideals that we profess to stand for.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Real Politics; 
When Energy Comes From Russia, It's Also Power

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
BEHIND the decision facing President Bush on whether to make war on Iraq is a set of calculations that ought to be called the realpolitik of oil -- and Russia is at the center.
 Since Sept. 11, oil experts and politicians, including President Vladimir V. Putin, have been promoting Russia and its burgeoning energy sector as the strategic antidote to the threat of another oil shock. The big fears are of war in the Middle East or a move orchestrated against Western interests by Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf heavyweights in OPEC, as unlikely as that has seemed for a long time. Many oil traders say there is a $3 to $5 premium on Middle Eastern oil already, because of war jitters. 
 But Moscow has been engaged in a strategic migration to the West since Sept. 11 that buttresses the view of Russia as a critical partner to the West. And this is changing the psychology of both the marketplace and geopolitics. 
Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Putin would be impolitic enough to say he has been drawing up an insurance policy against allies -- the stable oil-producing kingdoms and sheikdoms that have abandoned the notion that oil is a weapon in global politics. 
But even if loyalty and alliance hold between Washington and its Persian Gulf friends, who can say what the effect would be if Saddam Hussein fired Scud missiles loaded with anthrax, mustard gas or some ghastly radiological substance onto the main Saudi oil loading terminal at Ras Tanura, causing panic and shutdown?
And since Sept. 11, there has been an additional, intangible element corroding Saudi-American relations -- something between uncertainty and mistrust over the heavy Saudi representation among Osama bin Laden's martyrs and the Saudi tolerance for the culture of jihad. The Saudis, for their part, resent the loss of American initiative to secure a Palestinian homeland, so evident under the first President Bush and during most of the Clinton years. Today, America and Saudi Arabia drink tea laced with the hemlock of unstated recriminations. "The psychological factor is there," an adviser to the royal family conceded.
In the world of realpolitik, public reassurances about stable oil supplies count only up to a point. Capabilities matter, just as they will in any war with Iraq, where President Bush will have to weigh the risks of going it alone, or nearly so.
Last fall, President Bush told his energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, to add 108 million barrels of oil to the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. But that offers the American market just one layer of shock absorption.
"The first principle of energy security is diversification," said Daniel Yergin, the oil markets analyst and historian, and by that measure Russia suddenly figures in international energy markets. The post-Soviet sag in gross oil production is steadily being reversed; indeed, Russia overtook Saudi Arabia this spring by pumping 7.28 million barrels a day in March. In annual figures, Russian oil exports, which bottomed at 3.16 million barrels a day in 1994, are expected to reach 5 million a day this year or next.
"The Russian oil industry is growing at an amazing rate, and it is bringing in Western talent, technology and investment, but most of all it needs markets," said Sarah C. Carey, a Washington lawyer who is on the board of Russia's second-largest oil giant, Yukos, which wants to supply American refineries. By playing on the West's fear of disruption, Russia has found greater tolerance for its bully-boy tactics in the oil markets since Sept. 11; the only sound from the Saudis has been the gnashing of teeth. 
But here is the rub of the debate: Russia cannot supplant Saudi Arabia as the world's guarantor of stable oil supplies in a clutch. "They are at full production," the adviser to the Saudi royal family said, referring to Russia. "Everybody is at full production except Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Abu Dhabi and Venezuela." And the lion's share of spare production remains a Saudi franchise.
"The Russians know that, everybody knows that, and what we say is, just don't push us into a corner," he said, referring to fear that Russia might try to seize Saudi markets with overzealous production. The implied threat is that Saudi Arabia would flood the market to drive prices down, as it has before. Since Saudi oil is the cheapest to produce (about $2 a barrel, compared with $12 to $15 a barrel for new production oil), the House of Saud can best ride out low prices. "We have the elasticity to go down and still make money," the official said. 
But Saudi Arabia's pre-eminence almost doesn't matter. Russia's surging oil industry and the growing exports from it and from the Caspian Sea region will add to the pool of non-OPEC production over the next decade. This, as Mr. Yergin points out, will make the global market more resistant to shock, particularly with Russia's new attitude toward the West in mind.
"A lot of things have come together now," Mr. Yergin said, not least that under Mr. Putin, Russia is firmly back on a pragmatic reform path. And while Saudi Arabia raised its oil output after Sept. 11 to insure calm markets, Russia has been changing policy in a larger way. It is merging Russian interests with European and Western security interests in the battle against terrorism, a strategic realignment that is deflating its old fears of NATO expansion and Western encirclement. Russian oil and gas giants are cleaning up their act, making them safer for Western investment, Mr. Yergin says.
And the latter-day version of the Great Game in Central Asia that so recently pitted Russia against Western encroachment suddenly looks more like a joint venture of shared interests. Russian oil companies are joining major Western ones in bringing Central Asia on line as a major oil producer. Russia wants to insure that a healthy portion of any new pipelines cross its land, but that is now less important because both Russia and the West are beginning to see the virtue of variety and collaboration in a world where demand will only go up with the growth of new economies. 
In Mr. Putin, Russia's new oil barons have a leader willing to press their interests. "Putin is a master of making more out of what he actually has," said James Richard, a co-author of an essay this spring in the journal Foreign Affairs that asserted that "the contest for energy dominance between the world's two largest oil exporters, Saudi Arabia and Russia," will have "fundamental consequences for the world's economy."
Those consequences don't have to hurt the competitors, other analysts point out. If war in Iraq disrupts world markets, Russia and Saudi Arabia will both mobilize their production to fill in -- even though Russia doesn't have Saudi Arabia's vast reserves or the built-in spare capacity.
Still, Russia wants new markets and will likely use its elbows to get them, so some testing of its strength against the Persian Gulf giants may be inevitable.
ONE advantage for Russia is that what it lacks in oil reserves it makes up for in natural gas; it already provides a quarter of Europe's gas. In oil, Russia doesn't like the Saudi argument that it should wait its turn and take new market share from the rising demand for oil coming out of Asia. That argument might have more success if the pragmatic Mr. Putin were in full control of Russia's oil giants and their aggressive marketing strategies. On most days, instead, he happily rides the tiger of Russian oil expansion, hoping among other things that growth in energy will spur the rest of the economy.
The Sept. 11 attacks brought Russia into the Western camp with a seat, though not membership, in NATO for debates on Western security. So Mr. Putin's stature for playing Russia's version of realpolitik has only been enhanced. The question is, How will he play it? The answer almost certainly is that he will play for national interest, whatever is best to rebuild Russia's economy and a strong Russian state anchored in both Europe and Asia.
This strategic partnership is based on mutual interest, the two-way street of any relationship. And just as the United States and Europe welcome the freedom of action they get from Russia's more muscular presence in the oil market, Mr. Putin welcomes new opportunities for Russia, above all that Russian interests should be taken into account on the big issues of war and commerce. 
SO it is more than interesting that Mr. Putin has positioned himself between America and each of the states Mr. Bush counts as the "axis of evil." He has parlayed with North Korea's Kim Jong-il to press the Western agenda of arms control, while selling to both Koreas the concept of a common market that would connect them with Europe via Russia's rails.
In Iran, he has pursued the Russian power industry's interests, negotiating deals to sell nuclear power stations after Russian engineers complete their long delayed unit at Bushehr. As a partner with the West, he gets the right to argue Russian commercial interests in Iran, even as the Bush administration denounces Iran's support for terrorism and its quest for nuclear weapons.
And in the confrontation with Iraq, Mr. Putin has adopted the American position that Saddam Hussein must open his borders to United Nations inspectors or face the consequences. Still, he has kept the lines open to Baghdad to hold onto multibillion-dollar contracts to develop new Iraqi oil fields. And Russia, whose equipment built Iraq's army, is likely to supply Saddam's successor, perhaps in competition with the West. 
In other words, the concept of a resurgent Russian state providing energy security for the West is beginning to work to Russia's benefit, and the gains for Russia are palpable. In part because of President Putin's relationship with President Bush, the concept seems less threatening than most forecasts for Russia did a few years ago, even if Russia's new vibrance does not quite radiate to the grumpy shores of the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Some Woods Supporters Are Aware Of His Flaws

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
Golf pros are the corporate world's geishas. They are sweet-talking stroker-jokers. They ease the lives of stock rockers who need to network outdoors where it's hard to wiretap their insider-trade conversations. Teaching pros hustle the hustlers ("Just a few hundred more lessons, C.E.O. Billy, and you'll be ready for the Sing Sing Open, heh-heh."), make them feel manly and give them socially acceptable reasons to be out of the office and away from their families on those lush lawns where you can mix with your own kind.
 This is why the PGA touring pros, the divas of this world, are so important. They exist to give golf the patina of a real sport with popular appeal. It's on TV! The touring pros also reaffirm the natural orders of the country club and the corporation. No wonder that the reigning deities of golf, Bobby Jones, the Confederate prince; Arnold Palmer, the people's choice; and Tiger Woods, the world's highest-paid supermodel, are also conservative role models. 
 Last week, even as Tiger Woods was paired with Jack Nicklaus, his rival for greatest of all time, in a made-for-TV match, I was treading water on a tidal wave of e-mail messages responding to my chronic problem with the elevation of Woods to Jock Culture hero.
But there has been a shift in the response since the Tiger tweak last year, when the overwhelming response to the great Caucasian-black-American Indian-Asian, or in his words Cablinasian (so who was that masked man?), was that he bore the glorious face of the future and anyone who couldn't see it was covetous, racist, old. This time, perhaps because of events beyond the greens, certainly the loss of confidence in corporations, there was a kind of weary acceptance of Tiger's flaws.
A Manhattan woman, Annie V. Davis, wrote: "Who cares when the silly ole men at Augusta National (who refused Bill Gates, too) will invite silly ole women to join them. Pumping up this issue is also a form of harlotry, only of the journalistic variety. Get real! No woman, or man, that I know will ever be invited. And I don't care, as long as they continue to produce the best golf tournament in the world. That is the only real thing about them."
This was after Tiger, asked about the policy of discriminating against women at the Masters in Augusta (and by extension at Muirfield, in Scotland, the host of the recent British Open), carved this on the locker-room wall: "They're entitled to set up their own rules the way they want them. It would be nice to see everyone have an equal chance to participate if they wanted to, but there is nothing you can do about it."
Even the excuses for him were mild and sports-related. Ward Jones of Houston wrote: "I still take exception to your criticism of him for not speaking out against Muirfield's exclusionary policy against women. It may have been that he simply didn't want to get embroiled in a controversy that would take his mind off his golf game, rather than his allegiance to any corporate sponsor."
Phoebe Howard of Fresno, Calif., while affirming Woods's legitimate superstardom, wrote: "But his profound lack of regard for the world around him is distressing and disappointing. I mean, 26 years old? He's not 18. (Mr. Woods's dismissal of the comments was even weirder than his son making them.) Forget activism. It's too bad that Tiger Woods declines even to inspire constructive dialogue."
Of course, I had my supporters. The retired sports columnist and political activist Lester Rodney thought that Woods "sounds exactly like a lot of apologists for baseball's apartheid ban back in the 30's."
Calling Woods a corporado whose ultimate allegiance is to the conglomerates whose products he endorses brought several interesting responses. Art Lowrie of Tampa, Fla., asked: "Would you call Arnold Palmer a 'corporado' for endorsing the Callaway ERC driver against the rules of the U.S.G.A. after he had signed a lucrative endorsement contract with Callaway? I would."
But Brent T. Davis, a Mercer Island, Wash., educator, did not construe it as criticism. "Capitalism is the key to the salvation of the human race, physical and not spiritual, of course," he wrote. "We simply cannot sustain the world's population without free markets, increased capitalization and their corresponding technological and intellectual innovation.
"Tiger Woods seems to have a very adult grip on these concepts and realizes that barriers fall as conditions become economically rational for them to fall. There is certainly room at the moment, and probably will be for all time, for single-sex institutions."
All this sociology may be so much baggage that it will crush Tiger. My main source of wisdom on sports matters psychological -- the former Canadian national heavyweight lifting champion Dr. Michael Miletic -- wonders if Tiger self-destructed at Muirfield to avoid becoming the designated greatest golfer of all time. As a mixed-race man in an overwhelmingly white sport, Tiger might not have been ready for that added pressure. Miletic, a psychiatrist who treats many pro athletes, noted that Tiger tended to make his putts in the later rounds when he was too far behind to win. So, when Tiger reappears this week at the Buick Open, you can watch him being a patient as well as a performer and corporado.
Don't bother responding to this because I'm out of here for a month. When I come back it's going to be college football, this year's one true sport. And I don't want to hear that Bobby Jones, Arnold Palmer and Tiger Woods were all once college boys.

HEADLINE: Tentative Deal Is Reached That Would End 7-Week Bus Strike in Queens 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
The union representing 1,500 striking workers at three private bus lines in Queens reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday with the city and the bus companies that would end a seven-week walkout, union and company officials said.
 Roger Toussaint, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, said a ratification vote would be held on Tuesday at a meeting of drivers, mechanics and cleaners, making it possible for buses to begin rolling again on Wednesday morning. "It looks as if midnight Tuesday night, we could get the buses rolling," he said. 
 The city's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, became involved in intense negotiations over the last week after many Queens residents complained that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was doing too little to settle the strike. The tentative accord was reached at 3 a.m. yesterday, after a 17-hour bargaining session. 
The city had a major role in the negotiations because the three bus companies -- the Queens Surface Corporation, Jamaica Buses Inc. and Triboro Coach Corporation -- receive large operating subsidies from the city and said they needed additional aid to reach a deal with the union. 
To many Queens residents, the strike was a serious hardship because it came during unusually hot weather and halted services normally used by more than 110,000 people a day.
"The companies have signed onto the tentative agreement," said Mark Brossman, the chief negotiator for the three companies. "The companies are happy that the workers are coming back and service will be restored."
City Hall officials were cautious about trumpeting a deal, noting that there appeared to be an agreement three weeks ago, but it fell apart when a feud between union factions prevented it from being put to a rank-and-file vote.
"We're cautiously optimistic, but we've been down this road before," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mr. Bloomberg. 
The main issues in the dispute were health benefits and the union's demand for job security. To help finance the settlement, the city agreed to provide the bus companies with $3.75 million to help pay for the workers' health coverage.
The workers had insisted on guarantees to protect their jobs and pensions because city officials have proposed letting other companies bid for the Queens bus franchises, which expire on Dec. 31, 2003. The bus companies said they could not promise job security past the expiration of the franchises. For his part, Mr. Bloomberg refused to promise job security beyond the life of the workers' contract.
It appeared as if the strike would end three weeks ago when the Queens borough president, Helen M. Marshall, persuaded the city to lend the bus lines $2 million to finance health benefits. The strike continued, though, after several union leaders blocked a vote because there were no promises of job security. But over the last two weeks, a majority of City Council members have lined up behind job security provisions, pushed by the union, that would protect jobs even if other companies won or obtained the franchises.
Mr. Toussaint said the 27-month contract, which is to expire next March 31, calls for raises of 4 percent in the first year and the second year, and 1 percent on the contract's last day. The workers, who walked out on June 17, are to receive most of the wage increase retroactively, because their old contract expired on Dec. 31, 2000. The workers now earn an average of $20.35 an hour.
Ms. Marshall said she was delighted by the deal. "It's critical and important," she said. "This strike hurt the economy of Queens drastically. Businesses didn't have nearly all the local trade they used to get."
In May, the bus companies and the union signed a memorandum of agreement on several major issues, but they said signing a formal contract was contingent upon receiving more financial help from the city. When the city balked at providing aid, the union went on strike. Mr. Bloomberg had insisted that it was a private dispute that should be settled by the companies and the union and not by City Hall.
Mr. Toussaint said the city seized on the strike to weaken the union and put it on the defensive before it begins its most important negotiations later this year. Local 100 represents more than 30,000 New York City Transit workers, whose contract expires on December 15.
One of the last issues to be resolved was whether the city's $3.75 million contribution would be considered a loan. City officials wanted the money to be a loan, Mr. Toussaint said, but the companies considered it an advance. The tentative agreement calls the $3.75 million an advance that the three companies are to repay by making productivity improvements. 
Negotiators said that more than the original $2 million loan was needed because the city did not provide the companies with more than $1 million to finance the companies' health insurance premiums that came due during the strike.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL 3-15

New Laws for Turkey In Move Toward Europe
Turkey's Parliament approved a reform package aimed at improving its chances of joining the European Union by abolishing the death penalty and granting greater rights to the nation's Kurds. 12

Pakistan Wavers in Showdown
The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf appears to be backing down on the Islamic schools, or madrasas, in Pakistan often accused of spreading religious extremism. Caught between Western worry and the home-grown strength of the clerics, government ministers said they would consider watering down their proposals. 10

Bhutto Plans Candidacy
Benazir Bhutto, one of two former prime ministers of Pakistan who are living in exile, said she would return to her homeland to run for office in the elections scheduled for October and that she would face being jailed by the country's military dictator. 10

Taiwan Risks Beijing's Anger
Taiwan's president said separate countries exist on each side of the Taiwan Strait and backed legislation that would authorize a referendum on Taiwan independence. 4

Zimbabwe's Land Transfer
The government of President Robert Mugabe has ordered thousands of the country's most productive farmers -- the white commercial farmers -- to leave their farms for good by Thursday, even though the United Nations says that half the population is threatened by famine. 1

Korea Talks to Be Held
North and South Korea agreed to hold the first inter-Korean cabinet-level talks in nearly a year on a wide range of critical issues including a skirmish in the Yellow Sea in June in which five South Koreans were killed. 15

NATIONAL 16-24

Terror Detentions Prompt Sprawling Legal Battle
