HEADLINE: PROFILES; 
The Super Bowl

BYLINE:  By Sol Hurwitz; Sol Hurwitz, a freelance writer, is a former president of the Committee for Economic Development, an organization of business leaders and educators. As a school board member in Rye, N.Y., he headed a search committee for a superintendent.

 BODY:
Imagine a job that requires an Army officer's leadership skills, a C.E.O.'s management expertise, a lawyer's negotiating talents and an educator's understanding of how to teach children. That's what it takes to be a school superintendent in the 21st century. 
 It may be the toughest job in America. Superintendents are hard pressed to recruit and retain competent teachers and produce high-scoring students while balancing budgets and making the yellow buses run on time. They must maneuver a maze of government regulations and mollify a swarm of constituents: parents, teachers and community advocates, not to mention their bosses on the board of education or, increasingly, in city hall. 
 In fact, a superintendent's average tenure is only five years, half that in large, urban districts, even though experts say it takes 5 to 10 years for reforms to take hold. Los Angeles, the nation's second largest school district, has had six leaders in a decade. New York City, the nation's largest, has had 10 in 20 years. In another turn of the revolving door, its chancellor of just two and a half years is soon to step down, now that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has won control of the schools and is about to put his own choice in place. 
"The job consumes all of you, your personal life and your professional life," says Gerry House, who held the post in Chapel Hill, N.C., and Memphis and is now president of the Institute for Student Achievement in Lake Success, N.Y. "I made the decision I didn't want to be a superintendent again. I was actually exhausted." Superintendents also complain of isolation: their work allows little time for exchanging ideas with colleagues. To encourage off-the-record dialogue, the Aspen Institute has set up a superintendents' support group that meets annually to trade information and air anxieties. "There was a lot of complaining about school boards," one participant says. 
The job was not always so stressful. In the mid-1800's, school districts in large cities appointed the first superintendents to oversee several schoolhouses, assuring that the classrooms were orderly and the stoves had enough coal to last the winter. Today there are 13,500 districts, including some of the nation's largest institutions. If the New York City school system were a corporation, it would rank in the top third of the Fortune 500. 
What makes a good superintendent? Researchers are spending millions of dollars to discover the precise blend of leadership skills and local circumstances that spell success. But there are no easy answers. "There are some individuals whose talents run more to building programs, and others to maintaining them, and others to demolishing them and making hard decisions about what to put in their place," says Susan Moore Johnson, a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education who studies educational leadership. "While an effective superintendent should be strong in all those areas, it's not common to find someone who is." 
The typical superintendent -- a white, professionally trained male educator -- is now out of sync with the growing minority student population of America's school districts and their largely female work force. "When these superintendents call it quits," says Paul D. Houston, the executive director of the American Association of School Administrators, "we can expect to see more women, more minorities and noneducators take their place." 
While the most common career path is teacher to principal to administrator to superintendent, school boards are questioning whether conventional educators have what it takes to manage an enterprise that seems forever entangled in politics and bureaucracy and that requires skills far different from teaching children or running a school. Accordingly, some large cities are tapping business, government, law or the military as sources for nontraditional problem solvers. 
New York's departing schools leader, Harold O. Levy, is a Citigroup alumnus; to replace him, Mayor Bloomberg has searched primarily for a candidate with management credentials, who would be helped by a strong educator as deputy -- a model that can already be found in Chicago, San Diego, Los Angeles and Seattle.
But Mr. Levy's short tenure suggests that outsiders are no more secure in their jobs than traditional educators. In Baltimore and in Washington, the school board has replaced, respectively, a fiscal expert and a retired Army general with conventional educators who were experienced in the tricky business of managing teachers and administrators. For one thing, boards may bristle when a superintendent's thinking wanders too far outside the box. "Sometimes the district finds the approaches of that person too radical, too threatening, and so they go back to hiring an insider," says Professor Johnson of Harvard.
As Charles Taylor, an Atlanta job recruiter, said recently, "School boards are looking for God -- on a good day."

Four Who Are Reversing the Course of Failing Schools

Alan D. Bersin
Superintendent, San Diego
Unified School District
While discussing the business of running California's second largest school district (enrollment: 145,000), Mr. Bersin disarms visitors by sitting on top of a large inflatable exercise ball. The ball, for toning muscles, "keeps my back straight and my courage strong," he says. Last October, the ball got a workout when a storm erupted over an e-mail sent to colleagues by the school board president, a steadfast supporter of Mr. Bersin. It suggested that two rebellious board members should be shot. 
"Of course, the e-mail was inexcusable and unwarranted," Mr. Bersin, 55, says. "But it's a reflection of the tumult that accompanies large-scale reform." 
A troubling reality of Mr. Bersin's tenure is that he has functioned with a tenuous 3-to-2 majority on the board since he was hired four years ago. The two dissenting school board members have challenged his every move, despite his success in streamlining the bureaucracy and raising test scores.
Mr. Bersin says that his highest priority has been to reverse San Diego's slide in student achievement "by creating a system in which instruction drives all major decisions in the district." Evaluations of district personnel are based strictly on their contributions to teaching and learning, and schools at all levels have shown solid improvements in the percentages of students scoring above average on standardized tests. Moreover, the lowest-achieving students are making greater gains than the district as a whole. 
"San Diego invests heavily in mentoring and professional development for both teachers and principals rather than the blizzard of fads that have been the traditional response to low achievement," says Linda Darling-Hammond, a Stanford University professor of education who is studying San Diego's schools. "As a result, some of the best-trained teachers are choosing San Diego over nearby suburbs."
Mr. Bersin, a former varsity football player at Harvard and a Rhodes scholar, gained a reputation as a tough prosecutor in the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of California before joining the Clinton administration as its border czar on drug and immigration issues, a job he now considers easier than his current post. 
Lacking an educator's credentials, he recruited a chief academic officer with a national reputation, Anthony J. Alvarado, who had resigned as New York City chancellor amid questions of financial misconduct but later earned distinction for improving academic performance as head of District 2 in Manhattan. Mr. Bersin gave Mr. Alvarado the title of chancellor of instruction, avoiding the label deputy. "It's not the traditional hierarchy," he says. "We're partners." 
Mr. Bersin and Mr. Alvarado are frequent targets of the San Diego teachers' union, whose leaders have lined up behind the two dissident board members. Union officials fault the administrators for their top-down management style, citing the layoff of 600 teacher's aides and the appointment of peer coaches to train teachers without consulting the union. An independent study in February found that while teachers were now better trained, their low morale risked undermining the administration's efforts. 
"The superintendent and the current school board majority have made it very clear that they have no intention of working collaboratively with educators and parents in repairing the damage that has been done this past four years," said Marc Knapp, the union president, in one of the monthly grenades he lobs at Mr. Bersin from the union's Web site. Mr. Bersin disputes the statement. "The issue is whether people come to the table for constructive dialogue, or whether, like Khrushchev at the U.N., they bang their shoe on the table with a blunt nyet."
"The fault lines here remain very sharply etched," he adds. In June, by a 3-to-2 vote, the board approved a four-year extension of his contract. But an election in November for two open school board seats will be viewed as a referendum on his tenure. He is confident of retaining a majority. 
"I'm committed to seeing it through," he says.

Carmen Varela Russo
Chief Executive, Baltimore
City Public School System
From her office in Mid-City, headquarters for Baltimore's 98,000-student school system, Ms. Russo looks out on a depressed urban landscape of abandoned buildings -- a sharp contrast with the city's quaint tourist seaport and historic homes. It is in such impoverished neighborhoods that she has singled out nine failing high schools for wholesale restructuring.
"This job is not for the young or the faint of heart," says Ms. Russo, 66, a Bronx native whose no-nonsense tactics have led some people to cast her as an in-your-face New Yorker. Defying fierce opposition, she has rammed through a redistricting and school-closing plan -- a strategy, she says, that is rooted in concern for the students. "Everyone knows where the troubled schools are," she says. "I'm willing to say it's intolerable to teach children under those conditions."
Ms. Russo passed a crucial hurdle in February when the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and nine local foundations invested $20.7 million in her high school rescue effort. The initiative calls for creating rigorous academic programs and small supportive learning communities, as well as making teachers and principals accountable for results. A revitalized Southern High School, the first of the nine to be overhauled, will open next month. In addition, the plan -- affecting half the city's high school population -- envisions eight small "innovation schools," most established in unconventional settings like office buildings, shopping malls or colleges. 
A former teacher, principal and deputy superintendent in Broward County, Fla., and chief executive of the division of high schools in New York City, Ms. Russo grew up in a Spanish-speaking household. Her father and grandparents emigrated from Spain; her mother was reared in Tampa, where her mother worked rolling cigars. "My family had a strong work ethic and a belief in the importance of education," she says. 
Ms. Russo was chosen chief executive in Baltimore in 2000 for her experience managing large districts with poor minority populations. Her predecessor, a noneducator, was a fiscal expert who resigned after two years because of budget problems. On her arrival, Ms. Russo was saddled with a $20 million budget deficit, which she has since reduced by $11 million. 
Colleagues call Ms. Russo "a high-energy type" and "politically savvy" -- traits that may help when she tries to persuade the State Assembly to increase its five-year, $250 million investment in reforms. "She knows how to play the characters around her," an associate says. 
An independent study ordered by the Maryland Legislature and released in December found that Baltimore's schools were "tremendously improved" since 1997, when a city-state partnership began running the district. In June, school officials reported that first graders tested above the national median in reading and math for the second straight year, while middle schoolers showed improvements in both subjects. 
A hands-on administrator who reads books by the management guru Peter F. Drucker, Ms. Russo says she believes in "engaging the whole community in a dialogue." One group that feels excluded, however, is the district's 7,400 teachers. The independent study found that teachers were suspicious of the administration and felt disenfranchised. A third are new to the district or to teaching, and 27 percent are uncertified. Consequently, they are demanding more support -- mentors and master teachers in the classroom -- and professional development. 
"The teachers have had everything happening to them at once -- new books and a new curriculum aligned with state standards," Ms. Russo says. "Teachers need and deserve this support, absolutely."
Ms. Russo talks openly about her struggle to succeed in a field dominated by men. "There's a perception that women can handle the younger children, but when you get to high school and management positions, it's a different story," she says. "I had someone tell me that a woman would never be chancellor in New York City." Why? "Because the job was too hard."

Joseph Olchefske
Superintendent, Seattle
Public Schools
Adorning the credenza in Mr. Olchefske's office is a daruma, a bright red Japanese doll symbolizing perseverance and success. According to custom, the owner paints the left eye black when making a wish and the right eye when the wish is granted. Mr. Olchefske points proudly to the doll's two black eyes, a sign that he has fulfilled his wish for high academic standards.
For nearly a year Mr. Olchefske worked in the shadow of the charismatic John Henry Stanford, a retired Army general and a mythic figure among superintendents. Mr. Olchefske, 44, filled in while Mr. Stanford fought leukemia. He was named superintendent in 1999 after Mr. Stanford's death. 
Since then, the affable but tough-minded Minnesota native has put his own stamp on the district. Over the last three years the percentage of Seattle students meeting state standards has risen, attendance is up and dropout rates are down. Last October the Seattle school board extended his contract and handed him a hefty raise -- more than $12,000, lifting his salary to $175,000. 
Soon after taking charge, Mr. Olchefske began a corporate-style marketing campaign, complete with an inspirational slogan ("Delivering on the Dream") and a shooting-star logo, to sell an innovative program that revamps teaching to meet the state's new learning standards. With a new evaluation system in place, the district thinks it can determine how much a teacher and a school have contributed to a student's performance. 
The youngest of seven children in a close-knit family, Mr. Olchefske received degrees from the University of Chicago and the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, where, thanks to a photographic memory, he rarely took notes. After graduating, he went home to help support his mother and care for his father, a plant foreman who was dying of cancer.
He joined the Seattle Public Schools in 1995 as chief financial officer after a 12-year career with an investment bank -- a nontraditional background that has served him well with corporate leaders. "He speaks their language," says Robin K. Pasquarella, the president of the Alliance for Education, an organization of 55 business and civic leaders in Seattle. Mr. Olchefske has a gift for explaining complicated subjects in simple terms -- speaking, of course, without notes.
Though corporate and private support for Seattle schools has increased, with dwindling state funds the district faces a projected $16 million shortfall next year. The superintendent intends to offset this mainly through an infusion of $6 million in new federal funds and cuts in administrative and support services. To help place the district on a sound financial footing, Mr. Olchefske developed a formula that measures the cost of educating each of the district's 47,600 students, according to their needs. "A student with a hearing problem or a low performer who needs extra help will cost more than a high achiever," he explains. Parents may choose any of Seattle's public schools, and money follows the students. 
Academically, his strategy is to give schools freedom to create their own programs, while enforcing accountability for what students should learn and when they should learn it. He replaced 60 of 100 principals because of poor performance and negotiated a teachers' contract that allows schools to choose their own teachers, regardless of seniority. 
While Mr. Olchefske retains broad backing, his critics say the district needs an educator at the helm, not a manager. Teachers have faulted his corporate mind-set and what they see as his failure to grasp how much his demands distract them from teaching. Minority groups have blamed him for disparities in the academic performance of different races. 
But as an unflagging optimist, Mr. Olchefske is mindful of the daruma's chief feature: it bounces back after being knocked over.

Barbara Byrd-Bennett
Chief Executive, Cleveland
Municipal School District
Ms. BYRD-BENNETT is not a typical bureaucrat. She punctuates conversations about proficiency standards with "Cool!" Her signature is a pair of dangly earrings -- usually American Indian designs in silver and malachite. She calls Cleveland's 76,000 schoolchildren "my kids" and visits them unannounced, not just when news cameras are on the premises. "I want to know and be connected to the kids," she says. "I need to tie the data on academic achievement to the faces, blood and skin of real children." 
For her attempts to revitalize the decaying schools of Cleveland, she was named top urban school leader last year by the Council of the Great City Schools, an organization of about 60 large school systems. "She has been able to turn a critical corner in Cleveland that has not been turned before," says Michael Casserly, the council's executive director.
Before she arrived as chief executive in 1998, the school district was under state control with an operating debt of $185 million. Substitute teachers taught hundreds of classes, and the district had not met any of the state's 27 proficiency standards. Today the system is solvent, posting gains in reading and math and meeting four standards. But that leaves 23 more to go, and most students perform well below the norms. Improvement, she admits, is incremental in a school district where 80 percent of the students are from low-income homes. 
A former teacher, Ms. Byrd-Bennett, 52, has courted Cleveland's teachers with higher salaries and improved working conditions. Her supporters point to an intuitive ability to connect with people -- from kindergartners to C.E.O.'s -- and a laserlike focus on literacy. But her crowning achievement has been voter approval of a construction bond issue that will generate $1 billion to overhaul crumbling schools. Her goal, she says, is "to repair, renovate or rebuild" all of Cleveland's 120 school buildings, making them "warm, safe and dry."
From an early age, her father, a postal worker, and her mother, a sales clerk, instilled the lessons of study and hard work. Raised on 125th Street in Harlem, she graduated from high school at 16 and at 19 from Long Island University, with a degree in English literature. "The course load was 18 credits," she says. "I got the dean's approval to take 21. I could take courses in Latin, philosophy, foreign languages -- things I had a passion for." After college she took up painting, mainly landscapes, which she pursued seriously until arriving in Cleveland. She has restored arts to the district's curriculum. Signaling its importance, student artwork is the dominant motif in her office. 
Before migrating to the Midwest, Ms. Byrd-Bennett supervised New York City's Chancellor's District, a designation for its poorest performing schools, and a concept she imported to Cleveland by establishing C.E.O. Schools with increased academic and staff support. In fact, Ms. Byrd-Bennett's name emerged early on as a contender for the New York City chancellor position, or the deputy spot.
Cleveland is among a growing number of cities, including Chicago, Boston and Detroit, where mayors have taken over the public schools, arguing that centralization provides better integration of services and a single point of electoral accountability. In 1998, the Ohio Legislature removed responsibility for Cleveland's schools from an elected school board mired in charges of incompetence and corruption and gave it to the mayor, who appointed Ms. Byrd-Bennett. A voter referendum in November will determine whether the system will revert to control by an elected board, a move that Ms. Byrd-Bennett says would lead to her resignation. "Given the history in this town and what I have seen happen, most elected boards believe they are responsible to their constituencies, not to the children." 
Ms. Byrd-Bennett's district has also been at the heart of the voucher battle, and she remains opposed to the use of government funds for private-school tuition on the grounds that it siphons resources from public schools. About 4,000 Cleveland children receive up to $2,250 each, most to attend Catholic schools, as part of Ohio's seven-year-old voucher program. This summer, the United States Supreme Court declared the program constitutional. 
Ms. Byrd-Bennett thinks the Court was influenced by the financial and academic condition of Cleveland schools in the early 1990's, when the system was in state receivership. The ruling, she says, was made "in the context of the failures of the Cleveland schools that no longer exist."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Aforecaster predicts a recovery in the media sector, but not of the vigor seen in the past.

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the United States communications industry is expected to rebound in the second half of this year, it will no longer be one of the nation's top-three fastest growing industries, according to the widely followed annual forecast by the merchant bank Veronis Suhler Stevenson.
 And the bank, which plans to release its report today, does not expect the industry to recover from the current recession as robustly as it did from the last one 11 years ago. 
 In its 16th annual communications industry forecast, the bank, which specializes in the media, communications and information industries, said the last recovery had been fueled by the growth of the high-technology category, when the Internet was still in its infancy as a consumer medium.
"Tech spending has since cooled dramatically, and there is no equivalent new generator of advertising spending either developing or looming on the horizon," the report says. 
The bank also says the media industry's comparative growth rate is slowing. The bank said the communications industry will be the nation's fifth-fastest-growing segment of the economy from 2001 to 2006, at a 5.5 percent annual rate, on average. But it was the third fastest-growing from 1996 to 2001, when it grew 6.5 percent a year. And it was the second-fastest growing in 2000.
On a more positive note, Veronis Suhler Stevenson predicted that advertising spending would rise 2.9 percent this year, compared with a 6.2 percent drop in 2001, and that all communications spending -- including advertising and promotional expenditures, and spending by consumers and businesses on all media -- will increase 4.8 percent, to nearly $610 billion, after falling 0.3 percent last year.
Media categories expected to post the healthiest spending growth rates between 2001 and 2006 are consumer Internet, cable and satellite television, and radio, Veronis Suhler Stevenson said. Not coincidentally, all but radio are what the bank considers nonadvertising-supported media, whose usage by consumers is expected to continue rising, while that of advertising-supported media, like broadcast TV, will decline.
Veronis Suhler Stevenson's projections for advertising gains this year are somewhat more bullish than those by other industry analysts. Last month, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann, estimated that ad spending would grow 2.1 percent this year, while David Peeler, chief executive of advertising research firm CMR, earlier forecast a 2.5 percent gain.
Positive indicators have begun to emerge recently to set the stage for the industry's recovery, according to James P. Rutherfurd, executive vice president at Veronis Suhler Stevenson. He cited an increase in radio ad spending in the first quarter and an unexpectedly strong upfront buying season in the spring for broadcast television ads.
As the report predicts, "several other favorable economic indicators will prove positive for the communications industry by year's end, including increased business spending, low inventory levels, sustained low interest rates and the restoration of investor confidence."
Mr. Rutherfurd noted, "We then see a return to healthy growth, steady growth, non-Internet-inflated -- similar to the early to mid-1990's."
In preparing the forecast, Mr. Rutherfurd said Veronis Suhler Stevenson compared the communications industry's recent slowdown to its downturn during the 1991 recession, which was made worse by the Gulf War. He said recovery from the current recession would probably take longer than the last time and not be as vigorous.
"Advertising accounts for 30 percent of all communications spending and has a cyclical relationship with the economy," he said. "So as the economy improves, we expect advertising and therefore communications spending to grow in a parallel path."
One major bright spot in the forecast, is consumer spending on communications, which the report expects to rise 6.5 percent a year through 2006, mostly because of continued growth in spending on cable and satellite TV, consumer Internet, video games and box-office films.
Leo Kivijarv, director of research and publications at Veronis Suhler Stevenson, said that, compared with media consumers after the last recession, today's most influential consumers are "a younger audience, more technologically savvy, who spend on video games, DVD's, Internet access."
By 2006, he said, the average consumer will spend more than $100 annually on each of several media: cable or satellite television, home video and the Internet.
Consumers will continue to spend more time on nonadvertising supported media to the detriment of advertising-supported media, Veronis Suhler Stevenson predicts. In 1996, consumers spent slightly more than 68 percent of their media time on advertising-supported media, like broadcast television, magazines and newspapers, and nearly 32 percent on nonadvertising supported media, like recorded music and video games. But by last year, the report says, time spent on advertising-supported media had declined to 58.6 percent and is expected to drop further, to 56.3 percent, by 2006. 
The annual growth rate of spending on newspapers is forecast to rise 5.1 percent, from 2001 to 2006, while that of broadcast television is projected to increase 3.8 percent. Growth rates for spending are expected to be somewhat slower in consumer magazine publishing (3.2 percent), business-to-business media (3.1 percent) and consumer book publishing (2.8 percent).
And spending for recorded music is actually expected to decline 1.6 percent a year, on average, through 2006.

HEADLINE: What Voters Want 

BYLINE:  By Stanley B. Greenberg; Stanley B. Greenberg is chief executive of Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research and conducts national surveys with Public Opinion Strategies for National Public Radio.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Members of Congress are home for the annual August recess. No more all-night debates on the new Department of Homeland Security. No more failed compromises on a prescription drug benefit for seniors. No more lobbyists and Washington fund-raisers. It's back to family, friends and constituents for barbecues, visits to senior centers and trips to shopping malls.
 For members of Congress -- 98 percent of whom have been re-elected in recent years -- the August recess usually confirms that all politics is local. 
 But things are different this August. The country and all its people have lived through an extraordinary year, defined by searing events and inescapable symbols. People are haunted by the deaths of Sept. 11, the destruction of the World Trade Center and the still unsolved anthrax attack through the mail. This was followed by war in Afghanistan, and now the possibility of war with Iraq looms. 
Enron came to represent a new kind of villainy, as corporate executives cashed out and employees lost their jobs and pensions. Arthur Andersen did more shredding than accounting. Ken Lay and a parade of other chief executives who had run their companies into the ground slunk across the news. The WorldCom scam was followed by a stock market crash and the shrinking of once-flush 401(k) plans.
Meanwhile, revered public institutions, previously above criticism, came under intense public scrutiny. The scandal of pedophile priests forced the leaders of the American Catholic Church to struggle with the idea of accountability. And the top administrators of the Federal Bureau of Investigation faced public scorn when it became known that they ignored the warnings of F.B.I. field agents about terrorist attacks.
This unrelenting stream of bad news and broken faith has reshaped the public consciousness just as members of Congress head home. Nearly 75 percent of their constituents and likely voters say they are very angry about the Enron executives and their misdeeds, according to bipartisan national surveys conducted for National Public Radio. Nearly an identical percentage are very angry about chief executives taking lavish bonuses and perks as their companies fail and pensions lose value. 
With 74 percent of likely voters in next year's election owning stocks or having retirement accounts, the financial scandals hit close to home: Three in five of these voters report suffering losses this year. These voters are looking at substantially diminished college funds and retirement savings. 
A public consensus is emerging that the behavior evident in the Enron and other scandals reflects a bigger problem: people in powerful positions now feel free to act irresponsibly and hurt ordinary people, without fear of being held accountable.
It is not surprising that trauma from these scandals has in recent days overtaken the sense of national unity that existed in the months immediately after Sept. 11. Voters are moving toward a different set of conclusions about the country. In March, according to N.P.R. surveys, 60 percent of voters thought the country was headed in the right direction, and only 28 percent thought things were headed seriously off track. But in the last month, voters' moods have turned very dark. Just 36 percent still think things are going well, while 56 percent think things are headed in the wrong direction.
In the aftermath of Sept. 11, the public rallied around America's institutions, including Congress, but that feeling is gone. As recently as April, 52 percent of voters surveyed said they wanted to re-elect their member of Congress, but in the last month, many voters have moved to a different judgment: just 41 percent said they were likely to vote for the incumbent, while 42 percent said they now want somebody new.
President Bush is still a popular leader who gets high marks for managing the war on terrorism. And according to a recent poll by Public Opinion Strategies, terrorism is still the public's top concern. But that is not true when people focus on how they will vote for members of Congress. In that context, the war on terrorism slips to fifth place. According to N.P.R. surveys, the top issues for Congressional races are the economy and jobs (mentioned by 35 percent of respondents), Social Security and Medicare (24 percent), education (23 percent) and affordable health care (21 percent).
At senior centers, voters will be eager to talk about low interest on their savings accounts and the collapsed value of their investments, if they had any. They will almost certainly ask whether federal policymakers will make Social Security benefits dependent on the stock market. And of course, they will ask their representatives in Congress why they aren't doing anything about the cost of prescription drugs.
As members of Congress greet people back home, they will still have to deal with lingering fears of unknown terror, unrelieved by Congressional consideration of a new Department of Homeland Security. The country cannot easily take a break from the issues and remembrances that weigh it down. After this year's events, voters are worried about America's security, economy, retirement and corporations. During the summer recess, members of Congress will still take up issues like getting more money for schools, roads or county hospitals. But this year, not all politics will be local.

HEADLINE: Argentina's New Role Model: Its Old Rival, Brazil 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 

 BODY:
Argentina and Brazil have always been South America's odd couple, as different from and as suspicious of each other as the French and the Germans once were. 
 Brazilians have traditionally regarded Argentines as arrogant and excessively formal, while Argentines have tended to look down on Brazilians as darker happy-go-lucky inferiors wallowing in tropical indolence. 
 But no longer, at least on the Argentine side.
With their economy in ruins and their sixth president in less than a year begging to leave office, humbled Argentines are increasingly comparing themselves to Brazil and Brazilians and concluding that despite Brazil's own recent difficulties, there is much to admire and emulate, from governance to lifestyle.
Argentines today "are like new converts to a religion who feel they have to prove their faith is more intense than that of old believers" said Oscar Raul Cardoso, a foreign affairs columnist for Clarin, a leading daily here. "There definitely has been a change of attitude and perception regarding Brazil, and I don't see any going back." 
Evidence of what is called "the Brazilian wave" here is everywhere. Bars and nightclubs with Brazilian names are considered the height of fashion, and while Argentines have been interested in Brazilian music since the days of Carmen Miranda, there is a new fascination with Brazilian dances and learning capoeira, an Afro-Brazilian martial art.
Enrollment in Portuguese language classes has surged, in part driven by the hope of finding work in Brazil, and Brazilian television programs are carried on cable. In this most Europeanized of Latin American countries, even Afro-Brazilian religions like candomble are making inroads, with several terreiros, or temples, now operating here and frequented by white Argentines.
"Brazilians are warmer, happier and more amusing and open than Argentines, more comfortable in their own skins, I guess I would say," explained Gustavo Tedesco, 38, a veterinarian who has visited Brazil six times. "We need to learn from them how to be more cordial and less pedantic."
As he and his girlfriend, Luciana Casanova, 22, relaxed at a Brazilian nightclub here called Maluco Beleza, or Crazy Beauty, she added: "Brazilians just know how to enjoy life more and aren't obsessed with the dollar. They have their problems there too, but they don't let themselves get bogged down in melancholy the way we do."
The fascination with things Brazilian precedes the current crisis, the worst in modern Argentine history. But it has accelerated and broadened as a result of the collapse of the economy, during which the United States and Europe have largely stood by refusing to help while Brazil has emerged as Argentina's leading advocate and model.
Since taking office in January, President Eduardo Duhalde has repeatedly pointed to Brazil as a successful developing economy, particularly since its decision in 1999 to allow the value of its currency to decrease instead of keeping it pegged to the dollar.
Mr. Duhalde's economic ministers have consulted regularly with their Brazilian counterparts, especially Arminio Fraga, his country central bank president, who has visited here.
"Brazil has done a lot of things right and we have made a lot of mistakes," said Marcos Aguinis, a former Argentine culture minister and author of "The Intolerable Charm of Being Argentine." 
"They have become a formidable industrial power with an imaginative business class, which we don't have," Mr. Aguinis said. "And while we are still struggling to overcome the legacy of Juan Peron, they seem to have been able to erase the populism of Getulio Vargas," the Brazilian dictator of the 1930's and early 40's.
Most analysts agree that the main factor in demolishing stereotypes of Brazil here was rise of Argentine tourism during the 1990's, thanks to an artificially strong Argentine peso that was worth the same as a United States dollar and allowed even lower-class Argentines to travel abroad. 
As a result, the number of Argentines visiting Brazil rose from about 250,000 in 1990 to 1.75 million in 2000, according to Brazilian government statistics.
"Before mass tourism began, Brazil was like a dark spot on the map to most Argentines," said Alejandro Frigerio, an anthropologist and sociologist here, "and going there was like going to Timbuktu. But when you land in Sao Paulo you see right away that Brazil is a serious, developed, functioning country. And since our country is not, the old stereotype of the Brazilians as inferiors, as monkeys, has given way to a new, highly idealized image."
More often than not, the Argentines who have returned from their vacations in Brazil bedazzled by what they have seen "want to understand and know more, about literature and fashion and the language," said Monica Hirst, director of the Brazilian Studies Center and Foundation here. "Brazil is now perceived as a more sophisticated and interesting place. Even racism against Brazilians has decreased enormously."
Since 1991, Argentina and Brazil have also the leaders of Mercosur, the South American Common Market, now the third-largest trading bloc in the world. That association has not only "inculcated an ideology of brotherhood and cooperation," as Dr. Frigerio puts it, it has also required Argentina to shelve its own aspirations as a regional power and recognize Brazil as "the senior partner in Mercosur," the phrase most often used by newspapers here.
As early as the 1940's, Peron's grandiose geopolitical reveries envisioned what he called "the ABC alliance," composed of Argentina, Brazil and Chile. He assumed that Argentina would emerge as the natural leader of that group, with Brazil playing a secondary role. But Argentine strategists now recognize that since Brazil's population and economy are five times as large as their own, it is pointless to resist Brazilian hegemony.
"Argentina is becoming a sort of extension of Rio Grande do Sul, part of a larger polity, and maybe that's not so bad," said Carlos Escude, an author of several books on Argentine foreign policy, referring to Brazil's southernmost state, which borders Argentina. "We would rather not be anyone's satellite, but there is far less opposition to our being a star in the Brazilian flag than a star in the American flag."
Though trade within the bloc has been hurt by the collapse of the Argentine economy and the current market turbulance in Brazil, the two countries nonetheless continue to talk of adopting a single currency. 
The two governments have also agreed to undertake joint trade missions abroad and are even discussing putting Argentine diplomats into Brazilian embassies in places like Africa, where Argentina has had to close many of its own embassies as an economy measure.
A few members of the military, mostly retirees trained since their days as cadets to think of Brazil as the enemy, continue to resist the reconciliation, as have some business groups that have lost their markets to Brazilian companies. Though theirs is clearly a minority view, Ms. Hirst argues that Brazilians cannot afford to take Argentina's new empathy for granted.
"It is one thing to perceive the other as a partner and a strategic option when you're feeling good about yourself," she said. "It's an altogether different situation when you feel that you have no other choices, so even as this crisis breaks down barriers and prejudices, we need to remember that there are also risks."

HEADLINE: Bolivia Congress Picks Ex-Leader Over Coca Advocate 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 4 

 BODY:
Bolivia's Congress ended a presidential tie today, picking an American-educated millionaire, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, to lead the country as it confronts economic malaise and growing social unrest.
 Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, a mining executive and a political centrist who was president from 1993 to 1997, won by a congressional vote of 84-43 over Evo Morales, a radical Indian leader of Bolivia's coca growers. 
 The men were the top two vote-getters in a national election in June, but neither won an outright majority, forcing a vote in Congress.
Two congressman left their votes blank today, while 26 voted for Manfred Reyes Villa. 
The Legislature convened Saturday and debated for more than 24 hours. Each of the 157 members gave a speech, with some wearing multicolored Indian clothing and speaking in indigenous languages. Others chewed coca leaf, the base material of cocaine but also a part of centuries-old Indian culture in the Andes.
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada assured his victory in the vote more than a week ago by securing an alliance with his rival, Jaime Paz Zamora, a leftist former president. 
Known by the nickname "Goni," Mr. Sanchez de Lozada spent most of his youth in the United States and still speaks Spanish with an American accent that is often the brunt of jokes among Bolivians. He grew up in Washington, where his father was a diplomat, and later studied philosophy and English literature at the University of Chicago.
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada will face an opposition galvanized by the blunt-talking Mr. Morales, whose Movement to Socialism party has given Bolivia's downtrodden Indian majority a strong political voice.
Mr. Morales fiercely opposes a program backed by the United States that has wiped out most coca plantations, while Mr. Sanchez de Lozada has vowed to continue the eradication effort. Washington heralds the program as a shining success in its war on cocaine, but eradication has led to deadly clashes between farmers and security forces.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS; 
A Trout-Centric History Of Montana, With Latte

BYLINE:  By James Gorman 

DATELINE: BIG SKY, Mont. 

 BODY:
I caught an alien the other day, a fish from one of those aggressive, invasive species that can take over an ecosystem in the time it takes to tie an improved clinch knot.
 It was not the northern snakehead, the fish that walks on land and breathes air. Nor was it a lionfish, with poisonous spines and a greedy eye on the niches now occupied by East Coast grouper and snappers, or an Asian swamp eel, another opportunistic air breather now wriggling around the boundaries of the Everglades, plotting a hostile takeover. 
 The creature I caught was a Montana rainbow trout, as bright as the light on the stream it came from, as treasured, by fishermen, as clean water, but an invader nonetheless. 
Rainbows, as most anglers know, are interlopers in Montana. They are native to river systems farther west. And brown trout, of course, are native to Europe.
These invaders are celebrated rather than feared -- at least by humans -- but they showed no mercy to native cutthroats and grayling as they pushed them aside. And like other invaders, they had an economic and cultural impact far beyond the river ecosystems they changed. 
I was thinking about these effects when I took a break from fishing to pick up an iced latte at a drive-through espresso bar, and later when I tasted the bison and chevre empanadas at the Big Sky food festival. I also thought about it when I talked to people here and in the nearby town of Bozeman who were from New York and Minnesota and other parts east, and when I chatted with a recent emigrant from Los Angeles at the Salt Lake City airport. 
What I thought was: Look what fishing can do to a place.
There are still a few people left in Montana who were born here. I even know one or two. Eastern Montana, far from the Rockies and deep in drought, is full of them. But in cities like Bozeman, rimmed by mountains and graced with magnificent rivers, my unscientific survey suggests that the alien invaders, with their salsa and their fine cabernets, are spreading like rainbow trout.
My theory is that the alien fish species caused the human invasion. I know there are other factors contributing to Montana's popularity, like the Rocky Mountains, Glacier National Park, Yellowstone National Park, grizzly bears and wolves, pure mountain lakes, evergreen forests, skiing, hiking, kayaking and a night sky that makes you want to break up into your component atoms and float into the Milky Way. Still, I think it's mostly about the trout.
Here's my capsule trout-centric version of Montana history. In 1889, rainbows and brown trout were introduced to Montana. They loved it and just took over. It was, "Me first, and the devil take the cutthroats." 
In short order, fly-fishing for the new trout began drawing well-paying sports from the East and enchanting the young Norman Maclean, who eventually wrote "A River Runs Through It." Then Robert Redford made the movie, and the whole world bought rods and vests and came to Montana. Now, as long as you stay near mountains and trout streams, a fine wine and chai tea are right around the corner.
The good thing about trout as invaders is that they don't wreck the neighborhood, from a human point of view. The Gallatin River, as it winds through canyon walls and evergreen-lined banks, or flat meadow sections, is as lovely as a river can be. One evening, I fished in a stretch that runs through meadows, just above Yellowstone Park, and in a windy, darkening sky, two bald eagles flew close overhead, tussling in the air.
And if the hatch of rental S.U.V.'s along the Gallatin's many turnouts feels oppressive, you can seek a bit of room up Taylor Creek, past the warning signs for grizzlies. It all feels wild, even if the management of trout rivers is intensive. 
I suppose every invasive species has its good and bad points. Snakeheads might serve as a common enemy, thus uniting people from different backgrounds and restoring a sense of community. 
The trout and the trout anglers they attract may cause a troubling amount of residential construction and high real estate prices, but then, they also brought fine cuisine. I'm not going to come down too hard on big-city ways, since I also traveled this summer in northeast Montana, red-meat rangeland, where chicken is considered a vegetable.
If you want to be a true Pollyanna, you might hope that since many human immigrants to the state are entranced by fishing, they want to protect the health of forests and rivers.
I spent a fair amount of time visiting fly shops along the Gallatin, and received a wide range of advice on what to use -- big attractor flies with bead-head nymph droppers, small caddis dries and emergers, and baetis emergers. That last bit of advice turned out to be quite good. On Taylor Creek, I drifted a CDC baetis emerger with a microshot through the fast runs, using a small, foam strike indicator. 
I was prepared for a subtle hesitation, or the line stopping for a moment. But instead the strike indicator suddenly dashed across the stream, and the rainbow danced on the water as I brought it in. 
That was a lovely moment, and I really should have thanked the trout, the way American Indians thanked the animals they hunted, for letting me catch it and savor its beauty. I also should have thanked it for the bison empanada, although the crab cake with remoulade and spiced apple chutney was even better.

HEADLINE: EASING ITS STANCE, U.S. OFFERS LOANS TO NATION IN CRISIS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, softening its stance against financial help for struggling countries, said today that it would grant up to $1.5 billion in short-term loans to Uruguay, an infusion that should allow its banks to reopen Monday morning.
 The loan, announced after emergency legislation was passed in Uruguay to help quell the nation's economic crisis, would be the first of its sort by the Bush administration to assist another country directly in a financial crisis. It is the latest sign that a worsening economic picture in Latin America is forcing the administration to reconsider such aid. 
 Bush officials had long asserted that such assistance -- which was common during the Clinton administration -- is often wasted or unfair to American taxpayers, and that it makes little sense to lend money to countries already facing unsustainable debt loads until they take steps to restructure their finances. 
But they said today that they expect that the loan will be repaid within days, once Uruguay receives a longer-term package of loans from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Inter-American Development Bank that will bring total assistance to Uruguay to $3.8 billion.
The announcement in Washington came as Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill landed in Brazil on the first leg of a trip aimed at helping to reassure Latin American officials about the United States' attention to the troubled regional economy. The financial crisis that enveloped Argentina early this year -- leading the nation to default on $141 billion in debt -- has spread turmoil to Uruguay, Brazil and other Latin American nations, causing their currencies to fall in value and raising fears of major defaults on debt payments, including money owed to United States banks and investors.
Mr. O'Neill said tonight that the loan would "help Uruguay address the intense external pressures it has faced in recent months" and that it was made in recognition of "the extraordinary actions and commitments by the Uruguayan authorities to address these pressures."
Mr. O'Neill continued to backtrack from off-the-cuff comments he made a week ago in which he suggested that financial assistance to emerging-markets countries carries the risk that funds would be diverted by corrupt officials. 
"A government that puts in place and follows through on such strong economic policies merits the consistent support of the international financial institutions and the United States," Mr. O'Neill said tonight.
Administration officials asserted that the package for Uruguay, because of its size and duration, is nothing like the much bigger bailouts during the Clinton administration, including aid to Asian nations in 1997 and 1998 and to Mexico in 1995. A Treasury spokesman added that officials saw "no risk" to the Exchange Stabilization Fund, the account that will provide the money.
John B. Taylor, the Treasury under secretary for international affairs, said tonight that the I.M.F. and the other banks continued to be the "instruments of choice" for this sort of aid. He said the Treasury Department only intervened because "the Uruguayans want to open their banking system" on Monday -- before the funds from the I.M.F. and other banks arrive. Tonight, the I.M.F., World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank confirmed that they had asked their boards to approve the financing this week.
In 1995, the Clinton administration was attacked by some Congressional Republicans over its decision to use the Exchange Stabilization Fund for the bailout of Mexico. Tonight, Mr. Taylor said Congressional leaders had been informed about the Uruguayan financing, though he did not say who was contacted or whether the plan was endorsed. The $1.5 billion figure, he added, represents the amount needed to back 100 percent of the Uruguayan deposits that would be available for immediate withdrawal once the banks reopen.
While this is the first intervention of this sort by the Bush administration, Mr. Taylor said "bridge loans" like this one were common "all through the 80's into the 90's."
Still, the loan helps to illustrate how the Bush administration has moved in a short time to soften its criticism of financial assistance to struggling economies, as it reacts to the threat of economic contagion and political instability in Latin America.
Just last week, Mr. O'Neill roiled financial markets and created a diplomatic flap when he suggested on the television program "Fox News Sunday" that to obtain additional aid, Latin American nations needed policies to "assure that, as assistance money comes, that it does some good and it doesn't just go out of the country to Swiss bank accounts."
The comments contributed to driving down the value of the Brazilian currency, the real, by about 14 percent in the next three days, and helped lead to a sharp sell-off in Brazilian debt. 
But the panic selling abruptly reversed course on Thursday, when Mr. O'Neill publicly retreated from his earlier comments, saying that Brazilian economic leaders had "done a remarkable job of maintaining sound fiscal and monetary policies." Explicitly signaling support for additional aid from the I.M.F. to Brazil -- which are in talks now for a multibillion-dollar package -- he added, "I continue to favor support for Brazil and other nations that take appropriate steps to build sound, sustainable and growing economies."
After Mr. O'Neill's about-face, the Brazilian real soared by nearly 10 percent, its largest one-day gain. A sliding currency makes it more difficult for Brazil to make payments on its more than $250 billion in debt, much of which is owed to American financial institutions or denominated in United States dollars.
Mr. O'Neill arrived today in Rio de Janeiro, and he is scheduled to meet with Brazilian officials and then travel to Uruguay and Argentina to meet with officials there.
The financing package came after Uruguayan lawmakers approved legislation that would prevent certain long-term deposits from being withdrawn for three years. Uruguay, a country of 3.4 million people tucked between Argentina and Brazil, has been likened to Switzerland for its relatively stable financial institutions. But in the growing crisis, most of the nation's banking reserves -- more than $2 billion -- had been depleted by nervous depositors before the banks were closed Tuesday.
Gene Sperling, who coordinated economic policy in Clinton administration's second term, praised the move to aid Uruguay but said it represented a clear policy shift for the Bush administration as it faces the threat of economic contagion in Latin America.
"This is an appropriate policy shift brought about by economic reality," Mr. Sperling said. "It's one thing to make a categorical statement during a campaign denying the existence of contagion," he said. "It's another thing to confront contagion like in Uruguay."

Violent Day in Mideast Begins With Bus Bombing
A powerful bomb ripped apart an Israeli commuter bus in northern Galilee, igniting a fireball that killed 9 people and wounded 45, beginning a burst of Palestinian violence that defied Israel's tough crackdown. A shootout near the Damascus Gate in Jerusalem's Old City left three people dead; two ambushes wounded seven Israelis; and a fifth attack in the West Bank killed a married couple. The Islamic group Hamas claimed responsibility for the bus bombing. A1

U.S. Grants Uruguay a Loan
The Bush administration said it would grant up to $1.5 billion in short-term loans to Uruguay, an infusion that should allow its banks to reopen this morning. The loan, announced after emergency legislation was passed in Uruguay to help quell the nation's economic crisis, would be the first of its sort by the Bush administration to assist another country directly in a financial crisis. A1

China Condemns Speech
The Chinese government angrily condemned a speech on Saturday by President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, who said that Taiwan and China were two separate countries and endorsed legislation to allow a referendum on Taiwanese independence. The Chinese reacted even as Taiwanese officials sought to play down some of President Chen's stronger remarks. A5

More North Koreans Fleeing
Beijing has been trying to stanch the flow of North Korean refugees, after a string of high-profile defections into the safety of foreign embassies in China this year. But accounts from refugees who have made their way into China show that this large-scale migration is likely to continue, in what is both a crucial safety valve for the crumbling North Korean economy and a threat to the country's stability. A5

Dangerous Trek in Kashmir
More than 100,000 Hindu pilgrims over the course of a month will hike at least 19 miles, sleep in freezing temperatures above 10,000 feet and brave attacks from Muslim militants all for a glimpse of a nine-foot-tall ice stalagmite. Shaped like a phallus, it is considered the symbol of Lord Shiva, one of Hinduism's three most revered gods. A6

Bolivian President Chosen
Bolivia's Congress ended a presidential tie, voting 84-43 for an American-educated millionaire, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, to lead the country as it confronts economic malaise and growing social unrest. A4

Car Bomb in Spain Kills 2
Two people, including a 6-year-old girl, were killed when a powerful car bomb exploded outside a police barracks in Santa Pola, a southern tourist town. Officials blamed the attack on the Basque separatist group E.T.A. About 25 people were injured, a local official said. (Reuters)

Bilingual Teachers Lagging As Immigrants Increase
A wave of new immigrants has left school districts across the country facing a desperate shortage of bilingual teachers. There are 50,000 such teachers in the United States, or one for every 100 students with limited English skills. The number of students with limited English skills has doubled to five million in the last decade. A1

Return of the Mayfly (and How)
In an unheralded and sometimes annoying consequence of cleaner waterways, mayflies are swarming around the Mississippi in greater numbers than they have in half a century. They have to be shoveled from riverside streets and scraped from bridges with snowplows. A1

The miners did not speak during the service, attended by religious leaders from different denominations, but they posed for photos outside with those in attendance. (AP)

HEADLINE: The Americas Prepare for Trade On a Fast Track 

BYLINE:  By Walter Russell Mead; Walter Russell Mead, author of "Special Providence: American Foreign Policy and How It Changed the World," is a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
In a big and badly needed win for the Bush administration, the House and Senate last week gave the president trade-promotion authority. Future trade agreements negotiated through 2007 can only be approved or rejected by Congress as they stand (no amendments allowed), vastly increasing the ability of the administration to negotiate trade deals with foreign nations.
 The bill gave the president virtually everything he wanted. Trade critics dropped amendments that would have given Congress a veto over agreements that might endanger American antidumping rules. Provisions offering greater protection for American workers adversely affected by free trade were curtailed to suit Republicans. 
 Passage of trade-promotion authority contributes to the recent upturn in relations with Europe. Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, and his European counterpart, Pascal Lamy, have struggled together to contain an increasingly contentious set of trade irritants -- most recently, European anger over steel-import restrictions imposed by President Bush on March 20. So far, the European Union has resisted pressure to impose draconian sanctions in retaliation; passage of trade-promotion authority makes a trans-Atlantic trade war even less likely.
It will also invigorate the Doha round of negotiations, which aim to liberalize trade among all 144 members of the World Trade Organization. The Doha agenda emphasizes integrating poorer countries into the international system; given that lower wages and other costs are usually critical to the global competitiveness of less developed nations, trade agreements under the Doha rubric may be particularly sensitive in Congress. Trade-promotion authority will make such agreements far more likely.
For now, the new politics of trade may count most in Latin America, now threatened by the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. With Argentina and Brazil engulfed in economic chaos, with continuing unrest in Venezuela, civil war in Colombia, and political instability in Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru -- and with both Uruguay and Paraguay now embroiled in the aftereffects of the crises in Brazil and Argentina -- the Bush administration faces an extraordinary set of hemispheric challenges.
Trade-promotion authority is a vital tool for dealing with Latin America's economic problems. The one major Latin economy that has so far escaped a meltdown is Mexico -- which is also the one Latin American country that has a free-trade agreement with the United States. Despite initial complications, Mexican access to United States markets has served to keep foreign investors interested and to keep Mexican factories working even as the rest of the region melts down.
Trade-promotion authority is particularly welcome because the Bush administration has reached something of a deadlock with Argentina and Brazil over their requests for additional assistance from the International Monetary Fund. The political instability in both countries makes it virtually impossible for their governments to accept the tough conditions that the I.M.F. and its guiding force, the United States Treasury Department -- justifiably suspicious after so many failures in the past -- want to put on new money. While free trade won't provide a quick fix for these economies, conclusion of an agreement would offer hope in the long and medium terms.
Even trade-promotion authority may not be enough to get a hemispheric Free Trade Area of the Americas pact done by 2005, as the administration still hopes to do. Consider the orange. Currently, Brazilian orange juice exports to the United States must pay $418 a ton in tariffs, roughly equivalent to 40 percent of the value of the juice. With an estimated 90,000 Florida jobs dependent on citrus, a president who carried that state by 537 votes will not be eager to cut orange-juice tariffs.
However, lack of a full blown Free Trade Area of the Americas won't discourage smaller initiatives and may make them seem more urgent. Last week's legislation reauthorizes the Andean Trade Preference Act, which is intended to wean countries like Bolivia and Colombia off drug exports. A promising agreement with Chile should soon be concluded. Although labor rights issues could complicate matters, an agreement with the Central American republics is likely to move forward now.
There is even speculation that Argentina and Brazil will follow Chile and negotiate bilateral agreements with the United States. Their collapsing economies can no longer hope to build their common market, Mercosur, into a strong regional entity that could negotiate on a more equal basis with the United States. As a result, both countries might want to lock in limited, bilateral agreements with the United States now -- as Argentina and Chile already have with the European Union -- while trusting to the Doha negotiations to pressure the United States to open agricultural markets.
All this leaves the United States looking strong. If the European Union or Japan -- or the poorer countries that make up a large majority of the W.T.O.'s membership -- don't make enough concessions to the United States in the Doha talks, Washington can negotiate favorable bilateral deals with countries eager to gain access to its immense consumer market, which is almost 20 percent of world imports.
Last week's trade bill was also a signal victory for the Republican Party (Bill Clinton failed in three tries to get trade-promotion authority through Congress). Trade negotiations are about horse trading; now Republican officials have the chance to decide what products to push and where to make compromises on trade deals that will affect the future of key industries and states. These efforts will be remembered by corporations when it comes time for campaign contributions.
The bill is a major defeat for free-trade critics (or fair-trade advocates) even though its provisions would pay 65 percent of the health-insurance premiums of workers displaced by free trade. Business interests that lobbied for this law will lobby even harder for actual trade agreements that offer them specific benefits. Failure to block trade promotion authority makes it much harder to block future trade agreements.
With plunging stock markets, rising budget deficits, violence in the Middle East, corporate scandals at home and economic meltdowns in Latin America, the world remains a dark and stormy place for the Bush administration. Nevertheless, trade-promotion authority will give the administration some badly needed traction as it grapples with a global economy that is weakening.

HEADLINE: Affleck and Damon Find Real-Life Obstacles to Their Media Venture 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 

 BODY:
There is a moment in the movie "The Sum of All Fears," this summer's Tom Clancy spy thriller starring Ben Affleck, when Mr. Affleck's character, a naive agent, realizes that an unforeseen disaster has changed his world, altering his outlook and making him wary. 
 The same might be said of Mr. Affleck and his partners in LivePlanet, the fledgling film-television-Internet venture founded by Mr. Affleck, his best friend, the actor Matt Damon, and the producers Sean Bailey and Chris Moore. 
 LivePlanet, which seeks to integrate the Internet into mainstream entertainment programming, was one of the chosen few Internet-related start-ups to receive venture capital financing last year, in the aftermath of the dot-com disaster. The company also weathered the negative publicity of Mr. Affleck's drinking and gambling problems last year, which provided endless fodder for the tabloids. But last September, LivePlanet's luck seemed to have run out. 
After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, ABC decided to scrap plans to run LivePlanet's ambitious reality television series, "The Runner." The show was to have been a nationwide audience-participation manhunt, in which television viewers could phone in sightings and tips on the whereabouts of the program's contestant-on-the-run or track the target's movements online. If the runner was caught, the person who found him or her could have won up to $1 million. If the runner eluded detection, it was the runner who won the money. 
Since the cancellation of "The Runner," LivePlanet's staff has dwindled from a high of 63, which had included 19 software programmers in Silicon Valley, to 14 employees these days at the company's offices in Santa Monica, Calif. Mr. Affleck and his three partners have spent much of the $12 million investors gave them. And the four have explored splitting up or selling the company -- discussions that at times have tested their friendship. 
Fanning their hopes just now are a contract to produce a second season of the documentary series "Project Greenlight," for HBO; a drama series produced by LivePlanet, "Push, Nevada," that ABC has scheduled for this fall; and a film production deal with the Walt Disney Company that could be announced as soon as this week. But the firm's ups and downs have taught Mr. Affleck and his three partners that success is by no means certain.
"It's been a collectively humbling experience," Mr. Affleck said in an interview last week. 
LivePlanet's executives have come to the same realization that media giants like AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and Vivendi Universal have reached with greater financial consequence. While lip-service has been paid to combining film, television and the Internet into a one-stop media shop, compelling content is still difficult to produce and original ideas remain hard to come by. 
Many analysts agree that the long-predicted "convergence" of old and new media will flourish only if broadcast and cable networks are willing to risk ratings for innovation -- a gamble that may be unthinkable in the current economic climate for media companies. 
"The reality is that despite all the noise in the media, more people are online and interested in new forms of television," said Christopher Dixon, a media analyst at UBS Warburg. "The question is how do you create a cultural phenomenon that gets people talking around the water cooler?" 
Until an answer emerges, LivePlanet is relying on more traditional entertainment outlets. That includes the two-year movie deal with Disney that the two companies say is close to being signed. As part of the agreement, Disney gets a right of first refusal to finance or distribute movies that LivePlanet wants to make. 
If making movies for Disney sounds decidedly old-media, LivePlanet's partners explain that they simply do not have the heft to buck the current trend. 
"When you have the chief executive of AOL Time Warner saying on the front page of the newspaper, 'Convergence is dead,' then it makes it pretty tough for a little company like ours; that's why we had to diversify," said Mr. Moore, LivePlanet's chief executive, who previously was the producer of the "American Pie" movies as well as the 1997 film "Good Will Hunting," which starred and was written by Mr. Affleck and Mr. Damon. 
Certainly, Disney seems ready for new ideas, in light of its box-office disappointments. Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer known for his big summer blockbusters, bombed with "Bad Company," the action film starring Anthony Hopkins and Chris Rock. And "The Country Bears," Disney's attempt to capitalize on its theme park attractions, has brought in only an estimated $11.7 million during its first two weeks, through today, tying for last place among new releases.. 
"They look at the business differently, and we want that," Richard Cook, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, said of LivePlanet. 
Thinking differently is what led to LivePlanet's HBO hit "Project Greenlight," the Emmy-nominated documentary series that follows the winner of an online screenwriting and directing contest as he or she makes a film. LivePlanet is expected to begin accepting contest submissions in September for the second season.
Meanwhile, the Disney deal buys time for LivePlanet to pursue more experimental projects. The company has been forced to curb its early ambitions -- which Mr. Bailey once described as a cross of Turner Broadcasting and Electronic Arts, referring to Ted Turner's television empire and the cultish following among players of Electronic Arts' computer and video game software. 
A case of curtailed fancy is "General Manager," the documentary LivePlanet plans to produce next year for HBO about a minor league baseball team. When Mr. Bailey conceived the idea, he hoped to invest in several teams, perhaps even start a new league, enabling viewers at home and online to run them by popular vote. The concept never took full flight, Mr. Bailey said, because "the big media companies couldn't get their hands around it." 
As now planned, "General Manager" will focus on an existing team -- not yet disclosed -- that has agreed to go along with the idea. The plan is to allow the audience to vote on such moves as naming the starting lineup, benching players and even picking cheerleaders.
Then there is "Push, Nevada." Recently, on a 90-degree afternoon on the set of the series, just north of Los Angeles, Mr. Moore was meeting with Mr. Bailey in his sweltering office, which did not have benefit of air-conditioning. 
The series, scheduled to run on ABC Thursday nights at 9, opposite the popular crime drama "CSI" on CBS, is a drama created by Mr. Bailey and Mr. Affleck. Its story line involves an I.R.S. agent searching for embezzled money in a small town 
Like the ill-fated "Runner," "Push, Nevada" will place a viewer-participation game within the frame of a television show. But unlike "Runner," "Push, Nevada" is not a live event, which proved to be a daunting production challenge, causing friction for LivePlanet and the show's backers at ABC. 
"We learned from that," Mr. Bailey said. 
"Push, Nevada" is more manageable than "The Runner" because it follows a script, he said, which among other benefits makes it easier to integrate clues into the storyline, like phone numbers viewers can call or Web sites they can visit. But the game is only secondary to the plot. The program is meant to fail or succeed on its own dramatic merits -- or lack of them. 
Before "The Runner" was canceled, LivePlanet in some months was spending a combined $750,000 on that series and "Project Greenlight" and their two related Web sites, Mr. Moore said. By contrast the company's monthly operating costs now average $125,000, he said. 
"There was this moment last year when we said to ourselves, 'Are we too early? Are people ready for this?' " Mr. Moore said. "You could like look at this and say, 'We are crazy, chasing after windmills.' " 
The notion set Mr. Bailey and Mr. Moore to laughing, as Mr. Bailey described a Don Quixote scene with the four friends astride donkeys, charging haplessly toward a hazy apparition at the top of a hill. 
"Picture the conversation," Mr. Bailey said, turning to Mr. Moore and pointing skyward. "That looks like a windmill, but maybe it's a bank full of money. Who knows? We're too far away. We can't see it."
After "Runner" was canceled, LivePlanet needed a new source of revenue. Earlier this year, Mr. Moore said, he and his partners approached several large media companies about buying LivePlanet to have a distributor for their programs. "People said it was a genius idea, but no one bit," Mr. Moore said.
So he sought outside financing, talking to investors in this country and abroad. Redpoint Ventures, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm that had originally invested $10 million, was willing to give LivePlanet more money. But Mr. Moore and his partners wanted to expand beyond LivePlanet's original business plan, bymaking traditional movies, for example, eventually leading to the Disney deal. 
But along the way, discouraged, Mr. Moore suggested to his partners, all of whom he has known nearly a decade, that maybe they should split up and each pursue their separate projects. Mr. Damon, in fact, had been spending less time than the other three on LivePlanet projects as he focus on his acting career. Mr. Affleck was also busy and, at times, hard to reach. (He has been spending much of his free time in New York lately, now that he is dating Jennifer Lopez.) And running the company was beginning to wear on Mr. Moore. 
But the partners' professional, as well as personal, lives have long intersected and invariably bring them together. When Mr. Affleck entered a Malibu rehabilitation clinic last summer, for instance, he said Mr. Damon stepped in to promote the beer brewer Samuel Adams, one of the main sponsors of "Project Greenlight." 
And when LivePlanet was in the midst of testy six-month negotiations earlier this year over the rights to future "Project Greenlight" endeavors with Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, it was Mr. Affleck who defended LivePlanet.
Mr. Weinstein recalled that he had wanted to extend the "Project Greenlight" brand, perhaps into fashion, but that the LivePlanet partners "were protective of something they felt close to." 
As Mr. Affleck remembers it, he himself wanted more control over the type of commercial projects that he and Mr. Damon would attach their names to. "When the line is blurred between perception and reality," Mr. Affleck said, "it wasn't worth it to get fleeced." 
For now at least, the four LivePlanet partners say they have enough cash to run the business for two years and have decided to stick together. "The most selfish answer is we have fun," said Mr. Moore. "It's easier to fight battles in Hollywood together than by yourself." 
Mr. Affleck, pondering this real-life sum of all business fears, added: "If we stick around long enough and convince people we can do these things, we will matter in the new economy. I'd like to slip to the last page to see how it ends. But who knows."
