HEADLINE: Policing Wall Street 

 BODY:
The White House and Congress have done an abrupt about-face about corporate malfeasance this summer, belatedly recognizing the need to crack down on financial chicanery in the executive suite. Whether the rush to reform is translated into a new era of stricter law enforcement now depends largely on whether the Securities and Exchange Commission can snap out of the coma it fell into during the first year of the Bush administration. 
 The S.E.C., created in the aftermath of the 1929 market crash to protect the integrity of financial markets, was aptly described as "the investor's advocate" by William O. Douglas, a chairman of the commission in the 1930's before becoming a Supreme Court justice. When energetically managed, it serves both as Wall Street's cop and rule maker, regulating the stock markets and ensuring that companies that sell stock to the public provide accurate and timely financial reports. The commission can, and should, strike fear in the boardroom, as it did in the 1970's when Stanley Sporkin, a hard-charging chief of enforcement, brought high-profile cases against United Brands, Lockheed and Robert Vesco, an international financier. 
 Until the recent wave of corporate abuses, President Bush and his S.E.C. chairman, Harvey Pitt, were singing from the deregulation hymnal and doing their best to weaken the commission. The S.E.C. today is badly in need of an infusion of money and manpower. Its 3,000 staff members represent a growth of 20 percent in the last decade, a time when its workload, by most measures, has more than doubled. The agency has been devastated by high turnover rates. It wasn't until last month -- after the collapse of Enron and WorldCom and all the other corporate disasters -- that Mr. Bush asked Congress for a still-insufficient $100 million increase to the S.E.C.'s budget.
Mr. Pitt, who worked alongside Mr. Sporkin as the S.E.C.'s general counsel but later became a highly paid lawyer for the accounting industry, has presided over a flurry of enforcement activity in reaction to the scandals, but he has been far too timid in addressing some of the systemic problems that led to the betrayal of so many investors. Mr. Pitt has ordered the chief executives of major corporations to certify their companies' financial reports by Aug. 14. That's fine, but it doesn't begin to make up for his lax approach in regulating the practices of Wall Street firms and the accounting industry. 
We continue to believe that Mr. Pitt is ill suited to lead the S.E.C. during these critical days, but if Mr. Bush sticks with him, one measure of Mr. Pitt's leadership will be found in whether he appoints tough regulators to the new accounting oversight board created by Congress.
Mr. Pitt must also strongly support the work of the commission's four operational divisions, all led by capable directors. The corporate finance division, charged with reviewing the filings of 15,000 public companies, is particularly overwhelmed. As the front line in detecting accounting irregularities, it needs a substantial increase in staff. Last year it reviewed only 16 percent of corporate reports it received. 
The market regulation division, which oversees the exchanges and brokers, needs to be more vigorous in fighting Wall Street's glaring conflicts of interest. These involve the corrupt allocation of initial public offering shares and the hyping of stocks by analysts to please banking clients. 
The investment management division regulates all types of investment vehicles. It should tighten oversight of the secretive world of hedge funds and require greater transparency on the part of mutual funds.
The enforcement division investigates securities law violations and can bring civil cases. Its director, Stephen Cutler, is highly respected, and Mr. Pitt must allow him to vigorously pursue all cases, even such sensitive ones as the inquiry into Halliburton's accounting practices during Dick Cheney's tenure as chief executive. The corporate reform law's toughened criminal liabilities on executives who mislead investors will mean little if the S.E.C. fails to pursue such cases or does not refer them to federal prosecutors. 
At a time when more than half of American households are invested in the stock market, and a loss of faith in the integrity of Wall Street is a drag on the economy, it is imperative that the S.E.C. truly act as "the investor's advocate."

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Bush Makes Quick Work of Relaxing

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me. 

 BODY:
President Bush began his day yesterday at dawn on the golf course. He began Saturday on the golf course, too. A weekend earlier, the president played two rounds of 18 holes on the course at Andrews Air Force Base just outside Washington. Over the Fourth of July weekend here at his parents' summer home, the president played twice -- once on Saturday and again on Monday, before returning to the White House for a rocky news conference about his corporate stock dealings.
 Presidents have been playing golf since at least William Howard Taft, but Mr. Bush, unlike Dwight D. Eisenhower, Gerald R. Ford or even Bill Clinton, is not known as a golfer. (He's a gym rat and sub-seven-minute miler and will be on the cover of Runner's World in October.) 
 This tumultuous summer, though, Mr. Bush has been playing golf a lot, with his father and without.
Ken Raynor, the pro at the Cape Arundel Golf Club here who has played with the Bush family for the past quarter century, says the president plays to relax and to forget the mounting pressures of his office, whether it be the economy or the Middle East. "My job is to get him away from all that," Mr. Raynor said this past weekend, between golf games with Bush I and Bush II. "He's got business at hand, and I can sense that. I feel for him."
Sometimes business intrudes on the green, and not always smoothly. Before starting his game yesterday, Mr. Bush, his driver in his left gloved hand, took time to condemn an overnight suicide bombing of a bus in Israel that killed at least nine. "I call upon all nations to do everything they can to stop these terrorist killers," Mr. Bush said on the first green of Cape Arundel, at 6:15 a.m. "Thank you. Now watch this drive."
Without the slightest pause, Mr. Bush turned to his game -- and hit his first ball into the rough. In a replay of a favorite Clintonian golfing practice, Mr. Bush then took a mulligan, a free shot, teeing off nicely. The president let out a sigh of relief.
"Hard this early in the morning to loosen up," he said to a group of reporters and cameras recording his every move.
Mr. Bush is not a bad golfer, Mr. Raynor said, although not as good as one of his younger brothers, Jeb, the governor of Florida. Still, teeing off in front of a phalanx of photographers is not easy, and there were suspicions that Mr. Bush played golf twice a weekend earlier in Washington to tune up for his more scrutinized rounds with his father here.
"He struck the ball very consistently," Mr. Raynor said after the president's game here on Saturday. "His practice in Washington must have paid off."
Last weekend, however, Mr. Bush denied such golf performance anxiety, telling reporters at the Andrews course that he was not getting in shape for Kennebunkport but simply "trying to get out of the house."
Like his presidency, Mr. Bush's golf has its roots in family history. Mr. Bush's great-grandfather, George Herbert Walker, was a president of the United States Golfing Association and a benefactor who kept the Cape Arundel club afloat during its difficult World War II days, when 5 of its 18 holes were plowed to grow needed crops.
Mr. Bush's grandfather, Senator Prescott S. Bush, was also president of the golfing association as well as the family's best golfer. Mr. Bush's father has long said that his favorite course is "our little golf club in Maine, Cape Arundel," which became the title of a book about the club by George A. Douglas. Today, there are no fewer than seven photographs of the former president in Cape Arundel's tiny, no-nonsense clubhouse. A picture of the former first lady, Barbara Bush, with women who belong to the club hangs prominently in the ladies' locker room.
Like his father, Mr. Bush is a speedy golfer, and he finished his 18 holes ysterday in a nimble two hours and 14 minutes. But he has never approached the record for aerobic golf held by his father and Mr. Raynor of 18 holes in an astonishing one hour and 24 minutes. Still, watching the Bush group play yesterday was to watch a commotion, with people putting before others had finished -- a practice anathema in a serious game.
"He has two priorities out there, and that is to excel as an athlete and to play quickly," Mr. Raynor said of the president. "Nobody plays as fast as the Bushes like to play."
Mr. Raynor also said Mr. Bush plays golf to spend time with his father, 78, who got off a good drive on the first green on Saturday.
"Let's hear it!" the 43rd president said, indicating that he wanted to listen to some praise for his father's swing.
"Good shot, sir," one member of the press said.
"Make the old boy feel better," the president said approvingly, tooling off in his cart.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 6, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The White House Letter column yesterday, about President Bush's passion for golf, misstated the name of the golf group that his great-grandfather George Herbert Walker served as president. It is the United States Golf Association, not Golfing Association.

HEADLINE: Credit Offerings During the Week 

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow and 5-year and 10-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.
 According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.58 percent, on the six-month issue 1.55 percent and on the four-week bill 1.63 percent. In when-issued trading, the 5-year note was offered at a price to yield 3.29 percent, and the 10-year note 4.32 percent.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
A Camera-Toting Odysseus Looks Into the Face of Pain

BYLINE:  By Margarett Loke 

 BODY:
In person the Brazilian documentary photographer Sebastiao Salgado is genial and unassuming. He keeps himself trim and his head shaved. He delivers rapid-fire accented English, as if he can hardly contain his immense energies.
 Mr. Salgado chooses epic subjects and maintains an Odyssean traveling schedule. For his "Migrations" project in the 1990's he traveled to 40 countries over six years. He has not spent much time in Paris, his home since 1969. "That," he said in an interview, "is a problem for me." He and his wife, Lelia Wanick Salgado, have two sons, now in their 20's. "I did not see my sons grow," he acknowledged, "but I am very close to my sons." He rushed on: "I must tell you, the things that I shoot don't happen in my town. I am a photographer. I must do reportage." 
 That compulsion has resulted in compelling images of famine victims in the Sahel region of Africa, of manual workers around the world and of the vast number of people displaced by natural and man-made disasters. Mr. Salgado's latest work is of the global effort to eradicate poliomyelitis. A selection of those pictures is on view at the Burden Gallery, 20 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, through Aug. 16. 
His documentary projects have a way of growing out of previous work. His extraordinary images of workers at the Serra Pelada gold mine in Brazil -- evocative of both Pieter Brueghel and Cecil B. DeMille -- became part of his opus on workers. While photographing them, he noted the never-ending migration of peoples. 
But he failed to spot the polio story earlier, he said, because he had been inured to the sight of polio victims. In Brazil, where he was born in 1944, "there were many kids with polio," he said. "Polio was a natural thing." When he was in India photographing workers, he again matter-of-factly took in the sight of people stricken with polio.
His interest was finally aroused last year after the World Health Organization approached him with the idea of documenting the anti-polio campaign. He learned that the Global Polio Eradication Initiative -- created in 1988 and spearheaded by WHO, Rotary International, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and Unicef -- was working to make the world polio-free by 2005. But it had a $275 million fund gap. 
Mr. Salgado said he immediately prepared to go to the Indian subcontinent and to Africa to photograph polio immunization campaigns. As he had done in the past, he secured assignments from a number of magazines in the United States and Europe, including Vanity Fair, for his year-long project. The only way for him to photograph in-depth, Mr. Salgado said, was to work with humanitarian organizations; for the polio project he was a Unicef special representative. That way, he said, "you are much more close to the problem." 
Many of his pictures at the gallery and on the polio project's Web site (www.endofpolio.org/home.html) are plainly promotional: children given the oral vaccine; health workers announcing their arrival and going about their work, and so on. 
A large number of images are strikingly beautiful. There is the close-up of a Sudanese's somber face, a cloudy sky and a gentle horizon in the background, as an infant is given an oral vaccine. There is the astonishing picture of adults and children at a cattle camp in Rumbek County in Sudan walking toward a team of polio immunizers. Behind the slim, almost fragile advancing figures is a long row of tall, sturdy trees.
Some of the pictures are tinged with the low-keyed humor that Mr. Salgado shows in person. A woman in Sudan, for instance, is shown scrunching her face in sympathy, as if the child before her is being given an injection instead of a painless oral dose of vaccine.
To draw attention to the world's less fortunate groups, Mr. Salgado does not simply take his characteristically atmospheric, luminous and elegant pictures. With the publication of a book of his photographs or the opening of an exhibition, he gives interviews and lectures, talks to members of the audience and treats his personal life as an extension of his work.
"The kind of photography that I do is not separate from my way of life," he said. "It is not separate from the people that I photograph. It is not separate from the organizations I work with."
Mr. Salgado said he has been involved in social movements all his life. As a college student in Brazil in the 1960's he was active in leftist movements. After a coup d'etat in 1964, he recalled, "we were fighting against a big repression." In 1969 he and his wife fled to Paris, where they became, as he once put it, "part migrant, part refugee, part exile."
Trained as an economist, Mr. Salgado worked for the London-based International Coffee Organization. In Paris a friend taught him the rudiments of photography. He borrowed his wife's camera and in a matter of weeks, he said, photography invaded his life. As part of his job, he visited the coffee-producing countries in Africa. Photographing there was such an incredible pleasure, he said, that he decided in March 1973 to become a full-time freelance photographer.
His first big story three months later was famine in the Niger and Upper Volta. He worked with Catholic and Protestant relief organizations, he said. His pictures were sent to news organizations and were also used to raise money to bring food and medicine to those blighted areas.
Mr. Salgado has seen and photographed many of the world's miseries. The "Migrations" project was especially discouraging, he said. "What I saw was not very brilliant for us," he observed. "I lose a lot of trust in our behavior. I saw many terrible things." But, he said, "I have a big hope." 
Over the years Mr. Salgado has made frequent trips to South America. After civilian rule returned to Brazil in 1985, and his Brazilian passport was restored to him, he has visited there regularly. 
He was born within the Atlantic Forest, a rain forest reduced to a fraction of its former size. Near Mr. Salgado's birthplace a large tract of forest has been cut down. In 1998 he and his wife created Instituto Terra (www.institutoterra.org), which plans to reforest the area with native species. It also hopes to become a leading environmental education center in Brazil. 
"For me," said Mr. Salgado, "if there is a God, the God for me is the instinct for survival of human beings."

HEADLINE: Taiwan's Market Falls as Ties With Beijing Worsen 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Taiwan's stock market fell sharply today in response to deteriorating relations with China, but the dispute is unlikely to affect either side's economy or American companies and consumers unless it becomes much more serious, corporate executives and economists said here today.
 A speech on Saturday by President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, who described China and Taiwan as separate countries and endorsed legislation allowing referendums on issues including Taiwan's sovereign status, provoked an angry response today from Beijing, in a confrontation that frightened shareholders. 
 Share prices began tumbling at the opening today and continued falling when Beijing denounced the speech just before noon as "a brazen provocation." Taiwan's benchmark stock index closed down 5.8 percent. Trading limits here prevent each company's shares from falling more than 7 percent in a single day. 
"You could see today everyone wanted to sell shares," said Margaret Lin, a fund manager at the Truswell Securities Investment Trust Company here. 
Chinese officials clearly expected the market effect in Taiwan of their criticisms and couched their remarks in terms that would appeal to business executives, who tend to be the strongest advocates of closer integration with the mainland.
"The ramifications will be felt by Taiwan's economy, and the damage will be sustained by the personal interests of Taiwan compatriots," said Li Wei-yi, the spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, at a hastily convened news conference in Beijing. "This will lead Taiwan toward disaster."
While the comments from Beijing and Taipei continue a decades-long political divide, the economies of Taiwan and China are increasingly intertwined, with at least 500,000 of Taiwan's 23 million people now living on the mainland.
Complex webs of technology companies in particular now assemble components and computers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait for all of the big American computer vendors, especially Dell. They have turned Taiwan and China together into the world's largest producers of everything from certain desktop computer parts to notebook computers.
Business leaders pointed out that previous verbal skirmishes in 1996 and 1999 have had little effect on factory production or foreign investment, and said that the current confrontation also does not yet pose a serious problem.
"Fundamentally, I don't think really it is, unless things get worse," said Frank Huang, the chairman of the Taipei Computer Association and the chairman of Power Chip, Taiwan's third-largest manufacturer of computer chips.
But he added that with the slowing American economy already affecting chip demand, "this is not the best time for what Chen Shui-bian said -- it's not helping."
Richard Vuylsteke, the executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, said that the group's members were not alarmed. "People are kind of used to a lot of rhetoric on both sides," he said. "Basically for us, it's business as usual."
The New Taiwan dollar, the currency here, slipped only as much as 0.7 percent today, to 33.95 New Taiwan dollars to the United States dollar, after the central bank spent an undisclosed sum of United States dollars to buy its currency. The central bank is in a strong position to buttress the currency because it has been intervening heavily in recent weeks to prevent the New Taiwan dollar from appreciating quickly.
Until today, there had been upward pressure on the Taiwanese currency, which would sap the competitiveness of Taiwanese exports, as Asian stocks held up better than American and European equities.
A few Chinese companies' stocks were also down today, notably businesses in Xiamen, a large port near southern Taiwan that stands to benefit if China and Taiwan ever allow direct shipping routes and flights. But markets in China mostly shrugged off the hostile words being exchanged, as China's economy is not only larger than Taiwan's but also viewed as much less vulnerable to disruption if an actual crisis were to occur.
Yet China's export sector has prospered even as much of the rest of the economy has stagnated, notably state-owned enterprises that still dominate many older industries. China needs a healthy computer industry in Taiwan as much as the United States does, said Peter Kurz, the chief executive of the Insight Pacific Investment Research, a consulting firm here.
"The United States is dependent on it, but China is dependent on it as well," he said.
Fearing China's growing economic importance within Taiwan, President Chen urged Taiwanese businesses last week to invest more in Southeast Asia instead of China. The recent trend has been quite the opposite, and China, seeing President Chen's concern, is unlikely to punish or restrict the mainland operations of Taiwanese technology companies, Mr. Kurz said, adding that "China realizes that enticing businesses is the most effective way of winning the hearts and minds of the Taiwanese."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
Corporate Apartments: A Real Home on the Road

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN GREGORY 

 BODY:
Karen Conner, a financial manager for the DuPont Company, is away on business in Columbus, Ohio, this week.
 And next week. 
 And next month.
And next year.
In fact, Ms.Conner expects her mission in Columbus to last at least two years, but she has no plans to uproot herself from her lifelong hometown of Wilmington, Del., where DuPont has its headquarters.
Rather than selling the house she bought in 2000 and moving to Columbus, Ms. Conner has chosen a temporary, albeit long-term, living arrangement that is not quite a hotel or a rented apartment. Rather, it is a hybrid of the two that has become increasingly popular with business travelers on extended assignments: a fully furnished corporate apartment. 
"I just got my house put together the way I want it, and I didn't really like the idea of having to rip it apart," said Ms. Conner, who is overseeing the financial integration of a company DuPont recently acquired in Columbus. "There was a major strain gone in not having to move furniture, unpack, set up everything, get utilities established. Literally all I had to do was pack my suitcases, box up a couple of personal things and my cats, and I'm here. This is probably one of the easiest ways you can relocate.'
Her new, two-bedroom home away from home is one of roughly 71,000 corporate apartments across the United States, a number that has shot up significantly since the mid-1990's as more lodging providers seek a piece of the lucrative business travel market, said Mark Skinner, a partner with the Atlanta-based Highland Group, which tracks the hotel and lodging industry.
Corporate apartments are like hotels in some ways. They are furnished, and they often offer amenities like maid service, a full-time concierge and continental breakfast. Guests need only bring what they would ordinarily take on any business trip: clothes and toiletries.
But unlike hotel rooms, most corporate apartments are just that -- apartments in standard residential complexes that are leased by third-party companies and subleased to business travelers, typically for two or three months. The units are indistinguishable from, and frequently next door to, traditional rental apartments.
Life in such residential surroundings takes much of the sense of dislocation out of being away, say business travelers like Michael Emanuelo, who has a home and family in Atlanta but has spent most of the last six months traveling on behalf of his company, Cbeyond Communications, which provides telephone and broadband Internet services.
"You got a kitchen, a refrigerator, a living room," said Mr. Emanuelo, who recently wrapped up a month living in a corporate apartment in Dallas. "It's better than sitting on a bed in a hotel room watching TV. I just got my key, and it was like my own home."
Mr. Emanuelo, who paid $90 a night for a one-bedroom apartment that came with daily maid service, is one of an estimated 64,000 people who will live in a corporate apartment sometime this year, Mr. Skinner said.
Corporate apartments have their roots in the 1970's, when providers of standard rental dwellings like Oakwood Worldwide, based in Los Angeles, began marketing furnished apartments to businesses like movie studios and film production companies that frequently employed visiting, temporary workers.
Since then, the number of corporate apartment units nationwide has grown steadily, peaking in 2000 at more than 85,000, Mr. Skinner said.
That figure fell 14 percent last year and is expected to sink another 3 percent this year as a result of the sputtering economy. The Highland Group says it expects significant growth in inventory in 2003, but did not project a percentage figure.
Unlike the hotel industry, however, corporate-apartment companies are able to absorb such dips in demand because their contracts typically allow them to terminate leases after a negotiated minimum period. Such flexibility allows them to avoid much of the pressure that hotels face to discount rates in order to fill their fixed inventory of rooms in lean times.
Last year, for example, corporate-apartment providers were able to maintain occupancy levels of about 90 percent despite the faltering economy, while hotels could fill only about 60 percent of their rooms, according to a Highland Group study.
The report also found that many hotel chains favored by business travelers charged on average $42 more a night than the median rate corporate apartments were asking last year. Extended-stay hotels also came in on average $14 higher a night than corporate apartments.
Over the course of a two-month stay, or in Ms. Conner's case two years, such a difference can mean considerable savings.
"When we looked at the financial situation, it really made more sense for me to come and get set up in a corporate apartment," said Ms. Conner, whose rent, which includes utilities and rental furniture, comes out to $66 a day. "It's really quite economical."
The hotels aren't exactly quaking in their boots, however. John A. Fox, an industry analyst with PKF Consulting in New York, notes that hotel rooms outnumber corporate apartments 60 to 1, making a mass defection of business travelers improbable.
"It's a phenomenon that has certainly been increasing in size substantially in the past few years, but it's still a relatively small number of units," Mr. Fox said. "If you look at the traditional hotel market, only a very small percentage of travelers are interested in that kind of long-term stay. It doesn't provide a tremendous threat."
Many who do switch, though, welcome the change of pace. "I had close to four years of living out of a suitcase in a hotel, and that gets old," said Tom Bergeron, who lives in Connecticut but frequently journeys to Los Angeles where he hosts two television shows. Before moving into a corporate apartment last October, Mr. Bergeron said, he grew increasingly impatient with hotel amenities like valet parking. "It got to the point at the hotel where even the little things that most people would love to have were driving me crazy," he said.
Mr. Bergeron's employers, King World and Vin Di Bona Productions, now split his $3,600-a-month rent on a two-bedroom corporate apartment near the beach in Santa Monica. Though he normally spends just three days a week there, Mr. Bergeron recently stuck around for an entire month. "I just hit the grocery store on my way from the airport, throw some things in the fridge, and I'm set. I can make my own coffee in the morning, do my own laundry. I mean it sounds silly but when you're away as much as I have to be, it's that kind of stuff that makes you feel like you're almost at home."
Ms. Conner has tried to maker her apartment in Columbus more homelike by bringing a "care package of personal items from Wilmington, including a pillow, a toaster, potholders and a wicker basket for her place mats. Her cats have their beloved "kitty condo," and she has stocked the shelves with many of her favorite books and CD's. She has also put up pictures of her friends and family to help fend off loneliness, she says.
So has Mr. Bergeron. "The most important things are pictures of my wife and girls, and that's the first thing I see when I wake up in the morning," he said. "They just sort of place me. Business travelers especially can get to feeling like, 'Who am I again?' You sort of fall outside of yourself unless you have something to remind you of your connections."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karen Conner, a financial manager for the DuPont Company, just after she moved into a two-bedroom corporate apartment in Columbus, Ohio. (Matt Sullivan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: To Encourage Recovery, Encourage Investors 

BYLINE:  By Muriel Siebert; Muriel Siebert, chairwoman and chief executive of Siebert Financial Corp., was superintendent of banking for New York State from 1977 to 1982.

 BODY:
The gravity of the crisis in our financial markets cannot be overstated. Not only have investors lost significant assets, but they have also lost their faith in the integrity of the system. Solving these problems will take a commitment by our government and society equal to the severity of the situation.
 Part of the process is already under way. Confidence in the stock market -- which remains volatile -- has recovered somewhat since former executives of Adelphia and WorldCom were led away in handcuffs and strong new legislation on corporate governance was signed into law by President Bush. Confidence may be further strengthened as chief executives certify their financial results, as the Securities and Exchange Commission has required them to do by Aug. 14. 
 Unfortunately, restoration of confidence alone will not be enough. Even if we jail all those responsible for the recent debacle and somehow recover all the money they misappropriated, it will do little to replace the more than $7 trillion in wealth that has been lost since March 2000. Many Americans have seen their nest eggs devastated. For our system to recover, small investors must see that the government takes their plight seriously and recognizes the need for relief. We must quickly give individual investors a chance to rebuild their portfolios and incentives to return to -- and thus preserve -- our capital markets.
The most effective way to meet these objectives would be to double for three to five years the amount that investors can put into their 401(k) plans and individual retirement accounts. Currently individuals can contribute $3,000 annually to their I.R.A.'s and $11,000 annually to their 401(k) plans. These limits were increased slightly last year. Doubling them would benefit individual investors in several ways, providing additional income tax deductions and replenishing their tax-deferred portfolios.
To encourage participation in the program, investors would be able to reach the new maximum by placing stocks, bonds and mutual funds in their retirement accounts as well as cash. With additional assets set aside, participants will be well positioned to benefit from recovering stock prices and higher interest rates. The only cost to the government would be the loss of tax revenues on the additional income diverted into 401(k) plans and I.R.A.'s. This is a small price to pay to give so many people the chance to help themselves.
Some might question how willing individual investors will be to put additional funds in equities, given the current uncertainty in the stock market. And investors may well decide on a more balanced approach in the future, dividing their holdings among stocks and bonds. Longer term, however, history suggests that equities are the better investment: returns are higher than the alternatives. Whatever decisions investors make, it will only strengthen the system by which our government and corporations raise money to pay for expansion.
Aside from the remedial aspects of this plan, there is broader justification for its implementation. Without such help, the first generation of baby boomers will likely hit 65 underfunded for retirement, placing more political pressure to increase benefits in a Social Security system already facing a difficult future.
This aftershock of the current crisis is one we must move to prevent now, while we still can. Otherwise we may find ourselves still cursing today's business scoundrels decades from now.
The trauma has put our capital markets in grave danger. Coupled with stiff jail terms and disgorgement of ill-gotten gains for those who caused this crisis, this proposal can help put our markets back on sound footing. It can also help a generation of Americans feel more confident about their plans for a secure retirement.

HEADLINE: The Port Authority's Role in the World Trade Center 

BYLINE:  By Richard C. Leone; Richard C. Leone is president of the Century Foundation and former chairman of the Port Authority.

 BODY:
The debate about rebuilding on the site of the World Trade Center has taken a new turn since the design options presented two weeks ago were greeted with disappointment. State and local officials said the plans were just a starting point. But the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- which built the World Trade Center, owns the site, and has a decisive voice in what happens -- has insisted that the redevelopment of the site generate revenues comparable to those produced by the World Trade Center. Now, proposals are emerging that would remove the Port Authority and its financial requirements from the process altogether -- by trading La Guardia and Kennedy airports, which are owned by the city, to the authority in exchange for the World Trade Center site -- with redevelopment reassigned, perhaps, to new city-state agency. 
 There are many reasons for the effort to push the Port Authority out, but one may be the state of the agency itself. In its heyday, it was considered the most effective and professional public agency in the country. While building bridges, tunnels, and airports, Port Authority executives like Austin Tobin won virtually every fight they took on, including those with the more famous Robert Moses. The agency was a big-time operator with a long-term perspective: the original single span of the George Washington Bridge, underutilized at first, was designed not only to support the current second level, but has the strength for even a third. 
 It was natural for the Rockefellers to turn to the Port Authority to serve as the key player in reviving the flagging economic fortunes of downtown Manhattan in the 1960's. The authority had money, patience and expertise; it could plan ahead a dozen years as politicians could not; it didn't have to worry about next quarter's results; and it had built up a reservoir of public and media confidence in its ability to get the job done. New Jersey went along with the World Trade Center in exchange for a Port Authority takeover of what now is called the PATH system. The deal benefited both states, although neither the PATH, which loses over $150 million a year, nor the World Trade Center, which lost money for the first 10 years of its existence, was a particularly good financial fit for the authority.
In the end, though, the World Trade Center served the public purpose of reviving downtown. And while the buildings themselves generated architectural controversy, they did become global symbols of the city. Now, the events of Sept. 11 have left a void that goes beyond the empty physical space. We seem to be suffering from both a lack of imagination and a lack of confidence in the public sector's ability to follow through on the grand scale required.
The Port Authority is not what it was four decades ago. Robert Moses and Austin Tobin would seem hopelessly overbearing in the current environment, in which community engagement and transparency are necessary and desired. The special sensitivity of a site where so many died also restricts what might be done. 
The character of the authority has changed, too. For decades, governors of New York and New Jersey complained about the authority's independence. Now, the governors have taken it over; the formerly professional staff has been diluted by patronage employees from both states. Today the agency is ruled by reliable political allies of the governors, former lieutenants and campaign fund-raisers. Rather than functioning as an independent force for the interests of the region, it is more often just a place where bistate interests are brokered. But the building of projects like airports, bridges, tunnels and harbors is hardly ever a result of routine politics. Elected officials are notoriously reluctant to choose sides, lead fights and see projects through.
The final plan for the World Trade Center site should not be driven by the financial requirements of any agency or the patronage needs of any political leader. It should shaped by a body independent enough to pursue our common interest in creating something lasting. The architects, engineers and construction firms that will actually rebuild downtown need a client with power, patience, professionalism, political skills and courage. The Port Authority would have to be reformed to fit that profile again -- a scenario not very likely in the current political climate. It's not that the agency is worse than other public bodies in the region; it's just that it has been remade into a routine arm of government.
Only the governors and Mayor Michael Bloomberg can change this situation. They must decide that they actually want the Port Authority -- or any new development body for the World Trade Center site -- to have enough independence and insulation from politics to rise above the ordinary and fulfill the hopes of so many.

HEADLINE: Service Sector Growth Slow, Report Shows 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The service sector grew for a sixth consecutive month in July, but the pace of expansion slowed, according to a report released yesterday by an industry group.
 The group, the Institute for Supply Management, said its monthly nonmanufacturing index fell to 53.1 in July, the lowest since January,from 57.2 in June, the second consecutive month the index has fallen. The figure was below forecasts for a drop to 54.6. 
 A number above 50 indicates expansion in the sector that accounts for about 80 percent of the economy and includes everything from legal help to retailing and construction. 
"It doesn't look like things are going to turn around in terms of faster growth, significantly faster growth, until maybe close to the end of the year," said Ralph Kauffman, who directs the survey for the institute.
The institute, formerly called the National Association of Purchasing Management, compiles its diffusion index by surveying more than 370 purchasing executives in more than 60 service industries once a month. The responses reflect the change in the current month with the previous month. 
 The drop in the service-sector data came after the institute's manufacturing index last week showed that growth in the sector nearly stalled in July.
In one sign that growth in the service sector may slow further, the new orders index, a gauge of demand, fell to 52.6 in July from 56.9 in June. Survey respondents said that while the economy continued to improve, the outlook remained cautious through the end of the year. 
The report said the pace of layoffs slowed slightly as the institute's employment index rose to 45.8 in July from 44.3 in June, but it was still the 17th consecutive month of job losses. 
A second report released yesterday said that announcements of job cuts fell to the lowest level in 14 months in July, in a month in which 6,000 jobs were created. 
American companies announced 80,966 layoffs in July, down from 94,766 in June, a 15 percent drop, according to the report by the employment research firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. 
"While it is a positive sign that job cuts have slowed so significantly, the news is weakened by the fact that the economy seems to be in a no-growth state," the chief executive of Challenger Gray, John A. Challenger, said.

HEADLINE: If You Can't Stand the Heat, Get Out of the Suit 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY 

 BODY:
It is a little-known fact of social science that, above a certain temperature, the will to be fashionable fails. Experts are divided about the point on the thermometer where this phenomenon sets in, but after a string of days with temperatures in the 90's, even New York's hard-core fashionable tossed over their Edmundo Castillos last week for flip-flops and switched into clothes that made them look as if they were planning to mow the lawn.
 In truth, this is a look that already enjoys a great deal of local currency, most likely as a reflection of the looser approach a majority of Americans now take to personal presentation. The days of a hat and gloves for town are long gone. To get an idea of how long, one might consult Libby Vogel, a Brooklynite whose recall of New York in the doldrums seven decades ago remains remarkably clear. 
 During the summer of 1929, when Mrs. Vogel was being courted by her future husband, the typical costume for young women was a test of endurance. "You had to have very good clothing if you were keeping company," Mrs. Vogel said the other day. A bra, a slip, a pair of gloves and a hat were de rigueur for proper young women regardless of what the mercury read. For an evening out, Mrs. Vogel once wore a three-piece long-sleeve dinner suit of chocolate silk chiffon. "Nobody, but nobody" went without stockings, she said as the temperature in Brooklyn Heights crept past 95 and those who braved the searing sidewalks did so wearing almost nothing at all.
The situation was the same all over town. The sartorial inventiveness for which New Yorkers are justly famous has not been abandoned, yet overwhelmingly the urban look of this late summer is assembled from clothes that would not be out of place on "Survivor." Whether in Harlem or Chelsea or Williamsburg, on the Lower East Side or upper Madison Avenue, New York's dog days uniform is a pair of shorts at midcalf length, a tank top and a pair of rubber flip-flops, for men as well as women. It says something about changes in what it means to be a city dweller that -- far from wearing the structured two-tone spectator shoes of Mrs. Vogel's 1920's -- the footwear of the moment is a flat rubber thong first imported from Hawaii in the 50's by surfers and G.I.'s.
Why not? Isn't New York largely made up of islands anyhow, both real and conceptual? Metaphors of the melting pot, the salad bowl and the gorgeous mosaic are fine as far as they go. But another figure may be useful as New York increasingly comes to resemble a cultural archipelago. In the insular Caribbean reaches of Crown Heights, for instance, many people are wearing their dreadlocks in more extravagant branches and fountains than ever before, and their trousers with the waistbands at levels that flout gravity. On B-boy-friendly Nostrand Avenue, the locals now get themselves up in Brobdingnagian Yankees caps worn atop overlapping layers of nylon do-rags.
On the privileged reaches of upper Madison Avenue, the glossy blondes with the beautifully tousled $400 Frederic Fekkai haircuts are now accessorizing with parasols, their dermatologists will be pleased to know. In parts of central Harlem, bootleg Gucci-logo fabrics are now much in use as insets customizing Timberland boots. In the central Harlem area called Little Africa, the vendors dress with an extravagance that calls to mind coastal places like the Iles Tristao or the Ile de Goree.
"This is nothing so unusual," said Aminata Kadeye, a hairdresser on 125th Street who was wearing robes of neon-yellow kente cloth and a voluminous head wrap in acid green. The day's heat was fierce enough for Ms. Kadeye to move her stool onto the sidewalk, busily plaiting a customer's hair into minibraids colored the frosted blond tones that Beyonce Knowles, as Foxxy Cleopatra, has brought into vogue.
In the artist-intensive enclaves of Greenpoint, young women are now wearing their skirts atop trousers the way the scenemakers in Tokyo's Shibuya do, and are again sporting gas-jockey shirts with "Bob" embroidered above the shirt pocket, the way they did before the dot-com boom. "Once the economy went bust, everyone stopped wearing Prada and Gucci and started dressing the way I did when I was in seventh grade," Mark Van de Walle, a writer who lives in Williamsburg, said, meaning T-shirts and pinwale corduroys.
In the East Village, the revivals of the moment are the modishly scalped haircut dubbed the Fauxhawk and the spiked and dyed haircuts of rocker girls from the 1980's. (Think Bangles or Go-Go's or Pat Benatar.) "The look is punk rocker cowboy Roman sports," Suzanne Ethier, a downtown boutique owner, said on Wednesday. Ms. Ethier is one of the few New Yorkers who dress not for the weather but for a daily improvised game of self-invention. This steamy afternoon she had her rooster-comb hair and side curls tucked under a straw Stetson and was wearing 70's gym shorts, a fat naval belt with soccer stirrup socks and a pair of platform sandals she referred to as Romanesque. Her square-dance shirt was cropped to show off an elaborate tattoo that read "Jesus Died for Somebody's Sins but Not Mine."
"Society," Thomas Carlyle observed in the 19th century, "which the more I think of it astonishes me the more, is founded on cloth." Manhattan society, which the more one thinks of it astonishes one the more, is increasingly founded on no cloth at all. And few neighborhoods illustrate that better than Chelsea, where some people are so heavily armored in muscle that clothes can sometimes seem beside the point.
"There is definitely the gay ghetto stereotype of the muscle queen in Chelsea, but that stereotype is being broken," said Jesus Echezuria, a salesman at a popular Chelsea men's wear shop called Nasty Pig. Mr. Echezuria was referring to a group of men whose calendars are often marked in steroid cycles and for whom "liposculpting" and "abdominal etching" are by no means alien terms. If, however, the stereotype of Chelsea as a magnet for such men is dated, you couldn't tell it from the volume of cartoon action figures strutting the streets on a torrid Saturday night.
There was one place in recent days that called to mind distant summers when a New York man might be turned out in a well-cut suit and a straw hat, a time when rubber sandals were something one saw mainly in National Geographic picture spreads. It was on the steps of the Angelika theater on West Houston Street, and the man was an apparition. His white linen trousers were creased to a knife-edge. His white cashmere turtleneck set off a tan the color of an aged copper coin. His shoes had the softly buffed shine that Bill Blass used to say was the mark of a gent. The anachronism in question was the legendary fashion plate and Hollywood producer Robert Evans, and as it happened, he had just come from seeing "The Kid Stays in the Picture," a documentary about himself.

HEADLINE: South America's Troubled Economies 

 BODY:
For a group that came into office pledging to make ties with Latin America a priority, the Bush administration has managed to convey the opposite impression in recent months, just as the region's economic plight has worsened. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, who has contributed to the bruised relations, can help repair some of the damage this week as he travels through South America.
 Before Mr. O'Neill's departure over the weekend, the administration announced that it would use $1.5 billion in Treasury funds as a bridge loan to shore up Uruguay, whose economy has been clobbered by neighboring Argentina's financial meltdown. This was a welcome departure from the administration's past opposition to such bailouts. 
 Mr. O'Neill, whose diplomatic skills are more than a little shaky, was on his best behavior yesterday in Brazil. He lauded President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's economic policies. Last week Mr. O'Neill roiled Brazil's currency, the real, by saying he would be wary of supporting any new financial aid packages for South American countries for fear that the aid may end up in Swiss bank accounts. 
President Cardoso has instituted sound economic reforms since taking office in 1995. But the possibility that a leftist opposition candidate, Luiz Inacio da Silva, will win the October presidential election, coupled with Argentina's default last year of its $141 billion public debt, have left foreign banks and investors skittish about Brazil.
The resulting erosion in the real's value and a credit crunch afflicting Brazilian companies have raised fears about Brazil's ability to service its $256 billion public debt. This is more a crisis of confidence than of economic fundamentals, and the Bush administration and the International Monetary Fund can still address the former in order to prevent the latter. Brazil deserves an immediate vote of confidence, in the form of expanded I.M.F. support. Today Mr. O'Neill is in Argentina, which desperately awaits its own I.M.F. aid package. That country has mostly itself to blame, but the transitional government of Eduardo Duhalde has taken some steps to address lenders' concerns. Mr. O'Neill should push the Argentine government and the I.M.F. to come to terms soon.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Shares Plunge As Interpublic Delays Report On Earnings

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER with ALLISON FASS 

 BODY:
The Interpublic Group of Companies, among the world's largest advertising agency concerns, said yesterday that it would postpone the release of its second-quarter earnings report by a week, sending the company's stock tumbling nearly 24 percent.
 A statement issued by the company said that the earnings report was being postponed until next Tuesday so that Interpublic's audit committee "could complete its review prior to management certification of its financial statements." 
 Interpublic will probably not be the last company to postpone the release of financial results now that the Securities and Exchange Commission is requiring chief executives and chief financial officers at the nation's largest companies to certify the accuracy of corporate filings, lawyers and analysts said yesterday. Penalties for signing off on inaccurate statements could include fines and even jail time. 
A spokesman for Interpublic, whose agencies handle advertising for Coca-Cola, General Motors and Nestle, declined to comment beyond the statement. A spokesman for PricewaterhouseCoopers, which has been the auditor at Interpublic and its predecessor companies for decades, said the firm would not comment on client matters.
Shares of Interpublic fell $4.69, to $14.99. 
There was no way to know yesterday whether Interpublic's audit committee had found evidence of an accounting problem or whether it was simply being cautious because of concern about shareholder lawsuits and S.E.C. investigations, lawyers and analysts said. 
"It's really hard to say what to make of this," said Michael Russell, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. The postponement "really could be thoroughness," he said, adding, "We're in very careful times."
It is a difficult time for the media industry in general and advertising companies in particular. Clients are spending less on ads because of the sluggish economy, and investors have been skittish about advertising companies since questions were raised about accounting practices at the Omnicom Group, also among the world's largest agency companies.
A delayed release will not reassure investors, said Michael Young, a lawyer at Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York. "Companies are normally loath to postpone a previously scheduled earnings release because markets may fear the worst," Mr. Young said. "Of course, this is a highly unusual earnings season, and a postponement doesn't necessarily portend a major problem."
In previous years, members of audit committees have not caused such postponements of earnings releases because until recently they were under less pressure to make sure the numbers were accurate, Mr. Young said. "Historically, a phone call might be the totality of audit committee participation in a quarterly earnings release," he said. "These days, audit committees are looking to do a lot more."
After all, no audit committee wants to face harsh criticism from regulators if problems in accounting arise. And no one on an audit committee wants to battle shareholder lawsuits, a virtual certainty after any such problem appears, lawyers said.
Executives are also worried about the S.E.C.'s order, which requires certification not just of the most recent quarterly results but also of all financial disclosures since and including the most recent annual report. That means that with this quarterly S.E.C. filing, which is due on Aug. 14, Interpublic's chief executive and chief financial officer will be swearing to the accuracy of the annual report for 2001.
In 2001, Interpublic undertook a complicated reorganization after its $1.68 billion purchase of True North Communications, a smaller agency company based in Chicago. Analysts said that revisiting those transactions could be slowing both the audit committee and management.
Interpublic already took steps to try to bolster its credibility with investors early this year, when the company said that it would keep only two corporate insiders on its board -- John J. Dooner Jr., the chief executive, and Sean F. Orr, the chief financial officer. Its remaining seven directors and all five members of the audit committee are from outside the company.
Investor skittishness about ad companies the last few months grew after an article in The Wall Street Journal raised questions about the accounting at Omnicom. Shares in Omnicom and yet another large advertising company, the WPP Group, also fell yesterday, both by 7 percent.
Shares in Omnicom, which said in a release yesterday that it would stick to its previously announced plan to report its earnings this morning, fell $3.58, to $47.21. WPP's American depository receipts closed at $32.09, down $2.42.
Neither decline was as precipitous as that suffered by Interpublic, though, said Mr. Russell, the analyst. The difference was a result of the postponement, he said. "They would've been down today," he said, "but probably not this much."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks Plummet on Renewed Fears of Recession

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled again yesterday as investors digested another report showing that the economy was slowing sharply, or even falling back into recession.
 A key index measuring growth in the service economy dropped in July for the second month in a row to its lowest level since January, the report showed. 
 The major stock gauges fell more than 3 percent for the day. Coming on top of sharp declines on Thursday and Friday, the Nasdaq composite index has now given up all the gains since stocks began to rally from five-year lows on July 24. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have not yet pierced those lows but are closing in on them. 
Nicholas P. Sargen, global market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients, said that a few weeks ago he thought the economy was on a reasonably good footing and that the stock market would respond to that. "Now it is a matter of whether the economy withstands the stock market sell-off," he said.
As consumers watch their savings and investments dwindle, they may rein in their spending. Businesses, meanwhile, have shown a reluctance to invest absent signs of economic strengthening. 
 Concerns about corporate earnings are therefore building with the reports about a slowing economy. Most stock projections for this year have been driven by expectations of a strong rebound in earnings. For the second quarter, profits at the companies in the S.& P. 500 index are expected to grow about 1 percent from a year earlier, producing the first increase since the fourth quarter of 2000, according to Thomson First Call. Forecasters have said that earnings growth will accelerate in the second half of the year.
But with Wall Street scaling back its economic growth predictions for the second half, earnings expectations will also be trimmed.
Even companies like Procter & Gamble, which reported good earnings yesterday and raised its forecast for the current quarter, were swept lower, as P.& G.'s stock fell 2.7 percent. Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase were down more than 6 percent after Lehman Brothers issued a lukewarm outlook, citing concerns about headline risk amid all the corporate scandals.
The decline in stocks over the last three sessions also raises questions about whether the market has hit bottom, as some analysts surmised after the recent rally.
At the close, the Dow was down 269.50 points, or 3.2 percent, at 8,043.63, still ahead of its July 23 close of 7,702.34. The S.& P. 500-stock index shed 29.64 points, or 3.4 percent, to close at 834.60, ahead of 797.70 on July 23. The Nasdaq index was down 41.9 points, or 3.4 percent, to 1,206.01, breaking below its July 23 close of 1,229.05. The Nasdaq is now down 76 percent from its all-time high and at a level last seen in April 1997, making it one of the worst bear markets ever.
Stock prices also fell across Europe yesterday, with a 5.7 percent decline in Germany and a 4 percent loss in France. There were some signs that economic growth was slowing there, as factory production dropped sharply in Britain.
Last week's sharp shift in sentiment about the weakness of the economic recovery -- following reports of anemic growth in the second quarter, unexpectedly slow job creation in July and a cooling off of the manufacturing sector last month -- was reinforced yesterday morning when the Institute for Supply Management released its index of the service economy. The index dropped to 53.1 in July, from 57.2 in June. A reading above 50 means the service economy is still expanding, but the sharp deceleration suggested that the economy was on a precipice.
"I have been worried about a double dip all along," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer of Waddell & Reed, a money management firm in Overland Park, Kan. Double dip is the Wall Street term for a second recession on the heels of one that just ended. It is widely believed that the previous recession, which began in March last year, ended near the end of 2001.
Mr. Herrmann said that he had expected that the recovery would be very mild. But now, he said, "from a statistical point of view it is getting closer to a recession."
Mr. Herrmann did note that the sharp fall in interest rates that has accompanied the stock declines and the weakening outlook may provide people and businesses with enough incentive to spend to support the economy and prevent a double dip.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.21 percent yesterday, down from 4.29 percent on Friday. It is now within easy striking distance of its record low of 4.18 percent last November. This decline in yields should push mortgage rates to or near record lows, which could spark a mortgage refinancing boom. That in turn could help spur consumer spending by cutting monthly payments and allowing consumers to borrow at very low rates.
Automakers are also encouraging sales with no interest loans, which could continue to give the economy a lift, Mr. Herrmann said.
The yield on the Treasury's two-year note dropped to a record low of 1.89 percent, falling below 2 percent for the first time. This plunge, from 2.39 percent just a week ago, reflects the growing belief among many investors that Federal Reserve policy makers will have to cut their short-term interest rate benchmark soon to prevent the economy from falling back into recession.
The benchmark rate is now at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent. The next scheduled meeting of Fed policy makers is Aug. 13.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, was arguing against gloom yesterday. Although he has reduced his growth forecast recently, he expects the economy to skirt a recession. He is still forecasting 3.5 percent growth at an annual rate in the second half of the year, about a percentage point above the recent downward revisions of other Wall Street forecasters. "The job market is the overwhelming influence on consumer spending, and it's slowly improving," he wrote in an analysis distributed to clients. Although nonfarm payroll jobs rose only 6,000 in July, Mr. Steinberg said that this was the third consecutive gain and that June payroll growth had been revised up to 66,000 from 36,000.
Among the stocks leading the market lower yesterday were the Williams Companies, the troubled natural gas company, down 32.1 percent; AT&T, down 9.5 percent; Comcast, down 12.9 percent; Walt Disney, down 6.8 percent; and American Express, down 8.1 percent.
Mr. Herrmann said that the Nasdaq decline showed the dimmer outlook for the technology sector. Computer sales for the back-to-school season have been disappointing, he said, adding that he has not talked to anyone recently who has seen signs of a revival of demand for technology products.
In lowering its rating for Citigroup, Lehman Brothers said that "although we believe a material decline in the share price is unlikely from the current level, we believe the shares are likely to underperform near term due to the implications of a very tough operating environment, economic uncertainty and significant headline risk."
On J. P. Morgan, Lehman lowered its earnings forecast, saying the move was "based on a combination of factors including the expectations for weak trading results, lower revenues in the structured finance business, modest spread revenue performance and continued losses in private equity."
Citigroup was down $2.23, to $28.65, while J. P. Morgan was off $1.50, to $22.35. P.& G. fell $2.40, to $87.44.

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the steepest declines for the main stock gauges during bear markets misstated the most recent performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It reached its low on July 23, not this Monday. And the low followed the most recent peak by 821 calendar days, not 834. At its low, the index was 47.8 percent below its peak, not 45.4 percent, making the decline the sixth worst among the major indexes, not the seventh.

HEADLINE: Congo Peace Accord Evokes Cautious Hopes 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Congo, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
The Rev. Michaux Lukonga's eyes were closed on Sunday morning, his arms extended skyward. His voice seemed to come from deep inside him as he urged his congregation of 300 to pray hard, harder than ever before, for peace.
 "We've had so many agreements," bellowed Mr. Lukonga, a young Assemblies of God pastor, just three months on the job. "Those agreements are fruits of your prayer. They are proof that God is here. We are moving closer to peace." 
 The latest agreement devised to bring peace to this unhappy country, where as many as 2.5 million people have perished in the last four years of war, came along last week, raising cautious hope that the complicated conflict might be nearing an end. 
The accord, between President Joseph Kabila of Congo and his Rwandan counterpart, Paul Kagame, was signed last Tuesday in Pretoria, South Africa. Congo agreed to crack down on the Hutu militias within its borders. Rwanda, which blames the Hutu for mass killings of ethnic Tutsi in 1994, is to withdraw its troops from Congo, where they have exploited natural resources and held sway over large swaths of the east.
The agreement is not very different from one signed in Zambia in 1999, and it follows two more recent attempts at peace, one in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, last fall and another this spring in Sun City, South Africa.
Few people here in Congo's capital expect an immediate end to hostilities. Analysts warn that the timetable spelled out in the latest agreement is too optimistic. They doubt that either side will stick to the letter of the pact. But, one Western diplomat said, "it's something at a time when we needed anything."
"The most important thing is that they met and they talked and they reached some commitments," the diplomat said. "Both countries felt compelled to make a deal and just maybe they'll feel compelled to keep it."
There are some early signs that the pressure recently brought to bear on President Kabila by a range of outside powers -- the World Bank, the United States and Western Europe -- to cut a deal with Rwanda to get the Rwandans out of his country may bear fruit.
Diplomats said the Congo government, which in this complex war has been aligned with troops from Angola, Zimbabwe and Zambia against the forces of Rwanda and Uganda, who have backed Congolese rebels in the east, has played an important behind-the-scenes role with Angola in tracking down a prominent suspect in the Rwandan genocide.
The suspect is the former Rwandan Army chief of staff, Maj. Gen. Augustin Bizimungu, a Hutu accused of playing a significant role in the massacres of Rwandan Tutsi. His arrest -- which Rwanda would see as important -- may come soon, diplomats said.
Congo has not been alone in feeling pressure from the outside. Rwanda has taken a beating from its foreign donors, led by the United States, for keeping its soldiers in Congo for so many years and for backing the main group that is in rebellion against Congo's government.
The World Bank and others have long withheld funds from Mr. Kabila's government in Kinshasa but have pledged to help rebuild the country once the shooting stops.
At the pulpit at the Bread of Life Church, Mr. Lukonga was doing all he could to ensure that those funds would arrive soon. Among prayers for the people of six countries involved in the war, he singled out Mr. Kabila, who inherited the war after his father, President Laurent Kabila, was killed in January 2001.
The elder Mr. Kabila brought peace talks to a standstill, boycotting the main mediator, the former president of Botswana, Ketumile Masire, and not cooperating with the United Nations mission here.
"Without repudiating the mantle of his father, the son has basically undone much of what his father did," said one veteran diplomat.
The son agreed to accept Mr. Masire and began striking deals with the United Nations. His major challenge now may be winning over his own government. Any lasting peace would require power-sharing with the rebel factions and forcing current power holders into retirement.
Already a deal that Mr. Kabila reached earlier this year with Jean-Pierre Bemba of the Congolese Liberation Movement has soured. Mr. Kabila agreed to give Mr. Bemba the position of prime minister if his Uganda-backed group laid down its arms. Some aides close to Mr. Kabila have tried to scuttle that agreement, believing he gave up too much.
"There are those who would rather be a minister of 50 percent of the country than unemployed in a unified land," one Western diplomat said.
The United States, meanwhile, has been pushing Mr. Kabila to show his commitment to peace by cracking down on the Rwandan Hutu within Congo's borders. Some of them are wreaking havoc in the eastern part of Congo. Others, political leaders of the Hutu rebel group known as the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, are being given shelter in Kinshasa at government expense, Western diplomats say.
Some Hutu who led the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 were believed to have fled to Congo. Without having hard evidence, American officials suspect that some who are wanted by the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, on war crimes charges may be inside Congo.
"This is a critical moment in history, where there is a choice between leaving these fugitives and other negative elements to fester and foment ongoing conflict or making a strong effort to apprehend them," Pierre-Richard Prosper, the American ambassador for war crimes issues, said late last month in announcing a reward program for the capture of genocide suspects.
The history of vast, mineral-rich Congo has been sorry virtually since Belgian rule ended in 1960. But the particular despair now gives Mr. Kabila every interest in pursuing peace.
Many of the Congolese who have perished in the war did so not in the fighting, but because they had no food and no aid group could reach them. In Kinshasa's ramshackle downtown, jobless people outnumber the employed.
The University of Kinshasa, once the pride of Africa, is a shell of its former self, unable to attract students from any other part of the continent. Indeed, fighting has become so widespread in the countryside that the university has become a refuge for Congolese -- so popular that classrooms often have standing room only. Some students carry their own chairs into class, and others stand outside to listen to the lectures through the windows.
Dorm rooms designed for two students frequently house eight or more. With so much strain and so few resources, the buildings are decaying. Library books carry copyrights from three decades back, and professors rely on handouts from students to supplement their meager government salaries.
Graduates find few jobs waiting. Many continue in the money-making opportunities they carved out as students: one young man says he pays tuition by raising chickens, many others sell sodas or snacks, and some of the women even sell themselves in local bars.
Mady Mangwele, 26, was one of the lucky ones, securing a job at a bank after graduating with an economics degree last year. "I'm crossing my fingers for peace," she said.
If there is one potential benefit to all the misery, it is that Congo's churches are booming, even on campus. "The suffering has pushed students to be open to the Gospel," said Timothee Mbengela, coordinator for Kinshasa's Campus Crusade for Christ. "Now we find services inside the dormitories. After all they go through each day, these students need to pray."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about an accord to end Congo's war against Rwanda and Uganda misidentified one of three countries aligned with the Congolese. It was Namibia, (along with Angola and Zimbabwe). Zambia sent troops to Congo only as part of a peacekeeping mission and did not support the war effort.

HEADLINE: At Rutgers, Foes of Sports As a Priority Win a Round 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
A maverick alumni group has won another round in its effort to get Rutgers University to focus less on athletics and more on academics.
 A New Jersey appeals court ruled on Friday that the university's alumni magazine was wrong to reject an advertisement from the group encouraging Rutgers to withdraw from the Big East Conference. The ruling upheld a March 2001 decision in State Superior Court. 
 The ad, which the group tried to place in Rutgers Magazine in 1998, quoted a speech by the economist Milton Friedman, an alumnus, saying, "Universities exist to transmit knowledge and understanding of ideas and values to students, not to provide entertainment for spectators or employment for athletes." 
The ad took up a third of a page, and under the headline "Rutgers Alumni: A Time to Choose" urged the university to pull out of what it called "professionalized athletics."
The magazine said the ad violated a policy against "advocacy advertising." The alumni group sued, arguing that because Rutgers is a public institution, the rejection of the ad violated free speech protections.
In its ruling, the three-judge panel ruled unanimously that Rutgers had the right to adopt the advertising ban but had violated its own policy by running an ad for Big East tickets. 
"They weren't consistent," said J.C. Salyer, a lawyer with the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, which represented the alumni group, known as Rutgers 1,000. "If you don't apply it consistently, you might as well have no policy at all. Instead, they got to choose who they liked. This upholds our right to be heard."
University officials interpreted the decision as a vindication of its policy, despite what the court said about violating that policy. 
"To my mind, that is at worst a failure of perception or, as the court elsewhere calls it, 'a lapse of sensitivity,' not constitutional viewpoint discrimination," the university's counsel, David R. Scott, said in a statement. The university has not decided whether to appeal.
Several national lobbying groups for higher education, including the American Council on Education and the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, had joined the appeal as friends of the court on Rutgers's behalf, arguing its right to set a policy on which ads to accept.
But the alumni group said the real issue was Rutgers's focus on sports.
The group wants Rutgers to move down a notch in the National Collegiate Athletic Association, from Division I to Division II, where the competition to attract big-name players would be less fierce. That competition, the group argues, forces universities to spend too much on athletic facilities and to ignore bad grades or poor qualifications of athletes.
"This is a victory for free speech, but as for the athletics juggernaut, that's so deeply embedded in American society that it will take a lot more than a bunch of alumni dissidents to detract from that," said Richard Seclow, a leader of the group.
