HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Strikes and Strike Threat Are Stanton's Concerns

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

 BODY:
Mike Stanton is making $2.5 million this year. His salary was $2.45 million last season and $2.4 million in 2000. Stanton knows these numbers are printed in newspapers, and he understands many people may never understand what he's fighting for.
 Stanton, the left-handed reliever, is the Yankees' representative to the players union. He is simultaneously trying to help his team win a World Series, secure another good contract this winter and repair the economic problems of an industry with no such thing as a quick fix. 
 Things are back to normal for Stanton on the field. On Sunday in Anaheim, he secured eight outs in the 9th, 10th and 11th innings as the Yankees beat the Angels, 7-5, in 12 innings. It was the best outing in a while for Stanton, whose earned run average since the All-Star Game break is 5.73.
His push for a new contract is in the background. Stanton is one of seven potential free agents on the Yankees, and General Manager Brian Cashman said the club is not currently negotiating with any of them.
"I don't really think about it," Stanton, 35, said. "I've got too much on the table to worry about something that's in the future."
Smack in the middle of Stanton's table is baseball's labor situation and the time it chews from his schedule. Stanton is on the union's negotiating team, which means weekly conference calls with the executive board and other player representatives. Those average 45 to 90 minutes each.
Then there are surveys to take, literature to distribute, teammates' questions to answer -- "The questions are never-ending," he said -- and, because he plays in New York, occasional meetings in Manhattan. Stanton did not campaign for the job, but he takes it seriously.
"It definitely takes time away from my family," he said. "It definitely takes time away from other things I'd like to be doing, including sometimes here at the field. But it's something that has to be done. It's an important job to make sure, if nothing else, that the guys stay informed and up to date."
Stanton was the assistant player representative to David Cone when Cone played for the Yankees. Last season, after Cone left, Stanton held the unofficial title. His teammates formally appointed him in June.
At their hotel in Arlington, Tex., last week, Yankees players met with Donald Fehr, the executive director of the union. Later some players referred questions about the meeting to Stanton, and others were vague or admitted that they had little interest.
The union takes pride in keeping all members informed, but the attention levels are diverse. As the Rangers held their meeting later that day at the park, for example, outfielder Carl Everett cruised by the conference room in a sports car, oblivious.
"I'd say about half the guys really get involved and know exactly what's going on," said Yankees catcher Chris Widger, who served three years as the Montreal Expos' player rep. "The other half just wants to hear the bottom line: what happens if we do this, what happens if we do that. They're interested, but they're not interested in the details."
Mike Mussina has an economics degree from Stanford, and he served eight seasons as the player representative for the Baltimore Orioles. That tenure covered the 1994 strike, which caused the cancellation of the World Series. Mussina, who is Stanton's assistant, said the membership is more involved now.
"Definitely, because the last time resulted in a long work stoppage," Mussina said. "Previous times, except for 1981, there always seemed to be a last-minute settlement, and veteran players just assumed it was going to be the way it was the times before. It was more, 'Give us the bottom line, we'll get back to baseball.' It didn't happen. We were out."
It may happen again. Stanton said the general reluctance of players to set a strike date should prove how much they want to avoid a strike. But Stanton also knows a date will be set soon.
Stanton's job includes not only keeping his teammates informed but also trying to explain the players' side to fans. There are things he wants to make clear.
"I've said it a bunch, and I hope the message is getting out: in the situation we're in, the road that we're on, we absolutely have no choice," Stanton said. "As a union, we have things going on in negotiations that we can't control without the inevitable.
"We thought we had an agreement last summer, but it wasn't meant to be. People have to understand that as a union, we don't have a choice. If we go through the regular season in good faith and we don't get a deal done, this off-season the whole system will go down the tubes. Whether it's implementation, collusion like it was in the late 80's, whatever it is, the whole system is going to fold.
"Something else people should know is, we're not looking to get us more money. We're looking to be fair to everyone. Nobody gets everything they want."
Stanton said he had heard only general feedback from fans. "They don't want a strike, and we don't want a strike," he said. He has never been hassled for being on the front lines of an emotional public dispute.
Ultimately, Stanton knows, the players must decide whether the fallout from another lengthy strike would be more costly than the owners' implementation of a new economic system.
That decision, apparently, has already been made, even though no strike date has been set.
"We absolutely don't want to make that look like a show of weakness," Stanton said. "We're as united as ever, and we'll do what we have to do."

INSIDE PITCH
JASON GIAMBI and DAVID WELLS were among the players who reported to Yankee Stadium for treatment on yesterday's off day. Giambi left Sunday's game in Anaheim with soreness in his lower back, and Wells was also bothered by back pain. General Manager BRIAN CASHMAN said that there were no medical appointments scheduled for either player and that he expected Giambi to play tonight against Kansas City. Wells is still on track to start Saturday against Oakland, but Cashman said the Yankees would have a better idea after he threw this week. JEFF WEAVER could start in his place.

HEADLINE: Immigration Cut Into Income In New York, Census Finds 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The surprising drop in median income in New York City that has puzzled demographers studying the results of the 2000 census appears to be traceable in large part to immigration, according to new census data that show income declines concentrated heavily in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have become magnets for new arrivals.
 The data, released yesterday, indicate that median household incomes rose across most of Manhattan in the 90's, with especially big leaps in places including TriBeCa and parts of Harlem. Simultaneously, drops occurred in much of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, often in neighborhoods like Jackson Heights and eastern Flushing, where longtime residents have moved out and been replaced by immigrants. 
 A similar pattern was visible in New Jersey. The biggest percentage jump in median household income occurred in Hunterdon County, a heavily white county at the heart of what has been called the state's flourishing wealth belt. Meanwhile, median income dropped in Newark, Paterson and Trenton, and in smaller cities where less educated, less skilled immigrants have moved in. 
Everywhere, the biggest gains in income were among whites, often in places populated heavily by people working in businesses like finance, pharmaceuticals and telecommunications. The biggest income increases among Asians were in suburban Middlesex and Somerset Counties in New Jersey, which have attracted large numbers of highly skilled and highly educated South Asians.
Blacks did less well. Although the median household incomes for all groups in New Jersey rose, when adjusted for inflation, the median for blacks alone rose by only 1.1 percent, to $38,513. The median for whites alone rose by 5.1 percent to $59,153; the median for Asians rose by 3.8 percent to $72,145; and the median for Latinos rose by 1.1 percent to $39,609.
"The income data are the result of an economy that has reinvented itself during the 1990's," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "This was really the rise of the new information-age, knowledge-based economy, in conjunction with the sustained decline of old-line manufacturing.
"That change has placed a premium on education and skill levels, and people who have those attributes have been rewarded greatly. At the same time, with the decline in manufacturing, those who have just a high school degree have been penalized economically. So we have that growing disparity linked to education level. And that has a racial component to it, because blacks and Latinos have lower levels of educational attainment."
In many cases, the richest communities remained the towns and neighborhoods that had been the richest in 1990: mostly white suburbs like Scarsdale, where the median household income rose by 16.6 percent to $182,792; and a handful of mostly white census tracts on the Upper East Side of Manhattan between Fifth and Park Avenues, where the medians approach $200,000.
Among the poorest places in the two states were many upstate New York cities, including Ithaca, Buffalo, Utica, Syracuse, Binghamton and Jamestown, where median household incomes were between $21,400 and $25,850. In New York City, the 20 neighborhoods with the lowest median income were concentrated in the Bronx and Brooklyn. They included Coney Island, with a median of $14,908.
But the biggest percentage jumps in median income in New York City occurred in a wide variety of places, illustrating the breadth of the neighborhood revival that took place in the 1990's. They ranged from struggling Bronx areas like Highbridge and Mott Haven to St. Nicholas Terrace in Harlem and gentrifying districts in Manhattan and Brooklyn like SoHo and Carroll Gardens.
"The rich got richer, Manhattan got better and immigrant neighborhoods had an income loss," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociologist at Queens College who analyzed the new census data relating to income for The New York Times. "The people who are living there now are making less money than the people who were living there 10 years ago."
The data released yesterday, which covered only New York and New Jersey, are just the latest among the results of the 2000 census, which the Census Bureau is releasing over several years. Preliminary income data, broken down only by county, came out in May. Those numbers had puzzled some analysts, who had expected to see the benefits of the late 1990's boom more broadly shared.
Similar patterns had also surfaced in the income data for other Northeastern cities and parts of Southern California, leading some demographers and economists to speculate that immigration might be a factor: that is, as low-wage workers were pouring in from places like Central America and China, native-born people and more established immigrants were moving up and out.
The Census Bureau is scheduled to release detailed data for other states, including Connecticut, in coming weeks.
According to Professor Beveridge's analysis of the New York and New Jersey numbers, median income rose in nearly every part of Manhattan, but most steeply in places like Clinton, Little Italy and much of downtown, where affluent whites have moved in. In Harlem, the median rose most markedly in the St. Nicholas Terrace section, where it climbed by 40.6 percent, to $24,031.
Chinatown, a landing pad for less educated and newly arrived Chinese immigrants, was one of the few Manhattan neighborhoods in which the median household income dropped. For Asians alone, it dropped by nearly 14 percent to $18,629. Elsewhere, median household incomes rose significantly on the Upper West Side, the West Village, the East Village and Kips Bay.
The growing affluence of Manhattan and its financial sector seemed to spill over to nearby neighborhoods in Brooklyn, like Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill, and to some communities across the Hudson River in New Jersey. The overall median household income for Hoboken leaped by 38.2 percent to $62,550, with the increase even higher among whites alone.
Outside New York City, some of the biggest increases were in growing communities on the exurban fringe, like Far Hills in Somerset County, N.J., and Rumson in Monmouth County, N.J. The increases were especially striking among affluent suburban whites. The median household income for whites alone in Scarsdale jumped by 49.9 percent, to $194,597.
Some of the biggest declines in median household income among whites occurred in cities that many whites had abandoned in recent years, like Asbury Park and East Orange, N.J., and in New York City neighborhoods like Flatbush, Brownsville and Bedford-Stuyvesant, where whites were once dominant, but are now a tiny minority.
Similarly, the highest black median incomes were in communities where blacks were in a small fraction of the population, like Marlboro and West Windsor townships in New Jersey. But the median household incomes among blacks were also relatively high in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in New York and Middlesex and Burlington Counties in New Jersey, all of which have significant black populations.
In New York City, the neighborhoods with the highest median income among blacks still included Rosedale, Laurelton and Cambria Heights, three middle-class black areas in Queens where black incomes have tended to outstrip white. The black medians there had dropped slightly, but were still relatively high, at $64,391 in Rosedale, $62,801 in Laurelton and $59,144 in Cambria Heights.
Similarly, the highest household incomes among Latinos were in places with relatively few Latinos, including Scarsdale and the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The lowest were in upstate New York cities like Utica, Syracuse and Buffalo. In New York City, the neighborhoods with the lowest Latino median incomes were all in the Bronx and Brooklyn.
In Hunts Point, for example, where immigrants from the Dominican Republic and elsewhere have been moving into places that Puerto Ricans left behind, the median income among Latinos rose by nearly 10 percent, to $15,529. But it still remained among the lowest in the city.
The lowest median incomes for Asians in New York City were not only in Chinatown and Little Italy, but also Sunset Park and Borough Park in Brooklyn. The neighborhoods with the highest include Bellerose and Floral Park in Queens.
Professor Hughes, who also looked at the education data for New Jersey, said he was struck by two things: that 62 percent of all adult Asians in New Jersey had at least a bachelor's degree, a figure he called "extraordinarily high," and that 12.5 percent of adult Latinos in the state had a bachelor's degree, a percentage he called surprisingly low.
The average for all adults in New Jersey is 29.8 percent.

LENGTH: 600 words

HEADLINE: Signs of Change Are Appearing in a Struggling Area of the Bronx 

BYLINE:  By MARC SANTORA 

 BODY:
The Highbridge section of the Bronx is not a Starbucks kind of place.
 The neighborhood, north of Yankee Stadium along the Harlem River, is a rough part of the city where liquor stores and vacant lots line the block instead of boutiques and trendy restaurants. 
 Still, there are signs that the people of this community are, if not in a state of transition, at least beginning to peek around the corner at a better life. According to data gathered in the 2000 census, household incomes have risen 44.8 percent since 1990, the fifth-highest increase in New York. 
A quick tour of the neighborhood reflects the change. Some parks are newly refurbished and safe. There are still weedy lots surrounded by barbed wire, but there are also renovated six-story brick apartment buildings, their old stone scrubbed clean.
The sharp rise in median income is partly due to the low starting point. In 1990, the average family earned only $14,569. Today the average income, at $21,094, is still one of the lowest in New York. 
But it is real money.
"This place is not so bad as it once was," Larry Myers, 70, said yesterday as he watched children play on the jungle gym and splash in the water spouts in the recently refurbished Nelson Park. He pointed at buildings on the blocks around the park, rattling off which ones had been redone. "They are cleaning this place up," he said, satisfied.
Mr. Myers has been coming to the park for more than a decade, and he recalls when half of it was still a nasty parking lot and the other half was ramshackle. He said a drop in crime, not the rise in incomes, was the biggest change. "How many parents do you see around?" he asked as he gestured toward the children. "It's safe now."
He thought that attracted the new immigrant families that are rapidly changing the face of Highbridge. "We have Dominicans, people from the West Indies, Africa, you name it."
Demographers see this immigration influx, made up mainly of Dominicans and Africans, as a major factor in the census data. While immigrants may bring income levels down over all in the city, they tend to do the opposite in some poor neighborhoods, experts say.
"There is an experiment going on in Highbridge and in other parts of the Bronx," said Dr. William Bosworth, director of the Bronx Data Center at Lehman College. "Is it possible to establish a dynamic immigrant, minority, middle-class neighborhood?"
While the answer to that question is a long way off, Dr. Bosworth said, the initial signs are encouraging.
"About 80 years ago, people came to the Bronx from the Lower East Side to get one step up the ladder," Dr. Bosworth explained. He speculated that with the booming Dominican population just across the Harlem River in Washington Heights, perhaps a similar migration, west to east, was taking place as stable working families searched for more affordable and larger living spaces in Highbridge. Renovation efforts by the city and private groups have opened up opportunities for immigrants that simply were not there a decade ago, he said.
Of course, how well things are is a matter of perspective. Vernice Mazyck has lived in a high-rise housing project on Ogden Avenue for 33 years. "It's poor and getting poorer," she said. "I live in a place where the water leaks, the elevator is not running, rats are in the hallway, pit bulls fight outside and the kids with the drugs don't stop." 
Joe Johnson, who has lived in Highbridge for 50 years, also said the people at the census must be daft. "There is no more money here," he said. "The only money is in the Lotto, and no one has hit that around here for 20 years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The children playing behind him in recently refurbished Nelson Park represent one of the changes that Larry Myers is seeing in the Highbridge neighborhood of the Bronx. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

Israel Tightens Travel Ban In Northern West Bank

Four men shot their way into an isolated boarding school for the children of Christian missionaries, killing six Pakistanis. HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
MEMO PAD

BYLINE:  ByJOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
Travel Rebound Has Yet to Arrive
That expected travel rebound just isn't happening this summer.
 Despite deep fare cuts, the major airlines continue to report sharp drops in passenger traffic. American Airlines said its traffic dropped 9.7 percent in July from July 2001; Continental Airlines' traffic was off 8.6 percent, and Delta Air Lines' was down 6.6 percent -- on systems that are now putting 6 to 10 percent fewer seats in the air than this time last year. When they report their July traffic this week, the other major carriers, United Airlines, Northwest Airlines and US Airways, are not expected to buck the dire trend. 
 Meanwhile, the hotel business also languishes in the doldrums. Occupancy rates at domestic hotels were off 3.6 percent, to 59.5 percent, in the first half of this year compared with the first half of 2001, according to Smith Travel Research.
PKF Consulting said that hotels experienced an average 19.4 percent decline in profits in 2001. PKF also said that hotels in major cities -- which are typically most dependent on business travel -- had a drop of 9 percent in occupancy rates in the first quarter of 2002.
Hardest hit: San Francisco, where hotel occupancy was off 17.1 percent in the first quarter, compared with drops of 4.9 percent in New York, 13.5 percent in Chicago, 10.2 percent in Los Angeles, 14.5 percent in Boston and 12.5 percent in Dallas.
Any positive news? "We believe that full-year 2002 industry operating performance will improve slightly versus 2001," said Mark Lomanno, the president of Smith Travel Research. Assuming, he hedged, the economy starts growing and there are no further terrorist calamities.

Southwest Airlines Lowers Some Fares
Let the good times can roll in Las Vegas. Southwest Airlines last week announced a spate of low fares for travel between Los Angeles and Las Vegas this fall. That is a route, incidentally, that many more people are driving rather than flying these days to avoid airports.
From Sept. 3 through next Jan. 10, one-way fares between Los Angeles and Las Vegas are $19. You read it right, $19. That doesn't include various airport and security fees, which can pile another $17 or so onto that ticket price.
At the same time, feisty little National Airlines is cutting the cost of upgrades to first class on its routes between Las Vegas and any West Coast city it serves in a bid to attract business travelers and high rollers. First-class upgrades now cost $40 each way on routes between Las Vegas and Los Angeles or San Francisco, and $60 between Seattle and Las Vegas. JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: Illegal Immigrant Death Rate Rises Sharply in Barren Areas 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: EL CENTRO, Calif. 

 BODY:
The dying season began early here this year, with four bloated bodies found floating in the All-American Canal on March 14. The victims, young men ages 19 and 20, had made their way from Chiapas, in southernmost Mexico, before drowning in the canal's churning currents just 35 yards from United States land.
 For the Imperial County Sheriff's Department, it was an ominous sign. The dead usually start showing up in multiples in high summer, when the desert becomes an inferno and the canal, roiling beneath a calm veneer, lures migrants looking for a quick way across and relief from the killing sun. If bodies were washing up in groups in March, what would the summer be like? 
 The answer, so far, is grim. Even though deaths along the Mexican border have declined over all as the slumping American economy has attracted fewer migrants, the toll is reaching record rates in the most remote and dangerous outposts. To avoid the stepped-up border patrols in populated areas, the most desperate migrants cross in the more unguarded and desolate deserts of Arizona and eastern California. June was the deadliest month ever for the southwest border, with 67 migrants dying, mostly in the unrelenting heat of the United States Border Patrol's Tucson sector, a barely habitable land that covers most of southern Arizona. 
Here in the mountainous El Centro sector, which includes the vast Imperial Desert, 52 migrants have died since Oct. 1. The sheriff's department believes the deaths could outpace last year's record of 95.
"It seems quiet, but we're finding more multiples -- bodies in threes, fours and fives," said Gary Hayes, a deputy coroner in the department. "They're really trying to avoid detection, so they're going to more and more remote areas."
The rising toll in these barren regions is the more remarkable because illegal immigration from Mexico has fallen 29 percent, largely because of the faltering United States economy and tighter security, and border deaths in general are down 20 percent. 
Experts warn that the deadliest months are to come. August, traditionally, is the cruelest. They also note that the statistics do not include people who die in Mexico. (The Mexican government counted 22 migrants who died inside its border in June. It counts only Mexicans and not migrants who pass through from Central America or elsewhere.)
The deaths are full of suffering. People have suffocated in airless trucks, died in vehicle crashes, been struck by lightning or drowned. Most often, though, they are felled by heatstroke or dehydration. Some carry no identification and, in a tragic irony, end up where they wanted to be, in the United States -- but in anonymous pauper's graves. Other migrants, not counted by the Border Patrol, never make it across. 
Migrant advocacy organizations blame the Border Patrol for the mounting deaths, saying that its decision to focus its policing on border cities has driven migrant traffic to the most severe terrain, with the most extreme climates, winter and summer. The policy, which began as Operation Gatekeeper in 1994, added officers, enhanced surveillance equipment and put up physical barriers like concrete walls, as well as introducing other measures, at the San Diego border. The strategy was then expanded to Arizona and Texas.
Since the operation began, about 2,000 migrants have died trying to cross into this country, according to the Mexican government, with an average of more than one a day in the last two years. The shift has also made expensive smugglers -- called coyotes -- indispensable. Possibly hundreds of migrants have died because they have been abandoned by these smugglers, or because they have been led by people who themselves could not manage a brutal landscape, their advocates say.
"Once the deaths started happening by the dozens in the mountains east of San Diego," the federal government "never rethought its strategy," said Claudia Smith, border project director for the California Rural Legal Assistance Foundation, in San Diego. "The Border Patrol, as planned, went on to push them into the deserts," she said, "where the risk increased exponentially."
The Border Patrol denies that its policies are responsible for the increase in deaths and has no plans to change its strategy. It counters that it is doing everything it can to deter migrants from passing through the desert, including adding medically trained search and trauma teams to rescue migrants, helicopter patrols in treacherous areas and several rescue beacons in the desert that send an electronic distress signal with the push of a button. It has also mounted a public service campaign in Mexico and Central America, using celebrities to do television and radio advertisements to warn would-be migrants of the dangers of trying an illegal border crossing.
"Our primary mission is to protect our nation's borders," said Mario Villarreal, a spokesman for the Border Patrol in Washington, D.C., adding that unscrupulous smugglers, charging between $1,000 and $2,000 a person or more, are to blame for persuading would-be border crossers to make the dangerous trek.
Crossing the border illegally has always come with risks. Before Operation Gatekeeper, most traffic entered via cities like San Diego and El Paso, where migrants became targets for muggers and the like.
A study released in July by the Public Policy Institute of California, a research organization in San Francisco, found that the Gatekeeper strategy, which costs more than $2 billion a year, has done little to significantly diminish illegal immigration. It actually increased after the border buildup. Economic opportunities in the United States and Mexico, the study found, have a stronger effect on migration than does the number of agents at the border.
Migrants risking their lives in the extremes of the desert tend to come from the poorest states in Mexico, like Chiapas and Oaxaca, where the economy is in collapse and whole villages have been vacated by working-age men, and, increasingly, women. At Casa Madre de Asunto in Tijuana, a safe house for migrant women that is run by a Catholic nun, a dozen or more women at a time have either migrated to the city from the south or have stopped by on their way to cross the border.
Recently, a 31-year-old woman from Oaxaca said she and her brother, a cousin and a friend, who were resting at a safe house for men next door, had driven for two days and two nights to make it to Tijuana and planned to make a two-day trek through mountains with a "coyote" who was taking them into Los Angeles, charging them $1,500 each.
"That's $1,000 less than he charges others," she said, "because he knows us." She had tried to make the trek months before, she said, but lost her nerve after feeling faint and dehydrated and turned back after a day. 
She said she hoped to become a maid or work in a store and make some money to send to her mother. "I'm coming for a better life for all of us," she said.
Days later, a woman at the safe house said she assumed the group had made it across; they had not heard from the Oaxaca woman.
When smugglers are caught, said Mr. Villarreal of the Border Patrol, efforts are made to prosecute them. In a recent incident in Dallas, where two men were found dead in a stifling 54-foot-long truck that had transported 40 illegal immigrants from El Paso, a nine-hour trip, two truckers have been charged with murder. 
"This is good work' but we're not done," Mr. Villarreal said. "The main message we still want to get out is that it is dangerous to try to cross along the southwest border." 
Here in the El Centro sector, five suspected illegal immigrants died of heat exposure in mid-July in an area of the Imperial Desert that resembles a moonscape. "It's almost totally devoid of plant life," Mr. Hayes, the deputy coroner, said.
Spotted by a military aircraft, the bodies could not retrieved for a day because of the terrain. Mr. Hayes said satellite equipment was needed to mark the positions of the bodies.

(Monica Almeida/The New York Times)(pg. A12) Map of the Southwest and Mexico shows migrant deaths in border patrol sectors. (pg. A12)

Buyer for Hospitals Agrees To Change Its Practices
Under pressure from Congress, Premier, a company that helps about a quarter of the nation's hospitals buy drugs, medical devices and other supplies, has agreed to change the way it does business.
 Premier has agreed to contract with more companies, stop investing in supply companies and limit how much money it accepts from companies that receive contracts. Negotiators are trying to reach a similar agreement with another buying group, Novation. Page A1. 

Microsoft Plans Release of Data
In an effort to comply with a proposed antitrust settlement, Microsoft plans to disclose more technical data than it ever has before about its Windows operating system. C8.

Procter Reports Higher Earnings
Procter & Gamble reported fourth-quarter earnings that topped expectations largely because of sales of its beauty and health care products. For the quarter, Procter & Gamble reported earnings of $910 million in contrast to a loss of $320 million a year ago. Net sales rose 6.1 percent, to $10.17 billion. C4.

Cablevision Systems plans to retire shares that track its interests in Rainbow Media Group. The announcement could be a precursor to Cablevision's selling some networks or other assets; the company is facing a deficit of at least $600 million next year. C3.

Taiwan's stock market fell in response to deteriorating relations with China, but the dispute is unlikely to affect either side's economy. World Business, Section W.

S.E.C. Is Investigating Mirant

For Big Oil, Open Door in Far East
Vast reserves of natural gas and oil in Russia just north of Japan and Korea have drawn the interest of several multinational companies. Foreign companies are expected to invest about $13 billion there in the next four years. World Business, Section W.

Service Sector Growth Slows
The service sector grew for a sixth consecutive month in July but the pace of expansion slowed. The Institute for Supply Management said its monthly nonmanufacturing index fell to 53.1 in July, the lowest since January. C3.

President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil, left, has received assurances from Treasuary Secretary Paul H. HEADLINE: A Distracted China Issues Censure of Taiwan Chief's Remarks 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Distracted by back-room maneuvering over leadership changes here, China has offered little more than a boilerplate response to aggressive statements on relations with Taiwan by its president, Chen Shui-bian, and has suggested that his own constituents may provide the strongest censure of his remarks.
 Li Wei-yi, a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, issued a statement denouncing Mr. Chen's comments. Mr. Li said that the comments would have ramifications for Taiwan's economy and that they would probably have ramifications for the personal interests of Taiwan residents as well. 
 Mr. Chen said on Saturday that holding a referendum on Taiwan's independence was a "basic human right" and that, in reality, there was "one country on each side" of the Taiwan Strait. 
China has long threatened to use force against Taiwan if it declares outright independence or refuses to agree eventually to reunify with the mainland.
China may yet take some symbolic action to express its displeasure over Mr. Chen's remarks; war games are already planned on the coast opposite Taiwan in the weeks ahead.
But China's condemnation of Taiwan's president centered on an increasingly unavoidable reality in the decades-old standoff between the governments in Beijing and Taipei -- that Taiwan's economy is fast becoming dependent on the mainland.
Already, one quarter of Taiwan's exports go to China, the biggest and fastest-growing market for the island's goods, and nearly all of Taiwan's major businesses now have investments on the mainland, totaling more than $50 billion. 
With the island's economy at low ebb and the economies of its other markets slowing, goading China into punitive action could be economically, if not politically, suicidal for Mr. Chen.
Rebukes were swift. Taiwan's biggest opposition party, the Nationalist Party, which ran Taiwan until 2000, was harshly critical of him, saying he was turning the pro-independence policies of his Democratic Progressive Party into government policy despite having promised to pursue a centrist course in office.
"In this context, it is very risky," said Steven S. F. Chen, Taiwan's top diplomat in the United States until 2000 and now a national security expert at the National Policy Foundation, the Nationalist Party's research center.
Members of President Chen's administration, meanwhile, scrambled to discount the significance of his remarks.
"Do not overinterpret" Mr. Chen's comments, Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, said before leaving on a hastily scheduled trip to the United States to reassure American officials that the island is not pursuing a major shift in strategy. "Taiwan's China policy has not changed."
The United States has long counseled Taiwan against declaring independence, though China renewed its accusation today that Washington has emboldened Taipei with diplomatic support and continued weapons sales. 
President Bush said last year that he would do "whatever it takes" to help Taiwan defend itself against the mainland.
In fact, Mr. Chen's comments, while the strongest since he took office two years ago, did not go beyond the language of a 1999 resolution on Taiwan's future adopted by his Democratic Progressive Party.
Mr. Chen had not repeated that language since he took office, when he promised not to declare statehood or to push for an independence referendum if China would abandon its threat to use force against the island.
But Beijing has not renounced that threat, and some experts believe that Mr. Chen may be taking advantage of China's distraction ahead of the Communist Party's coming congress, at which crucial leadership changes will be decided, to put the language back on the table, pleasing pro-independence forces in Taiwan and putting some pressure on Beijing.
Andrew Yang, the secretary general of the Chinese Council of Advanced Policy Studies, a research center in Taipei, said Mr. Chen appeared to be calculating that China would pay attention to Taiwan only if he speaks strongly.

HEADLINE: How the States Are Run 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (column, July 30) indicates that recently many states have been financially run like banana republics, saying "responsibility gave way to political opportunism." In fact, I would argue strongly that over the boom period of 1995-2000, state governments were extremely prudent in their fiscal policies. 
 Aggregate state spending growth averaged only 6.1 percent over this period compared with the 6.5 percent average over the last 20 years. States also managed $27 billion in tax cuts while building almost $50 billion in "rainy day" funds in 2000. 
 While at times states make short-run adjustments, which are not always consistent with good long-term economic policy, that does not make them banana republics. A closer inspection of all the numbers would reveal that our state governments have been effective managers of taxpayers' money.

RAYMOND C. SCHEPPACH
Executive Director
National Governors Association
Washington, Aug. 2, 2002

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
 Visitors
Look for the the acclaimed Donmar Warehouse of London to be setting up shop at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January. The English company is bringing over its new productions of Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night" and Brian Friel's version of Chekhov's "Uncle Vanya," both directed by Sam Mendes. In an exclusive United States engagement, a cast featuring Emily Watson, Helen McCrory, Simon Russell Beale and Mark Strong will perform the two classics in repertory from Jan. 10 through Feb. 9. as part of the BAM Harvey Theater's 2003 spring season.

Milestones
When Mark Morris introduced "V" to New York last winter, Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times called it a life-affirming piece that "is also one of the few great works that modern dance has produced in a decade." From tonight through Sunday, when the Mark Morris Dance Group returns to Jacob's Pillow in Becket, Mass., "V" will be on its program.

Cash and Carriage
Around them, the world was changing. In the aftermath of the Civil War, the United States entered the Gilded Age, a period of swift industrial, economic and military growth in an atmosphere of intense commercialism and materialism. But the women depicted by leading artists seemed unaffected by its turbulence. Spirituality and serenity were their foremost characteristics. Through Aug. 27, in "The Gilded Age: Views of American Women, 1873-1921," the Corcoran Gallery in Washington is tapping its own collection of American art for more than 35 paintings, works on paper and sculpture by artists like John Singer Sargent, Mary Cassatt, Edmund Tarbell and Childe Hassam. Another Corcoran exhibition, "Art and Economics: Sienese Paintings From the Dawn of the Modern Financial Age," looks back to Siena, Italy, between the 13th and 17th centuries. Its focus is biccherne, small panels by leading artists who were commissioned by the Biccherna, the most important financial branch of the government, to create the covers of its semiannual collection of public ledgers. Through Sept. 23, 50 of the panel paintings and 12 related manuscripts will be on view.

Stepping Down
The president of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Henry Fogel, announced yesterday his decision to retire at the end of its 2002-3 season. Mr. Fogel, who turns 60 next month, said that after 18 years, "it was time for a change in my professional life." William H. Strong, chairman of the orchestra's board, will lead a committee to hire a successor by the 2003-4 season. Mr. Fogel oversees the operations of the orchestra, Symphony Center, the Civic Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony Chorus, the Chicago Symphony Singers and Symphony Center Presents, a series of classical and jazz attractions. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

HEADLINE: HSBC Raises Loan Reserves As 6-Month Profit Falls 7% 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
HSBC, the large banking company based in Britain, said today that its first-half earnings fell 7 percent as it set aside more money to cover bad debts.
 Like other global banks, HSBC is suffering from its exposure to Argentina, and it increased its provision for bad debt 62 percent, to $715 million. 
 But the provision was lower than analysts had expected, while the fall in profit to $3.28 billion was less drastic than had been forecast, leaving the company's shares slightly higher in London on a day when European and United States banking stocks declined. 
"The key point to note is a lack of negative surprises," said Paul Measday, an analyst with the Cazenove brokerage firm.
In the second half of last year, HSBC, , which is Europe's largest banking company in terms of market value, set aside even more money for bad Argentine debt, leading some analysts to conclude that the bank had written off the bulk of its Latin American exposure.
John Bond, the HSBC chairman, told a news conference in Hong Kong that the bank made no provisions for Brazil, which he called a well-managed country. The bank also said it saw no need to revise its already hefty provisions for its Argentine exposure.
HSBC says it does business in 79 countries and argues that this global reach has helped it withstand the shocks of a period in which, according to Mr. Bond, "the unfolding of a number of corporate scandals, particularly in the United States, drove investors to seek capital protection rather than capital growth."
Founded in Hong Kong almost 140 years ago, HSBC is looking to offset falling income in Hong Kong and Europe by strengthening its position in Britain and the United States, where it bought Republic New York in 1999 for $10.3 billion.
It said today that first-half pretax profit in the United States rose 9 percent to $652 million, while its pretax earnings in Europe fell 8 percent in the same period.
HSBC says it is looking for potential acquisitions in Mexico, China and the United States, but bank executives declined to comment today on the status of any discussions. HSBC says it has approached some shareholders in Bital, Mexico's fifth-largest bank and is in talks with Ping An Insurance in China. It has not identified further acquisition targets in the United States.
At a time when many investors are desperately seeking an end to the lurching declines of global stock markets, HSBC offered only a pessimistic assessment.
"It is unlikely that the decline in personal wealth caused by the fall in equity markets can be reversed quickly by macroeconomic policy actions," Mr. Bond said. "Consumers who drove a prolonged period of growth and mitigated the effects of the bursting of the technology and telecoms' bubble are becoming more cautious. Without growth in corporate profitability and investment, a stock market rebound is unlikely."

HEADLINE: Warlord Pushes for Control Of a Corner of Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: KHOST, Afghanistan, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Padsha Khan Zadran, a warlord as volatile as the region he rules over, is again making trouble for the new central government in Afghanistan -- and this time the government is hinting that it might hit back with force.
 For four days recently, supporters of Mr. Zadran demonstrated in the streets here, intermittently blocking trucks heading north toward Kabul, the capital. There is some question about how large the protests have been, but the message was clear: the protesters shouted for the nation's new president, Hamid Karzai, either to resign or to give some official post to Mr. Zadran. 
 Mr. Karzai's government, under pressure to control lawlessness in Afghanistan's outlands, struck back, in words for now. He issued a statement on Sunday, read on national television, calling Mr. Zadran and his heavily armed men a "group of bandits." But it warned further that the government might be "forced to take any actions deemed necessary to keep the peace and stability."
If Mr. Karzai indeed were to use military force, as his aides say is possible, it would be the first time -- and against a man who has defied him, and the notion of central authority in Afghanistan, repeatedly.
For his part, Mr. Zadran, 50, in an interview today under a mulberry tree and not far away from a box of mortar shells, smiled to the point of baring his silver molars and fairly dared Mr. Karzai to try.
"I don't know who would win if we fought," Mr. Zadran said, near the remains of his old house, bombed by Soviet planes two decades ago, on a dusty path outside Gardez in the southeast. "But he would be betraying Afghanistan."
"He has no power outside of Kabul," he added, referring to Mr. Karzai. "He is a man guarded by Americans. He has no one with him except some soldiers from the north. And now he wants to come fight us?"
Mr. Zadran's taunts stabbed deliberately to the heart of criticism against Mr. Karzai: that, after seven months as Afghanistan's effective leader, confirmed by a national council two months ago, he has yet to take firm control of this fractious nation. Last month, he accepted protection from American bodyguards.
Regional warlords operate freely, including Mr. Zadran in the east, and another, Ismail Khan, near the western city of Herat. Last week Mr. Khan engaged in fighting that some reports said left 50 people dead. 
Omar Samad, a spokesman for Mr. Karzai, said that the government developed a new focus and that "we know where we are heading." 
"But it's going to take time to overcome all the burdens and obstacles -- and part of that is overcoming all the local commanders," he said.
He said the government, so far, has been reluctant to continue Afghanistan's culture of violence. But, in regard to Mr. Zadran and the protests, he said the government may lose patience and "resort to other means -- I'm not going to spell out what other means."
If there is a showdown, it would occur in a place that is already one of the least stable in Afghanistan. Once a center for training camps for Al Qaeda, slammed by American cruise missiles in 1998, this small city near the mountainous border with Pakistan is where American forces have been most active in recent months. 
Indeed Mr. Zadran and his men have played several roles in the American hunt for Taliban and Qaeda forces here. He says 600 of his 6,000 soldiers are in the direct pay of the Americans.
Mr. Zadran's fight with Mr. Karzai stretches back to just after the peace agreement last December in Bonn, which brought the country an interim government and landed Mr. Zadran the job of governor of Paktia Province. But fighting broke out when another local warlord blocked him from taking office in the city of Gardez. 
Then in April, Mr. Zadran sought his revenge, carrying out a rocket attack on Gardez that killed 36 people, including many women and children. 
Since then, there has been an uncomfortable standoff, with Mr. Zadran claiming effective control over three southeastern provinces -- Khost, Paktia and Paktika. Mr. Karzai appointed a new governor of Khost Province, a professor who lived in Australia, and recently appointed a new regional military commander to replace one of Mr. Zadran's younger brothers, Kamal Khan, 28, who held the job for seven months. 
The standoff here is plain to see: Kamal Khan is occupying the governor's quarters and has refused to leave. He is guarded by dozens of his brother's soldiers, who have machine guns and rocket propelled grenades and who, incongruously but by local tradition, wear flowers in their weapons belts. 
"I want to leave," the younger brother said today. "But the people with weapons don't want me to leave."
He was surrounded in his office, decorated with a portrait of Afghanistan's recently returned king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, by nine local elders. They say they are the ones behind the protests here, which they say will continue until their demands are met. 
Those demands include a formal position for Mr. Zadran. They also want a greater say in the central government for ethnic Pashtuns like themselves, who they say have lost out to ethnic Tajiks under Mr. Karzai, who is himself Pashtun. 
"If they want to resolve this peacefully, we will accept that," said one of the elders, Zamil Khan. "Otherwise we will fight until they recognize Padsha Khan Zadran as head of the region."
On Sunday, the king himself issued a statement asking Mr. Zadran to back down.
"I declare openly that anybody anywhere who wants to disturb peace in this country, Padsha Khan Zadran or anybody else in any province of Afghanistan, do not have and will not have our support in any form," he wrote.
Even some of Mr. Zadran's supporters are worried. Today, he received a delegation of educated men from Khost -- doctors and engineers mostly -- who said they supported his goals but begged him not to push his struggle militarily. 
"Tonight we will try to convince him not to fight," said Wazir Padshah, 45, an economist on his way to a large dinner with Mr. Zadran. "We are afraid if they don't give him a position, he will fight. 
"This transitional government is not stable," he added. "If this fighting happens, it might collapse."

HEADLINE: Trailing in Polls, German Leader Tries Early Start in Race 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, his party trailing badly in the opinion polls, opened his campaign for re-election today, three weeks early, pledging to protect "the little guy" and warning against "playing around with war or military action" in Iraq.
 Mr. Schroder, appearing combative at a rally of 10,000 people in his hometown, Hanover, tried to give new life to his lagging prospects, badly damaged by a weak economy and high unemployment. 
 With his conservative opponent, Edmund Stoiber, thought to be the better economic manager, Mr. Schroder today presented himself as a wiser head in foreign policy, repeatedly questioning the wisdom of military action in Iraq. 
"I warn against speculating about war and military action and tell those who are making plans for such actions to think not only about how they are going in, but to have a political concept," he said.
"We are ready for solidarity, but this land will not be prepared for adventures, as long as I'm in control," he continued. "I believe we should keep up the pressure on Saddam Hussein, yes. But I'm not for playing around with war or military action."
The world's economy, he said, "is in no state to take on new burdens."
Mr. Schroder introduced a new theme, stressing "the German way," giving his campaign a bit of nationalist flavor and reminding some political experts of Willy Brandt's line: "Germans, we can be proud of our country."
In private, German officials say that Berlin will be with the United States on Iraq -- so long as the Bush administration makes its case publicly about the dangers of weapons of mass destruction, honestly pursues unconditional weapons inspections through the United Nations and seeks a new resolution authorizing military action from the United Nations Security Council.
Agreement on those conditions is shared among the major European nations, including Britain, the most pro-American of them. Still, no one expects the Germans to fight in Iraq.
The focus on Iraq is essentially about domestic politics, said Michael Werz, a political scientist at the University of Hanover, the capital of Lower Saxony, where Mr. Schroder was governor before becoming chancellor in 1998.
"Schroder and the Social Democrats are desperate to run a more polarized campaign versus Stoiber," Mr. Werz said, and are using Iraq to shore up support on the left and attract those who might vote for the former Communists. Mr. Stoiber, though expressing his own doubts about how big a threat to Germany Iraq represents, has regularly called for closer and less confrontational relations with the United States.
Mr. Stoiber's foreign-policy spokesman, Wolfgang Schauble, has criticized Mr. Schroder for making Iraq a campaign issue at a time when the world should be united with the United States in putting pressure on Iraq to open up to unconditional arms inspections. But pressure must be accompanied, Mr. Schauble says, by a credible threat of military action. That means, he said today, that nobody should say now "that we will never take part in military action."
Mr. Schroder, who had planned to start his formal election a month before the Sept. 22 vote, was driven to start early by the polls, where he is trailing the conservative parties by a steady 5 to 7 percentage points. But Germans prefer the media-savvy Mr. Schroder personally over Mr. Stoiber, a relatively colorless man who is stressing his economic competence as the leader of Bavaria. 
"The situation is still shaky for Stoiber," Mr. Werz said. "Stoiber is utterly boring, and nobody really likes him, and his strategy is to say little of any interest."
In the first of his visits to close to 50 German cities, Mr. Schroder promised a strong battle to the finish, saying, "I'm utterly convinced that a signal will go out from here: The Social Democrats are getting ready to battle."
But his current coalition partners, the Greens, are struggling with about 7 percent of the vote, not enough to recreate the existing "red green" coalition even if Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats beat the conservatives.
The resignation of Gregor Gysi, the leader of the Party for Democratic Socialism, the reformed East German Communists, has hurt their chances of remaining over the 5 percent of the vote required to get seats in Parliament. Mr. Gysi, charismatic and funny, was the only prominent party figure and the only one popular among younger voters and in western Germany, which has four times the east's population.
He resigned over a scandal about the use of air miles for personal trips, and quit his job as the economics minister in the city of Berlin, too, where he was replaced today by Harald Wolf, the party's parliamentary leader.
"If the P.D.S. falls out below the threshold, the beneficiary will be the Social Democrats," said Richard Hilmer, director of the Infratest Dimap polling group. With at least 26 percent of the electorate still undecided, he said, "the options are still open, but Schroder must convince voters that he really has a chance and the will to fix things."

HEADLINE: O'Neill Encourages Brazil in I.M.F. Talks 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Amid signs that the Bush administration is easing its resistance to bailing out crisis-ridden Latin American economies, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill assured Brazil's president today of Washington's support in its negotiations with the International Monetary Fund.
 Meeting here, Mr. O'Neill and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso held what the American described as "cordial and very useful" talks about how to help Brazil cope with its worst financial crisis since the sharp devaluation of its currency, the real, in 1999. 
 With some investors increasingly nervous that elections in October could end in victory for a left-wing candidate, the real has plummeted to record lows in recent weeks, settling in New York late today at 33.15 cents, up from 32.44 cents on Friday. 
This has aggravated a credit squeeze on international markets that is pushing Brazilian companies so hard that many analysts predict a series of corporate defaults. Last week, as the crisis worsened, Brazil dispatched negotiators to Washington to lobby for I.M.F. support.
"I repeated President Bush's strong support for Brazil," Mr. O'Neill said today after his meeting with Mr. Cardoso. "We support the discussions the Brazilian authorities are now having with the I.M.F."
"As the largest economy in Latin America, Brazil's success is important to the economic success of the entire hemisphere," he added. "Brazil has the right economic policies in place to maintain stability."
Just a week ago, Mr. O'Neill was less than enthusiastic about coming to Brazil's aid. He helped add to a sense of market panic by suggesting that there could be no fresh aid to sorely pressed Latin American economies unless there were guarantees that the money would not be diverted to Swiss bank accounts, presumably of corrupt officials.
Those off-the-cuff remarks infuriated Brazilian business executives and set off a diplomatic spat. The Brazilian foreign ministry summoned the United States ambassador, Donna J. Hrinak, to explain the remarks, and the weekly business magazine Istoe Dinheiro put the Treasury secretary on its cover with the headline, "O'Neill, Brazil Doesn't Want You Here." An article inside described him as a loose cannon who on several occasions has offended and damaged the country.
In speeches here today, Mr. O'Neill praised economic changes that Mr. Cardoso introduced over the last eight years. These have brought stability and large amounts of foreign investment. More recently, though, economic growth has been disappointing.
Brazilian officials who met with Mr. O'Neill when he arrived in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday night were upbeat about the visit, but none risked predicting the outcome of the talks with the I.M.F. And the currency's value failed to rally in any notable way.
Many analysts are skeptical that the I.M.F. will provide any fresh funds without a pledge from all the election candidates to continue a tight fiscal policy and to try to keep inflation low.
But the two leading candidates, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of the Workers Party and Ciro Gomes of the Labor Front, have refused to make any such pledge, saying that until after the elections, the economy is the government's responsibility.
Mr. O'Neill will leave Brazil on Tuesday for visits to the two other crisis economies in the region, Uruguay and Argentina. Washington has agreed to provide $1.5 billion in interim financing to Uruguay to keep its banks afloat until additional I.M.F. loans can be arranged, but it has yet to help Argentina, which at the beginning of the year defaulted on most payments on its $141 billion debt.
The hastily assembled aid package for Uruguay has been seen by some analysts as an easing of the Bush administration's philosophical opposition to bailing out emerging economies in trouble, unless like Turkey, they are deemed to be of strategic importance in American efforts against terrorism.
"It's not a lot of money, but it is highly symbolic in terms of a change in attitude," Douglas Smith, a New York-based independent consultant and former Treasury official, said of the interim loan to Uruguay. "This administration came to office vocally opposing such handouts."

HEADLINE: The Memory Hole 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Winston Smith, the protagonist of George Orwell's "Nineteen Eighty-Four," was a rewrite man. His job was to destroy documents that could undermine the government's pretense of infallibility, and replace them with altered versions.
 Lately, Winston Smith has gone to Washington. I'm sure that lots of history is being falsified as you read this -- there are several three-letter agencies I don't trust at all -- but two cases involving the federal budget caught my eye. 
 First is the "Chicago line." Shortly after Sept. 11, George W. Bush told his budget director that the only valid reasons to break his pledge not to run budget deficits would be if the country experienced recession, war or national emergency. "Lucky me," he said. "I hit the trifecta."
When I first reported this remark, angry readers accused me of inventing it. Mr. Bush, they said, is a decent man who would never imply that the nation's woes had taken him off the hook, let alone make a joke out of it. 
Soon afterward, the trifecta story became part of Mr. Bush's standard stump speech. It always gets a roar of appreciative laughter from Republican audiences.
So what's the Chicago line? In his speeches, Mr. Bush claims to have laid out the criteria for running a deficit when visiting Chicago during the 2000 campaign. But there's no evidence that he said anything of the sort during the campaign, in Chicago or anywhere else; certainly none of the reporters who were with him can remember it. (The New Republic, which has tracked the claim, titled one of its pieces "Stop him before he lies again.") In fact, during the campaign his budget promises were unqualified, for good reason. If he had conceded that future surpluses were not guaranteed, voters might have wondered whether it was wise to lock in a 10-year tax cut.
About that 10-year tax cut: It basically takes place in two phases. Phase I, which has mainly happened already, is a smallish tax cut for the middle class. Phase II, which won't be completed until 2010, is a considerably larger cut that goes mostly to the richest 1 percent of taxpayers.
That two-phase structure offers substantial opportunities for misdirection. If someone suggests reconsidering future tax cuts, the administration can accuse him of wanting to raise taxes in a recession -- implying, falsely, that he wants to reverse Phase I rather than simply call off Phase II. On the other hand, if someone says that tax cuts have worsened the budget picture, the administration can say that tax cuts explain only 15 percent of the move into deficit. This sounds definitive, but in fact it refers only to the impact of Phase I on this year's budget; by the administration's own estimates, 40 percent of the $4 trillion deterioration in the 10-year outlook is due to tax cuts.
There is, however, an art to this sort of deception: you have to imply the falsehood without actually saying it outright. Last month the Office of Management and Budget got sloppy: it issued a press release stating flatly that tax cuts were responsible for only 15 percent of the 10-year deterioration. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities noticed, and I reported it here.
Now for the fun part. The O.M.B. reacted angrily, and published a letter in The Times attacking me. It attributed the misstatement to "error," and declared that it had been "retracted." Was it?
It depends on what you mean by the word "retract." As far as anyone knows, O.M.B. didn't issue a revised statement conceding that it had misinformed reporters and giving the right numbers. It simply threw the embarrassing document down the memory hole. As Brendan Nyhan pointed out in Salon, if you go to the O.M.B.'s Web site now you find a press release dated July 12 that is not the release actually handed out on that date. There is no indication that anything has been changed, but the bullet point on sources of the deficit is gone. 
Every government tries to make excuses for its past errors, but I don't think any previous U.S. administration has been this brazen about rewriting history to make itself look good. For this kind of thing to happen you have to have politicians who have no qualms about playing Big Brother; officials whose partisan loyalty trumps their professional scruples; and a press corps that, with some honorable exceptions, lets the people in power get away with it.
Lucky us: we hit the trifecta.

HEADLINE: Economy Stirs G.O.P. Worry In House Races 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
Rising voter concern about the nation's future, driven by an unsteady economy and unrest on Wall Street, is stirring nervousness among some Republicans and lifting confidence among Democratic leaders that their party could capture control of the House in November. That turn of events had seemed impossible two months ago.
 Although Republican leaders noted the considerable obstacles the party out of power faces in winning back the House for the first time since 1994 -- starting with the fact that so few seats are in play -- they expressed concern today about a gathering election climate that some argued could favor what had once seemed an improbable Democratic quest. 
 The factors behind the perceived shift include a spike in the number of Americans who told pollsters that the nation was heading in the wrong direction, a slight but steady erosion in the popularity of President Bush and rising disapproval of Congress over the last month. 
"Up through late May and early June, through WorldCom, I was arguing that we were looking at the most pro-incumbent environment that I've seen in a 22-year career," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who has conducted regular national polls of the electorate this year. "What has happened is that, because of WorldCom and the stock market collapse, these key tracking numbers have changed very quickly. We are looking at a much more traditional off-year election -- which means the House is in play. Which I never really believed in June."
A senior Republican strategist involved in a number of Congressional campaigns, who asked not to be identified, said today: "The map has changed. The House is a much more competitive environment."
Other Republicans expressed similar concerns, though not so starkly, saying they believed that Republicans would ultimately be able to ride out this period. "The Democrats have a real opportunity here," said Stuart Stevens, who was Mr. Bush's media adviser in 2000. But, Mr. Stevens said, he did not believe they would be able to take advantage of it. "They are flailing around."
But Democrats have showed increasing if measured signs of confidence in recent days. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said in an interview that Democrats were "gaining in optimism" and that as of now he thought many House elections would turn not on Mr. Bush's handling of the war in Afghanistan, but on the state of the economy and Wall Street.
Representative Nita M. Lowey of New York, the chairwoman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said: "Something is happening out there that is putting a nice wind at our back. It's not a cyclone yet, but I think it's a strong wind. And let's face it, for most of the cycle, we were really going against the wind."
To a certain extent, these public expressions of confidence by Democratic leaders are calculated. The suggestion that victory is within reach is likely to lift Democratic fund-raising totals, which have lagged significantly behind those of Republicans, and rally Democratic voters as the parties head into the fall campaign.
"They do this every two years," Representative Thomas M. Davis III, the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said in an interview. "We're looking at this race by race. We're not seeing any big-picture trends. Honestly, we are seeing no evidence of it."
Ken Mehlman, the White House political director, said he had found unwavering support among voters for Republican Congressional candidates. "Their claims are without any factual support in individual races," Mr. Mehlman said of the Democrats.
Yet the statements reflect an atmosphere that is unsettled in a way that has historically spelled difficulties for incumbents in general, and Republicans in particular.
Most recently, in a poll of 721 registered voters taken last week for National Public Radio by a polling consortium that included Mr. McInturff and a Democratic polling firm led by Stanley Greenberg, the number of respondents who said the nation had "seriously gotten off on the wrong track" jumped to 56 percent from 39 percent in one month. An increase in the number of people who say the nation is headed in the wrong direction is usually a matter of concern for the party in power.
The percentage of voters who disapprove of Congress jumped to 40 percent from 31 percent during that same time. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points.
With the nation at war and led by an extraordinarily popular chief executive, it had appeared until now that the election of 2002 would defy what had been for a century a near-certainty in American midterm elections: The party of the president suffers significant losses in Congress. Democrats argued that the campaign could thus be reverting to a more traditional form.
"This is a pretty strong historical trend out there," Mr. Gephardt said. "And if you add to that that people are unhappy about the economic situation, and about some of the things that the Republicans have tried to do on Social Security, or that they failed to do on prescription drugs and corporate responsibility, it can add up to a trend."
The election in the House has drawn the most spirited discussion among political leaders here in recent days, although the future of the Senate, which Democrats control by a single seat, is hardly settled. Members of both parties said that the Democrats seemed likely to retain or increase their control in the Senate, largely because of the same national forces that are fueling Democratic hopes in the House.
For all the political forces that Democrats argue are turning in their favor, the task of winning back the House would require the party to thread a very narrow eye of a needle. There are 222 Republicans, 210 Democrats, 2 independents and 1 vacancy in the House. The Republicans enjoy an advantage that comes from having many Congressional district lines redrawn this year by Republican-controlled legislatures, so most Republican members of Congress are not spending the hot summer months worrying about the season ahead.
Amy Walter, an analyst for The Cook Political Report, said she now listed 39 House seats as competitive, of which 11 are held by Democrats and 19 by Republicans, and the remaining 9 vacant or new seats created by redistricting. That means the Democrats would have to win two-thirds of those seats to become the party in power next year. To complicate matters for Democrats, Ms. Walter said that three seats held by Democrats who are departing were considered likely to be taken over by Republicans.
What is more, the Democrats' best-laid plans could be upended in a moment by any event that might turn the nation's attention overseas again. James Jordan, the executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, made half-joking reference to that today when he asked if he was worried that an October surprise -- an incident orchestrated by the White House to affect the November elections -- could be in the offing.
"You mean when General Rove calls in the airstrikes in mid-October?" Mr. Jordan said, referring to Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's senior political adviser.
Democrats argued that their best hope for winning the House is that concerns about the nation's economy and future turn the election into a referendum on the party in power.
Republicans say they have seen no evidence of that to date. Still, in expressing confidence that they would hold the House, party leaders pointed not to the national mood, but rather to political, fund raising and demographic forces that have created a political fire wall for Republicans.
"I've seen grim off-years and we're a thousand miles from that," Mr. McInturff said. "Thank goodness for the Republicans that there are far fewer competitive seats than there normally are in a reapportionment year, and that they are well-funded."
Several Republican leaders today expressed relief that Republicans on the Hill had moved aggressively to try to neutralize many issues that Mr. Gephardt wants to use in the elections, from reversing course to agree on a Democratic bill on corporate governance to proposing their own version of a prescription drug benefit bill for elder Americans. "Over the last couple of weeks, House Republicans passed prescription drugs, a homeland security bill, trade promotion authority and an emergency spending bill that protects our homeland and protects their economy," Mr. Mehlman said. "House Republicans are in a very strong position."
Even Mr. Jordan acknowledged today that the Republicans had had "some success in blurring these issues," although he added, "I don't think it will be enough."
That said, some Republicans said they were not as confident as they were two months ago, and were now closely watching poll numbers for any further signs of erosion of the position of either the party or Mr. Bush. In one particularly telling finding of the National Public Radio poll, the unhappiness with the direction of the nation was highest among women and older Americans, two groups that tend to vote in disproportionately high numbers in off-year elections.
"I would not have said this six months ago, and I may not be saying it two months from now, but I think we can do it," said Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant. "But we have to do a lot of work to get there."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Vacancy RateAside, a Tower Rises in Austin

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Tim Hendricks, a Dallas native who fell in love with Austin after a brief job at the State Legislature and a series of real estate courses at the University of Texas, is pressing every connection he has made in half a lifetime of dinners and weekends.
 And Cousins Properties, a real estate investment trust based in Atlanta, is counting on his connections with law firms and lobbyists here to make a success of a major commercial real estate project that is moving under full sail but into uncertain waters. 
 It is called Congress at Fourth, a 33-story tower with 524,000 rentable square feet of office space spread over 22 floors and set atop an 11-story parking garage. Construction workers have put up nearly half the parking section in the 96-degree heat, and by late 2003 they will have built the tallest structure in Austin -- one distinctive for its glass exterior alone, and which will change the face of the downtown district where Sam Houston once pitched his tepee by Town Lake and walked to work as governor. 
The project has a lot going for it, in terms of zoning variances, permits and fee waivers, but Cousins is missing one basic thing that Mayor Gustavo L. Garcia, who says he is no real estate expert and no economist, identified without hesitation.
"Demand," Mr. Garcia said. "Can downtown office space absorb 500,000 square feet? Investors are better judges of that than we are."
Cousins bought the property and started building from its own cash reserves. By paying cash, Cousins avoided the preleasing requirements that have become imperative for developers since the crash in real estate prices that followed the demise of the savings and loan industry.
So far, Mr. Hendricks, 46, a senior vice president of Cousins, has signed only three tenants -- two law firms and a contractor -- for a total of 90,000 square feet, or about 18 percent of the office space.
He plans to market the space as worth more than that of any existing building downtown. His building, he said, "will be a beacon for downtown Austin as it continues to evolve into a world-class central business district."
Mr. Hendricks declined to discuss any aspect of the building's financing, but people with direct involvement in the transactions said the total cost of development runs from $250 to $260 a rentable square foot, or $125 million to $130 million -- about 10 percent of Cousins's market capitalization.
The company, best known for the Bank of America Tower in downtown Atlanta, has a reputation for holding its projects as long-term investments, often finding an equity partner after construction and leasing are well under way.
Vacancy rates for the most desirable office space in Austin's 7.6-million-square-foot central business district, including sublease space, have risen to 21 percent as of June from 13.4 percent a year before and 4.9 percent (not including sublease space) in 2000, according to Capitol Market Research, an economics firm here. Average annual asking rents have fallen 18 percent since December, to $27.06 from $32.96.
Jeffrey Munger, director of research for Holliday Fenoglio Fowler, a unit of LendLease Real Estate Investments, said the Cousins project exemplifies an economic incentive to build in spite of the high vacancy rates in places like Austin, where permit processes are rigorous.
"Austin is probably the most difficult market to build in in Texas, in terms of building controls, environmental regulation, protection of strange animals you've never seen before," Mr. Munger said. "But at the same time, you've got the development psyche that permeates from Houston and Dallas and in this case, Atlanta."
Cousins did not become involved in the project until the site had been assembled and all the permit work and other dealing with government agencies had been done. A local developer, Tom Stacy -- along with a partner named Will Wynn, who backed away from the project when he successfully ran for the City Council -- acquired the block between Fourth and Fifth Streets on the east side of Congress Avenue in 1999 and briefly explored building on it themselves. They then unsuccessfully tried to sell it to Equity Office, a major national real estate investment trust, but the obstacles to development were significant.
There was an alley that could not be breached and a limit on height to protect the view of the Capitol building. Then there was an existing lease on a two-story building occupied by the Mexic-Arte Museum, a downtown foothold for Hispanic culture.
Over more than a year, Mr. Stacy gained all the zoning variances, along with fee waivers from the city, which is trying to counter sprawl with incentives for downtown construction. His partnership, known as Block 42, sold the property to Cousins in January 2001.
"They closed knowing the market was in a downward cycle," Mr. Stacy said.
Another developer, Carr America, opened a 446,391-square-foot office tower a few blocks away at 300 West Sixth Street last January, and the vacancy rate there is 35 percent. 
Mr. Hendricks will also face competition from existing landlords, who can afford to undercut him on asking rents. Almost all the buildings in downtown Austin changed hands in the early 1990's, at prices then below $116 a square foot. Brokers expect Mr. Hendricks to ask $33 to $38 annually per square foot, compared with current prices in the most expensive space in the central business district of $27 to $33.
"You're looking at a building whose development cost is roughly twice the acquisition cost of the competition," said Michael A. Kennedy, president of Commercial Texas, a tenant representation firm. And, he added, "When everybody's battening down the hatches, it doesn't play real well to move into the newest, biggest thing."
But Mr. Hendricks said he was counting on winning over traditional Austin tenants, lobbyists and lawyers whose leases will expire around the time his building opens.
"Once you start a high-rise, and you are a private developer," he said, "you can't stop."
