HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Russia Agrees to Work With OPEC on Pricing

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Russia, the second-largest oil exporter, agreed today to help OPEC maintain oil prices but offered no new promises to reduce its exports.
 The secretary general of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Alvaro Silva Calderon, on a one-day visit to Moscow, met today with the Russian energy minister, Igor K. Yusufov. 
 While no agreement was expected, the meeting was closely watched because of its timing -- it comes shortly before a September gathering of OPEC members that will determine output levels. 
Russia, while not a member of OPEC, has played a crucial role in the cartel's decisions. It has steadily increased oil output, taking market share away from OPEC.
As oil prices sagged last autumn, Russia, in the midst of an oil boom, aggravated OPEC by increasing production. It finally agreed, along with two other nonmembers, Norway and Mexico, to trim exports for the first half of the year. Analysts were skeptical that Russia actually carried out the cuts.
Mr. Yusufov said today that "the need for such limits has fallen away."
Mr. Silva, for his part, played down past tensions with Russia and dismissed Russian concerns that OPEC would increase exports to drive down the price and take back market share, something that an OPEC official hinted at last month. 
"We don't have a price war, no country can imagine such a situation," said Mr. Silva in comments carried by Dow Jones news service. 
The price of oil has remained high enough to allow OPEC to avoid propping up prices. Less crude oil from Iraq has also buoyed prices, after a pricing dispute under United Nations sanctions reduced the number of buyers for Iraqi oil.
But with continued weakness in the American economy, demand remains unclear.
OPEC is "maintaining its contacts with Russia as no one knows what 2003 will bring," said Gary N. Ross, chief executive of the PIRA Energy Group, an energy consulting firm in New York. 
Russia has continued to increase its exports and production. Russian executives like Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, chief of Yukos Oil, expect Russia's output to rise to 9 million barrels a day from about 7 million in the next few years.
In July, exports were 3.25 million barrels a day, up from last year's 3 million a day for January to July.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Investors Capitalize on Bargains And Give Sagging Markets a Lift

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
After three days of sharp declines, stocks shot higher yesterday as bargain hunters stepped in to buy recently downtrodden shares.
 All three main gauges were up about 5 percent during the day but gave back much of those gains in the last half-hour of trading. The late sell-off was another indication that investors were only picking up stocks at low prices and remain tentative about the outlook for the market. 
 The indexes ended the day with gains of 2.9 percent or more, with the Nasdaq composite index leading the way with a surge of 4.4 percent. But the rally recovered only part of the losses since last Thursday, when the market began to decline on fears that the economy was slowing or even heading back into recession. 
"It seems to me that the market is being buffeted by decisions by institutional investors, some who see this as a buying opportunity and some who are using rallies to lighten up on stocks," said Thomas McManus, equity strategist at Banc of America Securities. "I think we are going to be bouncing around here for a while with a lot of volatility."
The rally may help calm some investors who think that the market has found a bottom. But doubts about the economy's strength will persist, and another negative report could jolt the market again. In addition, the large moves up and down are no doubt unsettling to many investors.
Though there has been much talk about the possibility of a double-dip recession the last few days, most Wall Street economists are merely cutting their growth projections for the second half of the year rather than predicting a recession.
Still, the fear of slowing growth has led analysts and investors to bet that Federal Reserve policy makers will cut their benchmark short-term interest rate in the months ahead to assure that growth will continue. That projection may also provide some comfort to investors, even if there has been no signal from the Fed of such intentions.
Fed policy makers are scheduled to meet on Tuesday, and investors are sure to be looking for some kind of signal that the Fed will cut rates if the economy shows more signs of weakness. Without such a signal, stocks could fall again.
At the close, the Dow was up 230.46 points, or 2.9 percent, at 8,274.09, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 24.97 points, or 3 percent, to 859.57. Still, both indexes are below the levels they had fallen to last Friday. The Nasdaq index was up 53.54 points, or 4.4 percent, to 1,259.55, just more than 11 points above where it was on Friday.
Stocks in Asia declined yesterday but climbed higher in Europe when they opened and added to their gains after the rally began on Wall Street. The DAX index in Germany rose 7.1 percent, while the CAC index in France increased 5.4 percent.
The dollar also rose against the euro as European investors found the American market attractive. In late trading in New York, the euro settled at 96.51 cents, down from 98.11 cents on Monday. The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, climbing to 120.67 yen from 119.67 Monday.
In the bond market, yields rose and prices fell as many investors apparently moved money back into stocks. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 4.33 percent, from 4.21 percent on Monday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped a full point, to 1046/32 . The yield on the two-year note, which is sensitive to expectations of Fed rate cuts, rose to 2.04 percent after falling to a record low of 1.89 percent on Monday.
Many economists think that the recent decline in interest rates will help offset the negative effects of the plunge in stocks on consumers. But because bond yields have tended recently to rise when stocks rally and fall when stocks decline, the benefit of these lower rates could be taken away quickly.
Among the downtrodden stocks that rallied yesterday were General Electric, Citigroup, AT&T, American Express and Intel, each rising 5 percent or more. They were up even more earlier in the day and helped push the Dow up by almost 375 points at its peak. The shares of all five companies had fallen 12 percent or more from Thursday through Monday. 
The stocks of two troubled energy companies, Dynegy, down 41 percent in the recent rout, and the Williams Companies, off 21 percent, gained 8 percent or more yesterday. TMP Worldwide, the advertising company that was off 23 percent in the previous three sessions, was up 8.5 percent yesterday.
Technology stocks also surged, helping bring the Nasdaq back from a more than five-year low on Monday. It was up 73 points at its peak. Tellabs, the maker of voice, data and network access systems, which was down 19 percent during the recent decline, and Conexant, a semiconductor company, off 25 percent, increased more than 11 percent yesterday.
One of the forces pushing stocks higher is pension funds, some analysts said. Many funds have lost a lot of their value because of the slump in stocks. This decline has in turn altered the weight of stocks compared with bonds within the portfolios. In some cases, analysts said, the percentage of stocks in any given portfolio, often about 60 percent of its value, has dropped below that level. Because of this, pension fund managers are buying stocks to return to that level.

HEADLINE: Long Hike and Yetis, Too? Abominable; 
Bhutan Official Seeks New York Sponsors for a Himalayan Walk

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
In the faraway kingdom of Bhutan, lost in the mists and mountains between India and China, the royal ministers know a thing or two about New Yorkers. One thing they know is that New Yorkers, and Americans in general, are very good at walking, running or cycling for a cause, or supporting others who do. 
 That explains why Dr. Sangay Thinley, the kingdom's secretary of health and education, was in New York last week looking for help. His political boss, the minister of health, is somewhere in the Himalayan hills training for what must be one of the most audacious hikes for a cause ever conceived: a 350-mile marathon across the kingdom along a mule track over mountain passes more than 13,000 feet high. The minister still needs sponsors. 
 The goal is to build up a $24 million trust fund to finance one of the world's most challenged village health systems. It can take hours or days to trudge to the nearest doctor or nurse, and kerosene generators keep the vaccines and medicines cold before they hit the trail in ice packs. 
Now AIDS, which is spreading rapidly in the region, has made an appearance in Bhutan. A vigorous education program has been created to alert vulnerable people in Bhutan, a Buddhist kingdom where there are few sexual taboos. 
Bhutan, slightly bigger than Switzerland, and more rugged, has only two major roads, and they were built in the last 25 years. Long-distance walking is something older Bhutanese did a lot of, from necessity. But this trek for health is something else. 
"I think in the history of Bhutan, this is the first fund-raising walk being carried out," said Dr. Thinley, who has a master's degree in public health from Tulane University. When he goes home, he has a three-hour walk from the nearest road to his house in eastern Bhutan.
Such challenges don't stop the Bhutanese from worrying about going soft. In the capital, Thimphu (population 60,000), people are riding in cars, eating too much and watching television instead of exercising, Dr. Thinley said. 
As Dr. Thinley made his rounds in New York, he looked up old friends of Bhutan first, wherever they could be found. 
There were some business leaders on his list, among them Frank G. Wisner, vice chairman for external affairs at the American International Group, one of the world's largest insurance companies. Mr. Wisner got to know Bhutan when he was American ambassador to India. The corporate world produced a few checks.
Dr. Thinley had the addresses of some physicians who had visited Bhutan and had an interest in health issues there. They pledged him support. 
He also tried to find David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, another visitor to Bhutan, a landlocked country where not many tourists venture. Mr. Stern was out of town, but Kathleen Behrens, the N.B.A.'s vice president of communications, welcomed Dr. Thinley and took note of his cause.
Then there was a meeting with Richard Gere, the actor, who has been a generous friend of Tibet and Himalayan Buddhism. He was asked to help spread the word about the hike.
The health minister, Lyngpo Sangay Ngedup, loaded down with a 55-pound backpack containing all his rations and a small tent, is going to start his trek from the eastern town of Tashigang to Thimphu on Sept. 25 in the company of a private secretary and four hapless underlings from his ministry, Dr. Thinley said. 
There will be no porters or cooks or flunkies, making this a very un-Himalayan expedition. Two security officers will tag along. They won't have human enemies to worry about.
"It could be bears," said Ambassador Om Pradhan, Bhutan's envoy to the United Nations and the only high-ranking Bhutanese diplomat in the United States, since the kingdom has no formal diplomatic ties with Washington. "We have leopards, we have wild boars, we have tigers -- and we have yeti-like creatures, the smaller yeti and the bigger yeti -- but all these will not normally attack. But if you suddenly come across a bear . . . ."
"And snakes you will have," added Dr. Thinley, who mercifully for him has been declared unfit for the trek. Asked about the age of the health minister, Lyngpo Sangay -- lyngpo is a title something like "sir," bestowed by the king, Jigme Singye Wangchuck -- the Bhutanese in New York huddled.
"He has completed four cycles, but not the fifth," Dr. Thinley said. Bhutanese measure ages in 12-year cycles. It was decided that the health minister was 50.
Bhutan, a country whose population is estimated by its government at fewer than 700,000 people (the United Nations estimate is higher, around two million), has done well in developing health care, given the geographical hurdles and the poverty of a still cashless economy in some regions. Childhood immunization is now effectively universal, and maternal mortality has been halved in a decade.
The United Nations reported this year in its annual Human Development Report that between 80 and 94 percent of Bhutanese now have access to essential drugs, compared with fewer than 50 percent of Indians. Nearly 70 percent of Bhutanese have adequate sanitation. Only 31 percent of Indians and 27 percent of Nepalis have basic latrines or toilets.
Lyngpo Sangay, the health minister, has recently been active in the Global Aids Vaccine Initiative, since there have been four deaths from AIDS in Bhutan. His education program, alerting Bhutanese to the potential spread of the disease from India, Nepal and Thailand, places where some Bhutanese travel, has kept the disease from spreading, Dr. Thinley said. 
Because of Bhutan's progress in health -- and its reputation for not accepting foreign aid without being sure it will be put to good use -- the Bhutan Health Trust Fund, established four years ago to make the system self-sustaining and safe from budgetary fluctuations, has already attracted some big donors.
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation gave $1 million, as have the Summit Foundation in Washington and the combined grants of the governments of Norway and New Zealand. The Royal Bhutanese government kicked in with about $12 million, and the minuscule Bhutanese private sector, in a country where per capita income is around $400 a year, raised $21,391. 
The fund's progress is followed on a Web site, www.move4health.gov.bt. Information is also available from the Bhutan Foundation, a recently founded channel for contributions, (212) 826-1919. 
But the health ministry is still $9 million short, Dr. Thinley said. 
"That's where the fund-raising walk came in," he said. "We were thinking a little bit big, targeting big foundations and governments. But now we think that individual contributions are equally important. Any sponsorship in any amount we would like to request, from individuals, families, communities, organizations.
"The walk is 560 kilometers. Then it's going to take 15 days. We estimate that they will be spending 8 to 10 hours walking every day. So people can sponsor on a kilometer basis, a day-to-day basis or an hourly basis."
One uncertainty lurks. The old mule trail across the mountains has no signposts. "The majority of the time they will be in the jungles following the old track," Dr. Thinley said. "We believe it will be quite difficult.
"They went for a trial run from Thimphu to Wangdue Phodrang, and actually they got lost on the way. They had to cross a stream 12 or 13 times because they couldn't find the road." 
The government is asking the villages for relay guides.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Acampaign to tell restaurant owners that smoke-free environments don't hurt business.

BYLINE:  By John Schwartz 

 BODY:
STANTON A. GLANTZ wants to tell restaurants and bars to go smoke-free -- but he is having trouble getting the word out. 
 Prof. Glantz, a tobacco researcher at the University of California, San Francisco, yesterday announced a new Web site, "TobaccoScam," to counter what he calls a 20-year campaign by the tobacco industry to use the restaurant industry as a stalking horse to defeat anti-smoking rules. 
 But Prof. Glantz's attempts to get restaurant trade magazines to accept ads for the site were not entirely successful. Two of the three magazines that were approached initially accepted the ads. But the publications changed their minds after Philip Morris sent e-mail messages asking whether they would be running the ads and suggesting that the company's own ad decisions would be affected by the answer. 
"We submitted the ads. They were approved -- and, later on, rejected," said Joe Therrien, a consultant who placed the ads for the university project. According to Mr. Therrien, one magazine told him that the first ad in the series was "too negative."
"Negative" is an apt description. The first advertisement in the series is a black-and-white, full-page call to arms for the industry that claims "Big Tobacco is Lying. Again." It then attempts to counter arguments made by the industry and its allies over the years -- that restaurant business goes down when smoking is banned, that second-hand smoke is not harmful, and that special ventilation systems can accommodate smokers. The ad also directs readers to the Web site, www.tobaccoscam.ucsf.edu, where it has posted selected economic and scientific studies, as well as polling evidence, to back up the group's claims.
That first ad also shows New York restaurateur Michael O'Neal, who looks out from the ad with the sort of tough, suspicious look that might appear on a bouncer's face before a surly patron becomes airborne. He says, "Big Tobacco has been conning the restaurant business for years. Don't be a sucker. Go smokefree."
A spokeswoman for VNU Business Publications, publisher of Restaurant Business, one of the publications that rejected the advertisement, denied that the magazine had received an e-mail from Philip Morris. "When the ad arrived, it was reviewed and found to be inappropriate because Restaurant Business does not accept advertising that is negative toward another company," said the spokeswoman, Deborah Patton.
Representatives of Penton Media, the publisher of the other magazine, Restaurant Hospitality, did not return calls. (A third publication, Nation's Restaurant News, owned by Lebhar-Friedman, accepted the ad.)
Generating controversy is nothing new to Prof. Glantz, a gadfly on steroids. He has been fighting the industry for decades, and on multiple fronts. In 1994, he uncovered a secret trove of tobacco documents from the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company -- including one 1963 document from a top executive that stated, "we are, therefore, in the business of selling nicotine, an addictive drug." That trove of documents provided powerful ammunition to the Food and Drug Administration in its efforts to regulate tobacco products. And they bolstered the efforts of state attorneys general in their lawsuits that led to a multibillion-dollar settlement over tobacco-related medical expenses.
More recently, Mr. Glantz has begun a campaign to fight the portrayal of smoking in movies. The pugnacious advertisements in that campaign, which cited the Miramax film "In the Bedroom" by name, were rejected by Variety and The Hollywood Reporter earlier this year.
The TobaccoScam site, which is funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the Rhoda Goldman Fund, he said, is "the opportunity to get the truth out to these people" in the restaurant business. "Restaurant people are very sharp, but they've been treated to the big lie that smoke-free measures will cost them business," Prof. Glantz said.
The National Restaurant Association opposes government-mandated smoking bans "because of the dramatic economic impact bans have on restaurants and their employees," according to an item on its Web site.
A representative for Philip Morris -- a company that has long championed First Amendment rights and the value of free choice, ideals that have served it well in its fight against tobacco regulation -- said the e-mail messages were a mistake.
"It was a decision that was made by a junior-level person" late on a Friday afternoon, said Brendan McCormick, a spokesman for Philip Morris U.S.A. "We realized immediately it was a mistake in judgment" because the e-mail messages could be interpreted as a threat to withhold advertising from publications that ran the Glantz ads. The company called each of the publications the next week "to clarify what our position is -- and our position is those publications are certainly free to take that advertising. We have not made, nor do we intend to make, any advertising decisions based on anybody else's advertising."
"The more voices that are out there the better," he said.
Mr. McCormick argued that his company's position is moderate while those of Mr. Glantz and his allies is extreme. "They want government to make the smoking-ban decision for everyone," he said. 
Mr. O'Neal, the restaurateur, said that he was happy to appear in the advertisement. "You go to a Yankees game, you can't smoke," he noted. "You ride an airplane to California, you can't smoke. Why do you have to smoke in a restaurant or a bar?" His own flagship restaurant, O'Neal's Lincoln Center, has historically allowed smoking, he said, because he was hoping that the city would pass tough anti-smoking laws, and he wanted "a level playing field" with other restaurants.
O'Neal's Lincoln Center is currently closed for renovation, he said, but he added that when it reopens this fall smoking will not be allowed. "It won't hurt our business," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 15, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day on Aug. 7, about a campaign for TobaccoScam, an antismoking Web site, omitted the name of the agency that created the campaign. It was the Public Media Center.

HEADLINE: On Camera, Jobless Argentines Vie for a Livelihood 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Other countries may have television programs that lure entrants with offers of a million dollars, a new car or a luxury vacation in a tropical clime. But in this nation of broken finances and shattered dreams, contestants on a popular new game show compete for a prize that is increasingly rare and precious: a paying job.
 Broadcast five days a week, the hourlong program known as "Human Resources" pits two unemployed people in a contest to win a guaranteed six-month work contract. They relate their life stories and answer questions that test their ability to perform the duties they are seeking. Then viewers vote by telephone to decide which of the two should get the coveted job. 
 On Monday, the prize was a position as a sales clerk at a bakery in a suburb of the Argentine capital. Both contestants were pleasant young women who have been unable to find work since finishing high school. Fatima Rueda, an 18-year-old single mother, and Nadia Bravo, 20, pleaded tearfully with the viewing audience. 
"I feel helpless" without work, said one. "I feel empty," confessed the other. After every commercial break, a well-groomed blond hostess, much in the mold of Vanna White, urged viewers to call a toll-free number to support their favorite.
On the air since mid-April, "Human Resources" is a reflection of a new national obsession in a country of 37 million that until recently was the most prosperous in Latin America. As the Argentine economy continues to contract in a collapse that is now the statistical equivalent of the Great Depression, fears of being pulled into the black hole are growing, especially among the middle class.
"We can't solve the problem," said Nestor Ibarra, the host of the show. "But we can help establish the dignity of work, and remind people that the unemployed are not just statistics, but also people with faces, names and lives."
Officially, the unemployment rate has climbed to 21.5 percent, the highest in Argentine history. But many people have simply given up looking for work, discouraged by the closing of thousands of factories and shops. Others have had their work hours or wages sharply reduced. Even those lucky enough to still have full-time jobs worry that the worsening economics will soon thrust them into the ranks of the unemployed.
Anxieties among Argentines about joblessness are running especially high right now. Wednesday is the feast day of San Cayetano, the patron saint of workers here. It coincides with a visit by the United States Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, who arrived in Argentina today as part of what he described as an effort to familiarize himself with the economic catastrophe here.
While some Argentines vied for jobs on television, entire families have been camped out for weeks in unheated tents outside the sanctuary of San Cayetano on the outskirts of the capital, enduring the Southern Hemisphere winter as an offering to the saint who they hope will gain them a job, or at least help them to keep one. Including the campers, more than 200,000 people are expected to pray or make other demonstrations of faith to the saint on Wednesday. 
Griselda Lopez, 53, is part of a group of 20 women who have been going to the shrine together for more than a dozen years and arrived this year on July 1. In the early years, all of the women were employed, she said, but most have lost their jobs.
"We're terribly afraid, all of us," Mrs. Lopez said. "Times are very hard for everybody. Those who have been let go suffer because there is no prospect of work, and the few who still have their jobs see what is happening around them and tell themselves 'I could be next.' "
Because of its association with the saint of "bread and work," the church at the San Cayetano shrine runs a well-known job training and placement program. But the director of that effort, Adrian Pagani, said that while the number of people seeking help has increased, job placements have dropped sharply as the crisis has worsened over the past three years: from 2,600 in the year ending on June 30, 2000, to 1,300 in the year that ended last June 30.
"The work world has fallen apart in Argentina, along with the whole web of social relationships that go with it," he said. "People have lost not only their income, but the sense of identity that work confers on them."
In that atmosphere of disintegration and desperation, "Human Resources" has flourished. The program's structure is simple: a job is announced, and from the dozens of initial applicants, 20 are selected to come to the studio before the choice is winnowed down to the final two.
According to the program's producers, the record number of contestants competing for any single job is about 650. That turnout came when a local theme park said it was looking for a tour guide and specified that it wanted a woman older than 40 for the job.
"We generally get our most massive response when someone who is hiring does not exclude middle-aged people," said Luis Oscar Obregon, one of the executive producers of the program. "Because those are the jobs that appear least often on the market and that is the group with the most responsibilities and the least opportunities, the turnout is always exceptional."
Mr. Obregon added that if the crisis here were not so severe, there would probably be even more contestants for jobs. 
"A lot of people can't afford bus fare anymore, and our theater is too far for them to walk, so they are forced to remain at home, trapped," he explained.
Most of the jobs "Human Resources" offers are blue-collar: waiter, clerk, mechanic. The economic situation here is grim enough that people with college educations also apply to the program for such posts. But they quickly find that their credentials bring them no special advantage.
"The audience's behavior is predictable and always very human," said Mr. Ibarra, the host. "They automatically vote for the person who they think needs the job the most. So the man with a disabled child, the woman who has children but no husband, is preferred over the person who is not quite as bad off."
On Monday, that proved to be the case. When the votes were tallied and displayed with a flourish on an electronic screen, Ms. Rueda, the single mother, had received 52 percent of the vote, to 48 percent for Ms. Bravo.
Crestfallen, Ms. Bravo was consoled by members of her family, who rushed from the audience to hug and kiss her, and then gamely walked over to congratulate the victor, who was holding her infant son and smiling broadly. The two young women embraced, and both began to cry.
But as Ms. Rueda went to sign her six-month employment contract, the bakery owner made a surprise announcement that was greeted with applause by the studio audience. He had decided, he said, to hire both women, and produced a second work agreement, which Ms. Bravo, suddenly animated, quickly signed.
"That happens a lot," Mr. Ibarra said afterward. "A contestant won't get the job on our program, but someone will call in later to offer them another job. People are really decent that way, because they are touched by what they see."

HEADLINE: 2 Major Airlines Reduce Business Fares by 20% 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
American Airlines and Northwest Airlines have lowered their business fares by 20 percent on most domestic routes where they compete, with other airlines matching the discounts to various degrees. The fare sale signals an attempt by the airlines to lure back business travelers who have abandoned them during the economic downturn.
 The fare war began late last week, when American, based in Fort Worth, offered a discount of up to 10 percent on business fares bought through some of the country's largest travel agencies. The sale was not offered through the more general computer booking system. Northwest Airlines said it heard about the discount through its corporate customers and decided to match the discount by introducing it as a systemwide published fare in the computers. 
 After American matched that, Northwest cut prices by a further 10 percent on Monday, forcing American to match for a total discount of 20 percent on published fares.
Both carriers are offering the discounts on routes where they compete with each other but not ones that fly into hub airports used by other competitors, like Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines. But Continental and Delta have also been forced to cut prices on some of the routes discounted by American and Northwest.
For example, before the sale, American had a walk-up business fare of $1,213 one-way from New York to Los Angeles, said Tom Parsons, chief executive of Bestfares.com, which tracks fares. Now, all the full-service carriers, with the exception of United, are flying that route for $983 one-way. But a business fare to Los Angeles from Newark -- a Continental hub -- still costs about $1,200, Mr. Parsons said.
"We think it highlights the frustration of the major airlines with respect to the continued weakness in business revenues," Susan Donofrio, an analyst for Deutsche Bank wrote in an investor's note today. "We expect that we will see a number of different methods tried in the upcoming months as the airlines attempt to react to this new business fare environment."
Traditionally, the airlines have relied on business fares for 60 percent of their revenue, even though those travelers make up only 40 percent of passengers.
This new fare war decreases the profit they would make on each ticket. "The airlines have actually come up to the point where they've got themselves in a pretty good jam," Mr. Parsons said.
Kurt Ebenhoch, a spokesman for Northwest, said his carrier was "competing for every customer we can and pricing our product competitively to do that."
Last month, the major carriers offered discounts of 25 percent to 50 percent on leisure tickets.
That was a sharp reversal of a strategy that the airlines tried earlier this year, when they tried unsuccessfully to raise prices on leisure fares.

HEADLINE: St. Alban's Guide to Populism 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD; E-mail: liberties@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Rule No. 1: So let's say, old sport, that one summer night in a hotel ballroom you gather your favorite fat cats and they all sit on their checkbooks.
 For some inexplicable reason, no one wants you to run again. But that is not an option. On this grim night, it becomes wrenchingly clear that since you are not popular, you must become a populist. 
 Without the support of Big Money, you'll have to rely on the support of Big Labor and Big Media.
Rule No. 2: In order to help the little people, you have to know the right people.
The best placement for an angry manifesto against the rich and powerful is not Mother Jones, but the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. Wave the Cross of Gold at the golden -- your rant against elitism must be heard by the Eastern elite. You have worked so hard to cultivate media bigwigs, with extended meals and endless calls tattling on your rivals.
Let's face it. There is an aristocracy of the mind. Average Americans, including those who don't have the brains to read a butterfly ballot correctly, should allow themselves to be led by a bright, socially distinguished, technologically savvy person. 
If you are one of the entitled, you are entitled to save people from themselves.
Rule No. 3: In the debate between those who believe they are entitled to govern because of their station in life and those who believe that the people are sovereign -- hedge, straddle, fib. Your political birthright, your Ivy schooling, your upbringing in the corridors of power certainly entitle you to govern. If you need to pretend that the people are sovereign in order to become sovereign of the people, what's a little lese-majeste? Lese is more.
If you are one of the entitled, then you are entitled to knock entitlement.
(For further guidance, see Andover Guide to Populism, Rule 186: When political dynasties are in trouble, patrician leaders must hobnob with hoi polloi, like rescued miners and unemployed factory workers.)
Rule No. 4: A cautionary note: The problem with Knowing It All, dear boy, is that some of the little people may find you insufferable when you explain to them that they are suffering now because they didn't listen to you in the first place -- sigh -- when you were right -- sigh -- as you always are -- big sigh and roll of the eyes. They may hold their hands over their little, average American ears. They may even feel compelled to vote for the president who spoke with such sensitivity on the first tee in Kennebunkport Sunday about the suicide bombing that killed nine bus passengers in Israel: "I call upon all nations to do everything they can to stop these terrorist killers. Thank you. Now watch this drive."
Cling to your faux populist fury against the "forces of greed," even though it did not help you when you tried it at the end of the 2000 campaign because most of the "forgotten middle class" was also trying to cash in on the stock market boom.
If you are one of the entitled, you are entitled to always be right.
Rule No. 5: If you let the presidency slip away, proclaim you are retreating, like Scarlett, to draw strength from the red dirt of Carthage. ID yourself in op-ed pieces as a college teacher in Tennessee.
Really, of course, you don't have to spend much time in that God-forsaken place, where they wouldn't know a metaphor from a two-by-four. Do not mention that you are really holed up in a Washington suburb writing a book about family with Tipper. Do not talk about being the vice chairman of an L.A. financial services company. 
If you are one of the entitled, you are entitled to any money you can get. (See Andover Guide to Populism, Rule 90: Populists don't have to be paupers. If you want to get bailed out in bidness, cash in on your famous name.) 
Rule No. 6: Let Hillary and Bill kowtow to the party's pro-business moderates; you are a proud populist. You wouldn't be caught within eight-tenths of a mile of a meeting of the Democratic Leadership Council. 
Feel free to attach yourself to Clinton ("Bill Clinton and I were right to maintain . . .") once you are sure it can't do you any good. Ignore all the party-poopers, including Bill, who grumble that you would be president today if you had mentioned his name even once after Labor Day in 2000.
Putting Gore First is a way of Putting People First.
And if you are one of the entitled, you are entitled to be first.

HEADLINE: New Colombian President Gets Jump on Country's Problems 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Alvaro Uribe Velez wants to get his government off to a fast start.
 Since May, when Colombian voters elected him president in a landslide, Mr. Uribe has traveled to Europe, Washington and four Latin American countries, seeking aid and assuaging concerns about his hard-line approach to combating Colombia's surging rebel movements. His transition staff undertook an assessment of the country's 16 ministries, devising policies they say will reform the bureaucracy and cut waste. 
 On Wednesday, the day he is inaugurated, he plans to introduce legislation to reduce the size of Congress by nearly half.
He has also been marshaling support from top business leaders for a tax increase, to help pay for his plans to double the size of security forces to battle the guerrillas.
Mr. Uribe knows that he has to show results quickly on the promise that led voters to elect him on May 26: that his would be a can-do presidency that would bring some order to this troubled country. That pledge appealed to Colombians tired of Andres Pastrana, the departing president, whose efforts to bring peace through negotiations with the rebels ended in collapse.
"Uribe is the embodiment of the anti-Pastrana leader," said Fernando Cepeda, a former government minister and analyst. "We can be sure that if things turn out badly with this government, no one can say it will be for lack of effort."
But for all his hard-working demeanor, Mr. Uribe faces a tough battle in a country short on patience and money.
His plans to double the army's combat force to 100,000 soldiers and the National Police to 200,000 will cost $1 billion a year, when the annual budget is just $27 billion.
Even though some top industrialists have voiced support for special taxes and so-called war bonds, the details of the financing remain unclear and troubling to economists worried about the country's economic stability.
The most startling of Mr. Uribe's proposed political reforms -- the plan to reduce Congress to 150 lawmakers from 268 while ending many of their special privileges -- has aroused opposition, even among politicians who won office by allying themselves with him.
"I find it absurd to revoke or reduce the terms of a Congress that won legitimately at the voting booth," said Senator Guillermo Chavez, who supported Mr. Uribe. 
Mr. Uribe's own advisers -- Fabio Echeverry and Rudolf Hommes, who oversaw the review of Mr. Pastrana's ministries -- offered a sober view of the state of the economy. In a news conference last week, they said rural unemployment had reached 50 percent, the economy would grow a dismal 1.5 percent this year and the deficit would reach 6 percent of gross domestic product.
But the greatest question is whether Mr. Uribe's promise to crack down on leftist rebels -- a pledge that resonated with a conflict-weary populace -- will bear fruit. Colombia's army, though more professional and efficient than it was in the mid-1990's, faces a powerful and experienced foe in the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the largest rebel group. 
The group has flexed its muscles in recent weeks by threatening hundreds of mayors, many of whom fled their posts for fear they would be killed. On Monday and today the group stepped up the violence, bombing a provincial airport in eastern Colombia, a government building and other targets, injuring several civilians.
In addition to expanding the armed forces, Mr. Uribe has proposed to organize a million-member force of civilian informers to help the army root out rebels. Critics fear that the project will create new dangers for noncombatants.
Such sweeping plans, which differ markedly from the laid-back approach of Mr. Pastrana, a former television anchorman, have led to rising expectations.
"He received a strong mandate from Colombians in the elections, but it will not be easy to fulfill the expectations that he created during the campaign," said Vicente Torrijos, a political analyst.
Mr. Echeverry, a key adviser, cautioned reporters that Mr. Uribe did "not promise streams of milk and honey."
The president-elect has also tried to ease concerns here and abroad about his shift to the right.
The day after the presidential election, he proposed United Nations mediation in peace talks with rebels.
A month later, he met with Secretary General Kofi Annan in New York. 
Not long after the election he also named his cabinet ministers, and 6 of 13 were women (three ministries were merged into others), including the defense minister and the minister of exterior relations.
Bush administration officials, who see Mr. Uribe as a dependable caretaker of American policy in Colombia, pledged firm support. Last month, Congress approved a provision in antiterrorism legislation that would allow some American-supplied equipment, like helicopters, to be used directly against the rebels, a change from previous guidelines that limited such equipment to use in antidrug operations.
"The hope is that the government's agenda gets set and that progress is made," John Walters, the White House drug policy chief, said in an interview today. He predicted that Mr. Uribe would make "a real and important start and progress" in his programs.
Many Colombians, worn out by four years of rising violence and kidnappings, believe that Mr. Uribe has the right prescription for the country's troubles.
"A new hope will be born this Wednesday," said El Espectador, a Bogota newspaper. "And though it is irrational to think that solutions for all of the country's problems will be found in the short term, there is a reason for that hope."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Armored vehicles patrolled the mountains around Bogota yesterday. Security has been increased for the inauguration of the new president. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Reactor Sales Are Said to Endanger Accident Payments 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
The sale of about two dozen nuclear power reactors around the country to a small number of companies has undermined the system Congress devised to ensure compensation for people hurt by a severe nuclear accident, according to an analysis commissioned by two antinuclear groups in New York.
 Federal law requires reactor operators to buy $200 million in conventional insurance. It also provides for about $9.3 billion in additional coverage by requiring that after an accident, each plant pay $10 million a year, up to $88 million, to compensate victims. 
 When the law, known as the Price-Anderson act, was approved by Congress, the idea was to spread the risk among all reactors. But as a result of recent mergers and purchases, four companies now own so many reactors that their liabilities would be more than half a billion dollars each in case of accidents. 
The study, which was commissioned by Riverkeeper, a Hudson River environmental group, and the STAR Foundation, a Long Island antinuclear group, points out that in many cases, the companies bought the reactors through limited liability subsidiaries that could declare bankruptcy and permit the parent corporations to walk away unscathed. It also says that the limited liability structure jeopardizes the money set aside for decommissioning the reactors at the end of their lives.
"Price-Anderson only works if those companies are reachable in the event of an accident," said Alex Matthiessen, executive director of Riverkeeper. "These limited liability structures seem specifically designed to put them beyond reach."
The report, prepared by Synapse Energy Economics and scheduled to be officially released on Wednesday by being posted on the World Wide Web at www.noradiation.org, details layer upon layer of corporate structures used in recent reactor purchases. Robert Alvarez, program director for the Star Foundation, said that most of the holding companies had no employees and were merely "shell corporations." He called them "Enron-style subsidiaries."
Representatives for the nuclear industry scoffed at the idea that the changes in ownership threatened the insurance system. Having nuclear plants concentrated in the hands of companies that specialize in running reactors has safety benefits, they said, and may also create greater financial responsiveness.
"If I'm a nuclear operator, I'm not going to undermine my core business to save $10 million a year," said Marvin S. Fertel, senior vice president at the Nuclear Energy Institute, a trade group. Failure to pay the fee for one reactor could jeopardize the licenses of the others, he said.
A typical 1,000-megawatt nuclear plant has fuel and operating expenses of $130 million to $140 million a year, he said, and a $10 million payment on top of that, in the unlikely event of a major accident, was a small increment.
In an introduction to the report, Peter A. Bradford, a former member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and a former head of the public service commissions in both New York State and Vermont, agreed that the consolidation of nuclear ownership might make for safer operation. But he said he thought it also "risks the shifting of accident and decommissioning costs from the plant owners to the general public because the relatively secure financial backing of substantial utilities companies has, in many cases, been replaced by a limited liability subsidiary whose only asset is an individual nuclear power plant."
Price-Anderson, established in 1957 by Congress, expired on Aug. 1. Provisions remain in force for existing reactors but new ones would not be covered. But that point is moot, since no new reactors have been ordered since 1978.
The insurance system established by the law could be crucial for people who live within a few miles of nuclear plants because commercial property insurance does not cover radiation accidents.
In creating the program, Congress set a cap on how much would be paid to any victims of a nuclear accident. The cap is periodically adjusted for inflation; it is now about $9.5 billion, with the money coming from the $200 million in conventional insurance and the $9.3 billion that would be paid by the nuclear industry after an accident.
Opponents say the cap is a subsidy to the nuclear industry; the industry asserts that the $9.5 billion is far more than would be available for a catastrophe at a chemical plant or some other industrial site. So far, they point out, payments have totaled only about $200 million.
Whatever the merits of the arguments on both sides, the emerging structure of the industry has clearly changed the underlying assumptions behind the building of nuclear power plants. Critics agree that having a single company operate 15 or 20 reactors is probably good for safety, since plants within a company share expertise more readily than plants owned by scattered utilities. 
But they also say that the new owners may lack the deep pockets of the mammoth regulated utilities that built the reactors, making an insurance scheme more necessary.
The new legal structure is radically different from what came before. For example, the Indian Point reactors, in a suburb of New York City along the Hudson River, were sold by Consolidated Edison and the New York Power Authority to Entergy, a utility that built five of its own plants and has bought six more.
A spokesman for Entergy, Carl Crawford, said the structure had tax advantages. Asked if it also created a liability shield, he said, "It has that effect, too."
But, he said, "anyone who thinks that a company that would spend a billion and a half of its own dollars is going to shirk a $10 million a year insurance payment, that's just not reasonable."

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about potential risks to the system that would compensate people hurt by a severe nuclear accident referred incorrectly to a problem at the Davis-Besse nuclear plant near Toledo, Ohio. An acid leak inside the plant ate a hole six inches deep into a steel cap that covers the plant's reactor vessel, federal inspectors said in March. No accident was reported.

HEADLINE: From Down-Home to Upmarket: Sam Walton's Town Gets Sleeker 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

DATELINE: BENTONVILLE, Ark., July 31 

 BODY:
Old-timers here still arrive by pickup truck to have their coffee and biscuits at Marty's, a plain-looking restaurant that has been a fixture for decades.
 Nouveau Bentonville, on the other hand, gravitates to a soaring space called the Market at Pinnacle Point, which appeared out of nowhere two years ago just down the highway in Rogers, surrounded by an office-and-shopping complex filled with Fortune 500 companies. 
 "We do a lot with the espresso machine," the Market's assistant manager, Matthew Scheide, said.
That is just one of the changes taking place in a region long defined by pine forests, poultry farms and Civil War memories that is now among the six fastest-growing metropolitan areas in the United States.
Manufacturers large and small -- the makers of packaged food, beauty products, beverages, toys, cleaning agents, cameras, clothing and just about every other item that fills the shelves at Wal-Mart's 2,200 discount stores around the country -- are stampeding into the Bentonville area where Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest company with revenue of $218 billion last year, is based. 
They all want to be where the action is: in Wal-Mart's backyard. And coming from major cities and accustomed to other lifestyles, they are gilding this once-humble slice of northwest Arkansas where Sam Walton, the company's founder, first made it his business to cater to rural, cost-conscious shoppers largely ignored by other retailers. The result is not just a population boom, but also a shift from the simple country style that once defined Wal-Mart and Bentonville to something sleeker, spiffier and more, well, suburban.
The outsiders come because they believe they must, especially since Wal-Mart began adding supermarkets onto its discount stores a few years ago.
"You can think of it almost like the lobbyists in D.C.," said Michael Porter, a retail analyst for Morningstar in Chicago. "It just makes sense to be where the decision makers are, and in this case, the decision makers are the heads of the largest company in the world."
As the migration has accelerated, the newcomers have caused a decided shift here to the upscale: to gated neighborhoods with names like Avignon, to restaurants serving sushi, to specialty stores and gourmet shops that are clearly worlds apart from Wal-Mart. It is the kind of thing that runs counter to the mentality held by the folksy Mr. Sam, who died in 1992.
"I don't believe a big showy lifestyle is appropriate for anywhere," Mr. Walton wrote in his autobiography, "least of all here in Bentonville, where folks work hard for their money and where we all know that everyone puts on their trousers one leg at a time."
Lately, however, it has become a lot showier with people living in trophy houses along the golf course at the Pinnacle Country Club, with cast-iron lions flanking the front door.
"We used to have a one-tiered system -- northwest Arkansas was hillbilly country," said Jeff Collins, director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the Sam M. Walton College of Business, part of the University of Arkansas. Now there is upward pressure on wages, and farmland is being snapped up for mansions. "Things have definitely changed."
It is not clear what effect all this will have on Wal-Mart itself, traditionally a company not given to lavish pay or perks of any kind. Then again, Wal-Mart has already been pushed in new directions by its relentless growth.
"Much of what has taken place since Mr. Sam's death has been a little bit different than what he would have done," said Tom Ginn, vice president for business development for the Rogers-Lowell Chamber of Commerce. "It is also a much larger company than it was 10 years ago. Companies have to evolve."
Several Wal-Mart executives have moved into houses in the Pinnacle development, said Jay W. Allen, a company spokesman, adding that Wal-Mart is committed, as always, to investing its profits back into its stores. "We are, at the end of the day, a very large multinational company based here," he said. "That is not going to change. It's important that this is an attractive place to live."
The region now includes about 300,000 people, and the once-tiny city of Bentonville has doubled in population to 22,000 since 1990. At least half that gain has come from people moving in from far afield: Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas and Cincinnati. Airlines have added direct flights from several major cities, including New York and Atlanta.
Specialty stores and services are flocking to the area. Office parks, hotels and new condominium complexes have sprung up on former cow pastures, and most of the remaining open land along major roads prickles with signs reading "For Sale" or "Will Build to Suit."
Even some of the newcomers seem shocked by the changes. "When we moved into our subdivision in Rogers three years ago, there was a sign that said, 'Welcome to Whispering Timbers, a quiet place in the country,' " said Sue Hess, who arrived from Kansas with her husband, Jerry, when he retired.
Mrs. Hess's golfing partners are all recent transplants from places like Oregon, Wisconsin, New Jersey, Minnesota and California. "I haven't played with anyone from Arkansas," she said.
Some suppliers set up small offices in Bentonville in the late 1980's, to work more closely with Wal-Mart. But since the retailer began adding supermarkets onto its discount stores a few years ago, it has been imperative for the multibillion-dollar makers of food and beverages to be in Bentonville, too. The trend seems inexorable, as Wal-Mart continues to grow in importance in the retail industry.
"Literally on a daily basis, they are adding people," said Rich Davis, a retired Wisconsin fire chief who directs economic development for the Bentonville-Bella Vista Chamber of Commerce. "If you see that product on the shelf at Wal-Mart, they are here."
He estimates that 450 companies with ties to Wal-Mart have established offices in the area, and that another 1,500 will do so before long, transforming not just Bentonville but adjacent cities like Rogers and Fayetteville. Procter & Gamble, which had 100 people working in Fayetteville five years ago, now has more than 200, all of them assigned to the Wal-Mart account. Ocean Spray opened an office here three years ago; Newell Rubbermaid recently completed a new building.
A drive around an office park called Beau Terre is a study in blue-chip names: ConAgra, Hasbro, H. J. Heinz, Exxon Mobil, Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, Gillette, Clorox and Unilever are nearby, along with Rayovac, Kellogg, and 3M.
Ever since last year, when Wal-Mart announced it would no longer share sales information with data-gathering companies like Information Resources and A. C. Nielsen, many manufacturers have believed the only way to keep on top of how their products are doing is to be in close proximity. But Mr. Allen said that was not Wal-Mart's edict. "There are suppliers that have offices here and suppliers that don't," he said. "We work with both."
The manufacturers describe their relationships with Wal-Mart as complicated but ultimately collaborative.
"What they basically said to us is, if you want to grow with Wal-Mart, you need to pay closer attention to how we go to market," said John Crossetti, vice president for sales at Ocean Spray. Ocean Spray's Wal-Mart business has grown by 76 percent in two years.
In interviews, most executives refused to identify themselves out of concern for future business. Many of them, no matter how well established, find themselves in the role of supplicant much of the time, bowing before the influence Wal-Mart wields in the marketplace and the fear of losing a make-or-break order to a competitor.
On most days, particularly Tuesdays, the lobby of Wal-Mart's low-rise headquarters is jammed with visitors, most wearing blue "supplier" name tags and toting racks, suitcases and cartons full of products. Once past the security desk, they are assigned to one of the dozens of tiny rooms on the first floor where they meet with Wal-Mart representatives to engage in notoriously tough negotiations over price, volume, replenishment, and the nuts and bolts of retailing.
The rooms are spare, in keeping with Wal-Mart's no-frills philosophy. One executive with a Fortune 500 company said opening his own office in Bentonville meant that meetings could be held in his conference rooms, not theirs. "Ours are more spacious, certainly," he said.
The odds of seeing Wal-Mart's top management on the golf course, however, are not good. "Wal-Mart is very judicious about that," he said. "This office is not for schmoozing. It's for servicing the account." 
Along with the newcomers have come fresh pressures on wages, on land prices, and on the area's roads, water and sewer systems. Addressing them is not a simple matter. In Bentonville, a $3,500-a-house development fee narrowly won approval from the City Council and went into effect July 1. The money pays for new water and sewer lines along with more fire stations.
The mayor, Terry Black Coberly, backed the measure, which is unusual for the area, in what she termed an act of "political courage." After running unopposed last time, she faces two challengers this fall who fought the fee.
Much of the recent development has catered to newcomers, who are typically paid more and accustomed to spending more than local people. As a result, Bentonville is splitting into two distinct groups.
As housing gears itself toward upscale buyers, the mayor worries that affordable homes may be more difficult to find. "It is hard for teachers and policemen and firemen, because prices have increased dramatically over the last few years," she said. "We have two constituencies, natives and newcomers. So far, we've managed to keep a happy balance."
Bentonville old-timers seem to be taking a wait-and-see position. They worry about the traffic, but they also point out that it is better to be part of a community that is growing than one that isn't.
"When I first got here in 1972, I could be in Pea Ridge in 17 minutes," said Charles Hatfield, a Bentonville veterinarian who now sees more puppies and kittens than cows in his practice. (Pea Ridge is 10 miles northeast of Bentonville.) "Now you can't get across town in 17 minutes."
Winters are mild, prices are mostly reasonable (though a medium cappuccino at the Market runs $2.50), and people are cheerful. While newcomers may turn up their noses when told to move to Bentonville, once they arrive, they seem to enjoy the life, which Mayor Coberly happily compares to Mayberry.
"I said I'd never move here," an employee of a Fortune 500 packaged food company said, "but it seemed like this is where everything is going on." In 1997, she bought a house with a pool, on an acre of land, for less than $100,000.
"The social life leaves something to be desired," she acknowledged. Because Wal-Mart is "such a high-dollar account," many of the new arrivals are seasoned executives with families rather than young people starting out.
She wants to stay, though. Not only has the town grown on her, but for corporate strivers, being in Bentonville these days is a plum.

HEADLINE: Longtime Assemblyman Takes Challenger Seriously 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Dawn had barely come yesterday, and Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. was already perched at the entrance to the Kingston Avenue subway station on Eastern Parkway. Impeccably dressed in a dark blue suit, Mr. Norman, the Democratic Party leader of Brooklyn and a 20-year incumbent, insisted that his re-election battle was a difficult one that demanded nearly 24-hour vigilance.
 "I don't take anything for granted," Mr. Norman said, between conversations with morning commuters as he passed out campaign fliers. "I have to be ready. She has some visibility. She is a lawyer and a woman, and most of the voters in this district are women." 
 The "she" in this case is Sandra Roper, a lawyer who achieved a surprisingly strong showing last year in her first venture into elective politics. She received 37 percent of the vote in a boroughwide race against Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney.
Ms. Roper is campaigning for the September primary on a theme not uncommon to insurgents running against longstanding incumbents. Mr. Norman, she charges, is so preoccupied with Democratic Party back-room maneuvering that he has little time to attend to the needs of the 43rd Assembly District, which includes the Crown Heights and Flatbush sections of Brooklyn.
"If you wield so much power in the Assembly, you should be able to point out something you have done for the people of Brooklyn," Ms. Roper said. "He has been busy politically, but the people of this district are not being adequately represented in Albany."
Specifically, she criticized Mr. Norman for supporting the repeal of the stock transfer tax and for not working to reinstate the commuter tax. "Given the economy and the events of last September, this would have been an absolutely ripe time to do that," she said. "I just think it's time for a change."
Ms. Roper, who is 45, is running with a team of insurgent candidates who complain that there is a need for more assertive legislators in Albany. Just yesterday, the candidates, who include Wellington Sharpe, running for the Senate, and Eddie Brumfield, an Assembly candidate, held a small rally outside Brooklyn Borough Hall. They criticized incumbent legislators for being inattentive to the needs of their various districts.
By her own reckoning, Ms. Roper's grass-roots, shoestring campaign will pay dividends at the ballot box because in a district as compact as the 43rd -- a working-class area with mostly Caribbean and African-American voters -- door-to-door and subway campaigning is especially effective. "I will be getting my message out to the people," she said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Norman is thought to be in a strong position. He has said he will spend $100,000 if necessary. (He will hold a large fund-raiser for his 51st birthday later this month.) He has the support of several large unions, and many rank-and-file union members live in the district. Ms. Roper said she has raised less than $10,000.
Why, then, Mr. Norman's concern? For one thing, he had a difficult time in last year's election, as most of the candidates he supported lost and his prestige was battered. Moreover, the present race comes four years after Mr. Norman was nearly defeated by James E. Davis, now a City Council member.
Another concern is that the strength of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn might be spread thin. Mr. Norman is investing a great deal of party resources in the campaigns of other incumbents who face strong challenges: Assemblyman Roger L. Green and State Senators Nellie Santiago and Carl Andrews (who is being opposed by Mr. Sharpe), to name a few.
In addition, Ms. Roper's strong showing in last year's election for district attorney came after a series of court challenges that knocked her off the ballot. After being reinstated just two weeks before the election, she managed 37 percent of the vote.
Nonetheless, the party leader expressed confidence. "The fact is that I've been doing my job as an elected official," Mr. Norman said. "We have helped to bring in more than $68 million in the last two years into this district for organizations, hospitals, schools and other groups."
He dismissed Ms. Roper as a "drive-by candidate" with little experience and history in the community. "My opponent doesn't live in the district and has no relationship with the people and the institutions within the 43rd Assembly District.".
Although Ms. Roper lives a few blocks outside the district, in a redistricting year candidates for state office are not required to live within the districts they run in. They must move into the district within a year of taking office.
Still, Mr. Norman said he felt compelled to campaign vigorously. "In 1998, when I did not get out there and campaign the way I should have, I had a big scare," he said. "I'm a big enough boy to admit it. And I'm not going to let that happen again."

HEADLINE: Settlement Offers Are Due on Trade Center Losses 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
In the most significant moment yet in the insurance battle over the World Trade Center, lawyers for Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, and Swiss Re, the lead insurer, are to make settlement offers to a federal judge in Manhattan tomorrow.
 While they remain as much as $5 billion apart in their assessments of the compensation owed, both parties, in recent days, have proclaimed a desire to settle the dispute. If they agree on an amount, it will determine how much money Mr. Silverstein will have to rebuild the trade center and, more broadly, how much influence he will have over the future of the site and the character of much of Lower Manhattan. 
 Swiss Re America, the leader of a coalition of 20 insurance companies that agreed to a $3.5 billion policy on the trade center, says that the destruction of the trade center was a single occurrence and that therefore Mr. Silverstein is entitled to no more than the total value of the policy. Mr. Silverstein has contended that the attack on the two towers was two separate occurrences and that therefore he was entitled to double compensation.
The two parties declined to say yesterday how much they would offer to open the negotiations on a settlement, but in the last week each has laid out vastly different assessments of the damage.
Mr. Silverstein said that the value of the property destroyed -- the twin towers, the center's buildings 4 and 5 and the retail mall -- were worth $5.7 billion. In addition, Mr. Silverstein said the interruption of business cost him more than $2.5 billion, bringing his total losses to more than $8.2 billion.
Herbert M. Wachtell, the lawyer representing Mr. Silverstein in the insurance case, said in an interview yesterday, "I would like to settle."
"I think a lot of insurers would be very anxious to settle this kind of thing," Mr. Wachtell said. "I think there are certain people who are intransigent." He said it was possible that a settlement could be reached involving some of the insurers, or none at all. 
Swiss Re, in turn, has estimated that the actual value of the World Trade Center buildings was $2.16 billion. If Mr. Silverstein decides to rebuild on the property, he would be entitled to payments of up to $3.5 billion as construction proceeds in the years ahead. The company says that because of the effect of inflation, it estimates the present value of that money as $2.4 billion.
"We've always said we would be delighted to negotiate a settlement within the framework of a single occurrence," said Jacques E. Dubois, the chairman and chief executive of Swiss Re America. "The property was destroyed only once."
In anticipation that the two sides will be unable to settle their differences, a jury trial has already been scheduled. Jury selection would begin Nov. 4 and opening arguments on Nov. 12. 
A closed hearing on the possible settlement is scheduled for Friday before Judge Lewis A. Kaplan in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Judge Kaplan was appointed a mediator in the case by Judge John S. Martin Jr., who, if a settlement is not reached, would preside over the trial. 
A dispute over whether a property loss was caused by one occurrence or two is not as uncommon a situation as it might seem, given the circumstances.
Take, for example, a fire in an office building that causes $1 million in damage on the 20th floor. The building owner, whose policy has a deductible of $500,000, might file a claim a month later stating that the 14th floor had $800,000 in water damage and that the 22nd floor had $500,000 in smoke damage. 
If the damage was determined to stem from three separate occurrences, the owner would have to pay $1.5 million in deductibles and he would receive only $800,000 from his insurer. If, however, all the damage was judged to be caused by a single occurrence -- the initial fire -- he would be liable for only $500,000, and the insurance company would owe him $1.8 million.
In most cases, the definition of "occurrence" rests on the particular language used in the policy. In the case of the World Trade Center, there was no formal policy, only a binding agreement that a policy would be drawn up under certain guidelines.
It is those guidelines that are in dispute. Swiss Re argues that "occurrence" is defined in documents that originated with an insurance broker working for Mr. Silverstein. According to those forms, a single occurrence is "attributable directly or indirectly to one cause or to one series of similar causes."
Mr. Silverstein and his lawyers argue that the decision should rest on an insurance form drawn up by Travelers, the large American insurer, which was seeking to participate in the group that was offering coverage for the trade center. Mr. Silverstein's lawyers say that according to that form's definition of "occurrence," the destruction of the twin towers was two incidents.
The dispute has the unusual twist of Mr. Silverstein arguing that the form used by his own insurance broker should be ignored, while Travelers, which has sided with Swiss Re against Mr. Silverstein, says that the form that it is most familiar with was not in effect.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Doubleday Allegations Looming Over Talks

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Because of the threat of a $1 million fine, baseball owners have basically been silent during talks between negotiators for the clubs and the players. But yesterday, without opening his mouth, the Mets co-owner Nelson Doubleday tossed a bomb onto the bargaining table that management officials quickly tried to defuse by debunking his accusations.
 However, Doubleday's allegations, made in a counterclaim to a lawsuit filed by the Mets' other co-owner, Fred Wilpon, do not figure to dissolve right away. 
 "There are some very serious and disturbing allegations, especially as they relate to the owners' collective bargaining strategy," a union lawyer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. 
The counterclaim surfaced on a day when negotiators took time off from the major issues of revenue sharing and payroll tax and discussed the lesser issues of debt regulation and funding of deferred compensation. 
Today the union plans to present its initial proposal on a joint drug program. A person familiar with the proposal said it would include some element of testing for steroids. The union has long opposed random testing for drugs but many players have said they would approve testing for steroids. Last February, the clubs proposed that players be tested three times a year for steroids. 
In another development, the union's executive board held a lengthy conference call in which the members discussed proposals but did not consider a strike date. The board is scheduled to meet in Chicago next Monday and could set a strike date then, depending on the course negotiations follow the rest of this week.
It remains to be seen what role, if any, is played in the next few days by the allegations included in Doubleday's 23-page reply to Wilpon's lawsuit over his purchase of Doubleday's 50 percent ownership of the Mets. 
Doubleday, believing he was "double-crossed" by Major League Baseball and Commissioner Bud Selig, accused them of manipulating franchise values and other economic data as part of management's labor relations strategy.
Doubleday alleged that baseball manufactured "phantom operating losses" and systematically undervalued franchises and that Selig began enforcing a long-dormant economic rule known as 60 / 40 to "impose an indirect salary cap." 
The 60 / 40 rule stipulates that teams must maintain a ratio of 60 percent assets to 40 percent liabilities. After ignoring it for years, Doubleday said, Selig resurrected it "in a purported attempt to bring fiscal restraint to baseball teams and gain advantage in M.L.B.'s negotiations with the Players Association."
"A de facto salary cap -- achieved through the 60 / 40 rule -- would solve a variety of problems faced by Baseball today," Doubleday alleged, including limiting "the owners' exposure to ever increasing salary demands by players."
Asked how Doubleday's allegations might affect the negotiations, Rob Manfred, the owners' chief labor lawyer, said the allegations were untrue and "ridiculous on their face," adding, "They make no sense in the context of these negotiations." The union and its leader, Donald Fehr, Manfred said, "are too smart to let nonsense derail these negotiations."
But he added during a conference call with reporters, "To the extent the union is interested in discussing those topics, I'll handle those topics at the table."
Asked specifically about the "phantom operating losses," Manfred said, "Don, since 1987, has had an unbroken chain of audited financial statements from each club. I do not think Don thinks for one minute that those numbers are manufactured."
The players have long been skeptical of the clubs' claim of losses, but the union has not made an issue of it in recent years. Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief operating officer and president, called Doubleday's allegations "nonsense and a complete fabrication."
Doubleday's allegations also touch on contraction -- the owners' attempt to eliminate two teams -- a move the union challenged in a grievance that awaits the arbitrator's ruling.
Much of the focus of Doubleday's counterclaim is on Robert Starkey. Doubleday is challenging his appraisal of the Mets' value. It was Starkey, Doubleday said, whom Selig relied on to create the 60 / 40 plan that values all franchises. 
Starkey was a principal witness for the owners in the contraction grievance and tried to refute the idea that contraction was related to the clubs' proposal on revenue sharing.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Mussina Pounded By Royals For 14 Hits

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
These are disturbing times for Mike Mussina, the intelligent and confident pitcher who has looked bewildered and uncertain for the Yankees for far too long. The potential explanations about why Mussina is sputtering sound like lame excuses as Mussina muddles through the fifth month of an unsatisfying season.
 Last night, it was the feeble Kansas City Royals who made Mussina look suspect and who gave the Yankees more reason to wonder whether Mussina can regain his effectiveness and his confidence by October. Mussina could not tame the Royals in a 6-2 loss, and he was routinely booed at a very ornery and very crowded Yankee Stadium. 
 If the team with the lowest batting average in the American League can hammer Mussina, what will happen against the premier teams in the postseason? The fragile-pitching Yankees need Mussina to be an anchor. For now, the Yankees can keep their concerns private and speak about how Mussina has been too sound for too many years to continue struggling. For now, the Yankees can maintain hope. They need to do something.
Mussina was bruised for 5 runs and a career-worst 14 hits in seven draining innings and only some foolish base running by the Royals prevented the damage from being more severe. It has been a forgettable week for Mussina, who allowed 7 runs on 11 hits in three innings in a 17-6 thumping by the Texas Rangers last Wednesday and probably figured it could not get worse.
It did. He is the softest 13-6 pitcher in the major leagues, his earned run average at 4.90.
"It's tough to explain," Mussina said. "I wish I could explain it. It's not what my past has shown. This is something I've never had to deal with before. I'm going to deal with it now."
Sometimes, Mussina admitted, he stands on the mound and wonders what is happening. How did he allow a run-scoring double to Michael Tucker in the second? How did Kansas City score three two-out runs in the third? It helped that Carlos Beltran completed an eight-pitch at-bat with a run-scoring double off a breaking pitch. How did that grounder find a hole? The questions keep coming, some from Mussina and some from others. He is stymied.
"I'm a little young to be losing my stuff," the 33-year-old Mussina said. "I'm not executing what I'm trying to do. That's the frustrating part. I work on things and then I let another big inning jump up and get me."
When someone suggested that Mussina might be tipping his pitches, he swatted away the theory. But Mussina said batters were hitting different pitches while he was ahead in the count, which sounds like a description for tipping pitches. To that, Mussina said: "I should just tell them what's coming then. Maybe that will make it easier on me." 
Mussina has attributed his inconsistencies to his difficulty with throwing fastballs for strikes and a tendency to overanalyze his mechanics. Manager Joe Torre also mentioned Mussina's problems with locating his fastball and a failure to be economical with his pitch count, obviously linked to the lack of command. Every pitcher works his other pitches off his fastball. Without a reliable fastball, a pitcher is handicapped. Mussina was handicapped again as the Royals beat the Yankees for the first time since Sept. 6, 2000.
Runelvys Hernandez, a 24-year-old rookie, pitched six innings, limiting the Yankees to Raul Mondesi's two-run homer. After beginning the season at Class A Wilmington, Hernandez outpitched Mussina in his fourth major league start.
Before the game, Torre acknowledged that Mussina's confidence could be wavering; his earned run average has grown after 14 of his last 22 starts. Torre explained how baseball is a sport where "you have to prove yourself to yourself" every day.
After Mussina had another poor outing, Torre focused on how he held the Royals scoreless in the sixth and the seventh and lasted 131 pitches in an attempt to find some answers.
Torre was so desperate for positives that he clung to Mussina's sixth and seventh, when he gave up three more hits.
"I'm not concerned," Torre said. "As long as he's physically sound, which we have every reason to believe he is, he'll be fine. He'll be fine."
Mussina had only one 1-2-3 inning and that came in the first. After two innings, he had thrown 39 pitches and trailed by 1-0. After three, he had thrown 78 and was down 4-0. If the Royals did not have three runners thrown out trying to steal second, in the third, fourth and fifth -- gift outs for a fading pitcher -- Mussina's ugly night would have been even uglier.
"You have to question some things," Mussina said. "I can't stand out there and accept what's happening. I have to correct it."

INSIDE PITCH
MARIANO RIVERA, who is on the disabled list with a strained right shoulder, pitched two scoreless innings yesterday for the Yankees' Gulf Coast League team in Tampa, Fla. Rivera's fastball reached 94 miles an hour. Rivera is eligible to be activated, but JOE TORRE said the Yankees would decide today if he needed one more rehabilitation appearance. . . .
