HEADLINE: O'Neill, Upbeat in Uruguay, Faces Tough Talk in Argentina 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
After making efforts to prop up the ailing economies of Brazil and Uruguay earlier in the day, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill arrived late this afternoon in Argentina, the third, final and most contentious stop on his four-day tour of a financially troubled region that blames the Bush administration for making many of its problems worse.
 In remarks throughout the day, Mr. O'Neill was unusually conciliatory compared with many of his declarations over the last year and a half, which have often reproached government leaders. 
 "We are eager to see all of Latin America succeed," he said at a news conference in Montevideo, the Uruguayan capital, "and with the right policies in place, the people of Latin America will succeed." 
Late last month, Mr. O'Neill set off wide anger in the region saying he wanted to ensure that assistance from international financial institutions to Argentina and Brazil "does some good and it doesn't just go out of the country to Swiss bank accounts." The implied lack of American support for Brazil led the currency there to plunge to record lows last week and ignited a diplomatic spat between the two countries.
At a news conference in Sao Paulo this morning, though, Mr. O'Neill sought to undo the damage. He recalled that as the head of Alcoa he had invested heavily in Brazil, believing in its potential, and he praised the country's leaders for their economic discipline.
"We're leaving with a very favorable impression of Brazil," he said. "I've seen only things that strengthen my view that Brazil is a great place to participate in economic development."
Mr. O'Neill's itinerary also included a brief stop this afternoon in Montevideo, where he met with President Jorge Batlle and other officials. On Sunday, the Bush administration relaxed its hands-off policy in Latin American fiscal crises, authorizing an emergency $1.5 billion interim loan to the Uruguayan government, and Mr. O'Neill said today he thought that the worst of the crisis there was now over.
A run on bank deposits, caused largely by economic turbulence in Argentina and in Brazil, led Uruguay to declare a four-day bank holiday last week. "By expediting this bridge credit," Mr. Batlle said today, "President Bush and his administration have allowed us to re-establish the economic life and financial system of our country."
Argentina, though, has been mired in negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for months and has consistently been criticized by the Bush administration for dragging its feet on the sharp spending cuts the I.M.F. is demanding before it renews a credit line that was suspended last year. Government officials made it clear that they expected little from Mr. O'Neill's visit.
"It's not like Santa Claus is coming with a bag full of gifts," Alfredo Atanasof, the Argentine cabinet chief of staff, cautioned on Monday. He said he hoped that Mr. O'Neill, whose schedule calls for him to visit an infant development center and an automotive plant here on Wednesday, will "get to know the reality of this region."
To coincide with Mr. O'Neill's arrival, groups representing bank depositors, the unemployed, labor unions and left-wing political parties organized a protest march on the Casa Rosada, the Argentine seat of government. Security was tight at the airport, with police sharpshooters posted on the roofs of neighboring buildings and others deployed along the route to the presidential residence, where Mr. O'Neill met for about an hour with President Eduardo Duhalde.
In contrast to Uruguay, there was no news conference after the discussion here this evening. But in a brief statement, Mr. Duhalde's press secretary, Eduardo Amadeo, described the meeting as "very cordial and positive."

HEADLINE: Bush Signs Trade Bill, Restoring Broad Presidential Authority 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 6 

 BODY:
President Bush signed a bill this morning in Washington giving him the authority to negotiate trade deals with foreign countries without interference from Congress, then left less than 20 minutes later for a monthlong "working vacation" at his 1,600-acre ranch here.
 The legislation and a recently signed corporate antifraud bill are two accomplishments Mr. Bush will be able to cite when asked what his administration has done to try to help the stalling economy. 
 Trade promotion authority, once called fast track, was first given to the presidency in 1974. It lapsed in 1994, and Congress did not re-enact it for President Bill Clinton. Its renewal is a major legislative victory for Mr. Bush, whose aides worked for months to push the bill through the House and the Senate, which approved it only five days ago.
"Five presidents before me had this advantage," Mr. Bush said at a White House signing ceremony this morning. "But since the authority lapsed in 1994, other nations and regions have pursued trade agreements while America's trade policy was stuck in park." 
Under the new legislation, the president can make trade deals through 2007 that Congress can approve or reject but not change. Mr. Bush said he would begin using his authority immediately to accelerate long-stalled trade talks and bolster the economy.
"Starting now, America is back at the bargaining table in full force," Mr. Bush said. "I will use trade promotion authority aggressively to create more good jobs for American workers, more exports for American farmers and higher living standards for American families."
Supporters of the bill, mostly Republicans, said the legislation would move the White House from the sidelines to a central position in making trade deals that would enable the United States to better compete with other countries.
The opponents of the bill, mostly Democrats, said they worried about the impact of liberalized trade on American textile and other manufacturing workers, who might be hurt by competition from cheaper imported products or by companies that move their plants overseas to take advantage of cheaper foreign labor. Only when House and Senate negotiators agreed to include subsidized health insurance and job-training benefits for workers who lose their jobs to foreign competition did some Democrats finally agree to vote for the bill.
Mr. Bush said his administration would move quickly to make trade agreements with Chile, Singapore and Morocco. In addition, he said, the United States will negotiate a Free Trade Area of the Americas, a 34-nation plan first proposed in 1994 to integrate most of the economies of North and South America into a single free-trade bloc, similar in concept to the Nafta agreement with Mexico and Canada.
The president also praised Congress for renewing the Andean Trade Preferences Act, which for a decade lowered tariffs for 6,000 products from Peru, Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador. The pact expired in December 2001.
Earlier today, Mr. Bush said that the White House would hold a conference at George Washington University on missing, exploited and runaway children on Sept. 24 and that the Department of Justice would release a booklet to schools throughout the country on how parents can safeguard their children.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Cisco Beats Earnings Estimate, Raising Hope for Technology

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Cisco Systems offered investors hope today that the nation's technology sector was not continuing to deteriorate, posting stronger-than-expected earnings.
 The company, based in San Jose, Calif., is viewed as something of a bellwether for the United States economy because it is the dominant supplier of the basic equipment that routes information over the Internet. 
 Cisco announced after the close of the stock market that it had posted net income of $772 million, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter ended July 27, compared with net income of $7 million for the same quarter a year ago. 
On a pro forma basis, excluding the effects of acquisition expenses, payroll taxes on employee stock option exercises and other nonrecurring expenses, the company had a profit of $1 billion, or 14 cents a share, compared with a profit of $163 million, or two cents a share, a year ago. 
Cisco reported a revenue increase of 12 percent, to $4.8 billion for the quarter, up from $4.3 billion a year ago.
Wall Street had been expecting earnings, excluding charges, of 12 cents a share on revenue of $4.88 billion, according to financial analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.
Cisco's stock closed yesterday at $12.07, up 71 cents, before the announcement, and rose further in after-hours trading, to $13.03.
For the full fiscal year, Cisco earned $1.9 billion, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $18.9 billion. In 2001, Cisco lost $1 billion, or 14 cents a share, on sales of $22.3 billion.
Significantly, Cisco said that orders for networking equipment from United States corporate customers were above its expectations for the quarter, but it also cautioned that the trend was likely not to continue. 
The company predicted that sales to service providers like Internet companies and telecommunications firms could continue to decline for "several more quarters."
And Cisco's chief executive, John T. Chambers, said he saw no evidence that America's corporations were planning to resume capital expenditures in a major way any time soon.
Cisco nevertheless cited strength in markets like retail, education, banking and the federal government, but said that it had seen weakness in other sectors like investment banking, energy, high technology and service providers.
"They're making the best out of a bad market," said W. Stephen Kamman, a financial analyst at CIBC Work Markets. He said that the earnings surprise was due to the company's strong gross margins for the quarter, but at the same time revenues for the quarter were a little weak and momentum going forward was not particularly good.
"You've now got a company that is really captive to the winds of the global economy," Mr. Kamman said.
Responding to growing investor concern over recent financial scandals, Mr. Chambers and his chief financial officer, Larry Carter, stated at the outset of the company's conference call for financial analysts that they planned to comply with a new Securities and Exchange Commission requirement that they certify the company's financial results in formal filings next month.
"The certification will be provided without hesitation," Mr. Chambers said. 
Perhaps the most cheerful news for Cisco for the quarter was that despite fierce competition that has led to the erosion of its competitors' market share, it was continuing to show dramatic increases in gross margins, up to 67.7 percent for the current quarter from 52.3 percent for the fourth quarter in 2001. The numbers should not erode significantly in the next quarter, according to the company's executives.
In an effort to put to rest rumors that Mr. Carter is considering leaving the company soon, Mr. Chambers said that the company had debated what to say over the weekend and had decided to announce that Mr. Carter, who is well-regarded as Cisco's chief financial officer, plans to retire next May on his 60th birthday. 
At the same time, however, Mr. Chambers said that he intended to try to persuade his chief financial officer to stay on.
During the analyst call Mr. Chambers, whose pronouncements about Silicon Valley are closely followed, said that during the quarter he had become more confident about his company's ability to execute internally, while becoming more cautious about external events beyond Cisco's control. 
He said the company was well positioned for a turnaround, whenever it arrives. "I'm the optimist in this industry in the long run -- that has not changed," Mr. Chambers said.
He also noted that he was not certain whether the company's surprising strength during the quarter had come from the general financial environment or from Cisco's ability to take market share away from its competitors. 
He said the company was positioning itself for an economic upturn, but he acknowledged that he did not have a clear idea of when such a turnaround might take place.
"The real concern for everyone is when will capital spending pick up," he said.
The company also announced that Cisco's board had authorized an additional $5 billion for repurchase of Cisco stock. The addition increases the total available for stock purchases of up to $8 billion through Sept. 12, 2003. The company has already repurchased $2 billion in shares, Mr. Carter said.
The company ended the quarter with $21.5 billion in cash and equivalents, up from $21 billion the previous quarter.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 8, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about quarterly earnings for Cisco Systems referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing planned by the chief executive and the chief financial officer for complying with a new requirement that they certify the company's financial results. It is next month, not next week.

HEADLINE: Schools That Succeed 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "One Man Can't Fix New York's Schools," by Arthur Greenberg (Op-Ed, Aug. 1): 
 There is one variable that is paramount for any enduring change in urban public schools: integrating classrooms with families that have taken refuge in private and parochial schools. 
Families with high educational goals for their children seek a learning environment that has a strong academic program, embraces the arts and has ample libraries, science laboratories and athletic fields. Those are the classrooms that have success in academic performance, motivation and attendance, and they are not exclusive to high-income neighborhoods.
Schools with enriched programs provide the model for New York City public schools that can deliver children prepared to play significant roles in the future economy of the city.

JOAN D. FIRESTONE
New York, Aug. 2, 2002

The writer is special adviser to the New York City schools chancellor for arts education.

HEADLINE: TURF; 
Suddenly, One House Isn't Enough

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
"WHEN people lose faith in accountants, lose faith in the clergy and lose faith in the government, and start to trust real estate agents, it's scary," said Diane Saatchi, a real estate agent in the Hamptons.
 In the weeks since the stock market began whipsawing, buyers looking for a second home in the Northeast have put their faith, if not in the agents, in the real estate. 
 In the past, when the economy shook and the stock market tumbled, vacation home catalogs gathered dust alongside Tiffany and Maserati brochures -- fantasies for another day. But this year, even with Sept. 11 and the recession hanging like a cloud, buyers are turning their country-house fantasies -- presto! -- into reality.
The quest, which is part of the robust real estate market nationwide, is more than a matter of personal finance. "This is all about fantasy, about having security, a base," said Frank Newbold, who runs the Sotheby's real estate office in East Hampton, N.Y. 
After a sluggish winter and spring, buyers are once again buying in weekend and summer destinations like Nantucket, Mass.; Rhinebeck, N.Y.; and Stone Harbor, N.J. (along with its poorer neighbors, the Wildwoods).
For Ken Beaugrand, who owns the Nantucket Real Estate Company, the first quarter was one of the worst in years. "We were at least 15 percent down from the same quarter a year ago," he said. But in the last two months, things have started to take off. "We're still down a bit from last year," he said, "but by the fall, I think we'll be pretty much even."
Things are swinging even more in the Hamptons, where buyers are stretching to afford more chimneys, more shingles and even bigger pools. "They'll pay more, and sit on a phone book without furniture for the first year," Mr. Newbold said. Two years ago, he said, "they would buy a small house, rent it out for part of the year, and the next year, trade up, like tiddlywinks -- this year, they're buying keeper houses."
Mr. Newbold said his office had 80 percent more accepted offers this July than last.
Ms. Saatchi said that business was 25 percent higher in dollar volume last month than in July 2001 -- especially at the low end (which, in the Hamptons, means $500,000 to $750,000). "Things are flying off the shelf," she said.
And not only in the Hamptons. Buyers have also been swarming to the lakes and the woods. "They're cashing out their stock portfolios," said Andrea Gabel of Gabel Real Estate in Spencertown, N.Y., near the Berkshires. "They're putting down 85 percent cash."
Business is booming. "Last year, we did $21 million," Ms. Gabel said. "By June of this year, we were up to $26 million, and I stopped counting." She has sold to artists, art gallery owners, magazine editors and, increasingly, Wall Street traders.
Today's second-home buyers are looking for instant nostalgia: meadows and fireplaces and postal carriers to greet by name. While they may be keeping the penthouse on, say, East 75th Street, it doesn't seem as glamorous, buyers say. A few years ago the country house was a status symbol, an extra piece of real estate. Now, increasingly, it feels like home.
In the past, most people traded up or down, but this year they tend to be first-time buyers. Matthew and Marion Wilson are two of them. In May, they had their first child, a girl, and decided to make the 3,000-square-foot loft they rent in Chinatown a pied-a-terre and raise her in a more traditional home. Mr. Wilson, a former investment banker, and his wife now sell rare books on the Internet. Last week, they found the house they had been waiting for in East Hampton: a three-bedroom villa on two acres north of Montauk Highway, with plenty of privacy.
Yes, Mr. Wilson said, East Hampton on a summer weekend is "Madison Avenue on Sea," but he added, "We'll have a cool breeze, we can eat out in our garden and we don't have to worry about noisy neighbors." The Wilsons, with a house-buying budget of $1 million, are in the process of making an offer. "A lot of what we saw was overpriced garbage," he said. "This is real quality, and there's room to add on."
Even so, he and his wife -- like many prospective buyers -- are nervous that real estate in the Hamptons is a bubble ready to burst. "There's so much stock market money," Mr. Wilson said. "There's been so much speculation." Like those investing in co-ops and condominiums in Manhattan, they say they hope their own real estate investments prove to be blue-chip properties that will remain stable. "That's why we've been very fussy," he said.
In the Poconos, Diane Grinaway, the owner of Century 21 Millennium in Stroudsburg, Pa., said that an influx of buyers since Sept. 11 has pushed prices 10 to 25 percent higher than they were a year ago. But instead of traditional lakeside chalets, newcomers are seeking out big houses in the countryside -- typically colonial styles that can double as primary residences if work schedules can be juggled.
The 90-minute commute to New York is "a nightmare," Ms. Grinaway said, "but some people are doing it." She added gamely, "There are buses leaving every day."
The term "second home" is increasingly obsolete as city dwellers -- not only in New York, but in places like Philadelphia and Boston -- come to think of their country houses as the new center of their home lives even if they stay somewhere else during the week, said Robert T. Rich, who owns Coldwell Banker Otton Real Estate in Stone Harbor.
"You can really see this town light up on Thursday night," he said.
With offices in five towns, Mr. Rich caters to varied income groups: he just sold a $2.4 million bay-front mansion in Stone Harbor and a two-family house in Wildwood for $87,000.
The main problem Mr. Rich and other brokers say they are now facing is a lack of listings.
"There's not a whole lot of inventory," Ms. Saatchi said, "but there's an incredible amount of irritability."
Although today's country and beach-house buyers are still reaching for their checkbooks, they don't seem entirely content.
"They're nervous, and that makes them cranky," she said. "They're cranky if people don't return their calls. I think they have subliminal anxiety since Sept. 11 -- they don't feel as safe.
"They're looking for real estate to make them feel good, and even as they're getting ready to buy it, they sense it isn't really going to work."

Best to Love Both Wisely and Well
WHILE real estate agents say that business is booming in the hottest second-home locations in the Northeast, financial planners urge would-be buyers to ask themselves, Am I doing it for love or for money?
If the purchase -- the bungalow in the Poconos or the mansion on the bluff on Martha's Vineyard -- is strictly an investment, this might be the wrong time. Real estate is cyclical, and prices are still high, some say precariously so. Planners and accountants are warning clients to buy a second house only if they love it and plan to hang on to it.
Stuart Kessler, a senior partner at Goldstein Golub Kessler, a financial planning firm in Manhattan, said that prices in some of the most popular "blue chip" vacation house locations, including the Hamptons, southern Vermont and the Berkshires, may well be overinflated. "Is it time to jump in?" he asked. "I'm not sure it is."
Prices have soared since the last real estate recession, a decade ago, and have gone up substantially in the last five years. An 18th-century saltbox in the Berkshires that went for $120,000 four years ago just sold for $400,000; a two-bedroom shingled 1910 cottage on a quarter acre in Sag Harbor, N.Y., sold in 1999 for $370,000, and again last year for $610,000. If a second home has antiquity and privacy and is in good condition, it can sell within weeks, said Joseph L. Carini of Wheeler & Taylor Real Estate in Great Barrington, Mass. 
Are you thinking of renting out your new vacation house? You've decided that the rent will cover all the costs? Remember that the rental market can fall as easily as the sales market. (Right now, rentals are way down in the Hamptons.) And don't forget taxes, lawn mowing and insurance. (Insurance for landlords may be a lot more.)
Even real estate agents concede that a vacation house is not the same as a primary residence. "Remember," Mr. Carini said, "it may be a desire -- but it's not an absolute need." TRACIE ROZHON

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marion and Matthew Wilson of New York (with their daughter) rent a house in Amagansett and plan to buy. (Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times)(pg. F10)

HEADLINE: Luxury Car Sales in U.S. Lift Earnings At Toyota 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its profit more than doubled in the first fiscal quarter as a result of strong demand for its luxury models, a weak yen and strong dollar, and a one-time gain from its pension fund.
 The company's outlook for the rest of the year, however, is clouded by slow sales at home, a stronger currency and signs of a slowdown in consumer spending in the American market, where Japanese manufacturers earn about three-quarters of their profits. 
 Propelling the gains in the quarter, running from April through June, was a 13 percent jump in vehicle sales, to 1.5 million, with the company's high-end Lexus line leading the way. The strong performance in the United States came even as Toyota reduced purchasing incentives, something that General Motors and Ford have relied on to clear inventory and bolster sales. 
Toyota was caught off guard by the demand for its cars in the United States and has shipped more vehicles from Japan to meet that demand. Last week, the company raised its 2002 global sales targets by 3.8 percent and made plans to increase exports by 18 percent.
"Barring any drastic change in the U.S. economy, we will probably be able to see the North American market do fairly well," said Takeshi Suzuki, a Toyota director.
Toyota also squeezed gains out of a weak link in its global network, Europe, where demand for the RAV4 sport utility vehicle and the Corolla helped increase sales by 15 percent.
The company, the world's third-largest automaker and Japan's largest, earned 352 billion yen -- about $2.8 billion -- in the quarter, up 117 percent from the quarter a year earlier. Most of those earnings came after Toyota shifted some of its pension obligations because of to a legal change. Without that move, profit would have risen 16 percent.
A weak spot for Toyota remains at home, where it has 43 percent of the Japanese market. Its sedans and other full-size cars face stiff pressure from subcompacts and other small cars that budget-minded Japanese drivers prefer. The company sold 8.2 percent fewer cars in Japan than it did a year earlier.
Toyota's Japanese rivals are also chipping away at its share of the United States market. 
Honda will release its updated Accord in September to complement its minivan, the Odyssey. Nissan will introduce half a dozen new models in the United States this year, including a revamped version of its Z sports car line. The Nissan Altima was named car of the year in North America.
"Toyota's domestic sales are falling short of target, but they are being countered by much higher exports to the U.S.," said Chris Redl, an auto analyst with UBS Warburg here. "However, Toyota is at a lower point in its product cycle, so their lineup is not too hot compared to Nissan and Honda."
More worrying are signs that the economic recovery in the United States, the world's largest car market, is losing steam. Data last week showed that the United States economy grew in the second quarter at nearly half the annual pace analysts had forecast, with consumer spending slowing noticeably. 
And like Japan's other carmakers, Toyota could face pressure later this year if the value of the dollar fails to recover against the recently rising yen. Toyota calculated last quarter's earnings at a rate of 127 yen to the dollar. The currency, however, has strengthened to an exchange rate of about 120 yen, and should it remain there, Toyota's dollar-based profits would be eroded when they are calculated in Japan.
The potential for a rising yen and slowing economic growth in the United States has shaved 25 percent off the value of Toyota's shares since their peak in March. 
Today, however, Toyota shares rose more than 4 percent both here and in trading of its American depository receipts in New York.

HEADLINE: Japan Savers May Find They're Paying Banks 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Racked by deflation and eager to stave off a bank crisis, Japan is considering pushing its rock-bottom interest rates on some bank accounts into uncharted territory: below zero.
 Lawmakers have suggested an exception to a law ending the government's guarantee on savings and other accounts that would allow the full guarantee to remain for no-interest settlement accounts that businesses use to pay their bills. Now, the government is considering allowing individuals to also have government guaranteed settlement accounts that would earn no interest, but these accounts would charge fees. 
 As part of his broader reform of the financial industry, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi wanted the government to protect savings of no more than 10 million yen ($83,132) for each account if a bank failed, a system similar to that of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States. The more limited protection, which was already delayed a year, is scheduled to start next April. But lawmakers from Mr. Koizumi's own party, fearing that the Japanese will abandon smaller, weaker banks and move their money to bigger banks that appear less likely to go under, are pushing for the loophole for businesses settlement accounts. Aware that such a provision might set off a rush by individuals to open such accounts, and to defray the costs of the guarantee, lawmakers returned to the drawing board. 
All the maneuvering has already drawn some criticism. "We are disappointed with Prime Minister Koizumi's backtracking on his commitment to reform the banking system," said Marshall Gittler, a currency strategist at Bank of America in Tokyo. "We are disappointed that Japan once again has decided to reward incumbency and avoid a market solution to a problem."
But regulators say that keeping the government guarantee on the business settlement, or clearing, accounts is key to stabilizing the financial system. "We have to discuss how to protect the credit clearing function because it is part of the economy's infrastructure," said Shokichi Takagi, commissioner of the Financial Services Agency.
These clearing accounts pay no interest, but since companies use them to transfer payments to other businesses, not as investment vehicles, few complain. That Japanese people -- worried about losing their nest eggs -- would be willing to pay banks for the full protection of their assets is another reminder of how little faith they have in their financial system, and how a decade of deflation has eroded their confidence in other investments, like stocks. 
While the proposal to protect these checking accounts would formally introduce negative interest rates, some Japanese have been paying to save for several years. Banks have been lowering the interest they pay since the Bank of Japan started cutting rates in 1991. In 1999, the central bank started driving short-term interest rates toward zero. And though it costs them almost nothing to borrow from the markets, banks continued slicing the amount they pay their customers. Ordinary savings accounts now yield as little as 0.001 percent a year, down from about 2 percent a decade ago, and one trip to the bank can wipe out years of interest.
The sting has been softened because consumer and wholesale prices continue falling. Accounting for this deflation, so-called real interest rates are actually in positive territory. But as Mr. Gittler of Bank of America said, "You can't buy a sofa with deflation." In fact, the minuscule interest rates the banks pay are brutal for pensioners and others who live off their investment income.
With their potential earnings diminishing, many people are cutting back on spending, sapping the broader economy.
The negative interest rate may have subtle effects on other parts of the economy, too. Frustrated with bank fees, savers may withdraw their money and stuff it under the futon. In recent months, vaults and safe boxes for the home have been selling well.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Let's hear from those who feel government has a role in stabilizing the economy.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick, who teaches at Cooper Union, is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. His new book, "Why Economies Grow," will be published by Basic Books in October. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
SO where are the economists?
 The latest data revisions from the Commerce Department show that the economy sank into recession well before Sept. 11, and not long after stock prices began to plummet. Consumer spending, which had been mysteriously strong, turned out to be significantly weaker. Little growth in the second quarter and July's paltry employment gains make the prospects of the dreaded double-dip recession a real possibility. 
 It is time to revive an old issue: Just how inherently stable are economies? But instead of getting much guidance these days from contemporary economists, we need to turn to some of the giants from the past. The work of the late Hyman Minsky, a well-regarded economic theoretician, is especially on the mark. 
He argued in a 1986 book called "Stabilizing an Unstable Economy" that precisely because financial markets at some point lead to excessive investment and speculation, the economy itself is prone to instability.
And what safeguarded the economy? Monetary policy is often inadequate, Mr. Minsky argued. Interest rates could be cut, but companies would not invest unless they thought there would be growing demand for their products. That is certainly true in the case of Japan today.
Rather, Mr. Minsky wrote, government itself is a necessary bulwark against recession. In particular, so-called automatic stabilizers are ideal tools for the job.
Today, Mr. Minsky's view is more relevant than ever, explain two economists, Charles J. Whalen of Wells College and Jeffrey B. Wenger of the Economic Policy Institute, because the nation's automatic stabilizers are much weaker than they once were.
Automatic stabilizers are programs like unemployment insurance and welfare that increase during economic downturns but recede in good times. As more people are unemployed, for example, the government disburses more, helping to maintain demand in a declining economy.
More sign up for welfare as well, helping to place a floor under the economy. What makes them especially useful is that when the economy strengthens again, the automatic stabilizer programs are reduced as, for example, unemployment declines.
Mr. Whalen and Mr. Wenger highlight four key automatic stabilizer programs that have lost impact.
First, the proportion of unemployed receiving benefits is now at record lows since cutbacks in the early 1980's. Unemployment insurance spending is consequently a much smaller proportion of gross domestic product.
Second, the 1996 welfare reform has no significant provision to increase spending as caseloads increase in tough times, unlike before 1996.
Third, a highly progressive tax system was once an indirect automatic stabilizer. As incomes rose, taxpayers moved into higher tax brackets, helping moderate speculative booms and closing the federal budget deficit. The same happened, to a lesser degree, in reverse. Now, there are far fewer such brackets.
Fourth, a higher minimum wage was also an automatic stabilizer as workers lost jobs and had to resort to lower-paying work. The minimum wage is considerably lower, discounted for inflation, than it was in the 1970's.
If there had not been a sharp increase in military and disaster relief spending in response to Sept. 11, in fact, the economic recovery may well have been even more tepid than it has turned out to be and a double dip more likely.
Other factors holding up the economy may also weaken soon. House prices, which have been supporting consumer spending, could be on the brink of falling as supply is beginning to look suspiciously high. Consumer confidence is already declining sharply, as is confidence in how President Bush is handling the economy.
A war in Iraq would pump up fiscal stimulus. But it would also drive up oil prices, much as it did in the Persian Gulf war, and dampen consumer demand. Too much spending could also undermine confidence in the markets as well as the inevitable uncertainty of war.
As the dollar declines, it will strengthen exports and weaken imports. But much of the world depends on America's imports, and weakness abroad is not easily offset because foreign economies are straddled by the new hands-off policy ideas that limit fiscal stimulus. The European Union has stringent restrictions on the size of budget deficits. Other nations are constrained by the International Monetary Fund from using fiscal stimulus as a serious stabilizing mechanism. 
Finally, any more market turmoil will only add to the concerns. Despite the recent passage of useful new legislation, there are many areas that remain unaddressed by Congress, including accounting for stock options, pension protection, conflicts of interest between brokers and investment bankers, and the complete lack of regulation of financial derivatives. The job is far from finished.
So far, most economists -- particularly those who recognize that the government has a role to play in stabilizing the economy -- remain on the sidelines. That leaves the playing field to those, including President Bush's advisers, who contend that falling stock prices are proof that unfettered markets work well and correct themselves. 
This is quite a claim. For years, the overvalued financial markets sent highly misleading signals that caused hundreds of billions and arguably trillions of dollars of valuable national savings to be misallocated to unneeded and wasteful investment. Now we know part of this resulted from corporate deceit. This was an enormous market failure that could have been mitigated by better regulation and earlier efforts to dampen speculation.
What is clear is that Mr. Bush's tax cuts, by contrast, are not the way to go. They provide near-term stimulus, but they, unlike automatic stabilizers, do not decline in future years. They portend large federal deficits in the future. 
There are good economists who believe that deregulation has gone too far, and that economies sometimes need righting by government. These economists should speak louder.

HEADLINE: Work Starts on North Korea's U.S.-Backed Nuclear Plant 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KUMHO, North Korea, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
With the first Bush administration envoy to visit North Korea joining in a rare ceremony, work began today on the foundation of a long-planned nuclear reactor, by far the largest Western aid project in this Communist nation and one on which its future cooperation with the outside world will hinge.
 The $4.6 billion reactor to be built here was first envisaged in 1994, when the United States and North Korea were edging toward war over suspicions that this country was trying to build nuclear weapons. It has been repeatedly delayed by North Korea's jagged relations with the United States and other nations. 
 Today, a succession of Western diplomats mounted the podium to declare the project the best hope for preventing nuclear proliferation -- and to urge North Korea to take convincing steps to comply with the pact that undergirds relations with the United States. 
Under that pact, the so-called Agreed Framework, negotiated in 1994, Washington committed itself to organizing an international consortium to build two light-water nuclear reactors for this poor country. In exchange, North Korea agreed to abandon and dismantle two existing graphite reactors, as well as a third that was under construction. North Korea -- which President Bush this year identified as one of three nations belonging to an "axis of evil" -- was also required to account for all plutonium it had produced and place it under international supervision. 
Time and again today, American and European officials hammered home the point that any hesitation now on the part of North Korea to open itself up to inspectors would result in a freeze in construction, leaving two coreless reactor shells in place and North Korea no closer to meeting its energy needs.
North Korea "must begin meaningful work with the energy agency right now," the United States special envoy here, Jack L. Pritchard, said.
"The Agreed Framework has been a key component of U.S.-North Korean policy," he said. "When we agreed to the terms of the Agreed Framework, we did so with the full expectation that all aspects of our concerns over North Korea's nuclear program would be resolved finally and completely."
Critics of the agreement have said that it is folly for the United States and its allies in the European Union, Japan and South Korea to give nuclear power plants to a country that remains technically at war with South Korea and maintains one of the world's largest armies, even while its economy collapses. 
They also complain that North Korea has failed, so far, to allow unhindered inspection of its nuclear facilities by experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency and warn that North Korea may simply use the powerful light-water reactors to produce new supplies of plutonium.
Officials of the consortium building the plants, the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, however, dismissed concerns that North Korea would be given operable nuclear power plants before it had cooperated fully with international inspectors. Furthermore, they say, the design of the new reactors would make it far more difficult, albeit not impossible, for North Korea to produce weapons-grade plutonium.
If the North Koreans do not cooperate with the international energy agency, "there is no chance whatsoever that they will get delivery of the critical components for these reactors," said Charles Kartman, the executive director of the consortium. "What they will end up with instead is a big hole in the ground, a lot of concrete and some steel fixtures. Do you want a completely uncontrolled nuclear program here, or do you want the agreed framework? You have to choose." 
The international energy agency has said that it would require about three years to complete a survey of North Korea's nuclear-related plants and laboratories. Western diplomats said here today that this put a premium on timely cooperation from North Korea because the reactors under construction here would also be ready to receive their nuclear materials in about three years.
Mr. Pritchard said his presence reflected the Bush administration's continued support for the Agreed Framework, which has been criticized by some in Congress, as well as by members of both the Clinton and Bush administrations.
Almost from its inauguration, the Bush administration has sent mixed signals about North Korea and has reacted skeptically toward South Korea's efforts toward reconciliation with the North, through President Kim Dae Jung's "sunshine" policy. 
Washington's reaffirmation of the nuclear project under the Agreed Framework, however, is regarded by many diplomats in Asia as an expression of continuity in American policy toward North Korea.
The graphite-style reactors built here in the past are regarded by scientists as optimal for the production of weapons-grade plutonium. North Korea is suspected of having produced two nuclear weapons and is known to possess enough plutonium for an additional 10 bombs.
North Korea closed those reactors in 1994 and has allowed the International Atomic Energy Agency to post monitors to safeguard the nuclear material from the plants. North Korea must also account for an unspecified amount of "missing" plutonium, which diplomats say may already be incorporated in weapons.
"The Agreed Framework is not appeasement," said one official who is close to the construction project here. "It takes away rights that the North Koreans had, to possess a reprocessing plant and graphite reactors, and it has placed I.A.E.A. inspectors on the old reactor site 365 days a year. 
"The critics would have us throw this away, but this is a real source of stability."

HEADLINE: Inventories Increased in July, And Import Prices Jumped 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Wholesale inventories grew in June at their fastest rate in 19 months, the Commerce Department said today, suggesting that at least as of two months ago, companies were eager to rebuild depleted stocks to keep pace with demand.
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said today that import prices posted a rise in July that was sharper than expected, pushed up by a big gain in the cost of imported oil. 
 Wholesale inventories increased 0.3 percent in June, to $281.86 billion, after remaining unchanged in May, the Commerce Department said. The rise in June was the biggest since a 0.6 percent increase in November 2000. 
Sales of goods climbed 0.6 percent, faster than the inventories increase.
The growth in inventories was led by increases in stocks of cars and professional equipment like computers. Car inventories rose 1.1 percent in June, while professional equipment was up 1.2 percent.
Sales of cars at the wholesale level increased 0.3 percent. Professional equipment sales increased 2.8 percent.
The strength for those categories of goods was partly offset by declines in the inventories and sales of machinery. Factories appear to be postponing purchases of equipment until they are more certain that the recovery is solid.
Total inventories of durable goods inched up 0.1 percent in June. Sales of durable goods rose 0.5 percent. 
The report said that wholesale companies kept on hand 1.23 month's worth of goods in June, the same as in May. But that was lower than the 1.34 months' worth that wholesalers maintained a year ago.
The Labor Department report said that import prices rose 0.4 percent last month, the biggest gain since April, after a revised 0.3 percent fall in June.
The drop in June was originally reported as 0.6 percent. 
The department said petroleum import prices were up 4.9 percent in July, reversing a revised 4.8 percent decline a month earlier. Petroleum import prices have risen 47.4 percent since December. 
Excluding petroleum, import prices were unchanged last month, indicating little risk of imported inflation. 
In a third report, the Federal Reserve said today that consumer borrowing -- credit card debt as well as car and personal loans -- increased $8.4 billion in June, to a seasonally adjusted $1.713 trillion. Though that was less than the $9.5 billion increase in May, it was larger than the $7.8 billion that Wall Street had expected.
Revolving credit, which includes credit and charge cards, rose about $3.8 billion in June after a $2.4 billion gain in May. Nonrevolving credit, which largely reflects car loans, were up about $4.5 billion, less than a $7.1 billion increase in May. 
Analysts say they expect many homeowners to begin tapping the appreciation in the value of their houses to start paying down high-interest debt.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Oil Giant On Lawsuit In Indonesia 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
The State Department is urging a United States court to dismiss a lawsuit brought by a human rights group against Exxon Mobil over its operations in a war-torn province of Indonesia. In response to a request by the corporation for an opinion, the department declared that pursuit of the case would harm Washington's campaign against terrorism.
 Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim country, is a focus of the Bush administration's effort to fight terrorists, and any action by the United States that could interrupt the country's revenues would be perceived by the Indonesian government as interference in its internal affairs, the department said. 
 And in a twist, the letter by the department's legal adviser, William H. Taft IV, cited business competition from China in Indonesia as another factor in the case. 
The International Labor Rights Fund, a nonprofit group based in Washington, represents 11 Indonesian villagers who accuse Exxon Mobil of doing nothing to halt the Indonesian military's killing, torture and rape of residents near the company's plant in Aceh Province.
The army is charged under Indonesian law with protecting national security assets, including natural gas fields like the one in Aceh, where it is fighting separatists.
Exxon Mobil, the world's biggest energy company, sought the opinion, arguing that the suit would set back efforts to fight terrorism. 
Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer of the U.S. District Court in Washington agreed to request a nonbinding opinion. The judge's decision on whether to proceed to trial is pending.
The State Department, which had the option of rendering a neutral opinion, sent its reply to the court last week. Copies of Mr. Taft's letter to the judge were released today by the United States Embassy here.
Mr. Taft's letter suggested that Chinese oil companies, which have made significant purchases in Indonesia in the past six months, might try to replace the American energy giant if it were forced to leave. The Bush administration has shown growing concern about China's increasing economic and political interests in Southeast Asia.
The lawsuit is one of a series in which human rights groups have sued multinational companies in American courts in an attempt to hold the corporations more accountable for the repercussions of foreign investment on local populations.
Human rights groups denounced the State Department opinion. "Corporate responsibility shouldn't stop at the water's edge," Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, said. He said the Bush administration "shouldn't be trying to stop this court case."
At the same time, Mr. Roth said that Human Rights Watch "takes no position" on claims regarding Exxon Mobil's operations in Indonesia.
At a news conference today at the American Embassy here, Ambassador Ralph Boyce said that the State Department's opinion "expressly reaffirms our human rights concerns in Indonesia."
The letter, which was a matter of contention within the department between those who favored a strong stance protecting human rights in Indonesia and those who wanted a strong commitment to efforts against terrorism, roused considerable interest because of its timing.
The State Department opinion was delivered in the same week as the visit here by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. He told Indonesians last Friday that the United States was prepared to renew military ties, though on a measured basis.
The letter to the judge mentioned the poor human rights record of the Indonesian Army.
"We would like to reiterate that a lasting, peaceful solution to the Aceh conflict that maintains Indonesian sovereignty can only be achieved if the military and police end human rights abuses," Mr. Taft wrote.
In presenting the department's argument that the case should not proceed, Mr. Taft said Indonesia "serves as a focal point U.S. initiatives in the ongoing war against Al Qaeda and other dangerous terrorist organizations." Those efforts, he said, could be "imperiled in numerous ways if Indonesia and its officials curtailed cooperation in response to perceived disrespect for its sovereign interests."
Moreover, because the investment climate was deteriorating in Indonesia, the suit against Exxon Mobil would further scare Western investors, the State Department said. It suggested that Chinese companies were waiting in the wings, saying, "We would expect that foreign companies, such as from the People's Republic of China" would be "far less concerned about human rights abuses, or about upholding best business practices."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Late Rally Gives the Dow 2nd Triple-Digit Gain in 2 Days

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A burst of buying yesterday gave the Dow Jones industrials their second straight triple-digit gain for the first time in nearly three months. 
 After a session spent vacillating from modest gains to losses, the market began to climb sharply in the last hour. 
 Analysts attributed the late surge to big institutional investors placing bets on stocks, which set off a wave of buying. Better-than-expected earnings and expectations of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, which meets next week, also contributed to the gains. 
"It's momentum driven," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "There's some enthusiasm for Cisco's numbers and what the Fed may do next week." 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 182.06 points, or 2.2 percent, at 8,456.15, after climbing 230.46 points on Tuesday. The last time the index scored two straight triple-digit advances was May 13 and 14. 
The broader market also posted gains. The Nasdaq composite index rose 21.35 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,280.90, after advancing 53.54 points on Tuesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 17.20 points, or 2 percent, to 876.77, after Tuesday's gain of 24.97. 
Shares in Cisco Systems, rose 92 cents, to $12.99, after the company reported slightly stronger-than-expected profits for its fiscal fourth quarter, but a cautious outlook for the rest of the year. 
Other networking shares also advanced, including Broadcom, which closed up 30 cents, at $17.42. 
Among blue chips, drug stocks rose on stronger-than-expected earnings from Watson Pharmaceuticals. Watson rose $1.80, to $20.90, and Eli Lilly advanced $2.88, to $55.52. 
Retailers traded higher ahead of July sales results that will be released on Thursday. Wal-Mart Stores climbed $1.10, to $48.38, and Best Buy rose 80 cents, to $30.80. 
Buying was so widespread that even financial stocks rose, despite Merrill Lynch cutting its outlook on several investment firms. Goldman, Sachs rose $1.05, to $70.95, and Morgan Stanley gained 33 cents, to $38.39. 
Still, analysts were guarded about reading too much into the market's two-day rally, saying investors are still cautious about the market's prospects. 
"Valuations are still high, earnings are not very good, and the economy is soft, so it's tough to get a lot of progress to the upside with all this overhang," said Gary Kaltbaum, a market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. "This volatility is not going to go away anytime soon." 
Others said Wall Street's gains are vulnerable, because they stem largely from institutional investors, like hedge fund managers, who capitalize on moving quickly in and out of the market. 
"The markets are so volatile and so thin," said Michael Murphy, head trader for Wachovia Securities. "There's just no reason for people to go out and throw everything in the market right now." --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Reuters)
Treasury prices increased yesterday, pushing down yields as a wobbly stock market and an uncertain economic outlook had many investors turning to government securities.
Demand for Treasuries came in part on expectations building in the market that the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates before the end of the year to help rekindle cooling economic growth. 
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.31 percent, from 4.33 percent on Tuesday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, increased 8/32, to 104 14/32.
The yield on the 30-year note dropped to 5.22 percent, from 5.23 percent, while the price increased 7/32, to 102 10/32.

HEADLINE: Ford Heir Says Nation's Affair With theCar Has Lost Its Zip 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 7 

 BODY:
William Clay Ford Jr. said today that a credibility gap on environmental issues had eroded America's love for cars. Mr. Ford, the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, also said he wanted to "lower the temperature" of the industry's often contentious relationship with California regulators. 
 "During the nearly 25 years I've worked in the industry, the love affair that people have had with automobiles has in some ways grown stale, and some would say it's even dying," Mr. Ford said. "If you remember, in California, people used to write songs about T-Birds and Corvettes. Today, they write regulations." 
 Two weeks ago, Gov. Gray Davis of California signed a landmark bill that would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by the 2008 model year, the first such action at the state or federal level. The auto industry is greatly concerned with the potential cost of the measure and said it would probably challenge it in court. California regulators are also intent on forcing carmakers to produce electric vehicles, but that plan, due to start this year, has been delayed by a court challenge from General Motors and DaimlerChrysler.
Mr. Ford's speech, at an industry management conference in this northwestern Michigan resort area, was his most forceful on environmental issues since becoming chief executive of the financially struggling company in October.
Before taking the helm, he was one of the few industry executives to talk about issues like global warming. But groups like the Sierra Club have bitterly criticized Mr. Ford recently because of his company's participation in lobbying campaigns against increased federal gas-mileage standards and California's initiatives.
Mr. Ford, while saying he did not support the California plan to force companies to produce zero-emission vehicles like electric cars, said his industry did face a problem on environmentalism akin to that of others on accounting and corporate governance. And he urged a more cooperative approach with regulators.
"The same basic issue, lack of trust, is there," he said, but added that he thought the auto industry was making a good-faith effort to solve the problem by pushing hard on two technologies: vehicles with hybrid engines, which combine gasoline and electricity, and fuel cells, a clean but complex technology that draws power from hydrogen. Toyota and Honda are already selling hybrid cars, and Ford has said it will start selling a hybrid sport utility vehicle at the end of next year.
"New technology could rejuvenate the love affair people have with automobiles by making it possible for them not just to love their own cars," he said, "but to love everyone else's as well."
Several other top executives also spoke at the conference. Dieter Zetsche, the Chrysler unit's chief executive, said the company would make bolstering its car business a priority. Chrysler derives 70 percent of its sales from light trucks -- S.U.V.'s, minivans and pickup trucks. That share is far higher than in the industry at large; last year was the first time light-truck sales exceeded those of passenger cars, a trend that has been reducing the gas mileage of the average new vehicle.
"We will refocus our attention on passenger cars," Mr. Zetsche said. "Two-thirds of the 21 new and refreshed vehicles we will soon introduce will be car-based."
But that does not mean they will be passenger cars, a Chrysler spokesman said. The term "car-based" is a confusing one in Detroit. Small S.U.V.'s are considered car-based in their design because their underbodies have more in common with a car and lack the stiff steel beams of pickup trucks. But many car-based vehicles, including Chrysler's PT Cruiser and the Audi Allroad, can still be configured to be regulated as light trucks and permitted to use, on average, 33 percent more gasoline. 
In another speech today, Hiroyuki Yoshino, president and chief executive of the Honda Motor Company, said China was perhaps his company's biggest future growth market. 
"Efforts to build a strong foundation in China have been very similar to the early stages of our operations in America," he said, adding that "for the coming years, business in China will be at the forefront of my attention."
Honda's goal is to have 20 million new customers annually by the fiscal year ending in March 2005, up from 12.7 million in the most recent fiscal year.
"Significantly, half of these customers, 10 million, will be in Asia," he said. 
Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman of General Motors, said his company would not match Chrysler's new seven-year, 70,000-mile powertrain warranty because he thought such a plan would be too costly and not lure enough buyers. Mr. Lutz, 70, the innovative former Chrysler president who has reinvigorated G.M.'s product development operations, said he might also stay beyond the two years left on his three-year contract. 
Several executives also extolled diesel technology, which is prevalent in Europe but has faced regulatory hurdles here and among some has conjured up bad memories of the "dirty diesels" of the 1970's. Carmakers say the modern diesel engine is much cleaner.
"We should get diesels in the mix because it's one way we could get 10 to 15 percent fuel-economy improvement," Mr. Lutz said. But new clean air regulations, to take effect in 2007, are seen as a deterrent.
No manufacturer could meet the new rules now, Mr. Zetsche said, adding, "Either we find a way to meet those extremely demanding targets or we should have meaningful discussions with legislators to see if this really makes sense."

HEADLINE: Profit Increases 79% At Clorox Company 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif. 

 BODY:
The Clorox Company said today that its quarterly profit rose 79 percent as strong sales in North America helped offset poor economic conditions in Latin America, where it had to write down the value of assets. 
 Clorox, which makes bleach, Glad plastic bags and Hidden Valley salad dressing, also said it had been helped by sales of new products, like the Clorox ReadyMop. 
 Clorox said it had earned $145 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with $81 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago. Earnings in the 2002 quarter were reduced by $29 million as a result of a charge related to writing down the value of the company's Brazilian business in the wake of economic turmoil in that country. 
Sales in the quarter, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of the company's fiscal year, rose 3 percent, to $1.14 billion.
Household product sales rose 4 percent in North America, with volume up 2 percent, helped by sales of Clorox ReadyMop and Formula 409 cleanser. Excluding divestitures, sales rose 6 percent, with volume up 4 percent. 
Specialty-product sales rose 5 percent, with volume up 2 percent, helped by record shipments of Kingsford charcoal, Armor All wipes and tire protection products, and K. C. Masterpiece marinades. Excluding divestitures, volume rose 4 percent and sales rose 7 percent.
Both household-product sales and volume fell 5 percent in Latin America and other regions; volume fell in Argentina, Colombia and Chile. Excluding divestitures, volume fell 3 percent and sales fell 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Global Arms Sales to Developing Nations Are Tumbling, Study Finds 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
International arms sales to the developing world tumbled steeply last year, reaching the lowest level in eight years, as those nations curtailed weapons purchases because of the global economic downturn, according to a new Congressional study.
 Global arms sales overall, including weapons deals in developed and developing nations, also dropped significantly last year, to the lowest total since 1997, the report said. 
 Even in the current economic turmoil, the United States maintained its dominance as the leading weapons supplier, followed by Russia, whose sales to Iran continue to be an issue of great concern to American officials.
Israel was the largest buyer of weapons last year among the countries categorized in the study as developing nations, although experts say the sales were part of long-term procurement plans rather than a response to specific developments in the the Israel-Palestinian conflict. 
The study, "Conventional Arms Transfers to Developing Nations, 1994-2001," was published this week by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress. 
The annual nonpartisan report is widely considered the most authoritative resource available to the public on worldwide weapons sales, as opposed to classified studies for the government and military.
There are two ways to track the flow of arms, by contracts for sales or transfers and by weapons deliveries. 
Because of production times, deliveries do not correspond to agreements signed in a given year.
The author of the study, Richard F. Grimmett, found that the value of arms transfer agreements signed with developing nations last year was nearly $16 billion and that the value of arms delivered to those nations was $14.4 billion.
Those figures were the lowest of the eight-year period that the study covered, wrote Mr. Grimmett, a specialist in national defense at the Congressional Research Service.
For comparison, the report adjusted the sums for inflation, a measurement called "constant 2001 dollars."
According to the report, the total value of all arms transfer deals worldwide, agreements for weapons signed by developed and developing nations, was nearly $26.4 billion last year, a significant drop from slightly more than $40 billion in 2000.
"This is a substantial decrease in arms agreements values over 2000, and is the first time since 1997 that total arms agreements decreased from the previous year," Mr. Grimmett wrote. The 1997 figure was $25.4 billion.
Even with the decline in sales and deliveries, "developing nations continue to be the primary focus of foreign arms sales activity by weapons suppliers," the report states.
In the eight years that the study covers, the value of arms transfer agreements to developing nations averaged 68.3 percent of all such deals worldwide. Even last year, purchase agreements with the developing countries remained high, at slightly more than 60 percent of worldwide sales.
The United States ranked first in arms transfer agreements with the developing world last year, signing almost $7 billion, or 43.6 percent, of all contracts. 
Russia followed, with $5.7 billion, or 29.6 percent, and China was third, with $600 million, or 3.8 percent, of all agreements.
The United States was also the leader in arms transfer agreements overall, to developed and developing nations, with deals last year valued at $12.1 billion, or 45.8 percent of all agreements. That total was significantly down from deals worth $18.9 billion signed in 2000.
Russia followed with $5.8 billion in total agreements last year, a drop from $8.4 billion in 2000. France ranked third in total worldwide arms transfer agreements, with $2.9 billion, also considerably less than its 2000 figure of $4.3 billion.
Of those nations categorized in the study as part of the developing world, Israel led in signing arms deals last year, agreeing to acquire $2.5 billion in conventional arms, followed by China, which signed $2.1 billion in contracts, and Egypt, with $2 billion.
"Most recently, many developing nations have curtailed their expenditures on weaponry, primarily due to their limited financial resources," the report said. "Given the tenuous state of the global economy, even some prospective arms purchasers with significant financial resources have been cautious in making major new weapons purchases."
Many such nations are now focusing on upgrading weapons systems and deferring buying new expensive arsenals, the report stated.
Persian Gulf states, which have since the war with Iraq consistently been the largest weapons buyers, continued to decline in the annual rankings, because they have taken delivery of expensive weapons systems bought in past years.
Even so, the United Arab Emirates remained the leading arms buyer in the developing world from 1994 to 2001, signing for $16 billion in weapons.
In the period 1998 to 2001, Russia became the dominant arms supplier to Iran, signing arms-transfer deals worth $900 million -- the vast majority of Iran's total agreements for $1.2 billion in weapons. European nations sold the rest of the total to Iran.
From 1994 to 1997, China sold Iran $900 million in arms of Iran's $1.6 billion in purchases. In that period, Russia signed deals with Iran for $200 million, and European countries supplied the rest.

HEADLINE: Decoding North Korea 

 BODY:
After years of delay, construction began yesterday on one of the two nuclear reactors that a Western consortium is building for North Korea, capping an encouraging few weeks in that country's erratic relations with the outside world. Although President Bush called Pyongyang part of an "axis of evil" in January, Washington has wisely decided to explore diplomatic avenues to the extent that the North's unpredictable behavior permits. North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, has sounded reasonable before only to reverse course and embarrass advocates of engagement in Seoul and Washington. The wisest American course for now is to keep open the lines of communication to learn more about Pyongyang's true intentions. 
 Earlier this summer the Bush administration was preparing to resume talks on North Korea's missile program and other issues that had been suspended after Bill Clinton left office. Then a North Korean gunboat opened fire on a South Korean vessel, killing five sailors. Seoul and Washington understandably broke off diplomatic contacts. Two weeks ago, Pyongyang issued a statement of regret over the naval incident. That cleared the way for cabinet-level talks next week between the two Koreas, the first in nearly a year. It also helped bring about a brief but cordial meeting last week between Secretary of State Colin Powell and North Korea's foreign minister. 
 The only consistent theme in North Korean policies over the past several years has been the increasingly desperate effort by top leaders to maintain control in the face of a catastrophically failing economy. Pyongyang's best hope lies in opening its economy to market forces and outside investment and abandoning an unconventional-weapons program that frightens South Korea, Japan and the United States, all of them potential targets. Yet the North's leaders hesitate, fearing that market liberalization would undermine Communist Party control. Rather than abandon unconventional weapons, the North has continued selling missiles and technology to Pakistan and the Middle East and demanding large payoffs from Washington as a condition of cutting off these lucrative exports. 
America should not submit to extortion, but should avail itself of serious and verifiable opportunities to eliminate real threats. That is a difficult path to follow, but the 1994 nuclear agreement that led to yesterday's start of construction is a good example of the benefits that can result. In that accord North Korea abandoned Soviet-era reactor technology that made it relatively easy for nuclear waste to be reprocessed into bomb fuel. Before the new reactors come into operation three years from now, Pyongyang will have to allow all its nuclear plants and laboratories to be monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency and will have to account for the plutonium it produced before 1994. 
The Bush administration showed support for that nuclear agreement by sending a special envoy to yesterday's foundation-laying ceremony. Provided that Pyongyang avoids any new provocations, the next step should be reopening talks to discuss similar solutions to other security issues.

HEADLINE: Burst Bubble Memorial Stadium 

 BODY:
The erosion of tradition and continuity in professional sports has gone too far. Not only have players and coaches become restless temps, but now even the names of the venues they play in have become transient. In this turbulent economy, in which yesterday's highest bidder may no longer be around today, the New England Patriots have become the third consecutive Super Bowl winners to be forced to change the name of their stadium. 
 Two years ago, near the end of the dot-com frenzy, the Patriots sold the naming rights to their new stadium to CMGI, an Internet company, for $114 million over 15 years. Back then, unprofitable companies were known to make such brazen gestures. An umbrella for a number of dot-com brands, CMGI was one of those hyped creatures of the bubble whose main product was its stock price. It reached $163 a share in late 2000, but is now worth less than $1. 
 On Monday the Patriots announced that CMGI Field's name would be changed to Gillette Stadium. It is a sad sign of the times that this name should have such a venerable ring to it, as if it were Lambeau or Soldier Field. Gillette, the 110-year-old Boston consumer-product conglomerate, acquired the naming rights for 15 years for an undisclosed amount. CMGI cited "drastic changes" in its business in announcing that it was now off the hook; nowadays $114 million seems like a lot of cash when you're unprofitable. The challenge for stadium crews is to shave off the 2,000 painted or etched "CMGI Field" inscriptions in time for next month's Monday night season opener against the Pittsburgh Steelers. 
Befitting Pittsburgh's no-nonsense industrial heritage, the Steelers were ahead of the curve when it came to the emerging "out with the new, in with the old" trend in naming rights. Their year-old stadium is called Heinz Field. Recession-proof ketchup, like razor blades, is here to stay.
Of course that is what the St. Louis Rams, winners of the 2000 Super Bowl, thought of storied Trans World Airlines, which has since been taken over by American while the stadium has been renamed in honor of a local investment firm. Many fans of the following Super Bowl winner, the Baltimore Ravens, were barely familiar with PSINet, another Internet firm, before it went bankrupt and the PSINet Stadium name was retired. 
The Tennessee Titans have spent this off season in court wresting back their stadium naming rights. Adelphia Coliseum has a sort of glamorous, Hellenic ring to it until you realize it's in honor of a bankrupt spinoff of the cable company whose founder and former chief executive was recently arrested and charged with defrauding investors. Then there is that ultimate field of dreams, the Houston Astros' new Enron Field. Making lemonade from its lemon, the Astros resold the rights surrendered by Enron's bankruptcy to Minute Maid, the Coca-Cola subsidiary. Fans should be reassured: Juice sales offer little room for accounting chicanery.

HEADLINE: Patient Deaths Tied to Lack Of Nurses 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Calling a shortage of nurses "a prescription for danger," the national organization that accredits hospitals reported today that the lack contributed to nearly a quarter of the unanticipated problems that result in death or injury to hospital patients.
 The shortages have been a perennial problem, and hospitals have taken the position that the lack of staff members does not harm patients. But experts said today's report, by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations, added to a growing body of evidence that links the shortage to ill health. 
 "Nursing staffing is low in many institutions, and patients are being hurt by it," said Dr. Jack Needleman, an economist at the Harvard School of Public Health who was not involved in the commission's report. "Now we need to move from arguing over whether that is the case to discussing how we can fix it." 
The commission's finding utilized its "sentinel event" reporting system, a computer database that includes 1,609 reports of patient deaths and injuries since 1996. 
Those reports include detailed explanations from hospitals, and when commission officials analyzed them, they found low levels of nursing staff were cited as a contributing factor in 24 percent of the cases.
"This data was so compelling," said Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary, the commission president. "We knew that some unanticipated deaths and permanent loss of function were related to inadequate numbers of nurses, but 24 percent surprised everybody."
More than 126,000 nursing positions -- about 12 percent of the total -- are vacant today, and the commission warned that the situation might worsen. As a group, nurses are aging -- only 12 percent of registered nurses are younger than 30, the report said -- and many more people are leaving the profession than entering it. 
At the same time, today's hospital patients are sicker than those in previous years, so the demands on nurses are rising, said Linda Aiken, director of the Center for Health Outcomes and Policy Research at the University of Pennsylvania. 
A recent report in Pennsylvania found 50 percent less nursing care available to patients today than in 1980, Ms. Aiken said.
Several factors contribute to the nursing shortage. Hospital mergers, and the ensuing cost-cutting and heavy workloads have prompted many nurses to leave the profession. The American Hospital Association recently called on its members to make recruiting and retaining nurses a priority.
"I don't agree that patients' lives are in danger," said James Bentley, a senior vice president of the hospital association.
Still, Mr. Bentley said, hospitals ought to be concerned about "the number of nurses who feel overstressed, overworked, worried that they're not able to spend enough time with the patient."
The shortage has drawn attention in Washington. Last month, Congress passed the Nurse Reinvestment Act, which authorizes financial aid programs for nursing students; President Bush signed the bill into law last week. Congressional aides estimate that the assistance will cost more than $30 million from 2003 to 2007.
But Dr. O'Leary said the new law did not go far enough. "I sure hope Congress doesn't think it's done with this issue," he said. "We need substantially greater investment."
The commission called for improvements to the nursing education system, and for the federal government, which reimburses hospitals through Medicaid and Medicare, to tie the payments to a hospital's performance in improving nursing care.
It also said hospitals must improve the work environment for nurses, a recommendation that Mary Foley, a past president of the American Nurses Association, applauded, saying: "What I hear from nurses on a regular basis is that they are struggling to do the best that they can. They talk about the long hours of work, particularly mandatory overtime practices."
The report cited surveys showing that nurses were unable to keep up with the demands placed on them. 
In one survey of nurses describing their last shifts, 31 percent said their patients did not receive necessary skin care, 20 percent said patients did not receive oral care, and 28 percent were not able to provide patients and their families with necessary education and instruction.
"Care is literally being left undone," the report said.
